Title: Kushal Punjabi's parents and his wife Audrey Dolhen jointly release a statement; call the late actor a doting father
Content: Television actor Kushal Punjabi known for his roles in shows like Ishq Mein Marjawan , Fear Factor, Zor Ka Jhatka, Kasamh Se amongst others committed suicide at his Bandra residence on December 26 last year. After Kushal's sudden demise, several reports of problems in the late actor's married life did the rounds in the media.However, Kushal's family has now jointly released a statement rubbishing these reports. The late actor's family which includes Audrey Dolhen Vijay Punjabi , Priya Punjabi and Ritika Punjabi, has released a joint statement saying that their son was a doting father and was emotionally and financially stable.The statement read, "There have been multiple reports through various media that have been falsely reported as being given by members of Kushal’s family and we hereby confirm these as not being true. Kushal was a very doting father who shared a close relationship with his son, and who was financially stable. Today, we stand together as one family in mourning."The statement further read, "The family stands together during these difficult times and will always remember the actor as a "much-loved part of this family."Kushal's wife, who had flown to India to attend his last rites, left for France four days after his funeral. The Kaal actor's last rites were attended by his friends from the fraternity, like Arjun Bijlani, Karanvir Bohra, Kavita Kaushik, Eijaz Khan, Bakhtiyar Irani, Chetan Hansraj, Apoorva Agnihotri and Shilpa Saklani amongst others.As per a statement from the police, the actor committed suicide by hanging himself and left behind a note that nobody should be blamed for his death.

Title: Hectic lobbying for 5 RS seats falling vacant in April
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

PATNA: Hectic lobbying has started for the five Rajya Sabha seats in Bihar falling vacant as Harivansh, Kahkashan Perween and Ram Nath Thakur from JD(U) and Dr C P Thakur and R K Sinha from BJP are to complete their terms on April 9 this year. The biennial election is likely to be held in March.

The MLAs cast vote to elect the Rajya Sabha members from the state. In Bihar, the first preferential votes of 42 legislators are required for a candidate to win a Rajya Sabha seat. As per the existing strength of different parties in the 243-member state assembly, RJD would be able to win two of the five Rajya Sabha seats as it has 81 MLAs and support of smaller allies.

Similarly, JD(U), BJP and LJP with the combined strength of 126 MLAs would be able to get three nominees elected to the Upper House of Parliament.

Since JD(U) has 70 MLAs compared to BJP’s 54, Nitish Kumar’s party would naturally field two nominees and the saffron party one. Thus, Lalu Prasad’s RJD would gain two seats while JD(U) and the BJP will lose one seat each. That’s why RJD has more aspirants than other parties and they have already started meeting the party’s top leaders like Lalu Prasad, former CM Rabri Devi and the leader of opposition Tejashwi Prasad Yadav to seek their blessings.

“Three of the aspirants recently called on incarcerated Lalu, who is convicted in fodder scam cases and now admitted to Riims, Ranchi, on health grounds,” an RJD leader said.

RJD insiders said senior leaders like Raghuvansh Prasad Singh, Jagdanand Singh, Shivanand Tiwary, Jai Prakash Narayan Yadav and Bulo Mandal are among the contenders for a Rajya Sabha seat. Party’s sitting RS member Prem Chand Gupta, who was last time elected from Jharkhand, also met Lalu in Ranchi recently. Gupta, insiders said, is learnt to have also staked his claim on one seat. Gupta’s current term in the Rajya Sabha is to end on April 9 and this time he wants to be elected from Bihar, sources said.

“RJD has many senior leaders who really deserve Rajya Sabha nomination. Any decision regarding candidates will be taken by Lalu Prasad and Tejashwi Ji. The party has already authorized them to take such decisions,” RJD spokesperson Chitranjan Gagan told TOI on Wednesday.

BJP also has many aspirants for the single RS seat. Insiders said the party’s central leadership has hinted to prefer someone from the younger lot. A sitting Rajya Sabha member is lobbying for his son, if he is denied re-entry in the Upper House. “Top leadership of BJP will take a decision at the appropriate time,” Bihar BJP spokesperson Nikhil Anand told TOI.

Since JD(U) is to lose one seat, at least one of its three sitting members is to be denied a ticket, if the party decides to repeat the two present members. “The party may like to change all its members like it did in 2014 when N K Singh, Shivanand Tiwary and Sabir Ali were asked to contest the 2014 Lok Sabha election,” a senior JD(U) leader said.

“In JD(U), the decision on RS candidates was taken only by the party chief Nitish Kumar and that, too, just a day or hours before the time of filing nomination papers,” a JD(U) leader said.

Title: Mixed response to trade unions’ bandh in state
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

PATNA: The nationwide strike called by several trade unions and youth political wings on Wednesday against the policies of the central government had a mixed response in the state.

In Patna, CITU, AITUC and CPI-ML among other trade unions blocked Dak Bungalow roundabout causing traffic congestion on joining Exhibition Road, Fraser Road, Bailey Road and Bhattacharya Road and adjoining lanes. Several workers of HAM(S) and its youth wing carried out an ‘Aakrosh March’ near Gandhi Maidan and joined the protest at Dak Bungalow roundabout.

AISF, AISA, AIDSO, Bhim Army, SFI and NSUI among others tried to stop trains at Rajendra Nagar Terminal, but police chased them away and detained four members of the student organizations. The youth wings of political organizations were protesting against CAA-NPR-NRC and showing solidarity with the students of Jawaharlal Nehru University and Jamia Millia Islamia.

Public and public transport in the city was as usual. Schools, colleges, shops, market areas, malls and hangouts remained open. The banking services were partially affected as only government bank employees were protesting. CITU and AITUC forcefully shut some private banks on Exhibition Road, but they opened again after a short duration. The Joint Forum of Unions and Associations of Airport Authority India (AAI), Patna, held mass demonstration at the city airport, but did not disturb flight operations and other aviation works.

However, normal life was affected in Begusarai as activists of various trade unions squatted on the NH-31 and disrupted traffic. Banks and insurance offices remained closed. Deputy general secretary of Barauni Telshodhak Mazdoor Union (BTMU) Rajnish Ranjan said as many as 19 unions of IOCL associated with its refinery, pipeline and marketing divisions remained on strike. Loading of oil tankers at depots of various oil firms like HPCL, IOCL and BPCL was severely affected.

Banking services were completely paralysed in Bhagalpur and Banka districts. Most of the banks and insurance offices did not open. But transport and other services were not hit by the strike. Markets were open and the trading and business activities remained normal. Bank customers, however, returned disappointed. A section of bank employees also protested against the central government’s decision to merge many banks and thereby causing uncertainty among the bank employees, who also apprehend about impending steps to close some bank branches across the country.

There was a mixed response in Bagaha as well. The main protest was seen at West Champaran collectorate where CITU, AICCTU, AITUC and INTUC members forcibly closed its gates for some time. Sunil Rao, Milan Aiman, Rabindra Kumar, Birendar Gupta and others participated in the protest, which included against NRC, CAA, NPR, JNU incidents. Work at Bettiah main branch of State Bank of India was effected but its Bagaha and Narainpur branches remained open.

The bandh was by and large peaceful and effective in Nawada town while it had no impact in rural areas. Chilly weather and heavy police vigil helped the bandh to remain peaceful. Banks were closed and ATMs were also shut apprehending trouble.

At Ara, CPI-ML leaders and workers blocked the Ara-Patna, Ara-Sasaram roads and Sahar-Arwal bridge for several hours. CPI-ML town secretary Dilraj Pritam said there were blockades at almost all the blocks and markets. While Ara-Patna main road was blocked for 4 hours by the protesters led by CPI-ML central committee member Jawahar Lal Singh and Tarari MLA Sudama Prasad, Ara-Sasaram main road was blocked by party workers led by Mahesh Prasad. The Sahar-Arwal bridge blockade for over 2 hours was led by CPI-ML Sahar block secretary Upendra Bharti. Sandesh chowk, Agiyaon and Jagdishpur markets, Lohia Chowk at Piro and Kayamnagar market on the Ara-Patna main road also witnessed blockade and protests.

(Contributed by Faryal Rumi, Rajiv Kumar, Kumar Rajesh, Tirthiraj Kushwaha, SB Sinha & Praveen Ranjan)

Title: 30 countries accept invite for naval exercise Milan in March
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A review meet was held comprising various stakeholders and administrators besides the Navy regarding multilateral naval exercise Milan 2020 to be held after mid-March in the Port City. Thirty countries have confirmed participation out of the 41 invited.

With just two months to the mega international event, preparations were reviewed at Eastern Naval Command (ENC) by vice admiral SN Ghormade, chief of staff ENC recently. A detailed presentation to apprise the attendees of the planned activities of Milan was conducted. Vice admiral SN Ghormade solicited support and cooperation from the stakeholders in co-hosting the multinational naval event as was done during IFR in 2016. The review meeting was followed by site visits to various venues by the nodal officers from the Navy and the attendees representing stakeholder organisations towards drawing out time-bound action plans.

The meeting saw the participation of civil administrators and stakeholder organisations with participation by Dr G Srijana, commissioner GVMC, Rajiv Kumar Meena, city police commissioner, A Srinivas secretary VMRDA, R N Hari Krishna, chief mechanical engineer of VPT, representatives from HSL, HPCL, IOCL, EPCL, Coromandel Fertilizers Ltd and police officers from special branch, Law and Order and Traffic. Milan 2020 is a naval exercise on the theme ‘Synergy Across the Seas’.

Title: Police foil Naidu’s attempt to hold capital shift ‘padayatra’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Tension prevailed in the city after former chief minister and TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu along with TDP and Left party leaders attempted to conduct a padayatra from Benz Circle to Autonagar area around 7 pm on Wednesday.

Naidu, who visited Benz Circle to open the Amaravati Parirakshana Joint Action Committee office, was infuriated as city police seized the buses meant to conduct a state-wide tour in protest against the proposal to shift the capital.

Soon, he along with MLAs, MLCs and leaders from CPI and CPI(M) attempted to hold a padayatra to Autonagar where the buses were seized. Soon, deputy commissioner of police (L&O–I) Harshavaradhan reached the spot to calm things down.

Naidu refused to stop his padayatra and arguments ensued as to why the bus tour was stopped. He questioned the need to take permission for conducting a ‘mere’ bus tour with the police. Traffic came to a standstill at the city’s busiest junction as trucks, buses and even ambulance services had to take a detour till Ramavarappadu.

Later, the cops brought in an Eicher van and detained all the TDP leaders, including Naidu. However, things took more dramatic turn after the driver lost the van keys that he had kept in the vehicle while boarding the van. The vehicle was stuck near the Benz Circle Flyover for almost 30 minutes.

By that time the news of Naidu being taken into custody had created furore across Krishna and Guntur districts as stray protests began to erupt across the place.

A man attempted to immolate himself in Nandigama town as the cops intervened while party workers burnt tires at Thullur area. Finally, the cops managed to move the van from the spot by using a few other similar keys and shifted him away from the spot at around 9.30 pm.

Police sources said that they would be registering a case against Naidu for violating prohibitory orders and disrupting law and order.

Title: Monthly SIP flows boost MFs’ assets to record Rs 27.3L cr in Dec
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

TNN

Mumbai: Helped by strong flows through systematic investment plans ( SIPs ) and also equity flows through lump sum routes, assets under management ( AUMs ) of the mutual fund industry touched an all-time high at Rs 27.3 lakh crore in December 2019.

The monthly SIP flow also reached an all-time high at Rs 8,518 crore, AMFI data showed, indicating investor interest for equity funds as the two benchmark indices — sensex and Nifty — scaled new peaks during the month. The previous highest monthly SIP flow was Rs 8,324 crore recorded in July 2019.

The record AUM came despite a Rs 71,160-crore outflow from liquid funds due to advance corporate tax outgo in December, which was expected, industry players said. However, net outflows from liquid and overnight funds were much less than what was recorded in September and July, probably due to the change in corporate tax rates announced on September 20, and the challenging business environment, the sources added.

Data also showed December was the 13th month on the trot that SIP flows remained above the Rs 8,000-crore level, despite all the volatility during this phase. According to AMFI chief executive N S Venkatesh, retail investors continued to repose trust in mutual funds , which was evident from the continued flows through the SIP route despite the challenging domestic economic scenario and global trade issues and conflicts.

“Markets have rallied and indices scaled new peaks, which is reflective of resolution coming through structural policies like IBC and lowering of interest rates, as also expectation from the Budget,” Venkatesh said.

Net equity flows in December jumped over threefold, boosted mainly by the rally in the stock market, and it is expected to improve if the markets remain strong “The net flow into equity funds has gone up by about 243% over the November 2019 figure. This in itself is a very positive sign, especially in conjunction with the fact that SIP flows have also increased by about 3%. The sustained rally in large-cap stocks has probably helped to build confidence among investors,” Union Mutual Fund CEO G Pradeepkumar said.

“It is also a reflection of the maturity of mutual fund investors and of the quality of sales process that the SIP flows remain robust and that there has been no large-scale redemption. As sentiments improve, we can expect the flows into equity schemes to gather further momentum,” he said.

Title: A/c numbers won’t change after Union Bank’s 3-way merger: MD
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Mayur.Shetty@timesgroup.com

Mumbai: Union Bank of India is set to double in size in a few months following the merger with Corporation Bank and Andhra Bank . The government has already infused Rs 11,700 crore into Union Bank and has indicated April 1 as a tentative date for the merger. In an interview with TOI, the bank’s MD & CEO Rajkiran Rai G speaks of how learnings from Bank of Baroda ’s amalgamation have helped save several months in implementing the merger. Excerpts:

What stage has the merger reached in terms of approvals?

We are working with a plan to compete the process as early as possible and we are working with April 1 as a tentative date. The boards of the respective banks have approved the plan. Once we get the approval from the government and the regulator, the board will decide the swap ratio and put up the same for approval with the shareholders.

Are there any preparations for the integration?

A lot. We have created a governance structure for execution. The governance structure comes from the board — a sub-committee of the board, a committee of MDs, and committee of general managers. There are 30 functional teams from the different banks looking at every product and process. There are 228 products out of 279 which have already been harmonised. Similarly, there are 179 policies of which 114 are harmonised. The functional teams have had 288 meetings. The GM committee, which approves what the functional teams have done, have met 71 times. Next, our IT teams will work on the products that will be launched on the zero date. From the customer point of view, it has been decided by the functional teams that there is no need to change the account numbers.

How will you rationalise the products? Will it be ‘best in three’?

We have decided not to go in for ‘best in three’ (of the three banks) but the ‘best in class’. Since we are already working on the products, we decided that if there are better products in the markets, we will go with them. By the third week of January, the IT teams would get into developing and rationalising the products.

What kind of integration has happened in IT?

We are in Finacle 10 (core banking system) and so is Corporation Bank. Andhra Bank is on Finacle 7, so it may take some more time. The full integration should be done in nine months. But on day 1, we will give basic services like cash withdrawal and cash deposit from all branches. We have saved at least three-four months in our amalgamation plan on the back of the learnings from the Bank of Baroda merger.

Will there be rationalisation of branches?

Fortunately for us, there is not much overlap except in some major cities. Even if we rationalise some branches in large cities, in future we will use the licence for opening more branches elsewhere. Branch network is very important for current & saving deposits and retail business. We are also thinking of moving some departments to the south. For instance, digital banking can be in Mangalore or Hyderabad. Similarly, audit and retail credit department need not be in the headquarters. Moving the departments will avoid unnecessary displacement of people. Also, we will need to expand the administrative structure to support the doubling of business that will happen after the merger. Besides having a new post of chief general managers, we will have more corporate branches, headed by general managers, in places where the merging banks are strong.

How do you plan to reposition yourself?

With three banks coming together, there is an opportunity to relook at the whole structure and position ourself as a strong digital bank. This is essential to push MSME and retail business where analytics and artificial intelligence are becoming important.

What about subsidiaries and partnerships?

In addition to our London and our mutual fund subsidiary, we will retain CorpBank Securities. There will be two life insurance joint ventures — Star Union Dai-ichi and First Life where Andhra Bank has a stake. Andhra Bank is planning to sell its stake.

Title: No reply to order, HC summons Adi Dravidar welfare secretary
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Chennai: The Madras high court on Wednesday directed the secretary to Adi Dravidar and Tribal Welfare Department and the warden of M C Rajan Government Hostel in Saidapet to appear before it and explain as to why they failed to respond to the directions of the court.

The first bench of Chief Justice A P Sahi and Justice Subramonium Prasad passed the interim order on a plea moved by S Anantharaj alleging uninhabitable conditions in the hostel and threat to its occupants due to its dilapidated state.

On November 16, 2019, the court directed the secretary to inspect the hostel and file a report with photographs by November 28. However, when the plea was taken up for hearing on Wednesday, counsel for the petitioner informed the court that the secretary had not filed any report as directed by the court.

Recording the same, the bench said, “No response has been filed despite two directions having been given by this court. The situation sought to be remedied to this PIL is directly under the nose of the high court and is a stone’s throw away from it. It is unfortunate that the respondents have not filed any response as per directions of this court. We direct the official as well as the warden to be personally present before this court on January 20 to explain as to why they have not given any response.”

Title: Bihar cops not getting allowances, benefits due to new software
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: State police personnel have not been getting their allowances and other monetary benefits since the implementation of Comprehensive Financial Management System (CFMS) in April last year. The new system is unable to cater to their several requirements as it lacks facilities for arrears disbursal, deduction for welfare fund from monthly salary and one month’s additional pay among other things.

In view of the problem persisting for so many months, the police headquarters has convened a meeting with senior officers through videoconferencing on Thursday. A letter has been sent to finance department secretary (expenditure) on Tuesday requesting him to nominate an officer posted for handling the CFMS to attend the meeting.

In fact, this is not the first letter written to the finance department by the police headquarters on this issue. Sources said letters were sent to authorities concerned on several occasions to apprise them of the difficulties caused by the CFMS.

Even DGP Gupteshwar Pandey wrote a letter to additional chief secretary (home) in December last year, categorically describing nine major issues being faced by the state police personnel due to CFMS. Pandey pointed out that the CFMS had no facility of group withdrawal of travelling allowance, arrears, deduction of house building advance taken before year 2012.

The DGP also highlighted that the software lacked facility for deducting provident fund amount of those employees who were working on contract. It also lacks facility to show annual salary details, option for 13 months’ salary and few other things.

In that letter, DGP apprehended that if timely solution is not found, the state police may have to surrender crores of rupees provided under the head of travelling allowance (TA) as the last quarter of the financial year will end in March.

Pandey mentioned that districts were allocated Rs128.95 crore under the head of TA, but only Rs36.76 crore could be disbursed and police personnel and officers were travelling on private expenses.

Bihar Police Men’s Association president Narendra Kumar Dheeraj told TOI that the TA disbursal issue was resolved hardly ten days back after the DGP’s letter. “Police headquarters has written several letters to the authorities concerned on the matter but problems persist. Salary payment for March and April last year was delayed due to this new software. Those paying EMIs were fined by banks and wards of several policemen could not deposit their fees on time,” he said, adding a month’s additional payable salary to policemen for 2018 was still pending in few districts.

Dheeraj also said there is a provision of annual payment of Rs6,000 by the association to the widows of police personnel who died while in service. “This may stop if deduction of Rs150 per month from everyone’s salary does not restart. The deduction stopped since the new software was introduced last year. It also doesn’t have the facility to deduct monthly amount from salary for payment to estranged wife on the court’s order,” he said.

Bihar Police Association president Mrityunjay Kumar Singh said Rs36,000 to maximum two wards of every officer is provided for higher studies after matriculation from the Rs150 monthly deduction for education, welfare and medical assistance. “Rs5,000 to Rs50,000 is provided in at least 25 different kinds of illness. Besides, Rs10 is deducted separately from the monthly salary of every cop from the rank of constable to inspector for their respective associations. All these are not taking place since the new software was introduced,” Singh said, adding that new software also prevents them from making mass deduction from everyone’s salary to donate for any cause as per wish.

He said the police association will enter its centenary year on May 20 this year. “But we are facing financial crunch to run this association as money is not getting deducted for the fund,” he said.

Title: Kite enthusiasts gear up for events, competitions
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Makeshift shops, selling colourful kites of all shapes and sizes, have come up across the city in view of Makar Sankranti celebrations next week. The harvest festival, which marks the arrival of spring, is synonymous to the practice of flying kites.

Everyone — from kids and youngsters to adults and elderly people — follows the tradition with utmost fervour. Hence, all types of kites are being sold in the city.

Some sellers claimed that kites with cartoon characters like Doraemon , Shin Chan and Chhota Bheem were in high demand. “I do not have plain kites because children, who visit my shop, buy ones with their favourite cartoon characters printed on them,” Shankar Gupta, a kite seller in Bakarganj, told this newspaper.

Another seller, Pankaj, said, “Kites are available in the range of Rs 3 to Rs 30 per piece. While a plain paper kite is priced at Rs 3, a fancy one is sold at Rs 30.”

Since kites are cheap, many people usually buy a large number of them before Makar Sankranti. Mahesh Shrivastava, a kite dealer in Boring Road area, claimed, “Kites are delicate and can be torn easily if not handled with care. Hence, kite lovers prefer buying approximately 100 pieces at a time.”

Meanwhile, Patnaites are excited to participate in kite-flying competitions on Makar Sankranti. “My friends and I organize a contest every year where we fly kites and eat lots of ‘tilkuts’ and sweets,” Saguna Mor resident Amit Sinha said.

To Aastha Kanika, a resident of Boring Canal Road, kite-flying is an age-old tradition, which should be kept alive.

There are some, who make their own kites, instead of buying one. “I have ordered bamboo sticks and thin, colourful sheets from an online store so that I can make kites at home,” said Sheila Tiwari, a kite enthusiast.

Title: Railways to cancel a pair of trains today, tomorrow
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The Gorakhpur-Narkatiaganj passenger (55073/55074) will be cancelled on Thursday and Friday because of the construction of a limited height subway on the Narkatiaganj-Paniahwa section of the East Central Railway’s (ECR) Samastipur division.

According to ECR’s chief public relations officer (CPRO) Rajesh Kumar, the Gorakhpur-Narkatiaganj passenger (55072) will leave Gorakhpur 90 minutes behind schedule on Friday. “The run of the Raxaul-Delhi Satyagraha Express (15273) will be controlled by 40 minutes between Bettiah and Hari Nagar on Friday,” he said.

Trains diverted: The railways has diverted the routes of seven pairs of mail and express trains via the Dhamalgaon-Moranhat-Sheosagar Town-Simaluguri Junction due to technical reasons till January 14. The diverted trains are the Dibrugarh-New Delhi Rajdhani Express (12423 /12424), Dibrugarh-Lalgarh Awadh Assam Express (15909/15910), Dibrugarh-Delhi Brahmaputra Mail (15955/15956), Dibrugarh-Chandigarh Express (15903/15904), Dibrugarh-Jhajha Express (15941/15942), Dibrugarh-Amritsar Express (15933/15934) and Dibrugarh-New Delhi Rajdhani Express (20505/20506).

Special trains: The railways will run special trains on the Dhanbad-Chennai Central and Dhanbad-Bengaluru routes on Friday to cope with the rush of passengers. While the Dhanbad-Chennai Central special (03307) will leave Dhanbad on Friday at 9.45am, it will reach Chennai Central the next day at 7pm.

Another special train (03309) between Dhanbad and Bengaluru will leave Dhanbad on Friday at 9pm and reach Bengaluru on Sunday morning at 8am.

Title: Five held for impersonating as police officers in Muzaffarpur
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

MUZAFFARPUR: Muzaffarpur police arrested five impersonators while they were trying to extort money from a truck driver and others by posing themselves as police officials near Kachchi-Pakki Chowk under the Sadar police station area of the town here on Wednesday.

Police chased the impersonators for nearly 5km to nab them while they were trying to flee towards Motihari by hijacking the truck which was loaded with cattle.

“The impersonators posing as DSP and other police officers first demanded extortion from the driver, failing which, they got inside the truck and asked the driver to take it to the nearby police station. Later, the truck driver saw that next police station passed and the impersonators kept asking them to drive. After a while, the driver saw a police patrolling vehicle and raised an alarm for help, following which the police team chased the truck for around 5km and nabbed the impersonators,” Sadar police station SHO Mithilesh Kumar Jha said.

He added that all arrested persons were being quizzed. “They have revealed some vital information about their gang and modus operandi. The rest of the gang members will be arrested soon,” said SP (city) P K Mandal, adding that further investigation is on after lodging an FIR based on the statement of the driver under various sections of IPC related to kidnapping, loot and impersonating their identities to extort money.

Meanwhile, the driver of the truck, Md Khalil told police that he was going to Samastipur . “As soon as we reached near Kachchi-Pakki Chowk, some men, dressed in police uniform stopped us on the pretext of vehicle-checking drive. I produced all the documents related to the truck and my driving license. Later, they threatened to seize our truck claiming that the vehicle is loaded with illegal cattle. They also asked us to pay Rs 5 lakh fine for letting us go without any hassle. When I refused to pay the money, they took us on gun-point and asked me to drive the vehicle to the nearby police station,” he said.

Title: Girl students fear for safety after two rape incidents in Patna
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The two recent incidents of rape in the state capital have created fear in the minds of young girls and women, who are worried about their safety. Though the main accused in the Monday rape case surrendered in a city court on Wednesday and two others had been arrested on Tuesday, the girl students, particularly those residing in private hostels and return from coaching centres late in the evening, expressed concern over the police functioning in the city as the BBA student was kidnapped in a car from the busy Boring Road roundabout in the evening hours and subsequently gang-raped in a flat at Patliputra Colony.

Another city college student was gang-raped in Nehru Nagar area of the city on December 9 last year. The case had triggered protests and debates over women safety in the state capital, but failed to wake up the police.

Several girls complained that they were often subjected to sexual harassment near the college campus or on roads. Many girls did not register their complaints due to societal pressure and fear of social stigma.

A BCA IInd year student of Shri Arvind Mahila College, on the condition of anonymity, said the incidents of sexual harassment are rampant near the college premises. “Several girls did not complain about the incidents due to stigma. They are also scared that their parents would not support their studies and ask them to stay at home,” she said.

In a unique initiative, the girl’s schools and colleges have been instructed to put a DGP box on their campuses for women’s safety on the instruction of Bihar DGP Gupteshwar Pandey. These complaint boxes are opened by the SHO of Mahila police station once in a couple of months. In addition to this, police constables were also deployed at several girl’s educational institutes.

According to sources, the initiative failed to attract complainants due to delay in opening of complaint boxes. Magadh Mahila College principal Shashi Sharma told this newspaper that earlier it was decided that the DGP box would be opened in 15 days. However, it was not followed. “Why should students endure eve-teasing for so long after submitting their complaint?” she asked.

“Even the police constables deployed near college premises are not active and keep busy playing games on their mobile phones. They do their duty only from 10.30am to 3.30pm. Even though the college hours are between 7am and 4.30pm,” she added.

Bihar State Women Commission’s chairman Dilmani Mishra blamed the casual attitude of police constables to address the women’s issue. “The police need to take strict action against the culprits of gang rape of the BBA student in Patna . Speedy trial should take place in this matter as well as other woman-related cases of rape and harassment,” she told this newspaper.

Mahila police station SHO Arti Kumari Jaiswal told this newspaper that due to staff crunch and engagement in investigation of woman-related cases, they are unable to monitor the complaints in the DGP boxes. “The staff crunch problem has been sorted out and from now on, we will open the complaint boxes twice a month,” she said.

This story is from January 9, 2020
