Title: Gold Price: Gold hits record Rs 42,000, global rates shine to 7-year high
Content:
(Representative image)

CHENNAI: The escalating US-Iran conflict , after ballistic missiles were launched early on Wednesday, fired up global gold prices by 2% to $1,611 — a 7-year-high. “Gold prices closed higher overnight. Today, in early morning trade, gold prices crossed $1,600 per ounce for the first time in nearly seven years as investors flocked to safe havens assets,” said Yes Bank chief economist Shubhada Rao.Domestic prices went up to Rs 42,860 in Chennai for 10 grams of 24 carats, a record high. Other cities saw prices hover around Rs 41,000 (see graphic). Prices are up by 5.5% in the first few days of this calendar year and nearly 25% in the current fiscal. Other precious metals such as palladium hit a fresh all-time peak of $2,056 an ounce and silver prices touched a three-month high of $18.6 per ounce. Domestic silver prices stood at Rs 48,875 per kg.The domestic prices rose by Rs 450 in one day for 10 grams and by Rs 2,000 over 10 days. The falling rupee (at Rs 71.71 per dollar as of Wednesday’s close) further pushed up domestic prices as India imports most of its gold and a weaker rupee means spending more for the same quantity of gold.Motilal Oswal associate director and head (commodity) Kishore Narne said that domestic spot prices could go up to as much as Rs 44,500 on the back of global developments.“But such prices have restricted purchases to buying merely for essential occasions such as weddings. Jewellers are not stocking up either and there is a significant drop in imports from India,” he said.Gold prices began rising last June because of the rate cut by the US Fed, and geopolitical crises such as the US-China trade war, Argentina’s currency crisis and protests in Hong Kong as well. Consequentially, demand fell by 30% in India starting from the July-September quarter of FY19 and the industry, which pinned its hopes on the festival and wedding season, is staring at uncertainty with escalating prices. The demand may not look up any time soon as analysts predict gold prices would rally until the US-Iran crisis persists. Other events, including US internal policy changes and Brexit , could also push prices up. “In the US, monthly non-farm payroll data will be released on Friday, which could give further direction to gold prices. The US Federal Reserve will also take cues from MNP data to decide the policy path in 2020,” said Abhishek Bansal, chairman of ABans group of companies.“Continued Fed intervention in the repo market could mean gold price performance will be impacted by uncertainty around monetary policy direction. Brexit would also push gold performance,” said World Gold Council in a report.

Title: Elders, mothers fight for rights at Kolkata’s Shaheen Bagh
Content:
The sit-in demonstration at Park Circus that the protesters plan to continue till the new citizenship law is r... Read More

KOLKATA: It’s almost 12.30am on a winter night, but more than 150 women sat in Park Circus Maidan, chanting slogans of ‘Azaadi’ even as a huge crowd of men stood in a circle around.Drawing inspiration from Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh, these women left their homes and gathered in the open to oppose NRC, CAA, NPR. The pillars of the movement, tagged ‘Kolkata’s Shaheen Bagh’, are mothers and grandmothers, mostly homemakers and first-time protesters, who, scared for the future of their children, have decided to stay put at Park Circus Maidan till the new citizenship law is revoked. “What will we answer when the future generations will ask us how could we let our country be destroyed in the name of religion?” said Shahina Hussain, who has stepped out to condemn the JNU attack and oppose NRC,CAA and NPR. “Students are being beaten up on campuses, which are considered to be safe places. I have a daughter and if I don’t protest now, she could be the next target.” Asked who is taking care of her household, she said her husband was managing home, while made efforts to reclaim peace in life.More women joined the protest on Wednesday, pushing up the number to 500. Holding placards and posters of Ambedkar, Gandhi and Bhagat Singh, the women sat, sloganeering while the men brought them food, tea, quilt and warm clothes, and ensured no unwanted person tried to disrupt the peaceful demonstration.Asmat Jamil, a kidney-transplant patient, who took the initiative to organize the protest, said, “The women assembled here are all homemakers and it is their fight for their rights. It is not possible for them to attend rallies at different hours and so, they have chosen this place for a peaceful demonstration. It will go on till government revokes this act.”Age seemed to be merely a number as 72-year-old Qaisar Hasan and 80-year-old Nurjahan Shakil took a lead in the protest with as much zest as the younger members. “I am here to save the social fabric of my country, my land, my home. This law will divide people in the name of religion and we will not let it happen. We have a past of living together with love and harmony and it is for the future of our children and country that I have hit the streets,” said Shakil.Benazir Hussain could not leave behind her one-and-a-half-year old son home. So, she brought Zohann along when she joined the protest on Tuesday night. “My son is not well and breastfeeding here is a little problem but I am managing. It is better to sit here and protest, instead of going to detention centres.” Like Benazir, Nazma Khatun has come with her son, Nabeel, and Tabassum with her 14-month-old daughter, Ayaat. Both the mothers had been up the entire night and said they were not going anywhere. Shagufta Yasmin (20), who has brought along her eight-month-old child, said, “We are all Indians and why do we need to prove it? Let the government prove we don’t belong. Hum kagaj nahi dikhayenge.”Kolkata’s Shaheen Bagh has turned into a community by itself, with people from all faiths and ages came together out to defend the Constitution. Presidency University student Aryan Agrahari has taught the kids, Hamza and Kashaf, the ‘Azaadi’ slogan. When the elders are getting exhausted, children like them are taking over. Feminist social activist Dolon Ganguly said the Muslim women coming out on the streets was a huge step forward. They sent out a message of secularism, she said.

Title: ‘SSNNL is liable for crop loss caused by unmaintained canals’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

SSNL is liable to pay damages to farmer for crop loss due to non-maintenance of its canals

AHMEDABAD: The Sardar Sarovar Narmada Nigam Ltd (SSNL) is liable for damages to farmers, if the lack of maintenance of its canals causes trouble for farmers and results in crop loss. The consumer court held so and ordered SSNNL to pay compensation to a Bharuch farmer for losses he suffered following a breach of a minor canal near his field.

The case involves Kirit Patel of Sarbhan village in Bharuch district . A minor canal of the Narmada project flows near his one-hectare field. He was a member of the Sarbhan Minor Narmada Irrigation Co-operative Society Ltd, which draws water from the canal. In return, each farmer pays Rs 330 per hectare per year for Narmada water irrigation.

Patel complained to the Bharuch District Consumer Dispute Redressal Forum in 2009 that due to breaches in the canal and it overflowing, his fields remained inundated, resulting in loss of crops for nearly two years – 2007-08 and 2008-09. The SSNL and local authorities did not maintain the canal and due to its poor construction, the leak continued. He claimed that he faced a loss of Rs 1 to Rs 1.5 lakh every year due to waterlogging.

The forum computed the loss and in 2011 ordered SSNNL and its local office to pay damages to the farmer. SSNNL challenged the compensation order before the Gujarat State Consumer Dispute Redressal Commission saying it is not a profit-making business body but aims to benefit farmers with its various irrigation schemes. Hence, it cannot be asked to pay damages to the farmer as its consumer. The SSNNL also argued that the farmer was drawing water in an unauthorized manner. The water is supplied to water users’ associations either without charge or at subsidised rates. It requested the commission to quash the forum’s order.

After hearing the case, the consumer commission concluded that since the farmer was paying water charges to the SSNNL, there was a consumer-service provider relationship. Hence, SSNL is liable to pay damages to farmer for crop loss due to non-maintenance of its canals.

Title: Owner arrested for changing bus chassis numbers to evade Rs 20 lakh taxes
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

SURAT: Sarthana police booked five persons on Tuesday for allegedly cheating the regional transport office (RTO) of Rs 19.66 lakh in taxes . One accused has been arrested by police on Wednesday.

Police arrested Rajendra alias Rajesh Vasvala, a resident of Kamrej, and booked four others Rajesh Vekariya, Vinod Bharwad , Vipul Gothaliya and Kirit Vyas based on complaint lodged by P D Vanda, police sub inspector of Varachha police station after preliminary investigation. The accused were booked for cheating, criminal breach of trust and other sections under Indian Penal Code.

Around two months ago cops came to know about a bus that was plying daily between Surat and parts of Saurashtra on forged registration number.

They seized the bus and got its chassis number examined forensically and found that the numbers of both chassis as well as engine have been tampered. Later police checked RTO records and found that the accused were using the registration number of a bus already scrapped.

“The original number of the bus was GJ-05-AU-9300 which had tax dues amounting to Rs 19.66 lakh, As such they were using the scrapped vehicle’s registration number as it had no tax dues,” said C K Patel, assistant commissioner of police, A division.

Investigation so far revealed that the bus originally belonged to a travel operator who sold it to Bharwad in 2017. The bus was later sold multiple times to the other accused. During the multiple dealings, they changed the chassis, engine and registration number plate of the bus to hide its original identity and evade paying the tax.

Title: Chemical factory gutted near Mehsana
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The fire in GIDC triggered panic among workers on Wednesday

PALANPUR: A chemical factory was gutted in fire at GIDC industrial estate near Dediyasan village of Mehsana on Wednesday afternoon. No person was injured in the incident that triggered panic among workers of neighbouring units. No person was injured in the incident.

At least four fire fighting teams were pressed into service to douse the fire that broke out at Linsol Polymer in plot 295 of Dediyasan GIDC. It took fire fighters from local municipality and ONGC over three hours to bring the blaze under control.

According to fire inspector Haresh Patel of Mehsana municipality said that the reason for the fire was not immediately known. The fire broke out at about 2.30pm had was brought under control at about 5.30pm, said Patel.

There were over 35 workers inside the factory when the fire broke out. They all managed to escape safely before the fire spread. Patel said that loss of property would be ascertained by factory owners.

Title: Trolls go whole hog to muzzle voices in season of protest
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

KOLKATA: Minutes after Deepika Padukone’s visit to the JNU campus to show solidarity with the students, social media was polarised with trends ranging from #ISupportDeepika to #BoycottChhapaak. While many praised her guts and quiet grace, trolls questioned her silence on campus, support for the ‘tukde-tukde gang’, alleged lack of knowledge about the issue and supposed indulgence in publicity.

In this season of protests, the actor is among many who have faced the wrath of trolls, their tone vicious and language derogatory. From raising doubts about their target’s intellect to lack of patriotism — trolls are leaving no stone unturned in pelting invisible hate bombs at anyone with contrarian views. In extreme cases, there have been reports of rape threats too.

To counter these critics, a city-based academic has changed the privacy settings of her Facebook profile and limited it to comments by her friends alone. “That has helped reduce random trolls from abusing me on Facebook. Of course, at times it’s a Facebook ‘friend’ who starts to troll you viciously and I have been surprised like this quite a few times,” she said, remembering how phrases like ‘anti-national’ and ‘naxal’ were randomly thrown at her by a Facebook friend for criticising the central government.

“Referring to my being a professor, this friend even described me as a ‘less than mediocre parasite who wastes taxpayers’ money’. Many people have come out in this fashion, particularly after NRC-CAA. At this point, there’s no option but to block them,” she said, refusing to disclose her identity to protect herself.

Visvak, an Indian student who went to London’s SOAS University on scholarship a few months back, is wary of being victimised for being vocal about his criticism of CAA-NRC on social media. From being called a “Maoist, sickular Pakistani” to a “member of the tukde-tukde gang”, Visvak has heard it all on Twitter. “I also know of girls who speak up but don’t use their profile photos and real names for fear of being identified by trolls. I do not engage with trolls. I block them or report them if they are abusive,” he told TOI.

However, not everyone can deal with barbs smartly. Some even land up in psychiatrists’ chambers for counselling after being trolled. Psychiatrist Sabyasachi Mitra told TOI that most cases of “e-abuse” involve girls. “E-abuse is in sync with the new world order. It is similar to physical abuse and generates the same consequences without the effect of violence. Victims slip to depression, anxiety and have post-traumatic stress disorder-like symptoms. Some even retreat into shells and the consequences can be similar to self-harm thoughts,” Mitra said, adding that he recommends supportive counselling, training in anxiety management and cognitive behavioural therapy for such patients.

On Tuesday, psychiatrist Jairanjan Ram had a youngster at his clinic who was crestfallen because the troll — an uncle — had accused her of making “ill-informed comments” like a “fool”.

However, Ram had a word of caution for anyone posting a strong statement on social media. The person, he said, must have the mental strength of a batsman entering a stadium to face the fastest bowler without a helmet.

“In the last four-five months, I have been seeing a rise in such cases at my clinic. In 15 days, I get to see two such cases,” he said, adding, “The moment you make a strong point, there will be people who will jump at you. It is for you to decide how far you want to take the argument. But always remember that you have to respect a person’s radical views and agree to disagree.”

Title: Tapi riverfront project to begin after formation of SPV
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The project will be implemented on 78% of the SMC and 22% of SUDA land

SURAT: The implementation of Rs 3 ,904 crore Tapi Riverfront development project will be taken up by forming a different special purpose vehicle (SPV) with a 13-member board.

Eight of the SPV members will be office bearers of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC). The project will be implemented on 78% of the SMC and 22% of Surat Urban Development Authority (SUDA) land. The SPV will be mostly formed on the lines of Sabarmati Riverfront development project.

Following the state government’s instruction, a proposal is being prepared for the development of 66 km of space — 33 km on each side of the river from Kamrej to Rundh (Proposed barrage) — for the approval of SMC standing committee.

Once the standing committee and the general board of the SMC approve the project, the ball will start rolling with a mode of finance and acquisition of land for the project.

SMC city engineer Jatin Desai told TOI: “Majority of this land is owned by different government departments and the SMC, so it will not be time consuming. Boundaries of the development are not fixed as it will based on land availability and existing development on both shores.”

The project is considered as a dream project for Surat city as it will open a whole new possibility of water transport route along with the formation of an additional reservoir for the storage of fresh water apart from number of other recreational and commercial activities. Amusement park, gardens and the development of religious places in the first phase of the project from existing, weir-cum-causeway at Singapore to proposed barrage at Rundh in downstream of Tapi, will also take place.

The SPV will include municipal commissioner, mayor, deputy mayor, standing chairman, city engineer, the SMC deputy commissioner, in -charge of road and development, the SMC deputy commissioner, finance, one independent member nominated by the mayor apart from the collector, SUDA chairman and irrigation department superintendent engineer. Chairman of the SSPV will be the government nominated director and MD will be municipal commissioner.

SMC commissioner Banchhanidhi Pani said, “As a preliminary activity to the riverfront project, we have started an exercise to block all the black and grey water going into Tapi on the whole stretch. We will complete the project to remove all outlets that dispose polluted water on Tapi riverbed and be ready for Tapi riverfront implementation.”

Title: Four fishermen injured in mid-sea clash off Mangrol
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: Four fishermen were injured in a fierce mid-sea clash between two groups off Mangrol coast in Junagadh district on Tuesday night.

The groups of fishermen crossed over into each other’s boats and launched attacks with bats, iron pipes and knives. However, they struck a comprise on Wednesday and desisted from filing police complaints.

According to the details of the incident, one group belonging to Kharwa community and the other belonging to Muslim community had gone fishing off Mangrol coast on Tuesday.

“The clash erupted between the groups when a member of one group navigated his boat through the spot where the other group had already laid its fishing net ,” said B K Vagh, sub-inspector with Mangrol marine police station.

“Though four persons were injured, the victims did not register any complaint. Traditionally, they first take permission from their group leaders before approaching the police. Their leaders asked them to strike truce,” explained Vagh.

Velji Masani , leader of the Kharwa community in Mangrol, “We have asked the members of both the groups to give compensation to those who suffered losses in the incident which they have agreed.”

Title: Amartya Sen speaks out against CAA
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Amartya Sen

KOLKATA: Nobel laureate economist Amartya Sen on Wednesday said the CAA “should be scrapped and the Supreme Court should turn it down on grounds of it being unconstitutional”. Sen, who reached Kolkata on Wednesday night and headed for his Santiniketan home, also reacted to the JNU vandalism, saying, “The big absence of justice in this matter is very conspicuous.”

Speaking to a Bengali news channel outside the airport, Sen said, “To give one citizenship based on religion is against the Constitution. The law is in conflict with the Constitution. It’s the job of the Supreme Court to see whether what was passed in Parliament can be legally attached to the Constitution.”

Speaking about the JNU attack, Sen said, “Some outsiders tortured the students and indulged in lawlessness. Police have failed to nab anybody till date and I heard the CCTV cameras weren’t working. I also heard that an FIR was lodged against those who got beaten up.”

Sayantan Basu, BJP state general secretary, said, “We have nothing to say if Sen reacts to the role of Delhi cops. But we expect him to be equally vocal when lawmakers like Swapan Dasgupta and Babul Supriyo are harassed on university campuses.”

Title: SBI Home Loan: SBI to ensure completion of housing projects it finances
Content:
SBI chairman Rajnish Kumar (File photo)

(With PTI inputs)

MUMBAI: State Bank of India (SBI) has launched a loan product that will protect home buyers financially against non-completion of projects that it has funded. The bank has introduced Residential Builder Finance with Buyer Guarantee (RBBG), which guarantees completion of projects funded by the bank to customers availing SBI Home Loans.According to SBI chairman Rajnish Kumar , the product will build confidence among home buyers for under-construction projects as it will secure their hard-earned money. At the same time, it will boost the under-stress real estate sector."We are committing that till the time a project receives an occupation certificate (OC), there will be a guarantee which the bank will offer buyers who take loans from it. This will be a win-win situation for homebuyers, builders and the bank," Kumar said.Under RBBG, the guarantee would be given by the bank till the project gets the OC."Suppose a buyer has booked a flat in a project for Rs 2 crore and has paid Rs 1 crore, and if the project gets stuck then we will refund Rs 1 crore. The term of the guaranteed will be linked till OC," he explained further.Initially, this product will be available in seven cities. “It is yet another effort by SBI to make affordable housing conveniently accessible to individuals with dreams of owning their desired home. Based on the response from both builders and customers, we may consider extending this product to other parts of the country,” said Kumar.RBBG will focus on the affordable housing segment with home prices of up to Rs 2.50 crore in seven Indian cities initially. Under this product, all reputed builders fulfilling the prescribed criteria by the bank can avail loans of between Rs 50 crore and Rs 400 crore.SBI commands 25% market share in home loans in India. The country’s largest lender has partnered Sunteck Realty — the first builder to avail this scheme. The bank is pushing home loans, the largest contributor to its credit growth this year, by bringing down interest rates to below 8% — the lowest in the industry.In Video: SBI to refund borrowers if builder delays project

Title: Agra Municipal Corporation proposes tax on pet dogs
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: The Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) administration is going to levy a tax on residents keeping pet dogs. During the municipal house session on Wednesday, Mayor Naveen Jain directed the civic body officials to start the work in this regard. The idea was put forward by councillor Ravi Sharma.

“Keeping a pet dog is not a necessity. It is a type of luxury. Owners of pet dogs take them out for a walk on streets and parks where they defecate and hamper sanitation and hygiene. Sanitation workers make efforts to keep the surroundings clean and healthy. Therefore, municipal corporation must charge at least Rs 1,000 per annum from the pet owners,” Sharma said.

According to the estimate made by Sharma, there are around 10,000 residents who keep a pet dog in 100 wards of the city. Charging Rs 1,000 per annum from each pet owner will result in earning Rs 1 crore. The funds can be used in improving the state of cleanliness in the city.

A senior civic body official said, “There is a provision to levy tax on owners of pet animals under the Municipal Corporation Act, 1957. However, in Uttar Pradesh , no tax has ever been imposed on pet dogs in the past. A policy is required to be developed in this regard. Every pet owner will have to apply for the licence and procure an anti-rabies vaccination certificate. The process will be started in the next financial year.”

Title: Thespians, authors extend support to JNU victims
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kolkata: Thespian Soumitra Chatterjee, author Sankha Ghosh and director Tarum Mazumder were among the signatories who have extended their support towards the JNU students who were attacked by masked thugs on campus.

In a statement released on Wednesday, the veterans mentioned their inability to be physically present beside the students. “Our hearts are with them. We are convinced that they will win the battle,” read the statement that was shared on social media by Chatterjee’s daughter Poulami Bose.

The intellectuals mentioned they were at a loss for words to condemn the atrocities on students. “In contemporary times, JNU is one of the premium institutions.... Despite knowing the identity of the goons who indulged in the planned attacks on campus, not one of them has been arrested by Amit Shah’s police. Such an incident is a big scar on the democratic history of our country,” the statement said. It also mentioned that the signatories believe they notice a “conspiracy” to destroy the future by taking away the right of students to think about the well-being of the nation and society. The statement was also signed by Koushik Sen, Badsha Maitra, Anjan Dutta, Sabyasachi Chakraborty, Samik Banerjee, Buddhadeb Dasgupta and Bidipta Chakraborty, among others.

Title: Apparel units, shops in Tirupur down shutters
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

TIRUPUR: Most of the commercial establishments and apparel units remained closed in the city on Wednesday in support of the nationwide bandh called by trade unions. Normal life took a hit due to the bandh.

Police detained 600 protesters, who gathered in front of the Tirupur railway station, and released them in the evening. Earlier, police had diverted traffic for two-and-half hours in order to facilitate the stir on the stretch. Apparel industrial sources said business transactions worth several crores have been lost in the day. Even most of the medical shops on arterial roads were shut in support of the protest.

The nationwide strike was called by trade unions including CITU, AITUC, LPF, MLF and HMS, urging the Centre to protect the weakened MSMEs sector and automobile industry, to give up plans to privatize public sector undertakings including Indian railways and to control inflation.

CPM state secretary K Balakrishnan, who took part in the protest here, said wrongful economic policies of the central government had squeezed MSMEs sector including the Tirupur apparel cluster, increased unemployment and inflation. “Moreover, the Centre has brought amendments in labour laws which deny various rights to employees. While people are suffering due to poverty in the country, the Centre has brought the Citizenship Amendment Act, which is against the constitution.”

“So, people, especially government and private employees, have supported the nationwide protest,” he added.

Title: Bihar: 725 trees to be felled for widening of old GT Road in Sasaram
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

SASARAM: At least 725 fully grown trees have been identified to be felled for widening of the GT Road that criss-crosses through the Sasaram town.

The foundation stone for the road widening project was laid on December 17. According to sources, the state road construction department (RCD), after completing necessary formalities at its end, has sent a proposal in this regard to Rohtas divisional forest officer (DFO) and sought his approval to cut down the identified trees.

The 5.28km-long GT Road stretch, which passes through the municipal area of Sasaram, has to be widened under the supervision of RCD’s Kochas division executive engineer Sanjay Kumar. “We conducted a survey and found that around 725 trees on both flanks of the road are coming under the alignment of the widened section of the road,” Sanjay said.

He added that a nod from the DFO will pave way for the road widening work entailing an estimated outlay of Rs 43 crore.

Asked about a notification of state environment, forest and climate change department dated July 26, 2019, which prohibits cutting of trees on government land for any project, the RCD executive engineer said the notification is not applicable to this project since it has already got the approval of the state government. “This approval was given in 2018,” he said.

Rohtas DFO P Gaurav told this newspaper that he had certain queries and the approval to fell the trees will be given only after he gets proper answer to the queries.

“Our department had earlier turned down a request from the RCD seeking permission to cut 7,000 trees for widening the Nasarigaj-Dehri road. We have asked the RCD to workout a plan so that less number of trees are required to be felled,” Gaurav said and added that as per the July notification, environment protection measures like translocation of trees and plantation of twice the number of trees cut would have to be taken into account while cutting down the existing trees.

Title: Probe ordered into death of convicts in Buxar jail
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

BUXAR/PATNA: A week after the death of two life convicts serving life term in Buxar Central Jail under mysterious circumstances, a high-level team of the prison directorate visited the jail to inquire into the incident.

Sources said that a team of officials led by deputy director (prison) Prashant Kumar Srivastava visited the jail on Tuesday and inquired about the cause of death of the two inmates. One of the two deceased, Suresh Kumhar (30), a resident of Nainijore village in Buxar district had died during treatment at Buxar sadar hospital. Another inmate Master Bind (80) was declared brought dead by the doctors after being referred from the jail hospital on January 1.

The members of the probe team talked to the prisoners, warders and other staff of the jail and collected information about Suresh and Master Bind. The probe team met the doctor and para-medical staff of the hospital who had attended to Suresh before his death.

A senior jail official said the probe team also discussed the issue pertaining to the inmate’s death with the doctors posted in the prison hospital. The documents related to the treatment of the prisoners were provided to the visiting team before it left for the prison directorate. "The probe into the deaths has been ordered by IG, prison directorate and correctional services, Mithilesh Mishra. We will submit the report to him in a day or two,” said a member of the team.

He, however, refused to share the findings of the investigation on the plea that the report is confidential and he was not authorized to talk to the media. Suresh had complained of severe pain in stomach, chest and also acute ikkheadache. His father and two brothers, who were also lodged in the same jail had claimed that Suresh had no serious ailment.

The relatives told the jail warden that Suresh had caught cold. Even the medical officer said that Suresh was being treated for symptoms of cold.

Suresh along with his father and two brothers was serving life term in a murder case lodged with the Brahpur police station in 2008. The four were convicted for killing their neighbour Kuber Tiwari on March 20, 2008.

Title: Ayurvedic doctor held for molesting woman in Rajkot
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

Title: Bihar: Jaggery, sugar ‘tilkuts’ find many takers
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: With Makar Sankranti around the corner, city shops have started selling ‘tilkuts’, ‘til papdis’, rolls, ‘gajaks’ and ‘laddoos’. Different varieties of the sweet sesame wafers are available, but those made of sugar and jaggery are the most popular among Patnaites.

While sugar and jaggery ‘tilkuts’ are priced at Rs 300 and Rs 240 per kg, the sugar-free variants are being sold at Rs 400. Besides, ‘khoya’ and chocolate ‘tilkuts’ are available for Rs 450 and Rs 500 per kg.

Also known as ‘Til Sakrat’, ‘tilkut’ is an important part of Makar Sankranti. City-based priest Upendra Nath told this newspaper, “Offering black and white sesame sweets to God can bring prosperity and good luck. People also offer ‘tilkuts’ along with curd and flattened rice to priests and the poor.

Numerous makeshift shops have been set up in every nook and cranny of the city for selling ‘tilkuts’. “Every year, I set up a stall almost a fortnight before Makar Sankranti. People start buying ‘tilkuts’ from the last week of December,” said Rajiv Kumar, the owner of a shop on Gola Road.

Several shops have also hired ‘tilkut’ makers from other cities. Ravi Gupta, the owner of a prominent sweet store in Kadamkuan, said, “I have been hiring ‘tilkut’ makers from Gaya for the last 20 years.”

Shopkeepers claimed that ‘khoya tilkuts’ were in high demand. “They have always been the customers’ favourite. ‘Khoya’, being a milk product, cannot be stored for a long time. Hence, I make sure that these ‘tilkuts’ are sold within two-three days,” said Nirmal, the owner of a ‘tilkut’ shop on Gola Road.

Some hotels and restaurants have also introduced sesame sweets in their menu. “We will offer ‘til laddoo’, ‘gajak’ and other sweets from January 10 to 18,” said Keshav Shrivastava, the manager of a hotel on Boring Road.

Meanwhile, Patnaites have started purchasing ‘tilkuts’ for themselves and their relatives. “All my family members love ‘tilkuts’. Many sweet shops sell them in colourful boxes, which can be gifted to others,” said Pritee Prasad, a resident of Kadamkuan.

Title: Dalai Lama hails Nitish Kumar’s efforts for environmental conservation
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

BODH GAYA: The Dalai Lama on Wednesday expressed concern over global warming and appreciated the steps taken by the Bihar government for environmental conservation through ‘Jan Jivan Hariyali’ mission, a brainchild of CM Nitish Kumar . The Buddhist spiritual leader expressed his opinion in this regard during an half-an-hour long meet with the CM on Wednesday.

The meet was held in Bodh Gaya-based Tibetan monastery, a few hundred meters away from the Mahabodhi Mahavihara, the seat of Lord Buddha’s enlightenment. Nitish had especially flown to Bodh Gaya to meet the Dalai Lama, who is here on a three weeks sojourn.

While discussing the global warming issue with Nitish, the Dalai Lama said the ambit of non-violence as espoused by Lord Buddha, included nature and, like human beings, nature too should not be subjected to violent cruelty. “The survival of humanity is at stake and global warming is adversely affecting all parts of the world, including India. I have personally observed that the incidents of snow fall in Himachal Pradesh has come down on account of climate change,” said the Dalai Lama, who has his headquarters based in Dharamshala in Himachal Pradesh.

During the meet, the issue of ancient education system with its humane approach in knowledge acquisition also came up for discussion and the need for revival and improvisation of ancient values of education as practised in Nalanda University was deeply felt.

Nitish, besides explaining the concept of ‘Jan Jivan Hariyali’ mission, also informed the Buddhist spiritual leader about the project to bring Ganga water to Gaya to tackle the issue of plunging groundwater level and claimed that Bodh Gaya too will benefit from it.

The Dalai Lama conveyed his good wishes for the proposed human chain being organised by the state government on January 19. Lobsang Sangay, president of the he Tibetan government in exile, was also present at the meet. Others dignitaries present in the meet, included Chanchal Kumar, principal secretary to the CM, Magadh range IG Rakesh Rathi, Gaya DM Abhishek Singh and SSP Rajeev Mishra and Bodh Gaya Temple Committee secretary N Dorje.

The CM presented a memento, calendar and Bodh Gaya coffee table book to the spiritual leader.

Title: Magadh University staff to get revised salary in January 2020
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

GAYA: About 1,700 teaching and non-teaching staff of Magadh University (MU) headquarters, 19 constituent and one deficit grant minority college will be getting their salary for the month of January in the revised pay scale as per the recommendations of the Seventh Pay commission.

Though eligible for the revised scale from January 2016, the scale was not being paid to more than 20,000 teaching and non-teaching employees of the universities in the state including MU. On an average, each employee is estimated to get a hike of around 20% in gross emoluments. Sources said that the salary difference accruing to employees for January 2016 to December 2019 will be paid later.

MU registrar Prof Sidnath Prasad Deen said that he discussed the issue of revised pay scale with senior officials of the education department on Tuesday.

“Rekha Singh, director of higher education, will hold a meeting in the third week of this month to review the financial requirements of the university in view of the implementation of the new pay scale. After the review meet, the payment-related formalities will be completed well in time to ensure disbursement of January’s salary in the enhanced scale,” the registrar said.

On the issue of students union election, the registrar said that a committee has been constituted to work out the modalities of the union elections.

Asked whether the office bearers of the central union of the university would be directly elected or college-level representatives would elect the central union office bearers, the registrar said a final decision on the election mode would be taken after considering the report of the committee constituted for the purpose. “The committee is expected to submit its report within a week,” the registrar said.

He added that recommendation would be made to the state government for grant or extension of affiliation to colleges located in five districts of Magadh division . Reminded about the legal provision regarding the university senate making the recommendation, the registrar said that once approved by the syndicate, the recommendations would be forwarded to the state government in anticipation of the senate’s approval.

The annual meet of the university senate is likely to be held in February to approve the university budget and other academic and administrative issues placed before the apex body.

Title: Railways to increase speed limit of trains on Patna route in April
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The East Central Railway (ECR) has approved the proposal of Danapur division to increase the speed limit of all mail and express trains up to 130 kmph on the Jhajha-Patna Junction-Pt Deendayal Upadhaya Junction mainline section from April 30. The Railway Board has given its nod to the proposal. At present all mail and express trains, including Rajdhani Express, are running at the speed limit of 110 kmph between Jhajha and Pt Deendayal Upadhaya Junction route.

ECR’s chief public relations officer (CPRO) Rajesh Kumar told this newspaper on Wednesday that railways is prepared to enhance the speed limit of trains up to 130 kmph on this particular route after successful completion of advanced signalling work. “Railways has also carried out track renewal work required to increase the speed limit from 110 kmph to 130 kmph. Linke Hofmann Busch (LHB) coaches are capable of running at the maximum speed limit of 130 kmph,” he said.

Kumar said track renewal work on the Jhajha-Patna — Pt Deendayal Upadhaya Junction route was significant as it replaced the 52kg tracks by those of 60kg with the length of each track to be about 130 metres. “It has already been declared as ‘Rajdhani Route’ by the Railway Board,” he said.

The CPRO said an increase in the speed limit is likely to reduce the journey hours at least by 30 minutes on the Patna-Delhi route in particular. “It would also help railways clear huge traffic rush on the Jhajha-Patna-Pt Deendayal Upadhaya Junction route. The division is presently coping with the operational needs of about 280 pairs of passenger trains. Thus, an increase in the speed limit up to 130 kmph will prove to be a boon for passengers as well,” he said.

Besides, railways has also increased the speed limit from 50 kmph to 100 kmph on Dauram Madhepura-Murliganj section under Samastipur division and from 60 kmph to 100 kmph on the Banmankhi-Purnia section followed by Dhanbad-Gaya-Pt Deendayal Upadhaya Junction from 110 kmph to 120 kmph, on Barauni-Katihar route from 70 kmph to 100 kmph, on Mohiuddinnagar-Bachwara route from 75 kmph to 90 kmph, on Raxaul-Chauradano route from 50 kmph to 80 kmph and Kursela-Karagola route from 70 kmph to 100 kmphccix:command value="252,1"/>According to sources, railways has already increased the speed limit up to 130 kmph from Pt Deendayal Upadhaya Junction- Allahabad-Kanpur onwards to New Delhi. Increase in the speed limit has thus become a must for railways to maintain a uniform speed limit of 130 kmph right from Howrah to Delhi via Patna, Pt Deendayal Upadhaya Junction, Allahabad and Kanpur for the fast movement of mail and express trains.

Title: IIT-Kharagpur students take a stand
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

At least 300 students gathered outside the first gate of the campus after they were reportedly denied permissi... Read More

KHARAGPUR: A large number of students in IIT Kharagpur staged a protest on Wednesday evening against the incidents at JNU, Jamia Milia Islamia and Aligarh Muslim University . Carrying placards that condemned “atrocities” and “coercion” on campuses, students from different classes and departments — shouting slogans, like “hum leke rahenge azadi” and “makkaro sun lo … azadi” — said they feared oppression was coming close to home.

At least 300 students gathered outside the first gate of the campus after they were reportedly denied permission to hold the protest meeting on campus. They said that for the past few days they had been trying to reason with the institute authorities to allow them to protest on the institute premises, which had delayed the agitation. They, however, insisted on anonymity. “We will not be surprised if we are singled out and attacked,” a girl said.

Registrar B N Singh did not answer calls despite sev-eral attempts.

Title: NRI battles for life after car overturns
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Such was the impact of the accident that the car got badly mangled

Surat: A non-resident Indian (NRI) suffered serious injuries when the car in which he and two others overturned after colliding with a truck and then crashing into a traffic island on Udhna-Magdalla Road early on Wednesday.

NRI Kirit Thummar, who lives in Ahmedabad, was returning after visiting a friend’s house in Vesu. He was sitting beside the driver. He was first taken to the New Civil Hospital (NCH) and then to Mahavir Hospital in an unconscious condition.

An official from Khatodara police investigating the case said, “The victim is unconscious. His daughter, who is a doctor at a hospital in Sola area of Ahmedabad, told us that she didn’t want to register any complaint.”

In another accident, Jitu Patil, a rickshaw driver, died after his vehicle was hit by a car from the rear on Dumas Road on Wednesday evening. Patil was returning home in Magdalla, with his friend Sagar Mistry when the accident happened. Mistry and Patil were rushed to NCH where Patil was declared dead on admission.

Title: Fireman injured, two rescued in Raghuvir textile market fire
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The fire might have been caused by a short circuit

Surat: One firemen was injured in the fire that engulfed several floors of Raghuvir Celeum Textile market on Puna-Kumbhariya road on Wednesday morning. Two persons were rescued from the blaze as textile goods worth lakhs of rupees were gutted.

Accourding to fire officials, 21 fire tenders were pressed into service and it took them more than three hours to douse the fire that is believed to have broke out due to a short circuit.

The fire started around 10th floor of the textile market and quickly spread to it top 13th floor and the terrace. Dense black smoke could be seen emanating from the top floors of the building from a distance. Most of the occupants of the building that houses several textile shops and warehouses, were able to move out safely. The two who could not managed to escape were saved by the fire officials.

Basant Parikh, chief fire officer of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) told TOI, “The two persons who had to be rescued had tried to escape from seventh floor in a lift and got trapped. Our men rescued them.”

“One of our fire fighters Hitesh Thakur, who was cutting the shutters on the terrace fell unconscious as dense smoke suddenly engulfed him as the cutter pierced through the metal shutters. He is normal now,” added Parikh.

“The fire started due to short circuit and spread quickly through wiring from 7th floor to the 13th floor. The market officials had isolated fire safety lines and as a result smoke detector alarm did not go off,” he said.

The textile market has floor which are 18-feet in height. So each floor is nearly double the height of a normal floor.

Large quantity of cloth material was gutted in the fire, said fire officials.

Title: HC upholds earlier order to sell gym gear of Talwalkars
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Swati.Deshpande@timesgroup.com

Mumbai: The Bombay high court (HC) has dismissed an appeal by Talwalkars Healthclubs and confirmed a judge’s order last month directing sale of its gym equipment by Tata Capital Financial Services from January 8. Justice Gautam Patel had permitted Tata Capital to sell the equipment at 50 locations all over India from January 8, if by then the gym chain failed to come up with a solution to settle its dues. The non-banking financial company (NBFC) had moved the high court last year in a dispute over dues worth Rs 36 crore in lease agreements for gym equipment.

The Talwalkars chain had appealed Justice Patel’s order. The appeal was heard on Wednesday by a division bench of Chief Justice Pradeep Nandrajog and Justice Bharati Dangre where Tata counsel Biren Saraf argued that since no solution was provided for payment, the company be permitted to take possession of the gym equipment and sell them. Tata Capital Financial Services said it had given finance to enable Talwalkars to take gym equipment on lease. The agreements are in existence since June 2014.

Saraf and law firm Manilal Kher Ambalal for the NBFC said their client was the owner of the equipment and, for the default on the rent amount for their lease, the Tata company was entitled to repossess and sell them since otherwise they would get rusted.

Talwalkars’ counsel Ashish Kamat had earlier said 40 of the 90-odd outlets are shut for want of payment of rent to landlords for the premises. The HC had last year also appointed a receiver for all the equipment plant and machinery, and noted that it is an admitted position that Talwarkars Healthclubs is facing financial difficulties. It had also noted that it was “ even now attempting to resolve with its other creditors”.

Title: Kolkata: ‘Take screenshots to lodge e-threat complaint’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: A day after the Kolkata Police assured action against an accused who allegedly issued rape and death threats to a Jadavpur University student, the police have assured every netizen in the city that they can lodge complaints against such threats by contacting the local police stations or the cyber cell with adequate evidence in the form of screenshots. The cops said that depending on the nature of the crime, the legal team will mull the legal steps that can be initiated.

The cyber cell has, meanwhile, contacted the victim — a 25-year-old woman — and asked her to write out a detailed complaint. “We have asked her to follow the legal procedure. An initial probe into who has threatened her has also been launched,” said a senior officer at Lalbazar.

DC (cyber) Aparajita Rai told TOI that they have a standard operating procedure (SOP) of dealing with such cases where each case is taken up for legal vetting and counselling is offered to the victim on future steps. “Once we get the initial complaint through email, we forward it to either Facebook, WhatsApp, Twitter or Instagram authorities, marking out the exact complaint. It usually takes some time for them to respond. This is the time when we launch an initial inquiry. Not all cases can be clubbed under the Information Technology Act. So, based on a written and signed statement — it is compulsory under CrPC — we slap charges under either IT Act or IPC,” an officer said.

“Some women might want the harassment to stop immediately. For these cases, we even try non-technical methods of policing to locate the culprit. If required, we get a psychiatric assessment of the accused and follow it up with counselling. In serious cases of threats — often repeated over a few days — we carry out a direct arrest. But for all such cases, the initial inquiry is vital to fix responsibilities and gauge the seriousness of the complaint,” said an officer.

The film studies student who is a known face in the anti-CAA movement and played a crucial role during the protest at Sulekha on Monday has now claimed she received rape and murder threats on social media.

Title: Tirupur: After 53 years, first water scheme of Tirupur corporation bids adieu
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

TIRUPUR: After serving for 53 years, the first water scheme of Tirupur corporation has come to an end. Though the closing down of the scheme was part of implementing fourth water scheme of the corporation, it has been done at least two years before possibly the new water scheme could come into existence.

The first water scheme was not only catering to the needs of the residents in couple of wards in the corporation in southern side of the city but also serving many common water taps in the corporation limits and in other civic bodies including Karuvalur, Nambiyampalayam, Avinashi, and Thirumuruganpoondi.

The 4.7-MLD scheme was implemented in 1967 when Tirupur was facing severe water crisis. The water was taken from Bhavani river in Mettupalayam of Coimbatore district for the scheme. With the pipeline laid for around 55km, people in civic bodies from Karuvalur to Thirumuruganpoondi demanded to erect common water taps for their use. So, the Tamil Water Supply and Drainage (Twad) board, the implementing agency, had obliged and erected the common water taps.

More than 10 such common water taps, including six taps at 15 Velampalayam in the corporation limits, were serving hundreds of people daily. Even after two other water schemes with a capacity of 114 MLD came into existence, the corporation did not drop the first water scheme though its capacity was less compared to other schemes.

On Tuesday, the corporation announced that since there was hindrance in laying giant pipes for the fourth water scheme, which was also implemented from Bhavani river in Mettupalayam, the pipelines of the first water schemes were getting damaged.

A senior Twad official told TOI: “The corporation has informed us that it no longer need the first water scheme. Hence, we are operating only second water scheme for the civic body.”

Tirupur corporation commissioner K Sivakumar said, “We wanted to dismantle existing facility of main water pumping station of the first water scheme to establish main water pumping station for the fourth water scheme. Now we are buying another 10 MLD water in third water scheme from the New Tirupur Area Development Corporation, a public-private partnership initiative, to overcome deficiency created by the first water scheme. We also have planned to feed some common water taps which were served by the first water scheme.”

But the residents of 15 Velampalayam and other civic bodies are unhappy over the stopping of the scheme even before the commencement of the fourth water scheme. “The water was not supplied in the common water taps for the past three months. More than 2,000 people utilize the taps daily. Since the water of the first scheme would be tastier than the water supplied in third water scheme, which draws water from Cauvery in Erode district, many residents from various areas would come to draw water from the taps,” said V P Subramaniam, a resident of 15 Velampalayam.

M Yuvaraj, a CPI functionary in Thirumuruganpoondi, said, “The common water taps were existing for decades and they were well utilized. If the authorities failed to bring back the taps alive soon, we will stage protests.”

Title: IMD predicts thunderstorm with lightning today
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Skies remained mostly cloudy on Wednesday under the influence of a western disturbance and light showers occurred in Patna in the late evening hours.

Weatherman forecasts light showers in most parts of the state on Thursday. India Meteorological Department (IMD) in its bulletin stated that thunderstorm and lightning are expected at isolated places in the state over the next 24 hours.

The Patna Meteorological Centre bulletin stated that weather remained dry across the state during last 24 hours, while dense fog was observed at Purnia and shallow to moderate fog at few other places as well.

Lowest minimum temperature was recorded at Sabour in Bhagalpur district at 8.2 degrees C. Minimum temperature in Patna, on the other hand, was recorded at 9.8 degrees C, which was a notch higher than the corresponding normal for the day.

Meteorologists attributed the comparatively higher minimum temperature to cloud cover, which prevented the radiation from the earth’s surface to escape in the upper level of atmosphere in the night and early morning hours.

The same cloud cover also led to tad higher maximum temperature in Patna at 20 degrees C, which was two notches higher than the corresponding normal.

The Patna Meteorological Centre stated that rise in night temperature is expected by 1-2 degrees C during the next two days and gradual fall by 3 to 5 degrees C thereafter. Shallow to moderate fog is also likely at one or two places during next 2-3 days.

Skymetweather, on the other hand, stated that minimum temperature will drop by two to three notches by January 10 and onwards after the cloud cover clears. It further stated that eastern parts of Uttar Pradesh received light rain during the morning hours. “This rain belt will shift further eastward tonight and cover many parts of Uttar Pradesh, Jharkhand, northern parts of Odisha, some parts of Bihar and West Bengal,” the Skymet report stated.

Talking about the weather system, meteorologists at Skymet stated that a trough was extending from Punjab to Bihar across east Uttar Pradesh. Easterly and south-easterly humid winds from the Bay of Bengal were also feeding moisture in east India.

“Due to the presence of this significant weather system, rainfall activities are expected to continue until Thursday in many parts of east India. By the evening of January 9, the intensity of rain will start decreasing and the minimum temperature will start increasing after this spell,” the Skymet report stated.

The meteorologists at Skymet have further predicted that the weather in east India will start clearing from January 10 and the minimums will drop by 2-3 degrees C.

IMD stated that a fresh western disturbance is likely to affect western Himalayan region from January 11 onwards, though its impact on Bihar was not ascertained yet.

3 flights cancelled: Altogether 13 flights to and from Jayaprakash Narayan International (JPNI) Airport, Patna, were affected due to poor visibility and inclement weather conditions in the city on Wednesday.

The flight operations at Patna airport began after 9.30am when the minimum 1,000m visibility of Runway Visual Range (RVR) was achieved, said a weather scientist at Patna Meteorological Centre.

According to sources at Patna airport, several incoming flights were delayed due to inclement weather in other cities, including Delhi, Hyderabad and Mumbai. “The flight operations remained unaffected at Patna airport. The visibility of RVR was normal throughout the day,” the sources said.

Several stranded flyers at Patna airport complained about the delays and missing their connecting flights and other important work.

One Anand Singh Gautam tweeted: “Flight-SG376 Patna to Kolkata. It was supposed to reach Kolkata at 10:50am today, but it got delayed. The flight departed at 11:10am. My friend had an interview scheduled in the afternoon.”

An executive of SpiceJet said that the flight was delayed due to the consequential impact of bad weather in Patna.

SpiceJet’s Chennai-Patna-Chennai (SG-323/324), GoAir’s Delhi bound flight (G8-133/134) and Air India’s Delhi-Patna-Delhi flight (AI- 409/ 410) were cancelled on Wednesday were cancelled due to operational reasons.

Title: Gujarat: Woman crushed to death in floor mill
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: In a freak accident , a woman operrating a mechanical flour mill met a brutal death after she got crushed in the machine in Rampar village on the outskirts of Jamnagar .

The accident happened when the sari of the victim, Gayatri Sadhu, 27, got stuck in the belt of the mill’s motor and she got dragged into it. Her head and hands got severed and she died on the spot on Tuesday evening.

Sadhu’s husband Deepak had died of dengue on November 11, 2019. Dipak had a flour mill, which she had started operating after his death.

“The livelihood of Sadhu’s family depended on this flour mill. Sadhu used to grind the grains brought by her customers and earn enough to run her family,” said PH Parmar of Panchkoshi police station.

He is survived by her two sons — six-year-old Prakash and four-year-old Yash, and her 70-year-old mother-in-law Sharda.

The police have registered a case of accidental death.

Title: Bihar Congress chief Madan Mohan Jha flays state govt
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Bihar Pradesh Congress committee (BPCC) president Madan Mohan Jha on Wednesday criticized the government for harassing the protesters and innocents while letting criminals roam free in the state. He cited the examples of gang rape of a woman who was allegedly kidnapped from a mall on Monday and raped while an undertrial was killed inside Hajipur jail recently and a couple was murdered in East Champaran on Tuesday.

While addressing a presser, Jha defended his party leader Ashutosh Sharma who is in jail after a complaint was lodged against him for thrashing a journalist during a protest in the city against Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and National Register for Citizens (NRC) on December 21.

“Police have yet not identified the murderers of our youth leader Rakesh Yadav who was killed on December 28 at Hajipur. This government is using all its power to harass the opposition leaders only. They are wasting their energy,” he said.

Jha rapped the state government for increasing crime in Bihar and said criminals were ruling the roost in the state. “Be it any day, one always gets the news of theft, robbery, murder and rape. There is no law and order here. While criminals are roaming free, innocents are being put behind the bar,” he said.

He also mocked chief minister Nitish Kumar ’s massive Jal-Jivan-Hariyali campaign as well as the other initiatives by the state government. “Has prohibition become successful? Are no dowry and child marriage being practised here? So what is the use of this new drama? Was Nitish not aware of increasing pollution level 15 years ago when he came to power? State government should make a plan to curb crime, instead of wasting time on useless things,” said Jha.

Title: CCI: Can probe unfair practices by e-comm companies
Content: BENGALURU: The Competition Commission of India (CCI) has said it can intervene — case-by-case — to check unfair practices by online players by investigating issues such as deep discounts, exclusive agreements between platforms and suppliers, business terms and platform neutrality. The CCI report comes after e-commerce companies like Walmart-owned Flipkart and Amazon were under government scrutiny following complaints of unfair practices by smaller online sellers and offline retailers.In a market study of online retail, food delivery and travel bookings, the CCI has said, “Eliminating anti-competitive behaviour that further tilts the scales or deters entry assumes utmost importance.” The CCI, in its 37-page report, has advised digital commerce companies to adopt a self-regulatory approach on these issues and come up with transparent policies on search ranking, discounting policy and treatment of user data.In India, the e-commerce market is dominated by Walmart ’s Flipkart and Amazon, while the food delivery space is dominated by Swiggy and Zomato . For travel bookings online, MakeMyTrip Group , which also houses Goibibo, enjoys a lion’s share.“Imposition of unfair condition or price in sale or purchase of goods and services by dominant enterprises is prohibited under section 4 of the Act. Thus, the commission can intervene, on a case-by-case basis, in matters where unfair conditions or price is imposed through contractual provisions, by an enterprise that is dominant in the relevant market,” the CCI said.Further, it can examine contracts under section 3(4) of the Act where terms may directly or indirectly lead to an exclusionary effect on competition while also being exploitative or unfair to the business users. On exclusive agreements, the CCI is of the view that while it is not per se anti-competitive, they raise potential competition concern “when used as an exclusionary tactic to foreclose competition to rivals or to impede entry”. The regulatory body had a similar view on deep discounts as well. “Discounts offered by platforms in the early years are typically seen as a means to establish network effects for user on-boarding. However, discounts can harm competition when used as an exclusionary device by enterprises with market power,” it added. These comments from the CCI highlight concerns on increasing focus on private label play by e-tailers and their pricing, often cheaper than third-party brands. The study was first launched in April last year.Satish Meena, a senior forecast analyst at Forrester, said the report shows CCI, as a regulator, is evolving and it has started focusing more on the development in these sectors. “This will help them make their reviews clearer in future and it sends a strong message,” he said. Last year, the government made changes to FDI policy for e-tailers which forced Flipkart and Amazon to change their operating structure, which included diluting their stakes in seller entities selling on their platform. TOI reported in December how Amazon was scaling up its private brand-focused Accelerator programme and has made partial changes on search mechanism.“The findings give the CCI all evidence to pursue suo motu case against erring platforms for their anti-competitive practices,” said a spokesperson of AIOVA, a group of online sellers. Amazon India said, “Amazon welcomes the initiative by CCI to conduct a study to better understand the functioning of e-commerce in India. We are reviewing the contents of the study.” Flipkart, without commenting specifically on CCI’s observations in the report, said, “Increased adoption of a marketplaces’ efficient, transparent and accessible model will propel true growth and prosperity for India’s seller community, the retail sector and the nation.”MakeMyTrip, Zomato, Swiggy did not immediately respond to TOI’s queries.

Title: Violence in JNU on for three months, claims teachers’ faction
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

NEW DELHI: Several members of JNU Teachers ’ Federation ( JNUTF ), a breakaway body of the teachers’ association, have alleged that the January 5 violence was perpetuated by those opposing the registration process. They further alleged that violence was being seen on the campus for over three months .

Asked about the allegation that some of them were involved in the violence, JNUTF members said they were only present at the spot where there was a scuffle between students.

Addressing the media, JNUTF members stated that it was unfortunate that the movement, which started against the hiked hostel charges, had now become violent. “With the active support and instigation by JNUTA, a group of students have been radicalised,” their statement said.

Calling the agitators “militants” for seizing and blocking the school buildings during their strike, JNUTF said the January 5 violence was neither sporadic nor spontaneous. “This was the culmination of a series of episodes of threats and acts of violence,” it said.

Giving the past instances of dean of students Umesh Kadam being prevented from boarding an ambulance on October 28 to how a professor was kept hostage in a classroom, JNUTF said, “Many faculty members have been abused, heckled, attacked and chased in these violent agitations. It looks like that the campus has turned into a battleground.”

Calling for normalcy on the campus, JNUTF urged the administration to ensure that they were not harassed.

JNUTF member Ashwini Mohapatra, chairman of School of International Studies, who was accused by several students of attacking them on January 4, said, “I had gone to the SIS building on the request of some students. A struggle ensued when a section of students stopped them from opening the building entrance. I didn’t attack any student.”

Mohapatra was seen in a viral video in which where ABVP member Sharvendra was hitting AISA activist Vivek Pandey.

Title: Alumni, faculty members join rally at Indian Statistical Institute
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Students and a section of faculty members stage a protest at ISI on Wednesday

KOLKATA: Around 200 students and a section of faculty members of Indian Statistical Institute (ISI) took out a rally on campus on Wednesday in protest against the assault on the students at Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU). Clad in black, the agitating students were joined by some of the faculty members and alumni. The students staged a street play and sang Faiz’s “Hum dekhenge” and a theatre group performed a satire, titled ‘Madhusudan Dada’.

“The rally was spontaneous and was organized mainly by the students of ISI. The institute has not seen any such protest by students or teachers in a long time,” said a faculty member who participated in the rally.

“The iconic song — “Hum dekhenge” — courted controversy for no apparent reason. Students at IIT Kanpur had to face trouble after they recited the poem and it soon became an anthem for the anti-CAA protests across India,” said a research scholar.

“We organized the first rally on December 23, after the Jamia Milia Islamia incident. Many of the participants have joined in the anti-CAA, anti-NRC rallies across the city since then. But we felt the need to organize a demonstration here as well,”the research scholar added. “Though we did not shout slogans on campus, we read out the preamble of the Constitution,” he said.

Students and faculty members later created a human chain and sang the National Anthem. “The fact that we are protesting against atrocity on students does not mean that any one of us is less patriotic,” a faculty member said.

Title: Paytm drops business fees on UPI, RuPay, e-wallet
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

(File photo)

MUMBAI: Paytm has decided to make the best of the new regulations barring banks from charging merchant fees on payment services offered by National Payments Corporation of India ( NPCI ).

The country’s largest payments company has said that it will allow shops that sign up to receive payments for free from the Unified Payments Interface (UPI), RuPay cards or Paytm e-wallet . Until now, merchants had to pay a fee if their total receipts crossed Rs 50,000 in a month. While UPI and RuPay card payments can be received from any app, including that of rivals, the only catch is that the mode of payment will be through scanning a Paytm QR code.

Unlike in the past when card payments could be made only through a swipe machine, regulators have in recent years allowed card payments to be made by scanning a QR code. Paytm’s new common QR code can be used for accepting UPI payments from any bank or any RuPay card.

“We are dedicating 2020 to merchants. We will also continue investing in the payments business until 500 million Indians come into mainstream digital payments,” said Paytm founder Vijay Shekhar Sharma .

Besides doing away with merchant fees, Paytm is offering other incentives for merchants in the form of merchandise and in-app support for those who sell on credit. Also, merchants can start using the Paytm for Business app with minimum KYC and the credit proceeds to any account of their choice.

Sharma said that while the government move to do away with merchant fees was costly for the industry, it was beneficial to merchants and would help increase acceptance. “We feel that the government should reimburse the cost,” said Sharma.

He said that the company was adopting a ‘Robinhood’ approach, and large retail chains which integrate Paytm’s APIs (application programming interfaces) with their billing systems will continue to pay. At the same time, Paytm had cut some of its cost by charging customers who add more than Rs 10,000 to their digital wallet through credit cards.

According to Sharma, of the 26 billion digital transactions in India, 15 billion were payments made to merchant, of which 9 billion were those made by scanning QR codes. “Our share of the transactions at 5 billion is 54% and we have 210 million registered users in India,” said Sharma.

Title: Surat: Businessman’s alertness saved gangrape survivor from more ordeal
