Title: Delhi cops tell JNU to secure walls to prevent entry of outsiders
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The JNU administration has been asked by Delhi Police to plug the gaps in the campus boundary walls to prevent the entry of outsiders.

During a survey conducted on Tuesday evening, police found several portions of the boundary walls broken or unfenced. Sources said these sections might have been broken by miscreants, giving them direct access to the forested areas within the campus, which are usually not under surveillance by security guards.

At least two points have been identified by police near the main gate on the north side of the campus where a portion of the wall is broken. A little ahead, the grilles fixed above the perimeter wall were found missing.

A few areas in the campus, including forested zones, are connected to Sanjay Van near Kishangarh . These can be used by outsiders to enter the campus without the knowledge of the security guards. The guards have been asked to conduct regular patrols in groups to apprehend outsiders.

The security officers at JNU have been advised to tighten the entry rules and only allow people with valid identity cards to enter the campus. They have been asked to increase the security at the six entrance gates, especially the ones on Khajan Singh swimming pool side, Parthasarathy Rocks and Pashchimabad.

The university authorities have been asked to step up security outside hostels, administration block and other important locations and increase the number of securitymen to nearly double the usual. A security team would also be deployed to patrol the dark areas. The security personnel have been directed to question unknown faces in the premises.

Police have asked the security agency to stop entry of outsiders in hostels without the permission from the university authorities. JNU had deployed over 270 ex-servicemen on security duty in the campus last year. They will now be put on surveillance duty outside the campus too.

Title: Hyderabad banks in predicament over Rs 10 coins, circulation takes a hit
Content:
Representational Image

HYDERABAD: It’s a problem of plenty for banks with Rs 10 coins bursting out of currency chests. With very few takers for these coins now, banks in Hyderabad and the state have stopped placing indents with RBI for Rs 10 coins.Senior officials attribute this mainly to banks facing storage issues. The currency chests are operated under the direct control of RBI, which supplies the coins along with cash after receiving indents from various banks. “However, the circulation of Rs 10 coins is very slow in Telangana when compared to other states,” pointed out the authorities.Little wonder, banks are urging RBI to take cognisance of this problem and create more awareness among customers. Banks are also organising meetings with traders and business community to allay their fears and sensitise them that coins are a legal tender. “Banks have been displaying boards that Rs 10 coins are valid and very much in vogue,” an official explained.Highly-placed sources said major banks have been impressing upon RBI to take the matter seriousl—y and not dismiss it as a small issue. Telangana has 156 currency chests, with a majority of them (37) located in Hyderabad.The issue struck a sore note after rumours started doing the rounds that fake Rs 10 fake were in circulation in the market and that RBI had demonetised the coins. Ever since, people have stopped accepting or exchanging Rs 10 coins.“Its impact is felt more in southern states. We used to convince customers that the coins are valid and they can use them,” said Manoj Bhat, who served as a manager in Andhra Bank, Ashok Nagar.Traders and shopkeepers have also developed cold feet in exchanging or rotating these coins. Mohammed Sharif, who owns a kirana shop in Vidyanagar, said: “People refuse to accept Rs 10 coins when I give the change. Many think they are fake. Though banks accept these coins, they hesitate to accept them in large quantities.”

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Bandh hits banking services; power staff too go on strike
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Bank employees taking out rally during the trade unions’ nationwide strike at MP Nagar on Wednesday.

BHOPAL: Banking operations in the state were affected on Wednesday as around one lakh employees and officials of central trade unions including banks observed strike.

Besides, several employees of the energy sector in Madhya Pradesh too called for a strike against the draft amendments to the Electricity Act, 2003.

As many as 10 Central Trade Unions (CTUs) had called for a ‘ Bharat Bandh ’ to protest the ‘anti-people’ policies of the BJP-led NDA government at the Centre.

However, operations of State Bank of India (SBI) were not impacted as very few of its employees and officials are members of the bank employees’ unions that called for the nationwide strike. The protesting bankers and employees of rest of the PSUs took out a rally from Oriental Bank of Commerce (OBC) in MP Nagar at around 10.30am till Indira Press Complex.

Veerendra Sharma, a member of a trade union , said, “Employees of around 5,000 different branches of banks participated in the protests, and these branches do business of around Rs7 lakh crore daily. In Bhopal alone, there are a total of 500 branches of the banks whose employees participated in the protests. These branches do a business of around Rs1.4 lakh crore per day which was affected due to strike.”

Meanwhile, thousands of engineers working in the energy sector of the state went on strike on Wednesday. Though office works were affected, energy supply and maintenance mostly remained unaffected. The Madhya Pradesh Vidyut Mandal Abhiyanta Sangh, a body of engineers working in the energy department, had called the strike as per the decision of National Co-ordination Committee Of Electrical Engineers and Employees (NCCOEE), a national body of employees in the energy sector, who have raised issues over the draft amendment to the Electricity Act, 2003.

“We have given an ultimatum that if the government moves on and calls an ordinance, we would go for complete shutdown,” the Sangh’s state general secretary VKS Parihar told TOI.

Title: ‘Appoint welfare officers to check people in coma’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

NEW DELHI: Plugging a gap, Delhi high court asked the state government to appoint welfare officers in each district to check on persons lying in coma , to ensure an oversight system was in place.

The court laid down broad guidelines for such patients who were comatose and were unable to put their finances and assets in order before the tragedy.

Justice Rajiv Shakdher noted that there were no rules and regulations governing the welfare of such persons, stressing the need for guidelines to ensure that the legal guardian in charge of the comatose patient was held accountable.

It directed the department of social welfare of the AAP government to ensure that public officials/social welfare officer or officers of equivalent rank visit patients lying in comatose state and submit a detailed report.

The court said only the spouse or children could be appointed the legal guardian of a person in coma and they must disclose the details of all tangible and intangible assets of the patient. In case the patient had no legal heirs or was abandoned by the family, his next friend could be appointed as a guardian with the prior permission from a court.

HC’s directions came while interpreting various laws — the Guardians and Wards Act, 1890, the Mental Health Act, 1987 (repealed), the National Trust Act for the Welfare of Persons with Autism, Cerebral Palsy, Mental Retardation, the Multiple Disabilities Act, 1999, the Persons with Disabilities (Equal Opportunities, Protection of Rights and Full Participation) Act, the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017 and the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016. Justice Shakdher said the definitions of these provisions showed a person in coma was not covered under any of the Acts which was why the court needed to step.

The guidelines also include that the sub-divisional magistrate (SDM) or tehsildar concerned, under whose jurisdiction the person lying in coma was located, should conduct an inquiry to establish the veracity of the assertion and to gather details of the person who wished to be appointed as a guardian.

HC said the person appointed as a guardian would file a report with the registrar of the high court after every six months and if the guardian misused his power, siphoned or misutilised the assets of the patient, the court would have the power to remove him and appoint another person.

HC’s order came on a plea filed by daughters of a comatose woman after the State Bank of India refused to release money deposited in a PPF account of their dead father. SBI took the stand that a guardianship certificate had to be obtained from the district court concerned but HC disagreed, and allowed the plea of the daughters. It asked SBI to transfer the amount to the joint account of the two women with their mother, after HC verified from doctors that the mother was comatose and needed expensive treatment.

Title: Jagan asks cabinet to pull up socks for win in local body elections
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Vijayawada: Chief minister Y S Jagan Mohan Reddy on Wednesday asked his cabinet colleagues to pull their socks up for the local body elections scheduled for the next two months. The high court had earlier directed the State to complete the local body polls — both municipal and panchayat — by March 2020.

The chief minister told the 13 ministers incharge for the state’s districts to leave no stone unturned in preparation for the elections. As this is the first election that his government faces after its massive victory in the 2019 general elections, the polls will be a litmus test to see if YSRC will be able to keep its vote base intact after seven months in power.

Also discussed during the meeting was agitations in parts of the state on the three capitals proposal of the government. The chief minister listened to the views of his cabinet colleagues on the matter and suggested ways to counter complications.

Some of the ministers, it is learned, expressed apprehension over public resentment due to the sand issue. However, the chief minister asked them to prepare the party rank and file at the grassroots level to counter allegations and explain real issues. The chief minister had told them to popularise government welfare programmes and initiatives giving due representation to weaker sections and women. He wanted them to talk more about the schemes that were rolled out in the last six months to cross sections of the people, besides Acts like Disha.

The chief minister had also asked them to explain the three capitals concept to people to counter the TDP’s “campaign against the government”. He directed the ministers to distribute copies of expert committee reports to party leaders at the grassroots level to counter criticism.

The YSRC had won the people’s mandate in the Assembly polls in a massive sweep, leaving the TDP to nurse wounds. Several TDP leaders in the aftermath of the polls had defected to the YSRC.

Title: VMC data reveals decrease in Vadodara’s infant mortality in 2019
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: While the deaths of children at various state-run hospitals across Gujarat have raked up a major controversy, data available with the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) indicates that the infant mortality reported in the city has gone down marginally.

VMC health department officials have been on their toes digging up data and preparing reports ever since the controversy came to light. Data collected for the years 2019 and 2018 reveals that the number had gone down by 152.

According to VMC sources, 1,338 infants had died in hospitals in the city in 2018. Against this, 1,186 infants died in hospitals in the city in 2019. Officials said that the data was more reliable as it included all the hospitals in the city.

Monthly data of infant deaths provided by officials for the two years also indicates that in 2019, there were only four months where the number of infant deaths was higher as compared to 2018. In the remaining eight months the figures had gone down ensuring that the total number of deaths of infants in 2019 remained lower as compared to 2018.

An official in the health department even defended the government hospitals saying that the numbers there often seemed higher as very critical cases were often sent there by private hospitals.

“If the parents cannot afford treatment or if there is little chance of the infant surviving, the infants are referred to government hospitals where deaths take place,” said the official.

Sources added that some infants died at government hospitals after births as they were often born to mothers from poor families who may not have got necessary care and nutrition during pregnancy. “Proper care during pregnancy under various initiatives can ensure this does not happen,” said an official.

Title: Coimbatore: Private finance firm owner held for duping investors
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The city police on Wednesday arrested a 40-year-old native of Kerala after he allegedly cheated people by promising to return triple the amount of their investments within 150 days.

The accused has been identified as T Bony Thomas, of Ernakulam.

“About three months ago, he started a private finance company at Alamu Nagar in the city. He publicized that the firm would provide 2% interest per day on investment and would return triple the investment amount within 150 days. Believing this, several people deposited lakhs of rupees in the company,” a police officer said.

About 20 days ago, Thomas closed the company and went into hiding. Initially, the victims waited for him to open the company. As the days passed without any progress, they lodged a police complaint.

Pointing out that the complainants had deposited about Rs15 lakh each, the officer said the company had returned them a few lakhs by way of daily interests. According to the officer, while five people had come forward to lodge a complaint, the actual number of people who had invested in company was yet to be identified. Thomas was arrested on Wednesday and produced before a judicial magistrate who remanded him to judicial custody.

Title: Kerala: Over 26,000 CRZ violations identified in 10 coastal districts
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Aerial view of the Jain Coral Cove flat complex (File photo)

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: As Kerala is set to witness the demolition of apartments built in violation of CRZ norms at Maradu , the government will have to deal with over 26 ,000 CRZ violations across 10 coastal districts. Coastal district committees (CDC), constituted by the government following the directive of Supreme court, has identified 26,259 CRZ violations, stated the interim reports furnished by respective CDCs.

The final report will be compiled and submitted by 10 CDCs before January 12. Though officials say that number could reduce further following site inspection and document verification, there would still be a sizable number of violations which will have to be dealt with by the government.

In September 2019, the Supreme Court had directed the chief secretary to prepare a list of CRZ violations and government constituted CDCs in Kasaragod, Kannur, Malappuram, Kozhikode, Thrissur, Ernakulam , Kottayam, Alappuzha, Kollam and Thiruvananthapuram .

CDCs submitted three interim reports between October and December 2018. As per the third interim report, Kollam topped the list with 4,868 violations, followed by Alappuzha (4,536) and Ernakulam (4,239). Kottayam recorded the least at 147. Over 3,000 violations were detected in the capital and Kozhikode. The list of Ernakulam identifies two CRZ violations in the third interim report in Kochi corporation. Both are residential flats with built-up area greater than 7,500 sq m.

The report said that a pilot survey on highrises in Maradu municipality and Kochi corporation was carried out by the town and country planning department. The survey identified 41 buildings in Maradu municipality and 93 buildings in Kochi corporation’s limits. This exercise was done by overlaying Coastal Zone Management Plan (2011) over the current Google images and verifying (on site) through departmental surveyors.

These identified highrises in CRZ areas of the municipality and corporation will be further verified with relevant documents to find the actual CRZ Violations among them. A special cell and advisory committee on CRZ has been constituted for the district under the chairmanship of the subcollector (Fort Kochi) to give notice to the constructions for submitting details regarding the approvals obtained for their construction.

In Kozhikode corporation area, 1,615 violations have been identified, one of the highest violations in corporations. Officials said that the government cannot take a call on regularization. The norms mandate that decision has to be taken by KCZMA for which the authority can forward a recommendation to the ministry of environment and forests.

Kottayam CDC reported that one of the limitations in identifying violations was the absence of a KCZMA expert in the committee. Other CDCs have also reported the inability to report on the latitude and longitude within a short time period. Categorization of violations based on floor area will be the key since even if exemption can be granted in case of residential constructions, there must be a limit which can be set based on floor area, an official said.

Title: T man impersonates IPS officer for VIP darshan tickets, nabbed
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Tirumala police arrested a government official from Telangana for posing as an IPS officer to obtain the most sought after VIP darshan ticket at Tirumala on Wednesday.

According to DSP T Prabhakar Babu, Shyamala Arun Kumar Pandu (45), who said he works as the deputy director of weaver’s service centre at Hyderabad, presented a fake identity card in which his designation was printed as officer on special duty at the agriculture, marketing and warehousing department, Andhra Pradesh secretariat, and tried to obtain VIP break darshan tickets from the additional executive officer’s camp office at Tirumala.

Upon verification by TTD staff, it was confirmed that the identity card was a fake one. Following a complaint lodged by the TTD, Tirumala police took Arun Kumar into custody. What startled the police was that Arun Kumar who works as deputy director as per protocol can apply for VIP break darshan using his own credentials, but instead chose to pose as an IPS officer.

DSP Prabhakar Rao said, ‘‘Our investigation revealed that Arun Kumar aspired to become an IPS officer. But since that could not happen, he got into the habit of impersonating IPS officers and enjoyed the attention.”

Title: Coimbatore: Three arrested for releasing obscene video on social media
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A day after a video of women staff of a petrol bunk changing dress in a room at their workplace at Kannappan Nagar in in Saibaba Colony went viral, the city police on Wednesday arrested three people for circulating the same on social platforms.

The Saibaba Colony police identified the arrested as Manikandan and Subash, both employees of the petrol bunk, and Maruthachalam, a vernacular journalist.

Subash had hidden a mobile phone in the dressing room of women staff of the petrol bunk and captured the images of them changing dress using its camera about four months ago. Manikandan’s wife came across the mobile phone and alerted her husband, who reportedly deleted the video and smashed the phone, a police officer said.

Police, however, didn’t register a case as none of the victims came forward to lodge a complaint. Meanwhile, the video surfaced on social media on Tuesday and went viral. Following this, two of the victims lodged a complaint with the Saibaba Colony police on Wednesday.

Based on the complaint, police registered a case under Section 354(C) of Indian Penal Code; Sections 66(E), 67 (A) of the Information Technology Act, 2004; Section 4 of the Tamil Nadu Prohibition of Harassment of Women Act, 2002; and Sections 3, 4 and 6 of the Indecent Representation of Women Act, 1986.

The officer said Subash had retrieved the video from the mobile phone and shared it with Manikandan, who forwarded the same to Maruthachalam. “It was Maruthachalam who circulated the video on social media.”

In a related development, the Saravanmapatty police have lodged a case against three employees of the petrol bunk – Shankarganesh, Kavidhasan and Saravanan – for assaulting Manikandan, who is undergoing treatment at the Coimbatore Medical College Hospital. The trio assaulted him following allegations that he stole petrol from the bunk, the officer said.

Title: Coimbatore: Kerala man held in Valparai for hacking girl to death
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The district police have nabbed a 26-year-old man from Kerala for murdering a Class XII girl student, with whom he was in a relationship, and dumping her body near Varattuparai in Valparai on the outskirts of the city on Tuesday after she started to avoid him. He was handed over to the Kerala police on Wednesday.

The Valparai police identified the arrested as S Sabharsha, a resident of Ernakulam in Kerala. He was employed with a car showroom at his hometown.

A police officer said Sabharsha had picked up the girl, also from Ernakulam, from her school around 2pm on Tuesday in a car that he had taken from the showroom without informing his senior officials.

As the girl did not return home even by the late evening, her parents lodged a complaint with the assistant police commissioner in Ernakulam. Based on the complaint, police launched an inquiry and found that the girl was last seen with Sabharsha. The Kerala police subsequently traced his whereabouts to Valparai by tracking his mobile phone tower details and alerted their counterparts in the district.

The Valparai police immediately sprang into action and alerted all the police stations in its limits to start vehicle check. They nabbed Sabharsha near Kadamparai check post around 7.30 pm on Tuesday.

“There was a pool of blood in the car and he was taken into custody. During the inquiry, he said he was in a relationship with the girl. About a couple of months ago, she told him her plans to pursue higher education in abroad and started to avoid him,” the officer said.

A provoked Sabharsha then hatched a plan to murder her. “On Tuesday, he brought her to Valparai and stabbed her in her neck and chest with a knife that was hidden in the car. After murdering her, he threw the body in a forest near Varattuparai,” the official said.

Pointing out that Sabharsha had forgotten the exact the location where he had dumped the body, the official said it took them almost three hours to recover the body. “We retrieved the body by 1am on Wednesday. Both the body and the accused were then handed over to the Kerala police.”

The combing operation was led by Valparai inspector of police Balamurugan. The team comprised SI Prabhakaran, special branch head constable Navaneetha Krishnan, SB-CID Yesian and other police officials.

Title: Dehradun reels under sanitation woes as rain lash city
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Continuous rainfall led to waterlogging in many areas of Dehradun

DEHRADUN/MUSSOORIE: Light to moderate rains continued to lash most parts of Uttarakhand, including Dehradun , for the second consecutive day on Wednesday. Besides, heavy snowfall was also witnessed in neighbouringhill stations of Mussoorie and Dhanaulti. The continuous rains that had been lashing the state capital since the past 48 hours threw life out of gear with most people preferring to stay indoors and offices reporting low attendance.

The rains also left drains in many areas clogged and garbage overflowing resulting in sanitation woes in many areas such as Selaqui and Premnagar. According to officials of meteorological department, Dehradun witnessed 6.9 mm rains on Wednesday while 19.2 mm rains had lashed the state capital on Tuesday. Waterlogging was also reported from many areas in the city.

Umesh Karanwal, a resident of Raipur, said, “Be it monsoons or winters, Dehradun roads always look like ponds. In Raipur, potholes have broadened in the past two days and authorities don’t seem to care.”

In a similar vein, Minakshi Singh of Dilaram Bazaar area said, “In our locality, rainwater has completely drenched overflowing dustbins leading to an unbearable stench.”

The winter rainfall also affected the public transport system of the city. Commuters were left stranded at several places as tempos and auto rickshaws struggled to move.Many commuters could be seen wading through water and braving the cold to reach their destinations.

Meanwhile, after two days of continuous rainfall, Mussoorie on Wednesday witnessed yet another spell of snowfall. Although it had started snowing in the morning, the Mall Road area witnessed little accumulation of snow on the ground due to intermittent rain .

However, heavy snowfall resumed around 5 pm and the Mall Road area was soon draped in a thick blanket of white with vehicles, buildings and other structures getting covered with snow.

Saurabh Singh, a tourist from Delhi said, “The snowfall that I have seen here is just amazing. It is very cold but still we don’t want to go inside our hotel room and keep revelling in this natural wonder.”

Meanwhile, due to slippery roads, vehicles got stuck at various parts of the town and Kulri. Vehicular movement was affected between Gandhi Chowk and Zero Point in the morning hours and JCB had to be deployed to clear the road. Similarly, traffic was affected at Mullingar and Lal Tibba area. Around one-ft snow cover was reported from Dhanaulti .

Vidhya Bhushan Negi, station officer of Mussoorie, said that they were stopping vehicles from going towards Suwakholi and Dhanaulti. Tourist vehicles were also stopped at Kothal Gate (near Dehradun) due to safety reasons, said sub-divisional magistrate Varun Choudhary. Many residents complained that vehicles of police and fire department were ill-equipped to drive through the snow. “We don’t know what would happen in case of an emergency,” lamented a resident.

Meanwhile, a video of tourists stuck at Dhanaulti also went viral on Wednesday. in which the tourists could be seen asking for help and claiming to have been stuck at Dhanaulti since Saturday with little cash and no additional clothes. They alleged that police and administration are not making efforts to rescue them.

Title: Nagpur: Conduct DNA tests, expel upper castes call at CAA-NRC protest
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Speakers from different communities called for making the DNA test demand known to the country through social ... Read More

Nagpur: In yet another rally in the series of protests against CAA and NRC, over 10,000 took out a march that began from Shivaji statue, in the backyard of RSS headquarters at Mahal, on Wednesday. These protests took on a distinct anti-upper caste tinge as participants demanded implementation of CAA, NRC and NPR on the basis of DNA tests “that would render the upper caste stateless” based on the notion that upper castes being descendants of Aryans were the real outsiders.

A mass pledge was administered to the participants asking not to let the Modi government implement CAA and NRC unless it agrees to conduct the DNA test.

Speakers belonging to different communities called for making the DNA test demand known to the country through social media. “I request my young brothers and sisters who are experts users of WhatsApp, Insta, Twitter, Facebook etc to make this demand on the virtual world,” said a speaker.

Slogans such as ‘Sabse Bada Atankwad Brahamanwad’ (Brahminism is biggest terrorism), an oblique reference to RSS and other Hindutva organizations, were also raised.

Organized by BAMCEF, an Ambedkarite organization, the protesters were predominantly Muslims and also a motley group of Dalit and other sects.

A few hands were also seen holding saffron banners with the picture of Maratha king Chhatrapati Shivaji, apart from tricolors. “We are from the Sena,” said a protester quickly as a member of the organizing team clarified that it is Chatrapati Shivaji Sena, an NGO, and not Shiv Sena. Jai Shivaji, Jai Bhim, chanted the protesters as they raised the regular slogans coined during CAA and NRC protests.

Billed to be a non-political rally, workers from Congress and other left organization were also seen, who said they had voluntarily joined. “A report said all the upper caste in the country are outsiders and they have Jewish DNA,” said a speaker. “We are the original inhabitants of the country,” he said. “We just responded to messages we got through social media. The protesters are from different sects. I am from Congress but there are others too,” said Nash Ali, a Congress worker.

Starting from Mahal, the rally passed through lanes of Mominpura and turned toward Dalit-dominated Kadbi Chowk before reaching Samvidhan Chowk.

Several protesters were seen making live videos and sharing photographs from the spot on social media. The move aimed to target the BJP’s IT cell which they accused of spreading ‘lies’ about the peaceful protest taking place across the country.

The rally Bahujan Kranti Morcha was part of similar protests in 550 districts throughout the country. Protesters were also seen holding creative posters ridiculing the NRC, CAA and the Modi-Shah duo. They also said core issues of petrol price hike, onion prices, lack of jobs, GDP, and country’s economy should be addressed.

The BJP’s call for removing ‘illegal migrants’, which protesters said was an indirect reference to Muslims, was countered by the slogan for cleansing the country of ‘Videshi Brahmans’. A Muslim speaker said the community had been quietly tolerating oppression by government over years. “Everyone is now a victim of their (BJP) oppression. They have to be unseated to stop this injustice,” he said.

Title: Uma Bharti defends Kailash Vijayvargiya, says party workers will court arrest
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Uma Bharti

BHOPAL: BJP leader Uma Bharti on Wednesday came out in support of BJP general secretary Kailash Vijayvargiya , and said party workers will court arrest and go to jail if he is arrested.

Condemning the Congress government for “filing cases” against Vijayvargiya and his supporters, Bharti tweeted: “Kailash ji has raised his voice against injustice. His statement is the sentiment of BJP workers. Police have registered FIRs against him and several other workers. The government has said Kailash ji could be arrested and sent to jail. If this happens, BJP workers will also court arrest.”

In Sehore, former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan joined a protest rally against what he called “high-handedness by the Congress government”. “Fake cases are being registered against BJP workers while police have been patronising crime, illegal mining and gambling in the region,” he alleged.

Attacking the state government, he said, “No public service, but an extortion drive is being conducted in Sehore district . A corrupt minister is trying to cause trouble for the people of my region. Shivraj will die but not let this happen.”

BJP state president Rakesh Singh also warned of an agitation against cases registered on saffron workers. “Efforts are being made to harass and suppress BJP workers through fake cases. If you put an evil eye on BJP workers, the entire BJP family will come out on roads to fight the cause. In Ashoknagar, a fake case under Section 376 IPC was registered against BJP district media in-charge Devendra Tamrakar. BJP will meet DGP to apprise him of the facts,” Singh said.

Title: Delhi: CM Arvind Kejriwal, Manoj Tiwari spar on Twitter over BJP’s power subsidy offer
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: A twitter war broke out between AAP and BJP on Wednesday when CM Arvind Kejriwal questioned the validity of the saffron party’s announcement that if elected to power it will give “five times” the subsidy given by his government.

“Five times more subsidy than us? Meaning? Will you give 1000 units of electricity free instead of 200 units? Instead of 20 thousand litres, one lakh litres of water will be given free? You are making fun of the public by making such promises. Start these schemes in any one of the BJP-ruled states before promising in Delhi (sic),” chief minister Arvind Kejriwal tweeted.

Replying to Kejriwal’s tweet, Tiwari asked Kejriwal the total amount AAP government spent on these facilities per family in the last five years .

“Whatever claims Kejriwal makes of having given benefits during the last five years, BJP will do at least five times more work for the people of Delhi. This will be done with the formation of government in February. The AAP leader should tell the people of Delhi how much benefits he has given to each family during the last five years,” Tiwari said.

“The chief minister is talking about those things which he has started doing in last three months of his government. Under the leadership of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, the BJP government will work for a prosperous Delhi with positivity,” he added.

Tiwari had earlier told TOI that his government would give five times the benefits currently being given by AAP government.

Title: MSU inks MoUs with 7 international universities
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

MSU’s Faculty of Science signed the 2 MoU’s on Wednesday

VADODARA: In an effort to increase its global visibility, MS University (MSU) on Wednesday signed MoUs with seven international universities for strengthening academic and research collaborations.

The MSU’s Faculty of Science has signed two MoUs with US-based University of South Florida, Tampa, and Finland-based Arbonaut Oy Limited.

Similarly, MoUs have been inked between MSU’s Faculty of Technology and Engineering with US-based St Cloud State University, Minnesota, Instituto Superior Technico, Lisbon, Portugal and Liuzhov Vocational and Technical College, China.

Spain-based Universidade De Vigo has inked MoU with MSU’s Faculty of Education and Psychology while France-based The Ecole Nationale Superieure Des Beaux- Arts has inked MoU with the MSU’s Faculty of Fine Arts.

The MSU’s Office of International Affairs (OIA) represented by director professor Dhanesh Patel and deputy director professor Vanisha Nambiar along with coordinators Dr Ranjit Devkar and Ruturaj Gaekwad facilitated the MoUs.

The MoUs were signed by MSU vice-chancellor professor Parimal Vyas and officer on special duty (registrar) Dr K M Chudasama in the presence of all deans and head of departments.

As part of MoU between The University of Hyogo, Japan and faculties of commerce, arts and management studies, an 18-member Japanese delegation including four professors and dean of School of Economics and Management is currently on a visit at the MSU campus.

The visit of the Japanese delegation which started on Tuesday is both academic as well for a cultural exchange. On Wednesday, the Japanese students conducted one day Japanese language workshop in association with the Department of Commerce and Business Management at Faculty of Commerce for around 50 staff members and the students of the MSU.

Title: 3 killed by truck in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Three persons died on the spot and one suffered severe injuries

AHMEDABAD: A speeding truck late on Tuesday night hit two scooter-borne men and two persons sleeping in a hut in Khokhra. Three persons died on the spot and one suffered severe injuries.

According to the FIR filed at I division traffic police, the accident took place near Anupam Cinema.

The deceased have been identified as Tara Sankania, 55, a resident of Bucheshwar Mahadev chawl, Dipak Khatik, 21, resident of Rajpur Slum Quarters and Kamlesh Khatik, 26, a resident of Patrawadi chawl in Sukhramnagar.

The injured person shifted to LG Hospital was identified as Rakesh Sankania, Tara’s son.

Kamlesh was riding his scooter and Dipak was riding pillion when the truck hit them. Tara and Rakesh were sleeping near a temple when the truck ran over them.

Gomtipur councillor Iqbal Shaikh said that the truck driver was probably drunk and had also hit three other scooters. Shaikh wrote to city police commissioner, Ashish Bhatia and AMC commissioner, Vijay Nehra to make a circle in front of Anupam Cinema as the area has become accident prone. “A year ago, a 30-year-old man, a teacher in a government school, had died at the same place when a speeding truck hit him,” he said.

Title: RSS is fascist, based on Hitler ideology, says Digvijaya Singh
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Digvijaya Singh

BHOPAL: Senior Congress leader Digvijaya Singh on Wednesday launched a fresh assault on RSS, calling it a “fascist organization” based on the ideologies of Hitler and Mussolini. He said the word ‘Hindutva’ doesn’t exist in the scriptures, and RSS “cannot be accepted as an organisation of Hindus”.

Addressing the training camp of Congress’ grassroots organization Seva Dal here on Wednesday afternoon, Digvijaya alleged that the Saraswati Sishu Mandir schools run by RSS educational wing Vidya Bharati “teach hatred to children, which gives birth to violence”.

Referring to the recent controversy over a book on Veer Savarkar distributed at the camp, the former CM said: “Veer Savarkar had two major phases in his life. One, when he fought against the British Raj and was sent to the Andaman prison. Second, when he apologized and returned. It is the second phase that we do not support after which he misled and polluted the politics of the nation.”

Singh argued, “Hindutva is not mentioned in the scriptures and has no relation with religion. We cannot accept RSS as an organization of Hindus. It is a fascist organization in which is imbibed in the ideologies of Hitler and Mussolini. This is in contrast to the culture of India. Unity in diversity is the strength of our nation.”

“The minds of RSS leaders and activists are constricted, only dividing and breaking society. But Congress unifies. The concept of Vasudeva Kutumbakam is the idea that identifies India,” he said.

Congress is weak in ideological politics, he remarked. “WhatsApp University is poisoning the minds of our children. Saraswati Sishu Mandirs are schools where hatred is taught, which gives birth to violence. And violence gives birth to terrorism,” he said, adding that the country is going through “critical times”.

Targeting the BJP-led Centre, Digvijaya said, “Violence generates violence. Non-violence spreads love and communal harmony. No country can prosper and develop with violence and hatred. Disturbance and violence breaks even families. Today, what is happening is only to divide the nation. Be it Article 370 or the Citizenship Amendment Act, they have all been passed to polarize the country into Hindu versus Muslim. They have no other agenda.”

Reacting to Digvijaya’s allegations, state BJP spokesman Rajneesh Agarwal said, “Vidya Bharati imparts education through Saraswati Sishu Mandirs in remote tribal and inaccessible areas. By saying that these schools teach hatred and violence, Digvijaya Singh is insulting the students of these schools and their parents. He was chief minister for 10 years and should have set up schools in such areas, which he didn’t. His intention is to incite feelings of minorities.”

RSS was founded by Dr Hegdewar in 1925 and many Congress leaders, including former President Pranab Mukherjee, have praised and recognised its contribution, Agarwal said. “At least, Digvijaya should learn to respect his party’s leaders. The Supreme Court had defined Hindutva as our nation’s way of life. Whose decision is more authentic? Digvijaya Singh’s or Supreme Court’s? Obviously, not Digvijaya’s,” he remarked.

Title: Residents stumble on Cuttack’s dug-up streets
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

CUTTACK: Residents’ organisations here have expressed concern at the alleged poor quality of restoration of roads that have been dug up for the laying of underground sewer lines. Convener of Mahanagar Nagarika Mancha, a residents’ organisation, said, “Re-establishment of the roads is being done in a hurried manner. They are not being strengthened adequately.”

“The stretches that have been renovated after completion of sewer line work over the past two years are riddled with potholes. They leave a lot to be desired,” said Pravat Ranjan Dash, a social activist and lawyer. Several residents also alleged that a few of the roads dug up for the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA)-funded integrated sanitation project had caved in as the restoration was shabby.

JICA project-in-charge Basanta Kumar Parida told TOI on Tuesday that residents had no cause of worry as the road restoration was being done following the ‘compaction process’.

“The foundation of the roads in most parts of the city is quite old. Before compaction, the roads are being restored temporarily through sand filling. The process of compaction takes nearly a month to two months,” Parida explained.

The JICA project envisages a sewage system with an underground gravity sewer line of length 352km. So far, 292km of sewer lines have been completed through digging, requiring restoration of an equal length of roads. Parida explained that previously only those stretches of the roads that had been dug up were restored. Consequently, the other stretches of the roads had deteriorated. “Now, we are trying to overcome the problem by renovating all portions of the roads that are being dug up,” said the project in-charge.

In October, the Odisha Human Rights Commission (OHRC) had taken note of the problems being faced by the people of the city because of the excavated roads.

The court had said the project was seriously affecting traffic and blamed it on the lack of coordination between different departments of the government and the project officials.

The OHRC had sought the formation of a four-member committee headed by the commissioner of the Cuttack Municipal Corporation (CMC) ‘to monitor smooth working of the JICA project’. The committee has as representative the DCP Cuttack, ACP (traffic), Cuttack, and the planning member of the Cuttack Development Authority .

Title: 17 apprehended for murder of gangster
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Tirupati urban police on Wednesday arrested a gang of 17 in connection with a murder in the temple city on December 21. Rowdysheeter Pasupuleti Murali, who was an accused in a murder case, was hacked to death by rivals near Korlagunta in Tirupati.

Tirupati East Division police registered a case and arrested 10 accused from Tirupati. Seven other accused were picked up from Renigunta on Wednesday.

Some of the murder accused have been identified as G Gajendra, Narasimhulu, Mallikarjuna, Arun Kumar, K Hari Krishna, K Arun, K Giri Babu, G Sathya Srinivasulu, Raghavan Dinesh, M Manikantan, S Mahesh, N Mahabub Basha and Naga Vijaya Kumar.

Police said a friend of the 17-member gang, S Bhargav, was allegedly killed by Pasupuleti Murali and his associates earlier. The gang kept a watch on Murali and attacked him using iron rods and knives on December 21. The accused left the spot only after confirming Murali was dead.

Title: Bamu’s ex-mgmt council member booked
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Aurangabad: Begumpura police on Tuesday booked Shankar Ambhore, a research guide and former management council member of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University (Bamu), for alleged obstruction of work and threating university’s deputy registrar Digambar Netke.

Ambhore, however, denied the charges and said he had gone to request the deputy registrar to call a subject expert in commerce for the interview of PhD students. He also alleged that Netke took this opportunity to settle score with him as the former had once chaired a committee, inquiring Netke’s involvement in scams.

According to police, Netke has lodged a complaint saying that Ambhore forcefully entered into his office asking why the latter was not following the directions on appointing referees for the PhD interviews.

“Netke told Ambhore that experts were being appointed according to norms. To which Ambhore got upset and started abusing the deputy registrar,” a police officer said.

“This led to an altercation between the two following which Ambhore threatened Netke. The suspect was accompanied by another 34-year-old man. We have booked Ambhore and the other suspect under sections 353, 504 , 506 and 34 of the Indian Penal Code,” he added.

Ambhore termed the allegations as baseless and said everything would be clear if the closed-circuit television (CCTV) camera footage is checked. “Netke and his supporters have got an opportunity to malign my image as I was to appear in the interview for university registrar’s post. While chairing a committee appointed to inquire into the allegations of corrupt practices, I had recommended action against Netke. The complaint has been made with a prejudiced mind,” he said.

Title: Barring SBI, trade unions’ strike hits banking services
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kanpur: The banking services in all the banks, barring the State Bank of India, were majorly hit though the business in the Industrial City was usual following the nation-wide strike called by various trade unions protesting the 'anti-people' policies of the Central government.

To recall, ten central trade unions--INTUC, AITUC, HMS, CITU, AIUTUC, TUCC, SEWA, AICCTU, LPF, UTUC along with other independent federations and associations, had adopted a declaration in September last to go on a nation-wide strike on January 8.

Most of the markets and commercial establishments in the city were open and the transport services also remained unaffected.

Arvind Raj Swaroop of All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC) terming the 'Bharat Bandh' great success in the city, said that it passed off peacefully with maximum participation of members of various trade unions.

The representatives of various trade unions held sit-ins at various government and non-governmental establishments across the city, he added.

The production in most of the factories in Dadanagar and Panki industrial area was hit with minimal presence of workers. No untoward incident, however, was reported so far from any part of the city. A large deployment of police personnel had been made at major junctions in the city.

Almost all the branches of the SBI were functional as its employees had limited participation in the strike.

Title: Farmer in Erode rescues injured Australian native bird Ibis
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Villagers flocked to the veterinary hospital in Modakurichi to see the bird before it was handed over to the V... Read More

ERODE: A black headed Ibis, believed to have originated from Australia, was found running around Kattupalayam, a small village in Erode district on Tuesday.

Villagers flocked to the veterinary hospital in Modakurichi to see the bird before it was handed over to the Vellode bird sanctuary.

As part of its annual route, the bird might have migrated to India but lost its way and was unable to fly back home due to sustained back injury.

On Tuesday evening, a farmer in kattupalayam heard the anguished cries of a bird only to see dogs chasing an injured bird.

The farmer immediately carried the bird in his arms and took it to veterinary hospital in Modakurichi.

“We gave the bird initial treatment for its injuries, likely caused by the chasing dogs.”

“The bird was handed over to the Vellode bird sanctuary on Wednesday evening, where it will heal fully and fly back to its country,” said an official.

Title: Entrepreneur with disability lights a lamp for others
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Twenty-five-years ago when Chumki Datta, an advertising professional from Kolkata, made Bhubaneswar her home little did she know that life would throw up challenges she least expected. She not only stood strong and weathered the storms in her life but has now extended a helping hand to the intellectually disabled, putting them on the path of economic empowerment.

“An accident in 2003 paralysed me from the waist down. I have been wheelchair-bound since. Within six to seven years of the incident, my husband, who was my caregiver passed away. Fate dealt a body blow to me but I did not give up on my dreams,” said Chumki, who has now stepped into her 50s.

Her dreams led to the birth of Vriddhi training-cum-production centre, an SHG, in December 2017. Operating from the National Career Service Centre for Differently abled under ministry of labour and emploment, Vriddhi trains people with disability, particularly those with intellectual disability, in making soaps and handmade paper bags. She was handed over the responsibility by the government that was looking for a business organisation for the disabled as she was already working for them. The government provided the space and equipment required for the unit.

At present, the organisation makes seven varieties of natural handmade soaps —honey oats, honey haldi, besan haldi, petals, chandan haldi, aloe vera and neem. Priced between Rs 60 and Rs 85, the soaps come in the shape of regular soap bars or in the shape of roses and sold in the market.

These soaps are made by 12 to 13 intellectually disabled young adults, aged 18- 25, and supervised by six to seven parents and an orthopaedically-handicapped person.

“These children are very receptive to instructions,” said Sanjukta Patnaik, 64, whose 34-year-old son is involved in soap making. The young adults are also happy coming out of the confines of their homes and working with their friends. “The profits are distributed among the young adult workers. The economic empowerment has boosted their confidence,” said Patnaik.

Vriddhi has also forayed into making incense sticks, scented candles, notebooks of handmade paper and “badis” of two different flavours. Before Vriddhi came into being, Datta worked as an entrepreneur in city beautification and doing up the interiors of the Tribal World showroom. She has won a national award for being a successful self-employed person with locomotor disability in 2017 and Anjali award in 2019.

Title: Madras High Court asks police to produce ‘abducted’ DMK councillor
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Madras high court

MADURAI: Madras high court has directed police officials to produce before the court on Thursday the DMK councillor of ward 8 in Mudukulathur panchayat union who was allegedly abducted. The order was given on a habeas corpus petition filed by the councillor’s son S Raja, a resident of Ramanathapuram district.

He said his father Sathaiah had contested the recent local body election on December 30 for the councillor’s post as a DMK candidate and won. After the results on Januray 2, his father returned to his house at Vaithiyanenthal. The next day, he went out around 5 am after informing his mother that he was going to meet some friends. However, he did not return and when his mother contacted him over phone, he informed her that he had been abducted and detained by four people.

Raja said when he came to know about the incident, he immediately informed the inspector of Mudukulathur police station and sought steps to rescue his father. However, there was no response. He further stated that his father was brought by the people to the block development office for the swearing-in ceremony on January 6 but was taken away after that. He said that four “highly influential” people had detained his father to prevent him from voting to elect the chairman of Mudukulathur panchayat union on January 11.

Though he and members of DMK lodged a complaint at the police station, the officials merely registered a community service register, which prompted him to the habeas corpus petition. When the petition was heard on Wednesday, a division bench of Justice T Raja and Justice B Pugalendhi directed the police officials to produce the petitioner’s father before the court on January 9 failing which the Ramanathapuram superintendent of police should appear before the court to explain about the status of the case.

Title: Piplantri showcases how to save girls and love trees too
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Shyam Sundar Paliwal, former sarpanch of Piplantri addressing students at Parul University

VADODARA: If more villages take a leaf out of this Rajasthan hamlet, rural India will not only make their surroundings green but also help their ‘betis’ live and prosper.

Narrating the story of how he changed a personal tragedy into a common good for his village of Piplantri in Rajasthan’s Rajsamand district , social activist and former sarpanch , Shyam Sundar Paliwal, said that it’s the people’s will that ushers in the change.

Paliwal had lost his daughter Kiran in 2007. He turned his grief into an opportunity to save girl child in his village. He started the ‘Kiran Nidhi Yojana’ — a scheme that starts with the birth of a girl child.

Whenever a girl is born in this village, 111 trees are planted. A fixed deposit of Rs 31,000 is also made with the family contributing Rs 10,000 and the rest by the NGO, the panchayat and other villagers.

On every Raksha Bandhan , a thread is tied to the saplings and nurtured, and are treated like they are part of the family, and the tribe of family trees in the region is only growing.

“We had started the initiative to ensure that the girl’s family has enough money to ensure that she can pursue higher education and also save for her wedding,” said Paliwal, who was in the city on Wednesday to interact with students and staff of Faculty of Social Work of city-based Parul University (PU).

Paliwal also interacted with sarpanches of villages in and around Vadodara under PUTalks inspiring them to take steps that can ensure holistic development of their villages.

Paliwal’s efforts have helped Piplantri turn into a model self-sustainable village where women self-help groups have planted aloe vera, bamboo and rose plants among others which are used to manufacture products that generate employment at the local level.

The village with a population of 5,500 residents has ensured employment generation for nearly 1,200 residents and thus arresting migration towards bigger cities.

Title: HC dismisses plea for more time to submit CCTV footage
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Madurai: Madras high court has dismissed a petition filed by the state election commission seeking extension of time to submit the CCTV footage of counting centres in districts falling under the jurisdiction of the court.

It was at the vacation sitting of the HC Madurai bench recently that some advocates made a mention before a division bench to direct the state election commission to videograph the counting of ballot sheets in the counting centres. Taking suo-motu cognizance, the court directed the commission to produce the CCTV footages before the registrar (judicial) of the court before 5 pm on January 3.

When the petition was heard on Wednesday, a division bench of Justices M Duraiswamy and T Ravindran observed that the SEC had filed a miscellaneous petition seeking extension of 15 days’ time to submit the footage. The judges observed that the election results were declared on January 2 and 3 and the reason furnished by the commission cannot be accepted and no further indulgence can be shown.

Title: Govt insensitive to famers’s woes: Lokesh
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Vijayawada: Expressing anguish about the death of 10 farmers in the capital city area, TDP national general secretary Lokesh asked chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy should go on Odarpu Yatra to meet the family members of the deceased.

He said even district-in-charge ministers were not meeting the kin of the farmers who lost lives due to the government’s plans to shift the capital from Amaravati. Lokesh consoled the family members of Addepalli Kripanandam, farmer of Krishnayapalem village in the capital city, who died of heart-attack on Wednesday. Lokesh also participated in the funeral rally of the farmer in the village.

Speaking to media, Lokesh criticized the government for not responding to the death of farmers in the capital. “Several people are losing their lives out of shock after the government declared its intention to shift the capital. How can any government be so insensitive to the woes of the people,” asked Lokesh.

He dared the ministers to visit the villages to gauge people’s mood. He said that no one in the 29 villages was happy after the chief minister revealed the proposal to shift the capital city. He slammed the government for ignoring the sacrifices of farmers who parted with their land for the capital city.

He said farmers were sleepless for past several weeks due to the illogical decision of the government. He said Jagan was trying to repay his debts to KCR by abandoning the capital city.

Earlier in the day, Lokesh visited the district prison in Guntur and met the farmers who were arrested. Lokesh assured the farmers all assistance from TDP.

Title: Nagpur: Bharat bandh hits work, Left & Congress unions get Sena support
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Work was affected in many central and state government offices in the city. The protesters also expressed soli... Read More

NAGPUR: The daylong Bharat bandh called by the Left and Congress backed trade unions affected work in a number of central and state government offices in the city. For the first time, they had the support of Shiv Sena-backed Kamgar Sena, a right wing outfit. Though the main demands were about labour issues, the union leaders also expressed solidarity with JNU students during the rally.

Sangh Parivar affiliated Bharatiya Mazdoor Sangh (BMS) did not take part in the strike on the grounds that the other unions were also raising political issues like NRC, CAA and the JNU case. The strike was also supported by smaller associations, ranging from class four employees in Government Mental Hospital in the city, nurses in government medical colleges, ASHA workers and medical representatives.

The main demand of the smaller unions was wage hike and better work conditions. The majority unions in public sector undertaking (PSU) banks, except State Bank of India, were also on strike. The unions also raised the issue of problems faced by BSNL, however employees in the state-owned telecom service provider did not take part in the strike.

The major organizations where the strike affected work include income tax department, Life Insurance Corporation (LIC), government-owned general insurance companies, department of posts, and a number of state government offices like zilla parishad and health department, said Gurprit Singh, secretary of joint council of trade unions.

Singh said the unions are pressing for a 12-point charter of demands, which covers opposition to merging of major labour laws into four codes, scrapping of new pension scheme (NPS), merger of banks and insurance corporation, and disinvestment. Singh said the new labour codes will also bring down minimum wage structure as the laws will become state subject.

After representatives of smaller unions raised their issues, mainly related to increase in wages, the senior leaders also made a mention about the developments at JNU. Among the three resolutions passed after the strike included one expressing solidarity with the JNU students.

Political sentiment could also be felt in the strike. “The fascist government thinks it has only two enemies, Marx and Ambedkar, however, the government will not last long,” said a veteran trade union leader while winding up the protest rally.

All speakers also targeted Prime Minister Narendra Modi over the economic slowdown in the country. “Around 25 crore in all have hit the streets throughout the country. Had it been a developed country like Germany the prime minister would have quit,” said a union leader.

The bank unions took out a rally near Kingsway and have been protesting against a number of decisions, especially merger of PSU banks, said Jayant Gurwey of Eastern Maharashtra Bank Employees Association (EMBEA).

Title: Protesting LRD candidates detained in Gandhinagar
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Cops haul away protesting candidates in Gandhinagar on Wednesday

AHMEDABAD: More than 100 women candidates who took the Lok Rakshak Dal (LRD) examination were detained by police in Gandhinagar on Wednesday as they protested the exclusion from vacancies in the general category after the exam, which was held in January 2019. A large number of LRD women candidates have been protesting in Gandhinagar for the past 30 days.

Four protesters were injured, one of them grievously, when they attempted to evade detention by running away from police. The protesters were trying to march towards the state assembly despite not having the required permission. A protester, Pooja Sangathiya, has been admitted to hospital.

The women protesters who have been sitting on a dharna at Sector 6 in Gandhinagar have also approached the Gujarat high court with a petition against their exclusion. The protesting aspirants belong to reserved categories — SC, ST, and OBC — and are meritorious candidates, but are being denied the option of choosing vacancies in the general category.

The state government had, in August 2018, announced the examination to fill 9,713 LRD posts. Of these, 3,077 posts were reserved for women. The examination was held in January 2019 and the results were announced in November 2019.

Minister of state for home Pradipsinh Jadeja said on Wednesday that the state government will ensure that no candidate faces injustice.

Title: Puri temple seeks more time from SC to list deities’ property
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

BHUBANESWAR: The administration of the Jagannath Temple in Puri has sought more time from the Supreme Court to compile a complete database of the immovable property and quarries owned by the 12th-century shrine in Odisha and other states.

On November 4 last year, the Supreme Court had sought information on the temple’s immovable property and quarries while issuing 23 directives to the shrine administration on temple reforms.

Though amicus curiae Ranjit Kumar had earlier stated in his report that the temple owned 60,418 acres of land, the apex court had on November 4 ordered the temple to conduct an inventory to list other immovable property owned by the deities in the state and beyond. The court had also wanted to know about the utilization of the land owned and the income generated by it.

“At present, we do not have the complete information on the volume of temple land in various states. Efforts are being made to gather information from the states on the presence of temple land and whether those properties have or have not been acquired by the temple administration,” the temple’s senior counsel in the Supreme Court, Swetaketu Mishra, said.

Mishra said another affidavit would soon be filed in the Supreme Court detailing the immovable property of the temple as well as the status of quarry operations. “We were asked by the Supreme Court to furnish a report on the exact number of quarries operating on the temple land and whether those are managed properly. The court also wanted to know whether the quarries generate revenue for the temple. We have so far not compiled the complete list of quarries,” Mishra said.

The temple advocate said the amicus curiae would prepare a note on the loose ends in the temple’s affidavit. “We will rectify our flaws and fulfil the observations of the amicus curiae and the Supreme Court,” Mishra said.

The temple officials said most of the 23 directives by the Supreme Court had been complied with. “We have acted on the apex court’s directive and started a probe against some servitors who had disrupted the rituals of the temple on December 28, 2018,” a temple official said.

Title: BMC earns record Rs 19 crore from selling ad space in Bhubaneswar
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: The Bhubaneswar Municipal Corporation ( BMC ) has sold advertisement rights to two private parties for Rs 19.80 crore, the highest since the civic body had started auctioning advertising space in the city in 2008.

The rights include setting up hoardings, bill boards and sign boards on government lands, which have been designated as hoarding zones. The private parties can’t put up advertisements on no-hoarding zones and on rooftops as the BMC had put a blanket ban on it in 2017.

“We had kept a minimum auction amount (offset amount) of Rs 14 crore for the two zones. The two parties who quoted the highest for the respective zones was given the rights,” BMC deputy commissioner Srimanta Mishra said. He said this is the highest that the BMC will be earning from selling advertisement rights.

The BMC has been divided into three zones for administrative purposes and while two of the zones have earned it rich dividends, there was no bidder for the third zone. “We may go for sole auction of this zone. We expect to earn about Rs 5 crore from its sale,” said a BMC officer.

On November 21, 2013, the state government had come up with a resolution that advertisement should not be driven by revenue and it should rather be driven by city’s development needs and aesthetic value. Considering this, the BMC banned rooftop hoardings and also designated places as no hoarding zones.

BMC sources said besides the rights to put up advertisements on government land, the BMC also earns revenue from ‘advertisement licence fee’ for putting up hoardings and bill boards on private land.

Title: Woman bags award from PM for record high sesame yield on farm
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

NAMAKKAL: When her husband died 30 years ago, Pappathi, then a 31-year-old mother of three children, was staring at an uncertain future. Three decades later, Pappathi returned from Tumkur in Karnataka after receiving the Krishi Karman award from Prime minister Narendra Modi for managing a record yield in her farm.

With sheer grit and determination she took up farming in her small tract of land left behind by her husband Ponnusamy. She never had much of an experience in agriculture apart from helping her husband in minor chores like de-weeding.

Today, Pappathi has become a celebrity of sorts in her village and an inspiration for fellow farmers in neighbouring villages as well. From a nondescript Kunjampalayam village in Namakkal district , Pappathi got an yield of 1210 kg sesame in her one hectare land, about 200 kgs more than the normal yield.

“We used to cultivate different crops in our land. In 2018 we sowed sesame. One day agriculture department officials visited our farm and said they want to take stock of the yield. Soon after, they called me to inform that I have recorded the highest yield,’’ she said, beaming with pride.

Pappathi was not aware that she was going to receive the award from Modi. She received the award on January 2 at a grand function in Tumkur. Besides a citation, she was also given a cash reward of Rs 2 lakh.

Her elder son P Ramesh who helps Pappathi in agriculture, said that they do not use any chemical fertilisers.

“We followed the agriculture department officials’s advise to use organic fertiliser. Now many more farmers from the region are seeking our advise to increase yield,’’ he said.

Title: One more held for fingerprint scam in Gujarat
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Cyber cell sleuths on Tuesday arrested Chintan Thakkar, 32, a resident of Mathak in Morbi and the owner of a fair price shop, in the public distribution system (PDS) fingerprint scam . Cyber cell sources said Thakkar and the prime accused Bharat Chudhary had met near Iskcon Crossroads in the city as part of the conspiracy. Thakkar is the 13th person accused arrested in the case.

DCP cyber cell Rajdeepsinh Jhala said Thakkar used to provide data to the scamsters, including the fingerprints of eligible beneficiaries who had not bought rations from fair price shops.

“The scamsters would replicate the beneficiaries’ fingerprints on a rubber-like material using a computer application, raise forged bills by fooling the biometric system, and sell the subsidized goods in the market at a higher price,” Jhala added.

The scam was carried out by three key persons, Bharat Chaudhary, 26; Dhaval Patel, 32, an electronics and communications engineer from Karamsad; and Dushyant Parmar, 22. They were arrested on December 7 and 8.

Cyber cell sleuths later arrested nine owners of fair price shops in Anand for their role in the scam based on the confessions of the principal accused. These owners were Rameshchandra Mohnani, 64; Joytaram Sargara, 38; Dilip Patel, 56; Manhar Solanki, 65; Vinod Vaghela, 43; Gangaram Vasava, 54; Chetan Tulsani, 42; Gangasagar Pandey, 38; and Praful Thakor, 62.

Jhala said the prime accused had colluded with more than 40 fair price shop owners. Other players from Gurugram, Sohna, Parval, Badshahpur and Mewat are also involved in the scam.

Title: Chandigarh: KYC fraud on rise, 55 complaints in 15 days
Content:
Representative image

CHANDIGARH: Frauds through “Know Your Customer” or KYC trick has seen a sharp rise in the city, with over 50 complaints of swindling on the pretext of Paytm KYC update being reported to the Cyber Crime Investigating Cell (CCIC) of the UT police in just a fortnight. Complainants lost money from Rs 10,000 to Rs 45,000, cyber cell cops said on Wednesday.According to them, starting December 25, 2019, they have received to date as many as 55 cases of online fraud using the trick of KYC updation.Giving details of the modus operandi of fraudsters, the cyber cell cops said fake messages asking Paytm users to update their KYC are being sent in bulk. These messages have the numbers of swindlers. As people call on those numbers, they are asked to enter their bank account details in a link provided by them or to download some app for the purpose. As soon as an unsuspecting Paytm customer enters his bank details, all his sensitive information reach the cheaters. For the next few minutes, the swindler keeps the Paytm user engaged in talks while his hard earned money is diverted to their accounts through multiple transactions. After the phone is disconnected, the customer finds he has messages of several transactions from the bank, but by then it is too late, the cops said.In his complaint, a Paytm user Bhusan Lal, a resident of Sector 49, reported that he received a call on January 5. The caller introduced himself as an employee of Paytm and asked him to update the KYC details, or else his wallet account would expire. Later, the complainant also received a message on his mobile phone to this effect. So, he called on the number. He was asked to download an app to update the KYC details. As he downloaded it and filled all his details online, the cheats allegedly withdrew a total of Rs 31,845 from his account, while he was kept engaged over phone.Another resident Deepak Kumar Rana of Sector 49 also stated that he had received an SMS to update his KYC, failing which his Paytm account would be blocked within 24 hours. Deepak called up at the given mobile number. The person responding introduced himself as Rahul Sharma, a Paytm employee. The complainant followed his all instructions, thus passing on all his bank account-related sensitive information to the fraudsters. After disconnecting the phone, Deepak realised that while he was busy talking to Rahul, the cheats had diverted Rs 44,980 in four transactions from his bank account linked to Paytm. So, he called his bank and got his account blocked, but the money was already gone.Both complainants has submitted their complaints to the public window at police headquarters, which forwarded those to the cyber cell for investigation.Devinder Singh, CCIC incharge of the UT police, said the cell has been flooded with complaints of frauds in the name of Paytm KYC update. They are getting two-three complaints every day, he said.He said that cheaters generally ask Paytm users to download apps like “Quick Viewer” and “Team Support”. “These apps are actually applications to remotely access your mobile phones. Once users enter their details in the app, fraudsters get full control of their devices. Next they ask customers to make a token payment from their debit or credit card to Paytm (to keep the account alive), which gives them all the required details to do online transactions.”The cyber cell unit of UT police has also written to Paytm to make their customers aware regarding fraudulent SMSs and calls, so that people do not fall prey to such fraud.

Title: Madurai: Two declared winners-High Court extends stay on swearing in
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

MADURAI: Madras high court has extended the interim injunction on swearing in a woman candidate as panchayat president of Sankarapuram village in Sivaganga district where election officials granted form 25, the certificate declaring the winner, to two candidates separately. The court also asked if the returning officer has the power to cancel form 25 issued to a candidate.

Petitioner M Devi and A Priyadharshini had contested for the post and form 25 was first issued to her after she was declared winner around 8 pm on January 2. However, she was shocked to know that Form 25 was later issued to Priyadharshini around 5 am on January 3. A division bench had heard her petition at a special sitting and observed that once the form is issued, the returning officer has no power to entertain the application for recounting as per rule 66 of Tamil Nadu Panchayats Act, 1994. Hence the court granted interim injunction on swearing in Priyadharshini as panchayat president.

When the case was heard on Wednesday, senior counsel for the petitioner submitted that it is illegal to cancel Form 25 after it is issued to a candidate and that it can only be done by the district court. Additional Advocate General K Chellapandian submitted that the election official had erroneously declared that Devi had won the election and issued Form 25 in her favour before the counting process was completed. He said that only 10,981 of the 11,924 votes polled were counted then. When the other candidate pointed this out, the remaining votes were counted and Priyadharshini was declared winner on completion of counting. The counter affidavit filed by the Sivaganga district collector stated that appropriate charges had been framed against the concerned returning officer and assistant returning officer calling for an explanation.

Taking note of the submissions, a division bench asked the government if the returning officer has the power to cancel Form 25 which has been issued to a candidate. The judges also observed that it is not known as to why the returning officer had taken the role of district court which has such powers to cancel Form 25 when a poll petition is filed under section 258 of TN Panchayats Act.

Title: ‘Army jawan’ beaten up for raising religious slogan
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: An Army jawan was allegedly beaten up by a group of men from a particular community for raising religious slogan in Khanpur area under Sadar Kotwali police station in Auraiya district .

Both the sides have lodged FIRs against each other and police have launched a probe.

The police initiated action after a video of the incident, which took place on Monday, went viral on Wednesday.

“Armed with a licenced gun and 21 cartridges, Ram Naresh had gone to supervise construction work at his plot in Khanpur under Sadar Kotwali police station on Monday. A group of locals dialled Sadar Kotwali police station and informed that Ram Naresh, who was armed with a gun and cartridges, was raising religious slogan in an inebriated state,” said Inspector Sadar Kotwali Shashank Rajput.

“Sensing the gravity of the situation, a police team from Kotwali police station rushed to the spot. After preliminary investigation, the police booked Ram Naresh under sections 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace) and 506 (punishment for criminal intimidation) of the IPC,” he added.

However, Ram Naresh later filed a police complaint alleging that men from a particular community were herding cattle and attacked him when he stopped them. He also alleged that they snatched his rifle, cash and mobile phone.

“Acting on the jawan’s complaint, we have booked 11 persons under relevant sections, including 395 (punishment for dacoity), 504 and 506 of the IPC. A video has also surfaced on the social media showing a group of men heckling and attacking the jawan for chanting the religious slogan,” the Inspector added.

“Investigations are underway. Ram Naresh claims himself to be an Army jawan posted at Army headquarters in New Delhi. We are verifying his claims,” the inspector added.

Title: Water connection charges should be reduced: Activists
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Aurangabad: Activists and water experts staged a demonstration in front of the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) headquarters to demand the reduction of the water tax to Rs 1,800 annually.

The AMC currently charges Rs 4,000 as water tax. They protested against the reported statement of the municipal commissioner that water charges would not be reduced till recovery reaches its 100% mark.

If the AMC staff could not recover more than 30 % of the water charges,The activists said that civic body chief should not force residents to pay for the lethargy of his staff,

The Aurangabad Samaji Manch and citizen’s action committee of water supply submitted a memorandum to the civic chief to draw his attention towards the problems of water supply, said professor Vijay Diwan.

Diwan had approached the high court challenging the civic body’s decision to go for the public-private partnership (PPP) model to implement the then Rs 792 crore parallel water supply system in 2006.

The AMC had eventually scrapped the contract with the private water company and then scrapped the scheme.

In 2011, the AMC mooted PPP model according to which the water supply was to be privatized for 20 years. the company didn’t start work between 2012 and 2014.

Diwan said that in 2011, residents would get daily water supply after paying Rs 1,800 annually. But after the company took over the residents would receive water supply six days in a month.

He added “We requested the municipal commissioner to provide daily water supply at Rs 1,800 for each domestic connection, and according to Bombay Municipal Act it’s the corporation’s responsibility to supply water, the civic body should not privatise it.’’ Senior CPI leader, Manohar Taksal, Madhukar Khillare, Devidas Kirtishahi and Subhash Lomte, social activist, led the demonstration.
