She has a lot more at stake."Nikkhil Advani, whose pinned tweet is a snapshot of Constitution, pointed out that Deepika was taking a bigger risk by expressing her solidarity as she is also producer of the film 'Chhapaak'. "As producer today Deepika Padukone would've been standing in the preview theatres in Mumbai waiting to hear praise being showered on her maiden production. She instead chose to stand in solidarity with JNU students knowing fully well the ramifications of her actions. Respect."Actress Chitrangda Singh posted a blend of religious symbols including along with a note saying, "This is the country my father fought for. This is the country he raised me to believe in. Students are the backbone of this country. We can't go far by breaking them."Earlier, Twinkle Khanna reacted to a report on the JNU attack saying, "India, where cows seem to receive more protection than students, is also a country that now refuses to be cowed down. You can't oppress people with violence. There will be more protests, more strikes, more people on the street."Actor Suniel Shetty condemned the attack in an interview to a film portal. He said, "Absolute disaster. I could be Hindu, Muslim, Sikh, Christian. I can be anybody from BJP, Congress, Shiv Sena, NCP or any other party. But I have no right to go into a temple of education and beat up the kids. You come wearing masks and call yourself men? If you are men why not roam openly? Whichever party has done it, it is not done. At the same time, some students might not be students, they might be protesters, putting up placards like 'Free Kashmir'. Kashmir was, is and will remain ours. I think these things should be very clear."Meanwhile, Maharashtra minister Ashok Chavan endorsed Deepika's action saying, "Whatever happened in JNU, anyone will speak against it. I do not see anything wrong in Padukone supporting the JNU protest."

Title: Dehradun: 80 lakh pilgrims to undertake Char Dham Yatra in 2023: Study
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

DEHRADUN: A study by Doon-based think-tank Social Development for Communities (SDC) Foundation has predicted that 80 lakh pilgrims would come to Uttarakhand ’s annual Char Dham Yatra by 2023. The study, released on Wednesday, also predicts that more than 55 lakh tourists will visit the Char Dham region this year.

According to the foundation, the report’s analysis of tourist numbers can help government agencies, policy-makers, and district authorities to better plan and accommodate the increasing number of tourists in the area and to manage the waste generated. The study titled “Analysing The Tourist Pattern In Char Dham Region Of Uttarakhand" was conducted by Abhiti Mishra, a student of Indian Statistical Institute, Bangalore who was helped by Ashutosh Kandwal, co-founder of SDC. Based on the data from government sources, the study analyses the pattern of pilgrims coming to Uttarakhand in not just the Char Dhams — Badrinath, Kedarnath, Yamunotri and Gangotri but other areas on the route as well like Srinagar, Rudraprayag, Joshimath and Uttarkashi towns. Kandwal said that as per their study, Char Dham region will witness 16.36% of the total tourists visiting Uttarakhand in 2021.

Title: Kerala: Malappuram tops list of world’s fastest-growing urban areas
Content:
Area near Malappuram Civil Station

MALAPPURAM: Three of the world’s 10 fastest-growing urban areas are in Kerala , according to a survey published by The Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU), a sister company of The Economist.While Malappuram tops the list, Kozhikode ranks fourth and Kollam is in the 10th position. No other Indian city has made it to the top 10 on the list, based on the United Nation’s population data.According to the report, Malappuram recorded a 44.1% rise in population between 2015-2020, while Can Tho in Vietnam, ranking second on the list, saw its population increase by 36.7%. Suqian in China, which ranks third, recorded a 36.6 % growth in population and Kozhikode recorded a 34.5% rise in population. Kollam registered a 31.1 % growth in population during the same period.With a population growth rate of 30.2%, Kerala’s cultural capital Thrissur features at number 13. The two other Indian cities that figure on the list of 30 are Surat (26.7%) and Tirupur (26.1%).Mohanachandran Nair, professor and head of department demography, Kerala University, said there was nothing surprising about Malappuram securing the top position on the list as population growth was a defining feature of urbanization.“If 75% people in an area work in non-farming sector, we consider the region as urbanized. Urban areas across the state have been redefined after the 2011 census and the number of municipalities and towns increased,” he said.“Urban population in Malappuram was only 3 lakh in 2001 and it increased to 16 lakh in 2011. The whopping increase signals the swift growth of urbanization even a decade ago. The total number of urban areas in Kerala before 2011 was below 30. But the number increased to 48 after 2011 census as we redefined the town areas across the state. Such a change in demography mainly occurred in the northern parts of Kerala, especially in Malappuram,” he said.About 48 % area in Kerala was included under urbanized category in 2011 itself, he said.

Title: Chennai: Banks, commercial buildings reserve parking space on NSC Bose Road
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The space outside SBI bank branch on NSC Bose Road has been illegally cordoned off

CHENNAI: Commercial complexes and public sector undertakings on NSC Bose Road opposite the Madras high court have ‘reserved’ parking spaces outside their buildings, much to the chagrin of visitors to the court complex.

Early in the day, parking spaces outside the Tamil Nadu State Apex Co-operative (TNSC) Bank building and State Bank of India (SBI) building are barricaded and other vehicles are not allowed to park there.

An official with the corporation’s Royapuram zone told ToI that parking spaces had not been let out to any particular building or organization and it was on a ‘first come, first served’ basis. A traffic policeman on duty outside Madras high court too told ToI that spaces were not earmarked for any particular building.

“The security guards of the buildings do not allow public to park vehicles on NSC Bose Road claiming that senior bank officials have to park their vehicles,” said a worker at an optical store nearby.

After the high court came down heavily on it for allowing hawking and parking of two-wheelers on the pavement along NSC Bose Road, the civic body raised bollards on some stretches to check parking. On Wednesday, ToI saw two-wheelers continued to be parked on pavements despite boards erected by the city corporation and the police. In front of the commercial complex adjacent to Armenian street, several two-wheelers were parked on the pavement and a temporary ramp had been put up.

“The menace has reduced. We will set up bollards to prevent two-wheeler entry from the approach roads of NSC Bose Road,” said an official with Royapuram Zone. Traffic on the stretch is always an issue as advocates and visitors to the high court too triple-park on the road, eating into the carriageway.

Title: Hindi poet Kishan Saroj passes away
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Bareilly: Noted Hindi poet and Sahitya Bhushan awardee Kishan Saroj breathed his last at his Azadpuram residence here on Wednesday. Saroj died 11 days before his 81st birthday that was on January 19 - leaving behind 60 years of work.

Harishankar Saxena, his close friend, critic and the editor of the book ‘Nirjharini’ written on Saroj’s work, said that Saroj had been suffering from memory loss for the past few months. Saroj is survived by two sons and a daughter.

Saroj was publicly last seen at a Kavi Sammelan organised by Bareilly Municipal Corporation in November 2016. Though, his last appearance was not less than a nightmare to him as a few audiences had started hooting as soon as he started reciting poems. However, he continued reciting the poems and once completed, he received a standing ovation. He had then said that the incident reflected the “decline in good audience”. It was his last stage show after which Saroj had stopped participating in Kavi Sammelan.

Saroj had penned two collections of his poetry – ‘Chandan Van Doob Gaya’ (1986) and ‘Bana Na Chitra Havaon Ka’ (2006).

Starting at the age of 16 in 1955, he was felicitated in 2006 with Sahitya Bhushan award by Uttar Pradesh Hindi Sansthan for his remarkable contribution in Hindi poetry.

Title: Motorcyclist, pillion rider suffer injuries as bike skids
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Pune: A four-wheeler hit two men on a motorcycle after their vehicle skid on Solapur highway at Fatimanagar around 4.30am on Monday.

The injured victims Nilesh Trishinge (26) from Hadapsar and the pillion rider Amit Jamble are undergoing treatment at separate private hospitals. Jamble’s condition is reported to be serious.

Trishinge, a hotel manager, and three other persons celebrated a friend’s birthday in a restaurant at Malwadi in Hadapsar on the night intervening January 5 and 6. Around 4am, Trishinge and Jamble left on a bike to Fatimanagar. Two of their friends were following them.

Investigating officer Prashant Thakre from Wanowrie police station said, “Trishinge, while passing near Kroma mall, suddenly applied brakes in the middle of the highway. The impact was such that his bike skid and a speeding light vehicle ran over Trishinge’s left hand and Jamble’s left leg, critically injuring them.”

Thakare added, “The two friends, who were following them, rushed them to a nearby hospital. The police received a call regarding a medico-legal case from the hospital around 6.30am. A police team rushed to the spot and launched investigations.”

“Trishinge could not give details of the spot where the accident took place since it was dark. He could not identify the vehicle that injured him and his friend. Jamble was later shifted to a hospital in Bibvewadi. It has become difficult for us to analyse the CCTV cameras to establish the identity of the vehicle responsible for the accident,” the officer said.

An offence has been registered under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code and Motor Vehicles Act.

Title: Man stabs estranged wife, her mom to death after tiff
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Indore: A man stabbed his estranged wife and her mother to death after chasing them on 60 Feet Road under Dwarkapuri police station limits on Wednesday evening.

The accused - Sandeep Soni- started stabbing the duo inside their house. When they tried to run away he gave chase to them and attacked the duo outside too.

Dwarkapuri police station in charge Vijay Sisodiya said that the accused Sandeep Soni had an affair with Nitu three years ago and had married her. Their marriage, however, fell apart after a dispute. A few months ago, Soni had attacked the family members and a case was registered at Dwarkapuri police station. They had also attended a hearing for the case in court a week ago, said family members adding that after this the dispute had started.

Nitu had moved in with her mother Padma. They lived in Dwarkapuri area, a few blocks away from Sandeep.

On Wednesday evening, the accused and his family members reached Nitu’s house and entered into a dispute with her. The matter escalated to an extent that Sandeep took out a sharp-edged weapon from his pocket and stabbed Nitu brutally. When Nitu’s mother Padma came to her rescue, he stabbed her as well before fleeing the spot.

Rajmal Verma, Padma’s father told reporters, “They were at least four people and before anyone could understand what were they fighting about, Sandeep stabbed Nitu and Padma and fled the spot.”

As the news spread, Dwarkapuri police station in charge and senior police officials reached the spot.

The body was sent to MY Hospital for postmortem.

ASP Manish Khatri said that Nitu used to work at a chocolate factory and also worked as a tailor, whereas Sandeep was not employed.

Title: Tamil Nadu cop shot dead at Kaliyikkavila
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM /KANYAKUMARI: An on-duty officer of the Tamil Nadu police was shot dead at the Padanthalumoodu checkpost near Kaliyikkavila on Wednesday night.

Identifying the deceased officer as special sub-inspector Wilson of Marthandam, Tamil Nadu, Kaliyikkavila sub-inspector P Swarnalatha said the incident occurred around 10pm.

Wilson was checking vehicles along with other officers when a man got off a Mahindra Scorpio that was flagged down and opened fire at him.

He suffered three bullet injuries. Though other officers rushed him to a private hospital, his life could not be saved. The motive for the murder was not known.

After gunning the officer down, the assailant escaped in the vehicle, bearing the registration number TN-57-AW-1559.

Tamil Nadu and Kerala police have launched a coordinated search on suspicion that the assailants might have fled to Kerala.

“We are coordinating with the Kerala police as the accused have fled to the neighbouring Thiruvananthapuram district,” deputy inspector general of police (Tirunelveli range), Praveen Kumar Abinapu, said.

Superintendent of police, Kanyakumari , N Shreenath and other officers visited the scene.

Tamil Nadu police formed three teams to arrest the assailants. More teams would be formed if required.

Superintendent of police (Thiruvananthapuram rural) B Ashokan said the Neyyattinkara police sub-division and all patrol teams have been alerted.

Police were suspecting that an accused in two murder cases, Rajkumar, was involved in the incident.

A Tamil Nadu police officer said Wilson was to retire from service after five months. He was hospitalized for two months after an accident and had re-joined duty four days ago.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Dalit panchayat president seeks police protection
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

K Nagalakshmi, the president of Sakkimangalam reserved panchayat in the district

Tamil Nadu: K Nagalakshmi, the president of Sakkimangalam reserved panchayat in the district, has sought round-the-clock armed police protection after miscreants set ablaze the tent erected for her oath taking ceremony. In a petition to the district collector, she also sought CCTV cameras to be installed at her house and panchayat office.

“Only the government hopes that dalits will be uplifted by reserving such panchayats. But to this day, people from the BC community want to use us as puppets and take control of the panchayat administration,” she told TOI. However she admits that many non-dalits too would have cast their votes for her. The widow who grazes cattle for a living had unsuccessfully contested the panchayat president polls thrice in the last 33 years. “I have been contesting when the president post was not reserved. This time it was reserved for dalits and six of us including three women were in the fray. Intermediate caste Hindus had fielded three of them, but I won as the people know me as a long-time contestant and easily approachable,” she said.

Nagalakshmi secured 2,021 of the 5,600 votes polled and won by a margin of close to 300 votes. She said that till 11 pm on January 5 they were busy installing the tent for the oath taking the following day. Fearing threat from mischief mongers, she said they also petitioned the local police. However, early next morning she got news about the tent being torched.

Police registered a case under sections 427 (mischief causing damage to the amount of fifty rupees) and 435 (mischief by fire or explosive substance with intent to cause damage) of the IPC

Title: Maharashtra: Long monsoon, warmer winter and cloud cover rob markets of red roses
Content:
This Valentine’s Day, roses will come at a premium. Last year’s prolonged monsoon and the unseasonal rain, alo... Read More

PUNE: This Valentine’s Day, roses will come at a premium. Last year’s prolonged monsoon and the unseasonal rain, along with the consistent cloud cover , have led to a decline in the production of the flowers in the state.Flower growers from the state said the demand for roses ahead of Valentine’s Day from the domestic market has grown and prices have gone up phenomenally. Low production is likely to impact the export of roses.Ramesh Patil, chief executive officer of Shrivardhan Biotech in Kondigre village in Kolhapur district, has 103 acres of polyhouses. He exports over a million roses every year to domestic and international markets. He said production has halved this year.The international market has already suffered and there is a huge demand for roses and prices have gone up in the local market, he added.“Every year, we get good profits from the international market. This year, the weather has affected the rose buds. Fungus and bacterial infection have affected the quality of roses. The long bud and stem fetches the best prices. If the roses are small, then our profits are down,” Patil told TOIAt present, the domestic market is fetching almost as much money as the international consignments, he said.Pravin Sharma, president of the Indian Society of Floriculture Professionals, said they hoped the weather condition would improve from the second week of January which in turn will boost market conditions.Both markets have a demand of around 10 million roses around Valentine’s Day. This year, there will be a demand-supply gap, he added.Low temperatures are required for roses to bloom late and stay fresh for exports. The society expects a decline in the exports this year in terms of volume and value as compared to last year.Prasad Dev, director of the flower growers’ association in Maharashtra, said changing weather has affected many farmers into rose cultivation in Nanded who have now shut down their polyhouses.Babaji Ghadge, a farmer from Rajgurunagar, said more roses were affected by the Downy mildew fungus this year and production has taken a hit.

Title: Eating from vendors on beaches, streets may become safer soon in Chennai
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

In the last few weeks, at least 80 street food vendors on Elliot’s beach were taught about food safety

CHENNAI: Hot bajjis served on beaches or crispy hot dosas had at roadside stalls are set to become safer to eat if regulators in the city have their way.

In the last few weeks, at least 80 street food vendors on Elliot’s beach were taught about the need for food safety, what the Food Safety and Standard Act expects out of every food business unit, violations and punishments. At the end of the day, vendors who attended the camp were given Food Safety Training & Certification (FoSTaC). “If we have at least one certified personnel in every unit we will improve food quality and also emphasise that they follow all rules,” said A Ramakrishnan, designated food safety officer, Chennai.

For instance, street vendors on the beach were taught about the reuse of oil and safe way to dispose cooking oil. They were taught the importance of hand wash, food preservation and how things they use and their surrounding should be clean, he said.

Street food vendors will be given basic guidance including catering services. Under the FoSTaC programme, the regulator plans to train staff in the organised as well as unorganised sector. For street food vendors, anganwadi workers and Amma canteen staff, the authority is raising funds from people for the course. “We will be rolling out day-long training programmes for vendors on Marina and staff of Amma canteens soon,” another senior official said.

The course offers 17 types of competence-based certification programmes — each of 8 to 12-hour hour duration spread over a couple of days. Street vendors and aganwadi workers were given the basic course and training manuals. Most of the staff were also taught about where and how they should source ingredients and how they can check quality of the ingredients difference between edible oil/ghee and the cheap ones that are made for lighting lamps at temples.

Several studies by doctors’ bodies and nutritionists have shown high volumes of Ecoli coliform, salmonella, shigella, staphylococcus aureus and pseudomonas, which are major causes of infections such as diarrhoea, typhoid, food poisoning, urinary tract infections and pneumonia. Food safety training teaches the importance of handwash, which keep a majority of these infections at bay, officials said.

Title: Lt General SK Saini writes to Uddhav Thackeray for GST share of seven cantonments
Content:
Maharashtra chief minister Uddhav Thackeray

PUNE: General Officer Commanding-in-Chief, Southern Command, Lt Gen SK Saini has written to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray seeking the release of GST funds to seven cantonments, including Pune, Khadki and Dehu Road.“Funds (must) be allocated as per the state finance commission’s recommendations,” the letter written on December 21 said. Apart from the three cantonments in Pune district, the state has cantonments in Ahmednagar, Aurangabad, Deolali and Kamptee.As on date, the budgets of all the seven cantonment boards of Maharashtra are in the red. All taxes earned from commercial/rental properties located in cantonments are now not available to the cantonment boards for their own use, the letter stated.The central and the state finance commissions have recommended a share of funds for cantonment boards from various schemes. But these are not being received by the cantonment boards, the letter added.The cantonment boards are deemed to be a municipality as per the Constitution. Their source of revenue generation was to be akin to municipalities and all cantonment boards were self-sustaining till the introduction of GST, Saini said.“In the past, cantonments used to receive a share of octroi from the neighbouring municipal corporations, which formed considerable percentage of cantonment board budgets. Collection of octroi was abolished by the government of India throughout the country in April 2013. Local Body Tax was levied by cantonment boards but that too got subsumed in GST. The share of state GST, however, was not released by the state government to cantonment boards,” the letter stated.Senior officials from the office of the Director General Defence Estates, which controls the cantonments, elected members of cantonment boards, activists and local residents said the state government has been ‘ignoring’ the cantonments.“We have discussed it with the then defence minister Nirmala Sitharaman, finance minister Arun Jaitley and chief minister Devendra Fadnavis,” Priyanka Shirigiri, member of Pune Cantonment Board , said. “We have not been able to launch any new project,” Amit Kumar, PCB’s chief executive officer, added.Dehu Road Cantonment Board vice president P B Shelar said, “ Cantonment boards have limited sources of revenue. We cannot function smoothly.”

Title: Madurai: Three get lesson in policing after TikTok video
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The youths had climbed on a police van to make a TikTok video

TUTICORIN: Three youngsters, including two 17-year-olds, who made a TikTok video sitting on the bonnet of a police escort van in Tuticorin district, had a taste of policing as police engaged them in traffic regulation on Wednesday. Police said it was not punishment but an opportunity to help them understand the importance of policing.

The trio climbed on the bonnet of the van that was stationed in Caldwell Colony in the city on Tuesday. The van attached to the armed reserve unit of the district police was taken to a workshop at Caldwell Colony when the boys made the short video. One of them recorded it while the two others sat on the bonnet it and acted. The video was circulated on social media platforms on Tuesday night and it did not miss the attention of the police. On Wednesday morning, the three were inquired by the Tuticorin South police. It came to known that one of them is a BA English graduate from Munisamipuram while the two teenagers hailed from Levinjipuram.

Sporting orange reflective jackets, they assisted the traffic police in regulating traffic at the busy market area from 9am to 1pm. They were given snacks and lunch and asked them to come for a similar shift in the evening. One of them did not have a pair of slippers, and the police got him one.

“It is not punishment. It was their choice. The boys had expressed their willingness to be part of the police force. They said they had not intended to tarnish the image of the police by making the video. We gave them an opportunity to serve the public along with the police,” said deputy superintendent of police in Tuticorin town sub-division R Prakash.

Title: CM V Narayanasamy, others vent out ire on Kiran Bedi at a government function
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kiran Bedi

PUDUCHERRY: Chief minister V Narayanasamy, public works minister A Namassivayam and government whip R K R Anantharaman chose a government function on Wednesday to vent out ire on lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi .

Declaring open a new building to accommodate the village panchayat office in Ariyankuppam Commune on Wednesday, Narayanasamy, Namassivayam and Anantharaman accused Bedi of interfering in the day-to-day affairs of the elected government and posing several hindrances to the administration.

Narayanasamy said none of the governors or lieutenant governors in the country interfere in the administrative affairs of elected governments in the states and Union territories unlike Bedi in Puducherry. Bedi has been posing several hindrances on a daily basis to the elected government in Puducherry under the instigation of the BJP-led government in the Centre, he said.

He said the government has been forced to take the legal route to counter Bedi's interferences and expressed optimism that all the obstacles posed by the Centre and lieutenant governor will fade away by February this year.

"Bright days are ahead for Puducherry. All the sufferings, obstacles and hindrances will disappear. We know that the influence of 'sani' (Saturn) will be only for a brief period. The obstacles faced by the government will fade away by February," he said. Namassivayam said Bedi, who was projected as the chief ministerial candidate by the BJP in 2011 Delhi assembly polls and was rejected by the electorate, has been attempting to rule the Union territory of Puducherry sidelining the government elected by the people of Puducherry.

"A person, who cannot understand the requirements and sentiments of all kinds of people has been imposing several obstacles in implementing people welfare schemes. She has no right to do so. She is not an elected representative but appointed by the President. She was fielded as a chief ministerial candidate by the BJP in Delhi. She lost the polls and her deposit too. She was rejected by the people in Delhi has attempted to rule Puducherry," he said.

Anantharaman challenged Bedi to contest from an assembly constituency in Puducherry and win polls to serve the people of the Union territory. He also challenged Bedi to resign and contest polls to assembly in Delhi declared in February and win the polls to serve the people if she believes in Constitution of India and democracy.

Title: Nationwide strike of trade unions partially affects services at RTO
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

An almost empty Pune RTO office on Wednesday.

PUNE: The nationwide strike of trade unions hit the services at the Regional Transport Office on Wednesday, compelling many people to leave the facility only to return another day to get their work done.

Processes like transfer of vehicle ownership and licence tests were hit partially. “I had to get a choice registration number for a new car that I have bought. I went to the RTO (Regional Transport Office) today (Wednesday), but my work couldn’t be completed because of the strike. Many employees were absent, and I couldn’t fill all the forms,” said Rajesh Kulkarni.

The online services were available mostly without any hiccups. “Most of the services provided by the RTO, like filing for appointments for driving tests and seeking registrations, have gone online. So, people filing for appointments didn’t face any issues,” said an RTO official.

Another official said, “There were some problems regarding the driving tests for licences, both learners’ as well as the permanent ones, and tests ascertaining the fitness of vehicles. Some procedures like transfer of vehicle ownership and acquiring no objection certificates were hampered in a major way as these required clerical staffers to be present.”

Kishore Raut, who had gone for his learners’ licence test, said, “The RTO office was practically empty. The tests were happening but after two batches, the exam suddenly stopped. It started again after a while but stopped again. I was able to take the test, but the wait was too long, and many couldn’t appear for the test. They were told to come back on Thursday,” he said.

While operations of the Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) and the Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) remained normal, there was close monitoring of the service.

“Instructions were given to the drivers to be careful. They were told to park the bus at a safe distance if they saw trouble and remain in touch with the depot managers. The passenger volume was a little thin as people were anticipating trouble,” an official with the MSRTC in Pune told TOI.

Title: DM: Proposal to replace collectorate bldg revived
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Old collectorate building

Varanasi: The proposals for replacement of around 200 years old collectorate building, constructed in 1820, and abhilekhagar (record room) close to it has been revived again. The PWD has been asked to prepare drawing and estimate of the new buildings. Initially this proposal had been made during Mulayam Singh Yadav government in 2006 and it was finally put on backburner in 2013.

Talking to TOI on Wednesday, district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma said, “The proposal for replacement of the collectorate building was made about three months ago and its preliminary drawing and design has also been received. The PWD has been asked to prepare final design and estimate of the proposed new building and submit it in maximum 15 days.” The Archaeological Survey of India is also being consulted to find out whether the building has any heritage value, he said.

On receiving the final design and estimate, the proposal will be forwarded to the state government for approval, said the DM adding that if the proposal is approved by the mid of February the government may sanction its budget in the next annual budget.

Initially, the proposal was floated in Samajwadi Party government’s regime in 2006 and a government order was issued on January 30, 2009 declaring the building unfit for use as it was found in a dilapidated state. The officials had forwarded a proposal of Rs 871 lakh for replacement of the building to the revenue board and government. However, even after the project was sanctioned, its funds were diverted to west UP district.

In December 2010, another proposal was sent to the government and the revenue board revised the budget of the project to Rs 725 lakh. But the government decided for re-examination of the proposal and the construction and designing section (CNDS) of UP Jal Nigam was asked to prepare a new detailed project report (DPR) keeping the actual requirements of the collectorate in view. The CNDS prepared new DPR of Rs 18.18 crore proposing a multi-storied building. But later the CNDS was ousted from the project and the Rajkiya Nirman Nigam (RNN) was engaged revising the budget to Rs 17.47 crore.

In October 2013, the then district magistrate Pranjal Yadav, citing the proposal worth Rs 17.47 crore as a waste of public money, mentioned that the existing building was strong and sufficient for the work. A huge sum of money was invested in facelift of the building.

Regarding the record room Sharma said that an estimate of Rs five crore has been prepared for its replacement by a completely furnished and CCTV network equipped building.

A proposal for new annexe of circuit house to add 60 new rooms in view of high inflow of VIPs is also in pipeline, said DM Kaushal Raj Sharma adding that this proposal is also being prepared by the PWD.

Title: Hailstorm, rain in Bareilly cause waterlogging, traffic disruption
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Bareilly: Heavy downpour accompanied with hailstorm lashed across Bareilly on Wednesday afternoon causing much inconvenience to road users. Many were left stranded.

Traffic in several city pockets, including Satellite road, Shyamganj, Quila, Choupla and Civil Lines, among other areas, was disrupted. The Met has predicted more hailstorm and rain in Bareilly and other parts of UP in the next 12 hours.

Small-sized hailstones covered up several city roads, forcing commuters to take shelter. Thereafter, heavy downpour lashed the city which continued till late evening, resulting in waterlogging in several areas such as Quila-Choupla road and Rampur Garden. However, no injuries were reported due to hailstorm or lightning.

According to Indian Meteorological Department (IMD), 20.3 mm of rainfall was recorded in Bareilly on Wednesday. The maximum temperature was at 16.6 degrees Celsius (four degrees below normal) while minimum was 11.5 degrees Celsius (four degrees above normal).

The maximum humidity stood at 100 per cent and minimum was 87 per cent. However, the weatherman said that they did not record hailstorm activity. On Tuesday, city had witnessed mild showers in the afternoon. The maximum and minimum temperatures were recorded at 17.6 degrees C and 11.5 degrees C, respectively.

Head of geography department, Bareilly College, Neeru Agarwal told TOI, “The change in weather is mainly due to western disturbances and fresh snowfall in Himalayan region, which has aggravated the cold conditions. The skies will remain generally cloudy throughout the day with light to moderate rainfall, thunderstorm or hail in coming days as the entire state is in the grip of cold wave.”

Soon after the rainfall, city roads were left submerged, throwing traffic out of gear. Areas worst hit with waterlogging were Choupla and its adjoining places, Quila, Kudeshiya road, parts of Rampur Garden and low lying areas such as Subhash Nagar, Madinath and parts of old city.

“The hailstorm in the city was surprising. Within moments, several city roads were seen covered with hail. Commuters on road were forced to take shelter in petrol pumps, roadside shops and eateries to save themselves. Hailstorm lasted for 20 minutes and thereafter, it started raining heavily. Traffic came to a halt, especially near prominent junctions such as Satellite, Choupla, where construction of flyover is underway,” said Akshay Agarwal, a resident of Rampur Garden.

The IMD has predicted further drop in both minimum and maximum temperatures with more rainfall, hailstorm and gusty winds expected in UP districts of Agra, Aligarh, Allahabad, Amethi, Ghaziabad, Baghpat, Gonda, Meerut, Rae Bareli, Mathura, Moradabad, Shagaranpur and Varanasi, in the next 12 hours.

Title: 7 diagnosed with H1N1 in Kozhikode
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kozhikode: An outbreak of H1N1 has been confirmed at the Anayamkunnu VMHM higher secondary school near Mukkam with seven samples taken from students and teachers of the school testing positive for the disease in the tests conducted at the Manipal Virology Institute.

According to district medical authorities, around 200 people, including students and teachers of the school, have so far contracted fever.

District medical officer Dr V Jayashree said the throat swab tests of seven people tested positive for H1N1 virus on Wednesday.

Increasing number of students has been falling ill since January 1. Classes were suspended on January 8 and 9 following the disease outbreak.

The DMO said preventive measures have been undertaken in the area to prevent the further spread of the disease. As the disease is spread mostly through coughing and sneezing, those affected have been advised stay in their houses.

“There is no need for panic as most of the people have reported low-grade fever. We have asked those with fever to take rest and those who have other difficulties like breathing problems and associated complications to get admitted in a hospital,” the DMO said.

She said health department staff was undertaking house visits in the area as part of fever surveillance and are collecting contact details of students with fever to monitor them.

She said initially it was the high school students who reported fever but later on students from other classes including the upper primary section also reported illness.

Health department authorities said that family members of the students have been asked to exercise vigil to avoid contracting the disease.

“We have advised to use towels while coughing and sneezing and to wash hands frequently,” she added.

Karassery panchayat president V K Vinod said that a special medical camp will be held on Thursday at the school and all the fever affected students in the area have been urged to attend the camp.

Title: ‘Appointing Senkumar as DGP was a big mistake’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala on Wednesday said he committed a big mistake by appointing T P Senkumar as state police chief. Talking to reporters here Chennithala said he bypassed seniority to make Senkumar police chief to favour a Malayali officer.

“Mahesh Kumar Singla was the senior-most officer then. He was bypassed to give the post to Senkumar since we preferred a Malayali police officer as DGP in-charge of law and order,” he said adding that he now regrets the decision. Chennitala was reacting to the political leniency shown by Senkumar after he got retired from the DGP post.

Senkumar had become a controversial figure by spitting communal venom through his social media handles and advocating the agenda of Sangh Parivar. “We are now facing consequences of making him the DGP of the state,’’ Chennithala said.

The UDF and opposition leader had advocated for T P Senkumar when the LDF had replaced him with Lokanth Behra. Senkumar had returned to the post through a court directive and the UDF backed him during this period. tnn

Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan then had flayed the UDF and the opposition leader in particular for supporting Senkumar.

Title: Gujarat: Disturbed Areas Act amendment held back by MHA
Content:
Representative image

GANDHINAGAR: The ministry of home affairs ( MHA ) has raised objections to certain key features of the Disturbed Areas Act amendment bill, which passed by the state assembly in July.The Gujarat Prohibition of Transfer of Immoveable Property and Provision for Protection of Tenants from Eviction from Premises in Disturbed Areas (Amendment) Bill 2019, has been pending clearance from the MHA.The ministry sought clarifications on the definition of the phrase “immovable property” among some other provisions in the amendment. More significantly, the MHA sought to know whether provisions of the amended act are in violation of any other law of the Indian Constitution. The Disturbed Areas Act is applicable in communally sensitive areas of Ahmedabad, Vadodara, Surat, Himmatnagar, Godhra, Kapadvanj and Bharuch. The state government had amended the act citing loopholes being exploited by vested interests.Before the amendment was passed, a number of new areas were included in the DA Act. In Ahmedabad alone, 74 new localities were notified under this Act in 2018. These new localities are in Paldi, Sarkhej, Vejalpur and Aslali.The MHA queries triggered anxiety among local investors and realtors who, in hope of smooth passage, had parked funds in redevelopment projects and plots located near these new localities now under DA Act.The majority of big ticket investments have been around Sarkej, Vejalpur and Paldi. In Sarkhej, a number of businessmen have bought plots to build homes and commercial projects. In some cases, Hindu-Muslim partnerships have been struck to develop high-end apartments in plots near posh Prahladnagar, which fall on either side of the new DA boundary. “These projects will take off only after the Union government ratifies the amendments suggested in the DA Act and the revenue department finalises the list,” said a builder from the Paldi area. A developer in Paldi pointed out how negotiations for redevelopment of flats around Ashiana, Modern Flats, Zara Apartments and certain housing societies in Kagadiwad, which have a mix of Jain and Hindu residents, were stalled due to the pending MHA approval.Amid opposition from the Congress to the amendment, the state legislature passed the bill, ostensibly to prevent the growth of ghettos in cities like Ahmedabad, Vadodara, Surat, Bharuch and smaller towns.A key source in the government said the Gujarat government has replied to the MHA queries, but the home ministry has neither sought further clarifications nor sent the bill to the President for assent.Under the new provisions, the government proposed imprisonment of three to five years and a minimum fine of Rs 1 lakh or 10% of the property value, if a property under the purview of the act is sold by a member of one community to a member of another. Provisions of the act will now also be applicable 500 metres from the limits of disturbed areas.

Title: Pongal special trains from Chennai to southern Tamil Nadu to clear extra rush
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Railways has announced special train services to clear the extra rush of passengers travelling from Chennai to the southern districts during Pongal.

Train no. 82601 Chennai Egmore – Tirunelveli Suvidha special will leave at 6.50pm on January 10 and reach Tirunelveli at 6am the next day. Train no. 06002 Tirunelveli – Tambaram special will leave at 6.15pm on January 11 and reach Tambaram at 5am the next day. The above trains will stop at Tambaram, Chengalpattu, Villupuram, Vriddhachalam, Trichy, Dindigul, Madurai, Virudhunagar, Sattur and Kovilpatti.

Train no. 82603 Tambaram – Tirunelveli Suvidha special will leave at 7.20pm on January 12 and reach Tirunelveli at 6am the next day. Train no. 82604 Tirunelveli – Tambaram Suvidha special will leave at 6.15pm on January 18 and reach Tambaram at 5am the next day. The above trains will have stoppages at Chengalpattu, Villupuram, Vriddhachalam, Trichy, Dindigul, Madurai, Virudhunagar, Sattur and Kovilpatti.

Train no. 82606 Nagercoil – Tambaram Suvidha special will leave at 5pm on January 19 and reach Tambaram at 5am the next day. Train no. 06075 Tambaram – Nagercoil special will leave at 11.20am on January 20 and reach Nagercoil at 2am the next day. The trains will stop at Valliyoor, Tirunelveli, Kovilpatti, Satur, Virudhunagar, Madurai, Dindigul, Trichy, Vriddhachalam, Villupuram and Chengalpattu.

Train no. 82609 Tambaram – Nagercoil Suvidha special will leave Tambaram at 7pm on January 13 and reach Nagercoil at 7.10am the next day. It will stop at Chengalpattu, Villupuram, Vriddhachalam, Trichy, Dindigul, Madurai, Virudhunagar, Sattur, Kovilpatti, Tirunelveli and Valliyoor.

Train no. 06006 Nagercoil – Trichy special will leave at 10.15am on January 14 and will reach Trichy at 6pm the same day. The train will have stoppages at Valliyoor, Tirunelveli Kovilpatti, Sattur, Virudhunagar, Madurai and Dindigul.

Meanwhile, due to maintenance work, train no. 56624 Madurai – Palani passenger scheduled to leave at 7.45am will be cancelled from January 10 to 13 (4 days). Instead a passenger special will leave Madurai at 6.30am and will reach Palani at 10am on those four days. Train no. 07686 Rameswaram – Hyderabad (via Madurai) special scheduled to leave Rameswaram at 5am on January 12 will be rescheduled to leave by 165 minutes at 7.45am.

Title: Country’s intelligence, skills not being utilised: Governor Bhagat Singh Koshyari
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Governor Bhagat Singh Koshyari (centre) was accompanied by a Fellow of the Royal Society, Gagandeep Kang (left... Read More

PUNE: Governor Bhagat Singh Koshyari on Wednesday said the country was not utilising the intelligence, labour and skill available in abundance to generate employment.

“Nowadays, you hear that there is no employment. Who is saying that there is no employment? We are importing so many things,” Koshyari said. He is the chancellor of Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) and was addressing the 116th convocation ceremony of the university.

There was heavy security on the campus. Unauthorised vehicles were not allowed near the convocation venue and there was strict checking at the entrances for black objects. There was talk that students would wear black badges to protest against CAA and NRC.

Koshyari urged students to work toward an aim instead of getting stuck in a routine job that they don’t like. “We should have self-confidence. Be an optimist. Everybody goes through failures. We have to remember that defeat and failure are not crimes,” Koshyari added.

University officials said due to paucity of time, the university gave away gold medals in a separate ceremony in the morning. Only one gold medal in honour of former President Shankar Dayal Sharma was given to Kajal Mahajan Pandit by the governor in the afternoon ceremony. “I invite all gold medallists to Raj Bhavan for tea the next time I am in Pune,” Koshyari added.

Gagandeep Kang, executive director, Translational Health Science and Technology Institute and the first Indian woman to be elected a Fellow of the Royal Society was the chief guest at the function. Kang had three messages for the students, ‘be brave, be accountable and have a contingency plan.’

“While speaking about courage and risk-taking, people talk of Steve Jobs or J K Rowling. We need to look no further than Krantijyoti Savitribai, who was reputed to have carried an extra sari so that she could change when people threw dung at her. A pioneer in every sense, she stood up to her husband’s family and to a community that insulted her, but she persisted, and with results that transformed society. That is true courage,” Kang said.

Known for her interdisciplinary research, development and prevention of enteric infections and their sequelae in children in India, Kang has built national rotavirus and typhoid surveillance networks, established laboratories to support vaccine trials and conducted phase 1-3 clinical trials of vaccines.

Title: Don’t misuse my photo for political purpose: Collector
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kozhikode: Wayanad district collector Adeela Abdulla has strongly objected to use of photographs of her accepting pro-CAA pamphlet from BJP activists for political purposes.

BJP activists had visited the district collector at her camp office on January 7 as part of the party’s on-going mass door-to- door campaign to garner support for the CAA . They took photographs of the collector accepting the pamphlets. It was widely shared on social media groups stating that she was in support of the Act.

Adeela issued a statement on Wednesday asking people who took the photograph to desist from using it for political purposes or to mislead people. “Yesterday a group of BJP activists came to the camp house to give a pamphlet and said they wanted to take the photograph of it as well. As a district collector it is my duty to receive any representations given to me by people. Though I accepted the pamphlet, I didn’t tell them that I agreed to the contents of the pamphlet in the slightest,” the collector said. Adeela added that it would have been better if the reply she gave to the activists who came to visit her was also published along with the photograph.

She said activists of some Muslim organisations were also undertaking smear campaign against her on the basis of the photograph. The collector said she was planning to file complaints against those who engaged in both type of false campaigns.

Adeela is not the first person in the state to protest the use of photogrpahs for BJP’s pro-CAA campaign.

On Tuesday, the media department of Jamia Markaz came out strongly against the Facebook post of BJP leader A N Radhakrishnan that Sunni leader Kanthapuram A P Aboobacker Musaliyar had held discussions with him on the controversial law.

Karat Razack, LDF-backed independent MLA from Koduvally, had also expressed his displeasure over the BJP using his photograph for pro-CAA campaign. Local BJP leaders had met the MLA at his house to hand over the propaganda material to him.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Donkeys to deliver Pongal gifts to remote village in Vellore
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Donkeys transport Pongal hampers to Nekkanamalai village in Vellore district

VELLORE: For villagers of Nekkanamalai, this Pongal will be special. This time around they don’t have to climb four kilometres down a steep hilly path to collect their Pongal gift hampers. The district authorities have arranged 12 donkeys to deliver the gifts at their village.

Tirupattur collector M P Sivan Arul said he came know about the plight of the villagers in absence of road recently, and so ordered the gifts to be delivered to them on 12 donkeys at the village Public Distribution System (PDS) shop on Thursday.

Residents of Nekkanamalai village, for several generations, have been facing several hardships in absence of a proper road. Villagers said youths find it hard to get married as no one wants to shift to a village with no road connection.

The village, which is about 9km from Vaniyambadi , is home to around 650 people. It is situated at an altitude of 1,500m above sea level.

Valliammal, 70, a villager, said, “Though we are happy and excited to receive the Pongal gift hampers without much hassle this time around, what we really need is a proper road.”

E M Munisamy, 42, a social worker and a native of Nekkanamalai, said, “ The hardships faced by the villagers cannot be explained in words. Not even an ambulance or hearse van can make it to the village. For generations, we carry sick people or the dead in cloth cradles to the nearest city.”

Recently in December 2019, after the death of a villager, Munusamy, his body was carried to the village in a cloth cradle for his funeral, that too during the night time.

After TOI carried a report, collector Sivan Arul had visited the village and assured construction of a road at the earliest. “Our perennial demand is contruction of a proper road between Nekkanamalai and Vaniyambadi. It will solve most of our problems,” Munisamy said.

Speaking to TOI, Sivan Arul said, “We have deployed donkeys to carry the Pongal gift hampers to reduce hassles of the Nekkanamalai villagers. On Thursday the gifts will be distributed to the beneficiaries from the Nekkanamalai PDS shop.”

He said a proposal seeking fund to construct a road covering 300m distance in revenue area, 5,525m in forest area and 1,323m in plain land between Komanampatti Junction and Nekkanamalai had been sent to the department of rural development.

Title: Madurai: Corporation intervenes, restores water supply to hostel in a day
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The hostels had been getting only limited quantity of water due to some faulty connections

MADURAI: Madurai Municipal Corporation has set right faulty water connections to a girls’ hostel in Chinna Chokkikulam run by the Adi Dravida Welfare Department within 24 hours after it was brought to the knowledge of the officials.

As many as 680 girls studying in various schools and colleges in Madurai are staying in the hostel. There are seven separate hostels for school, college and polytechnic students functioning on the same campus. While the number of students staying on the campus is high, the hostels have been getting only limited quantity of water due to some faulty connections.

S Malaisamy, a high court lawyer and B Pandiaraja, member, Dalit Vigilance and Monitoring Committee met Madurai Corporation commissioner S Visakan on Monday evening and handed over a petition explaining the plight being faced by the students in the hostel. “The commissioner immediately ordered to set right the problem over phone in front of us. Work started on Tuesday and the issue was set right,” Pandiaraja said.

Pandiaraja said that the issue was with two connections, which were given through the backside of the hostel buildings. Due to sewage leak, the pipe carried sewage mixed water, which could not be used by students. They faced water shortage as water was supplied through only one line through the front side of the building. Now all the three connections have been routed through the front side of the buildings.

Visakan said that he also given instruction to provide new connections as per the requirement of the hostel. The work on new connection has already been taken up by the officials concerned, he said.

Title: ‘Money, houses for Gandhi ashram dwellers’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The central and state governments have chalked out an elaborate plan to redevelop the ashram and convert it in... Read More

GANDHINAGAR: The state government plans to provide alternate housing facilities and even monetary compensation to families who have been living on land owned by various trusts around the Sabarmati Ashram. The central and state governments have chalked out an elaborate plan to redevelop the ashram and convert it into a tourist attraction.

Claiming ownership rights to their houses, residents of the ashram as well as those around it have been protesting against the acquisition of land by the government, contending that Mahatma Gandhi himself had given their forefathers space to stay there.

A top official in the state government said that in a bid to preserve Hriday Kunj (the house where Mahatma Gandhi stayed), the entire ashram complex will require redevelopment. “There are private houses, a girl’s hostel, a state tourism department hotel, petty shops and other establishments within the ashram complex. People park their vehicles in close proximity of Hriday Kunj. The state government has decided to offer alternate homes as well as monetary compensation for those who will be displaced because of redevelopment of the complex,” the officer said. He added that all private buildings, including Toran hotel, will be removed as part of the redevelopment plan. Elaborating on future plans for the ashram, the official said the government intends to develop the whole complex in such a way that visitors can spend three to four hours and get a comprehensive understanding of Gandhiji, India’s freedom struggle and various key milestones in the life of the Mahatma.

“All the trusts working in premises of the Sabarmati Ashram and a proposed new entity will take over management of the proposed new Gandhi Ashram complex,’’ the official added. Allaying fears raised from several quarters, mainly over ownership of land, the official said, “The interests of every stakeholder will be considered before redevelopment work is taken up. The plan will be presented before Prime Minister Narendra Modi soon, after which action will be undertaken.”

Title: Mayor, office-bearers from BJP meet Fadnavis
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

PUNE: BJP officer bearers, including mayor Muralidhar Mohol, standing committee chairman Hemant Rasne and leader of the house Dheeraj Ghate, recently met former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis in Mumbai.

They said it was a courtesy visit but party insiders said the changed political equations in the state had prompted them to meet Fadnavis to discuss a strategy for the next two years to ensure that the party continues its dominance in the PMC.

With over 95 corporators, BJP is in complete command in the PMC. The party is set to face a united opposition from Shiv Sena , NCP and Congress ahead of the 2022 civic polls. It is also likely to be challenged while getting support from the Sena-led state government for executing civic projects.

A senior leader from the BJP said, “There was good coordination between the civic body and the state government till Diwali. However, the equations changed at the state level in the last two months. We are no more in the driving seat there,” he said.

The leader said the next two years were crucial for the party as it will have to come out with a good performance in the city. Party leaders, especially corporators, will have to maintain the momentum and keep themselves engaged with citizens.

Mohol, who was the standing committee chairman, said the meeting with Fadnavis was a courtesy call and had no political agenda. “Since the party has introduced new officer-bearers in the PMC, we decided to meet Fadnavis and the other leaders of our party to seek their guidance on various issues. Every corporator of our party in the PMC is working hard for the city’s development,” Mohol said.

Sources from political circles said the outcome of the state elections is likely to impact political developments in the city. An NCP leader said, “ The assembly results and Ajit Pawar as the guardian minister have recharged our party workers. People are fed up with the BJP and are looking for a change,” the leader said.

Title: Ahmedabad: Bail denied to Asha Foundation trustee
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A city sessions court on Wednesday denied anticipatory bail to Harmesh Bhatt, one of the organizers of an NGO, Asha Foundation, in connection with charges of selling livestock that a court had remanded in the custody of the NGO.

In December, some 1,360 goats and sheep were impounded by Ramol police and handed over to Asha Foundation for keeping until the case for animal cruelty was decided by court. A few days later, some of the animals were spotted at the Ranip Bakra Mandi on sale. The owners complained at different police stations that their livestockhad gone missing, said the complainant’s advocate, Shamshad Pathan.

The police in Ramol, Odhav and Naroda arrested a few persons. At the same time, the organizers of the NGO, Amit Bhavsar, Vinu Salat and Bhatt applied for pre-arrest bail.

The court has already refused protection to Bhavsar and Salat. Additional sessions judge V J Kalotara refused bail to Bhatt on Wednesday, after Ramol police told the court that the foundation’s claims about handing over custody of the animals to various cattle pounds were not all true. The animals were handed over to the Idar panjrapol, which claimed that the animals were then given to a panjarapol in Deesa. On inquiry, the Deesa panjarapol denied having received the animals.

Title: Strike total and peaceful in Kerala
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

A couple during a ‘save the date’ photoshoot at SM Street in Kozhikode on Wednesday

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The nation-wide strike called by the various trade unions virtually turned into a hartal in the state. With KSRTC buses, private buses, taxis and auto rickshaws keeping off the roads, shops and establishments remaining closed and government offices, banks and educational institutions shut, life was paralysed across the state.

The strike was peaceful with no major law and order issue being reported in the state. Though pro-BJP trade union BMS stayed away from the strike, the impact was not visible as a majority of workers in the state are affiliated to unions under CITU, AITUC and INTUC.

All ministers, including the chief minister, stayed away from the office at the Secretariat. Finance minister Thomas Isaac didn’t attend Soorya festival, a cultural event he had committed to, on Wednesday. Devaswom minister Kadakampally Surendran shunned his official car and rode a scooter to the protest meeting of the trade unions in the state capital. The joint protest rally organized by employees to the Secretariat was inaugurated by CITU general secretary Elamaram Kareem.

The KSRTC did not operate regular services in the state. However, the bus service to Pampa was not affected and Sabarimala witnessed a huge crowd on the strike day. Though train services were not affected, those who alighted at the railway stations were stranded for want of vehicles to reach their destinations.

In the state capital, the police operated services to the medical college, regional cancer centre, airport and to other important destinations.

In Ernakulam, Kunnathunadu police registered two cases of attacks during the strike. Two shop owners, in separate incidents, were injured after strike supporters forced them to down shutters.

Elamaram Kareem, S Vijayakuamra Nair of the joint council and INTUC state president R Chandrashekar thanked the people for supporting the strike. K K Divakaran, general secretary of All India Road Transport Worker’s Federation said the strike was total in the state and about 3.5 crore workers and owners in the transport industry across the country participated.

Meanwhile, BJP came out against the strike terming it a government-sponsored one. “Labour strike by a section of trade unions swelled into a hartal in Kerala with the active support of the CPM-led state government,” said BJP spokesperson M S Kumar.

“Police stood mute witness to atrocities in connection with the strike. It’s a paradox that the state government supplied fodder to a shutdown strike ahead of the state hosting a global investor’s meet. Politically motivated actions of the state government would only help drive away investors. The attack on Muthoot M D George Alexander is a telling example of the plight of investors in Kerala,” he added.

Title: Roorkee: Village head was murdered by contract killers hired by old enemy
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

ROORKEE: Police on Wednesday said it had solved the murder of Qamar Alam, the 50-year old village head of Nagla Kubda village near Roorkee , who was shot dead on December 20. According to police, Alam had an old enmity with a man Abeed Ahmed, who hired Muzaffarnagar-based shooters to murder him. Police have arrested the three shooters who allegedly carried out the murder.

According to inspector Rajesh Sah of Gangnahar police station, the enmity between Alam and Ahmed dated back to 2010, when the latter killed Alam’s older brother. Alam then retaliated by having Ahmed’s younger brother Farukh killed in 2012. “Due to this ongoing enmity, Ahmed hired contract killers for Rs 10 lakh to eliminate Alam,” said Sah. Police said that Ahmed paid Wasim, a history-sheeter from Muzaffarnagar Rs 10 lakh to kill Alam. Wasim then assigned the task to his brothers Naim and Salmaan and their friend Dilshad. On December 20, when Alam was returning from Roorkee court, two bike-borne men emerged at the gate and shot him from a close range

Title: BJP MP held hostage at Visva-Bharati
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

SANTINIKETAN: BJP Rajya Sabha member and writer Swapan Dasgupta was forcibly confined to an auditorium at Visva-Bharati in Santiniketan for almost five hours on Wednesday as students protesting against the new citizenship law stood outside, shouting slogans and refusing to let him leave.

Dasgupta had vice-chancellor Bidyut Chakrabarty for company inside the auditorium, whose collapsible gate was locked from outside by the protesters.

After his ordeal ended, Dasgupta tweeted: "Drama ends in Visva-Bharati without the confrontation that some protesters desperately wanted."

The siege was reminiscent of the hostility Union minister Babul Supriyo had faced from students at Jadavpur University when he visited the campus for an event on September 19. But unlike Supriyo, who was allegedly manhandled, Dasgupta apparently didn't face any violence.

"How does it feel to have a mob attack a peaceful meeting on CAA ...? This is what is happening to a meeting I am addressing at Visva Bharati now. Locked into room now with a howling mob outside, itching for confrontation," Dasgupta had tweeted from captivity after some students allegedly scaled a wall and shouted slogans through the windows.

The gherao at Visva-Bharati started around 4.30pm and was lifted at 9.25pm, minutes after governor Jagdeep Dhankhar contacted DGP Virendra. "Such anarchy and failure of law and order are worrisome," Dhankhar tweeted.

During the protest against Supriyo at JU, the governor had rushed to the south Kolkata campus to escort him out of the campus. "I had come on an invitation from the university to speak at a lecture series on CAA. This was not a political forum. If someone does this, it only reflects an attitude that goes against the principles of democratic thinking. I had expected the students to participate in the seminar and oppose CAA. It could have been a healthy discussion. Initially, the seminar was planned at Lipika auditorium. But later, the venue was shifted because I was told there were chances of confrontation. But we didn't want any confrontation," Dasgupta said.

Somnath Sow, an SFI leader, accused vice-chancellor Chakrabarty of precipitating the stand-off. "The VC organised the seminar on a day the entire country was protesting against CAA-NPR-NRC. He invited Swapan Dasgupta as the sole speaker at the seminar," he said.

The protesters had assembled at the university's central office hours before the scheduled start of the seminar at 10.30am, locking the gates and hanging posters bearing slogans against PM Narendra Modi and CAA. At 2pm, they moved to the main entrance of the auditorium and blocked the gate before Dasgupta arrived to speak at 3pm. Sensing the mood, the university authorities shifted the venue to an auditorium on the Sriniketan campus, about a kilometre away.

The protesters came to know about the venue change 45 minutes later and reached there at 4.30pm. Around 6pm, Visva-Bharati officials tried to persuade the students to disperse, but they wouldn't listen.

Suchitra Bhattacharya, a professor in the department of economics and politics, said the situation could have been avoided. "We had urged the VC to shift the seminar to a different date and invite a panel of speakers instead of just one. The VC didn't pay heed to our request. He only invited Dasgupta."

With the stir continuing into the night, Trinamool functionaries started sending feelers to the Visva-Bharati protesters that being a central university, the CISF was in charge of its security. "While the VC didn't call CISF to clear the protesters, there was a chance of disturbance and confrontation from the outside," a Trinamool leader said.

BJP national secretary Kailash Vijayvargiya said in a video message: "Our Rajya Sabha member Swapan Dasgupta is being held up at Visva-Bharati for hours. Police haven't taken steps as yet. If anything happens to the MP, things will get out of control."

Title: 175 shisham trees felled illegally in Pilibhit forest
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Pilibhit: More than 175 matured shisham and Jamun trees were allegedly cut and smuggled from Haripur forest range of the Pilibhit Tiger Reserve, according to superintendent of police Abhishek Dixit, who busted a nexus between forest department personnel and smugglers.

The SP said, “It was a well-planned conspiracy by the smugglers who managed to obtain the forest and wildlife division’s permit for cutting trees standing in the agricultural fields close to the forest area. However, gradually they started cutting trees in the forest area in collusion with the range officer and field staff.”

According to the SP, the exchequer suffered a loss of over Rs 5 crore; besides, it also harmed the forest’s ecology.

“The forest and wildlife division had issued eight permits on December 18, of which only one was found to be genuine. Of the remaining seven, four permits issued for the agricultural field which was eroded by the Sharda and the standing trees washed away,” said Dixit.

PTR deputy director Naveen Khandelwal said shisham trees were cut in a vast area of over 200 hectares in the PTR’s Haripur forest range, where migrants from eastern UP were rehabilitated nearly 30 years ago. “The area is saturated with shisham trees mostly over 100 years old. The valuable trees could not be freed from trespassers and we brought the matter to the knowledge of the high court as well.”

As the police department needed the land record during the inquiry, the matter was referred to district magistrate Vaibhav Shrivastav, who set up an inquiry by Pilibhit Sadar SDM Vandana Trivedi.

“We are waiting for the report for lodging an FIR in the matter. However, we have seized the remaining stock of timber,” added the SP.

Asked about the SDM’s findings, the DM said, “She has been promoted to the city magistrate and transferred to Banda district. Now, I will hand over the inquiry to another officer. This completion of inquiry may take some time.”

Title: Pune: Road resurfacing to benefit techies at Hinjewadi IT park
Content:
PCMC has begun resurfacing potholes on the road in Wakad, which leads to Hinjewadi IT Park.

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The daily commute of thousands of IT professionals from Pimpri Chinchwad to Hinjewadi IT park is expected to become easier since the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) has begun resurfacing potholes on the road in Wakad .The road from Bhumkar Chowk on Pune-Bengaluru highway to Hinjewadi IT park phase II sees a lot of traffic during peak hours.While there is a four-lane road until Laxmi Chowk in Marunji village, there are two stretches on this route that are heavily damaged. Commuting on the route is a nightmare.The first stretch is from Euro School to Pumpkin Patch School and the other is near Vinode Vasti, particularly from near Hotel Mastiff to Hotel Aditya OYO.Both 200-300 metre stretches are rather treacherous due to the condition of the road. The absence of a divider adds to the commuters’ woes.Shirish Poredi, spokesperson of the civic body’s engineering department, said, “There were land acquisition problems due to which we could not widen and tar the road properly. We have been able to acquire one stretch of 150 metre and will tar this land to create a road. We have also repaired the potholes near Pumpkin Patch School in Wakad.”“Pothole repair work in other areas will be completed in a fortnight. There is still land acquisition problem in some parts due to which we cannot widen the road and tar it,” he said.Sagar Baheti, who lives near Bhumkar Chowk, said, “Minor accidents involving two-wheelers occur regularly as they skid due to the potholes and gravel. Further the vehicles move slowly due to the potholes causing traffic snarls. We had expected that the PCMC begin pothole repairing work immediately after the end of monsoon . People have had to suffer hardships due to the delay.”Another local resident Mihir Mistry said, “The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) must complete the land acquisition quickly for widening the road to reduce the traffic congestion on this busy road linking the city to Hinjewadi IT park.”

Title: IT audit of Hi-Tech School from today
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The efficiency audit of the Hi-Tech School project, in which 45,000 classrooms in the state were technologically upgraded, will begin on January 9.

As the initial step of the IT audit, the institution heads (principals & headmasters) were asked to provide details of the respective schools through an online system. The IT audit is being conducted under the aegis of KITE (Kerala Infrastructure and Technology for Education).

The IT audit covers all the 4,752 government and aided secondary schools. In the survey for teachers, monitoring of classroom activities using digital tools, usage pattern of Samagra resource portal in classrooms, efficiency of digital resources provided to schools, need for further trainings, unique activities of schools using ICT, etc., are included. Ahead of the IT audit, 68,000 teachers have provided the details.

In the questionnaire for school heads, details such as the actual usage of digital mechanisms, details of lesson plans and reflection notes through Samagra portal, basic IT facilities, IT labs, complaint redressal mechanisms of equipment, real time review of internet connectivity and networking, data usage, etc, have been included. As part of the IT audit, data will be collected from an average of 10 students from each school on the effectiveness of learning activities using digital resources, usage and maintenance of equipment, etc.

“As per the MoU signed between the schools and KITE for the implementation of Hi-Tech School project, the usage of digital resources in classrooms, whether the equipment was properly taken care of, will be inspected specifically through the IT audit. KITE will complete the IT audit for all schools in January and the report will be submitted to the government,” said K Anvar Sadath, chief executive officer, KITE.

Title: Ensure effective functioning of STPs in highrises: GCDA to corporation
Content: KOCHI: The Greater Cochin Development Authority ( GCDA ) hit back at Kochi Corporation for the latter’s inability in ensuring effective functioning of sewage treatment plants (STPs) in high-rises across the city.GCDA chairman V Salim said in the wake of the demolition of four apartment complexes at Maradu , the local body ought to be extremely responsible in issuing building permits and also in ensuring that sewage does not flow into the backwaters.With the Corporation filing an affidavit in the high court highlighting the case of 65 outlets or pipelines to the backwaters from apartment buildings and commercial structures constructed along the Marine Drive walkway, he said, “It clearly exposes the local body’s lackadaisical approach. If buildings do not have STPs, then Corporation should initiate penal measures and legal action against them. Instead, they are blaming the GCDA and are avoiding responsibilities.”For obtaining building permits from the Corporation, builders have to produce a service plan for power/water connection and sewage while submitting applications, as per Kerala Municipal Building Rules (KMBR). The builders or apartment owners’ association is responsible for timely renewal of the approvals granted by the Kerala state pollution control board. “The local body has to check whether the building has obtained renewed certificates,” he said.On a question regarding the functioning of the STP at Marine Drive, Salim said GCDA convened a meeting of occupants of both commercial and residential structures on the old walkway. The plant has been set up to serve buildings on the old walkway. He said that it has come to GCDA’s attention that many buildings on the old stretch have not been connected to the STP. Some of them have not paid their share of money for using the facility. “In such cases the waste water is mostly pumped directly to the backwaters through underground pipes. Building owners are avoiding expenses related to the operation of a sewage treatment plant. GCDA has started to collect data relating to those using the plant and its operations,” added Salim.According to GCDA, most of the apartment complexes are located on the new stretch of the walkway from Old Boat Jetty at HC junction to Goshree bridge. “These are all new structures and these buildings should have an effectively functioning STPs,” said Salim.GCDA also said the corporation should publish a list of high-rises which do not have STPs, and those buildings which have not renewed the permits of pollution control board. The health wing of the local body can take the initiative to inspect buildings in all zones. Such a measure would also bring in positive results for the efforts taken to clean the Thevara-Perandoor canal.

Title: Dehradun: Why are roads repaired shoddily year on year?
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The state of Raipur road

DEHRADUN: The roads in the state capital are claimed to be repaired by the Public Works Department (PWD) throughout the year. However, it doesn’t seem to show, as most roads either have potholes or their top surface is eroding, highlighting the shoddy quality of repair work that has been done. As per data provided by PWD officials, the department repaired 93 kilometers of main roads — connecting Dehradun to other parts of Uttarakhand , Himachal Pradesh, New Delhi and Uttar Pradesh — while carrying out patchworks on an almost 104 kilometer-stretch within Dehradun district in 2019. In 2018, the department claims to have repaired 198 kilometers of highway roads against their target of 263 kilometers as well as carrying out patchwork and new road construction in around 21.6 kilometers.

Residents say that money spent by the department seems to be getting wasted year on year. “PWD spends lakhs in constructing roads and filling up the dug-up patches. Still, the roads here in Dehradun, even though it is the state capital, wear a shoddy look,” said Vineet Semwal, a resident of Race Course.

Many feel that the biggest reason for the shoddy work is poor material quality and lack of monitoring. “The contractors often use poor quality material. There is no mechanism to monitor the work of the contractor and they take advantage of this loophole. PWD should blacklist the contractors who do shoddy work which is the only way to inculcate fear among those responsible for road construction,” said Naveen Kumar Sadana of Waste Warriors, an NGO involved in waste management and other civic issues.

So, what are the possible solutions? According to Sadana, MLP (multi-layer plastic) roads should become the norm in the city as these roads have longer durability and less maintenance cost.

“Back in 2016-17, the road near Dehradun Club was turned into an MLP road and PWD data reveals that it incurred the least amount of maintenance cost. However, I believe the contractors are not interested in MLP roads as it is highly unlikely they will get another contract for the same road soon,” he said.

According to Ashish Garg, a civil engineer and resident of Kewal Vihar, the solution lies in constructing roads after completely scratching the dug-up and dilapidated road.

“PWD keeps on constructing new roads over the already existing ones. This is the reason why, in many areas like Canal Road, the roads are getting elevated while level of houses has gone down. Re-layering also affects the quality of roads which is happening rapidly in Dehradun,” said Garg.

PWD officials meanwhile chose to put the blame on other departments.

BN Chaudhary, senior engineer, PWD, alleged, “We construct roads and then officials of other departments dig it up again. There are many examples. After the monsoons, we had constructed the road near Astley Hall but the Jan Sansthan dug it up again to lay sewage pipeline. We have just constructed roads in Rajpur area and now received a letter from GAIL that they will be digging the road again to lay CNG pipeline. How many times are we are expected to construct a road in a year? There should be better co-ordination between departments.”

Whatever be the excuses that are being put forth, there can be no excuse for shoddy roads in the state capital. All talk of making Doon a smart city will be hollow unless the government sincerely focuses on making the city’s roads smooth — and ensure that they remain so.

Title: Public demand, cost-cutting make metro rail tweak design of stations in north Chennai
Content:
