Changes in design were made to the stations to cut cost and speed up construction without compromising on comm... Read More

CHENNAI: From small stations where people will walk straight to the platforms to buy tickets to massive underground stations with four-level shopping arenas and spartan interiors — metro stations in North Chennai will have a new look and feel when the Washermenpet to Wimco Nagar line will be commissioned in six months.Changes in design were made to the stations to cut cost and speed up construction without compromising on commuter comfort.“We have made changes to make stations smaller and smarter, but the passenger area will be the same in terms of size,” a metro rail official said. “Track and electrical traction work will be completed by February. We will need four months for trials. We will be ready for a June or July opening and we expect 30% to 40% more passengers,” said a metro rail official.The line will have six elevated and three underground stations. Changes were made to the stations because of protests by locals for various reasons. For instance, commuters will directly walk into the platforms of the elevated Gowri Ashram metro station built at a height of 17m as CMRL did away with concourse or ticketing level and raised the elevation of the corridor to ensure the line does not hinder the movement of a temple car during festivals. The average height of the elevated corridor is 13m while the height was increased only in Gowri Ashram station, making it the tallest station on the stretch.Access to this station will be through a foot over-bridge with stairs and escalators sandwiched between a row of shops on the narrow and congested Thiruvottiyur High Road.At the Theagaraya College underground station it’s a quid pro quo. Metro rail officials said they would give the college access to the columns of the station to raise another structure. The station is being built under the college playground about 100m away from the main road with an 80m underground passage for commuter entry. The college students protested against CMRL for taking over their college land for construction of the station. “If the college plans to build a four-storey building above our station box, they could raise pillars from our columns and our station already has a foundation to hold the structure,” said an engineer at the site.While construction on top of underground station boxes are otherwise not allowed, those in north Chennai have been built with a four-level shopping area which could be accessed both by commuters and shoppers.The interiors of the stations will have a raw design with no false ceiling but black painted roofs holding the cables and air-conditioning ducts in place. “We were able to make stations 25% smaller than those in phase-1 by incorporating changes in the equipment like procuring smaller vertical exhaust fans that would now be installed in the shaft jutting out to the road level inside of placing them in a separate room like it is in phase-1 station,” an official said.

Title: Special children win volleyball championships
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

PUDUCHERRY: Puducherry boys bagged the 7th national junior and sub-junior volleyball championships for the deaf held at Calicut in Kerala . Puducherry girls finished runners-up in the national sub-junior championships.

The boys' and girls' teams comprised differently-abled students of Anandha Rangapillai government special higher secondary school. Puducherry junior boys outplayed Gujarat in the finals of the championship while Puducherry sub-junior boys overcame stiff competition from Kerala to lift the sub-junior national title.

Puducherry sub-junior girls went down fighting against Kerala in the finals and must be content with the runners-up title.

Last year Puducherry girls won the junior national volleyball championship for the deaf held at Chennai. Puducherry sub-junior girls finished runners-up in the nationals last year.

Welfare minister M Kandasamy, secretary (welfare) R Alice Vaz, director (social welfare) K Sarangapani and deputy director cum field officer D Kalavathi lauded the students for their achievement and team coach S Santhosh and special teachers M Shanmugavelu, S Lourdes Seliane Eliza and A Vasanthimala for their guidance.

Title: Uttrakhand: Two killed in Champawat accident
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

UTTRAKHAND: Two persons identified as Manoj singh (25) and Puran Nath (59) were killed when their vehicle fell into a gorge at Chaturkot on Champawat Tamli road on Tuesday night. Three persons were travelling in the car from Manch to Champawat on Tuesday night. “Around 8pm, when they reached Chartukot, 20km from Champawat, the car got stuck in mud. One of the persons, Gaurav, got out of the car and tried pushing it out of the mud. In the process, the driver lost control and the car tumbled down a 150 meter deep gorge,” said Champawat SP Lokeswar Singh. Local residents informed police and carried the injured persons to the district hospital in Champawat, where doctors declared them dead.

Title: Railway passengers lose sleep over bedbugs at Pune station dormitory
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

File photo of the dormitory at the Pune railway station

PUNE: Bedbugs are forcing passengers to spend sleepless nights at the dormitory of the Pune railway station.

Responding to complaints, the authorities have promised extermination of the pests in the next two months.

“There have been some complaints related to cleanliness. A tender has been floated to hand over the facility to an independent agency. Within a month, it will be finalised and things will change. The selected contractor will draw up a plan on development of the dormitory. We are hoping that things will be in order by March,” said a source at the Indian Railways Stations Development Corporation (IRSDC) which looks after the facility management of the Pune station.

Ajay Sahani, who lives in Nagpur and travels to Pune frequently, said he spends sleepless nights at the dormitory.

“The main issue is with bedbugs. With the facility to be given to a private party, we hope that things will improve,” he said.

In May last year, the officials of the BVG Group, appointed by the IRSDC for facility management at the station, told TOI that the commercialisation of the dormitory was on the anvil and there could be a possibility of hike in booking charges.

“The idea is to upgrade the dormitory. A plan to properly brand the dormitory of the Pune station is being prepared,” an official said.

Another passenger said, “If the charges are increased nominally, we are okay with it but the services need to improve. How can one sleep on beds full of bugs? Besides, there is the problem of low water pressure in one of the washrooms.”

The Pune station has a 26-bed dormitory at present.

In addition, there are six beds with air-conditioned facility.

One can log on to eRail.in and book beds at the facility. The rates are Rs200 for 12 hours and Rs400 for 24 hours.

“The contract will be given to someone specialising in the field and the proposal as to how the facilities could be improved at the dormitory would be studied carefully,” the official asserted.

Harsha Shah, president, Railway Pravasi Group, said that such services needed to be perfect right from the start.

“It was said things would be improved from May last year, but nothing has been done in the past 9 months. By now, the facility should have been perfect considering that the station is now in private hands,” he said.

Title: Ahead of April 1 deadline, Chennai begins to get BSVI fuel
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Indian Oil has six fuel terminals in the state, one each in Tondiarpet, Korukkupet, Trichy, Madurai, Sankaridu... Read More

CHENNAI: With April 1 being the deadline to switch over to cleaner BSVI-compliant auto fuels, select pumps in Chennai have begun to dispense the upgraded petrol and diesel with a target of complete conversion in Tamil Nadu by February.

The country will migrate to BSVI fuel standards from April 1 from the present BSIV. BSVI fuel will bring down sulphur content by five times from the current BSIV levels. It has 10 PPM of sulphur as against 50PPM now.

By reducing toxic substances in the air, it will help reduce air pollution, besides reducing NOx, high levels of which can cause respiratory problems. The lower sulphur will help reduce harmful exhaust emissions like NO2, CO and SO2.

Indian Oil has six fuel terminals in the state, one each in Tondiarpet, Korukkupet, Trichy, Madurai , Sankaridurg and Coimbatore. The Korukkupet terminal, which feeds pumps in Central and South Chennai, has already begun to dispense BSVI fuel.

“We started the conversion to BSVI last November. We have almost completed all the BSVI related work at our end and by February everything will be BSVI,” said P Jayadevan, executive director, Tamil Nadu and Puducherry , Indian Oil. All the fuel terminals of Indian Oil are almost ready except Coimbatore which will be fed with BPCL fuel from Kochi Refinery.

“We don’t think there will be an appreciable increase in pump prices due to this as international prices dictate fuel pricing,” he said. “The best part of BSVI is that it will completely eliminate adulteration possibilities. As we stand now, fuel adulteration is a thing of the past.”

Existing BSIV vehicle users do not need to tweak or modify or worry about the new fuel. “There is no need to change anything in your old vehicle. These can run on the upgraded fuels,” he said adding that vehicle owners will not be able to feel any difference while driving or riding.

Title: PMC permits home-based business without licence
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Here is a news for home-based entrepreneurs to cheer about. They can run their business without the corporation’s permission. Better still, they will not have to pay a penny as fees.

The Pune Municipal Corporation ( PMC ) has decided not to make licences mandatory for home-based businesses, including beauty parlours. According to the corporation officials, the decision was taken in the standing committee meeting during the discussion on licence fees on Tuesday.

A proposal to increase the fees for beauty parlours, hospitals, hotels, eateries and clinics was tabled before the standing committee. The proposal had suggested a hike in charges for licence to keep dogs and other pets, too.

“The elected members of the PMC decided not to go for a hike and keep the fees as they were. The proposal to increase the fees was rejected,” said a senior official of the PMC.

The elected members claimed that the decision to keep the domestic enterprises out of the purview of the licence regime was taken to prevent any hassles for the operators.

“Most of those who operate these businesses belong to the middle or lower middle class. They cannot afford to start big set-ups and their aim is to give a helping hand to the family. Many women run these enterprises. So, the decision of not charging any fees has been taken,” said Hemant Rasane, the chairman of the standing committee.

He said the health department and other civic departments used to give permits to the businesses that operated out of homes. But now they would be exempted from seeking such permits.

Many small entrepreneurs hailed the decision of the corporation. “This will help me concentrate more on my business, without worrying about permits,” said a woman, who runs a stitching business from home.

A senior official of the PMC said the home-based entrepreneurs would have to follow the set norms of the PMC though they would not have to seek permit from it.

“These ventures should not be operated by flouting the norms of the civic body. They should not function out of illegal premises. The establishments should be encroachment-free. Besides, they should not violate any rules of building permissions or property tax ,” said, adding that the PMC would maintain a record of such enterprises.

Title: NCM seeks report from PWD, fin secys
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: National Commission for Minorities (NCM) has sought reports from principal secretaries of state finance and PWD secretaries on a complaint of harassment filed by social activist Jomon Puthenpurackal. In a petition filed to NCM vice-chairman George Kurian, Jomon alleged that both PWD and finance departments were haunting him by forging fake reports, asking him to pay hefty amount as fine for overstay in PWD guest houses.

The petitioner alleged that he was being targeted as he belonged to Knanaya Catholic community and has been fighting for justice in the Sister Abhaya murder case. He alleged that the officials conspired and harassed him over the issue of paying rent. According to Puthenpurackal, he was asked to pay Rs 42,670 as rent arrears to the government by the PWD buildings assistant engineer on July 12, 2019. He alleged that the notice was the result of vendetta by the officials as he had filed some complaints against senior officials of PWD and finance departments.

By submitting supporting documents, Puthenpurackal said a department level enquiry conducted by the PWD concluded that he didn’t need to pay any arrears as that had been a fault of officials who hadn’t charged the rent as per norms at the time of stay. He said the PWD issued a notice by ignoring this report with a clear intention of harassment. The NCM asked both officials to file their reports within three weeks. tnn

Title: Power dept employees protest privatisation bid, seek revival of old pension scheme
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Bareilly: Power department employees on Wednesday held a protest against the UP governments’ bid to privatise the electricity distribution and demanded revival of the old pension scheme.

In Bareilly division, around 300 power department employees under the banner of Vidyut Karamchari Sanyukt Sangharsh Samiti, UP, staged protests at respective regional offices. Nearly, 15 lakh power department employees working with various distribution companies under UPPCL participated in the one-day nationwide strike.

Gaurav Sharma, co-coordinator of Vidyut Karamchari Sanyukt Sangharsh Samiti, told TOI, “Nearly, 300 employees under Bareilly division — including Bareilly, Pilibhit, Budaun and Shahjahanpur — joined the protest at their respective offices. Our demands included the rollback of the UP government’s decision to privatise power distribution, withdrawal of the regressive changes being made in the Labour Law, and cancelling the contract of power distribution franchise in Agra and privatisation in Greater Noida, among others. Besides, the old pension scheme should be revived and should apply to the employees joining services post-2000.”

Madhyanchal Vidyut Vitran Nigam Limited (MVVNL) superintendent engineer (rural) Tariq Jalil said, “The privatisation experiment has failed in Agra and it should be taken as a lesson. The government says the move is aimed at improvising power distribution and minimising the loss, but we are already giving 24-hour supply in urban areas and working on replicating it in the rural areas as well. Privatisation, therefore, is unnecessary.”

Due to protest, the departmental works remained suspended from 10am to 5pm, causing inconvenience to consumers; electricity bills could not be paid as the counters remained shutting, while complaints such as power-cuts and break-downs were not entertained throughout the day.

Title: MLA, collector lock horns over flood rehabilitation
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Malappuram: A tussle is brewing between Malappuram district collector Jafar Malik and Nilambur MLA P V Anvar over the rehabilitation of flood-affected tribal families in Kavalappara and Pothukallu regions of Nilambur.

The issue started when Anvar on Tuesday alleged lapses on the part of the collector in rehabilitating flood-affected tribal families of Kavalappara. The MLA along with a group of tribal families in Kavalappara blocked the construction works of houses being built for the flood-affected families at Chembankolli in Edakkara panchayat on Tuesday afternoon.

Construction of 34 houses on five acres in Edakkara panchayat using CSR fund of Federal Bank had begun last week. The revenue authorities were planning to rehabilitate flood-affected tribal families in Chalikkal Colony in Pothukallu panchayat, in these houses. The land was identified by the district administration and tribal development department. However, Anvar alleged that the revenue authorities did not discuss the plan of the project with people’s representatives. “Revenue authorties should give priority to rehabilitate tribal families in Kavalappara who are currently staying in an auditorium, instead of rehabilitating families in Chalikkal colony”, he said.

But the collector immediately responded to the MLA’s allegations through a social media post on Tuesday night. He said he will take legal action against the MLA for blocking construction. He said revenue authorities had offered the new houses in Edakkara to Kavalappara families. But they rejected the offer as they were not ready to move to another panchayat. Responding to the allegation of Anvar, the collector said there is no need to inform him procedures of land purchase as he is not part of purchasing committee.

But, on Wednesday the MLA said in a press meet that he would file a defamation case against the collector for making wrong statements against the Rebuild Nilambur programme, which was designed to collect money and land to help the flood victims. Collector, earlier made a comment that Rebuild Nilambur received 12 acres of land from a sponsor. However, P V Anvar challenged collector to prove his claim in the court.

Title: Nobel laureate Levitt’s boat cruise blocked
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Alappuzha: Nobel prize winner Michael Levitt was stranded in a houseboat after general strike supporters blocked the boat in which he was enjoying the beauty of Kuttanad in Alappuzha on Wednesday.

The organizers had exempted the tourism industry from the strike, but they blocked Levitt, a guest of the state government. “Levitt was miffed and told us he is a VIP guest, and its not fair blocking the houseboat even after the tourism industry was exempted from the strike. He had a bad impression of Kerala since this experience,” one of the boat crew told TOI.

Levitt began his cruise in a houseboat named ‘Lake View’ from Kumarakom in Kottayam on Tuesday evening and was anchored near R Block in Kuttanad for night halt.

“On Tuesday evening, the strike supporters asked us not to operate the boat. However, on Wednesday morning, we started our trip around 10am. Around 10.30am they stopped us. They asked us to anchor near C Block in Kuttanad and we did so,” an employee of the boat said. Around 12.30pm, the boat was allowed to continue the journey.

Levitt, an acclaimed biophysicist, received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2013 for the development of multi-scale models for complex chemical systems. Levitt called at Kerala University in Thiruvananthapuram on Monday and delivered a lecture at the department of Computational Biology and Bioinformatics on the Karyavattom campus.

Pulinkunnu police registered cases under Section 283 of the Indian Penal Code (Danger or obstruction in public way or line of navigation), IPC 342 (Punishment for wrongful confinement) and IPC 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention) against four strike supporters in connection with the incident.

Sub-inspector C Gopalakrishnan said that he had met Levitt but the Nobel laureate refused to lodge a complaint. “Levitt told me that he had read in newspapers that the tourism industry was exempted from the strike asked why the houseboat was blocked. But he was not ready to lodge a complaint,” said the sub-inspector. Police registered the case based on the complaint of the boat crew.

Achuthsankar S Nair, head of the Department of Computational Biology and Bioinformatics at University of Kerala, in his Facebook post said that Levitt mailed him after the houseboat was blocked by the strike supporters. His FB post read, “Prof Michael Levitt, Nobel laureate was a fan of Kerala till yesterday. Today, he was stopped from a pre-booked houseboat journey. He mailed me this: I have been warned against protesting to the union people who are illegally enforcing the strike against the union declaration that “tourism is excepted”. This treatment of a guest of the state government is not good for tourism, state, or the country.”

Sreekumar MP, the houseboat owner, said that his guest Levitt was upset after the boat was blocked . “He is disappointed. We had prepared special Kerala-style non-vegetarian dishes. But he could not enjoy his lunch. He will check out on Thursday morning at Kumarakom,” Sreekumar said.

Title: Madurai: Economic growth, big data in limelight at TIES conference
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Niti Aayog vice-chairman Dr Rajiv Kumar addresed various economic scholars from across the country at a nation... Read More

MADURAI: Big data solution is much-needed in India for accurate data collection and analysis, said Niti Aayog vice-chairman Dr Rajiv Kumar at the inaugural session of the 56th annual conference of The Indian Econometric Society (TIES) held in Madurai on Wednesday.

A three-day national conference jointly organized by TIES and School of Economics, Madurai Kamaraj University (MKU) was inaugurated at the university’s Nagamalai-Pudukottai campus.

Delivering the presidential address, professor Ravindra H Dholakia, member of RBI’s MPC, said “Inflation impacts economic growth . For our country to become a five trillion economy by 2024, we need at least 8% rate of growth. For such a result, our fiscal deficit target should be at 6.5% and the inflation target should be at 5.4%. We can only focus on one objective at a time.”

On the other hand, Dr C Rangarajan, former RBI governor who gave the Prof Sukhomoy Chakravarty memorial lecture, was of the opinion that threshold inflation could vary with differences in opinion and that inflation must never be out of control. “Inflation rate must not exceed 6% to avoid an adverse impact on economic growth. Price stability must be maintained while accelerating growth. Under threshold inflation, we should be able to adopt policies so as to promote other objectives. The RBI’s objectives and targets must be clear,” he added.

Around 150 delegates, all students / scholars of economics are participating in the conference this year. Various eminent speakers from across India will be addressing them over all three days and several technical sessions have also been planned.

Title: ASCEND just an eyewash: Chennithala
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala has come out against ASCEND 2020 global investors meet, which is beginning in Kochi on Thursday. While terming the meet as an eyewash, Ramesh said the government has only 11 more months in power and in this short period of time none of the projects that might come up in the meet are going to get implemented.

“The next assembly election is likely to happen in March or April, 2021. In between, the local body election will be held in November this year and Kuttanadu bypoll is also expected in another four months. Once the election notification is in place for all these polls, the government will only get 11 months for governance. How can they then implement any of the new projects which might come up in the investors meet,’’ he asked.

If the LDF government was sincere in the development projects, then it would have organised such an investors meet in the first or second year after assuming power. Now, the government will not even get time to have a preliminary discussion to execute the projects. Hence, the government is now organising this event to claim that they have attracted several investments during their tenure, Chennithala said.

The LDF government under Pinarayi Vijayan was a total failure in the development front and they cannot even claim a single major development project was commenced during their tenure. “When Thiruvanchoor Radhakrishnan had asked a question to the chief minister in the assembly in September, 2019 about the major infrastructure and development projects launched in the state under the LDF rule, the answer given was ‘details are being collected’. A government, which cannot even collect the details of the projects they have carried out even after four years in power, is fooling the people by organising such an event,” said Chennithala. LDF has flayed the previous UDF government for organising global investors meet in Kochi. “When the UDF government had organised such events, LDF had boycotted and campaigned against them,” he said. Even several of the projects executed by the previous UDF government were taken into a slow pace under the present LDF government, he said.

It has become the habit of LDF to oppose such investors meet and block all the investments raising protests when they are in the opposition and then come back with an investors meet when they are in power to fool the people of the state. The fate of Vizhinjam port, Smart City project in Kochi and national highway development are the perfect examples of their double standards, said the opposition leader.

Title: Madurai: Woman murdered before her daughters
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: A 33-year-old woman was murdered by some unidentified persons when she was sleeping in her house. The incident took place in Bharathi Ula Road near Thamaraithotti in the city early on Wednesday morning.

The deceased was identified as K Lavanya, a mother of two girls aged 14 and five years respectively. Her mother-in-law M Seeniammal alias Jayanthi suffered stab injuries on her neck and was admitted in a hospital. Lavanya’s husband M Kumaraguru is running a utensil shop in East Veli Street.

According to police sources, two unidentified persons, who came on a bike entered the house at 3.50am. They first attacked Seeniammal, who was sleeping in the hall. Then they went to the first floor, where Lavanya was sleeping in a bedroom along with her daughters. The duo hacked and stabbed her using sharp weapons.

Police said that while her younger daughter froze on seeing the brutal attack, her elder daughter rushed to the ground floor and alerted her father, who was sleeping in a separate room. By the time Kumaraguru reached the first floor, the murderers escaped. He found his wife lying dead on the bed. He alerted the police and shifted his mother to a private hospital.

The Tallakulam police registered a case. Deputy commissioner of police (law and order) E Karthick visited the house and hospital and conducted an inquiry.

Police said they are yet to find out the motive behind the incident and the perpetrators involved. They had analysed CCTV footage available in nearby places. Footage has corroborated the information given by the daughters that two people entered the house.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Book LPG refill, get it the same day
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Upping customer satisfaction, state-owned Indian Oil has said it will deliver booked LPG cylinders in one day from Tamil New Year’s day.

Domestic LPG cylinders, which are subsidised by the Union government, normally takes three to four days for delivery after booking. “Our internal assessment is that it takes 1.8 days to deliver a cylinder now. We have embarked upon a programme along with our distributors to cut this delivery time. Our promise will be delivered in a day, or a maximum 24 hours from booking a refill,” said P Jayadevan, executive director, Indian Oil, Tamil Nadu and Puducherry .

“Ideally, we want our customers to book using the IndianOil app or through WhatsApp so that there is a time trail. Also, if payments are made digitally it will help everyone,” he said. “If they do not delivery in 24 hours, they can call our toll free numbers and lodge a complaint.”

TN has the highest LPG penetration in the country with nearly 99.7% coverage and Indian Oil covers 57% of the state’s LPG households.

Title: Government school management committee wins education department’s praise
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: A panchayat union primary school (PUPS) at K Paramathi in Karur district has earned praise from the school education department for the commendable performance of its school management committee (SMC) which usually remains a namesake in most schools. The department has asked government schools to take inspiration from the PUPS in constituting SMC and shared the link to a short film on the best practises adopted by the school.

The Right to Education (RTE) Act 2009 mandates formation of school management committee (SMC) in every government school to ensure community participation. However, the committee comprising parents and members of the local body to enable interaction with teachers has been remaining on paper in most state schools. “The general complaint among schools is that parents don’t attend SMC meeting. But we can ensure their participation by involving them in school activities.,” said headmaster PUPS K Paramathi R Selvakkannan. Many schools also avoid empowering SMC as they see it as an infringement on academic activity. Development of the school cannot happen without community participation, he said. Selvakkannan, also recipient of national award for best teacher, explained how parents as SMC members are working as special teachers in the school and contributing to the students’ allround development. They teach spoken English and train students in handicrafts. One of the SMC member, who works as a driver and is an avid painter has been training interested children in painting. President of SMC at the PUPS K Paramathi C Thanikaiselvi expressed happiness over the best practices adopted by the school becoming a government order for implementation in other schools in the state. Selvakkannan told TOI that it was at the monthly meeting of SMC where he received most of the ideas which he could implement in the school with the help of SMC.

Title: Power dept employees protest privatisation bid, seek revival of old pension scheme
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Bareilly: Power department employees on Wednesday held a protest against the UP governments’ bid to privatise the electricity distribution and demanded revival of the old pension scheme.

In Bareilly division, around 300 power department employees under the banner of Vidyut Karamchari Sanyukt Sangharsh Samiti, UP, staged protests at respective regional offices. Nearly, 15 lakh power department employees working with various distribution companies under UPPCL participated in the one-day nationwide strike.

Gaurav Sharma, co-coordinator of Vidyut Karamchari Sanyukt Sangharsh Samiti, told TOI, “Nearly, 300 employees under Bareilly division — including Bareilly, Pilibhit, Budaun and Shahjahanpur — joined the protest at their respective offices. Our demands included the rollback of the UP government’s decision to privatise power distribution, withdrawal of the regressive changes being made in the Labour Law, and cancelling the contract of power distribution franchise in Agra and privatisation in Greater Noida, among others. Besides, the old pension scheme should be revived and should apply to the employees joining services post-2000.”

Madhyanchal Vidyut Vitran Nigam Limited (MVVNL) superintendent engineer (rural) Tariq Jalil said, “The privatisation experiment has failed in Agra and it should be taken as a lesson. The government says the move is aimed at improvising power distribution and minimising the loss, but we are already giving 24-hour supply in urban areas and working on replicating it in the rural areas as well. Privatisation, therefore, is unnecessary.”

Due to protest, the departmental works remained suspended from 10am to 5pm, causing inconvenience to consumers; electricity bills could not be paid as the counters remained shutting, while complaints such as power-cuts and break-downs were not entertained throughout the day.

Title: Kozhikode to get 26 electric vehicle charging stations
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kozhikode: The Kerala State Electricity Board is set to start 26 electric vehicles charging centres in the district.

The plan is to start charging stations with the support of empanelled agencies and private parties.

The KSEB has already floated tenders for six electric vehicle charging stations. The plan is to set up charging stations in the city and other areas in the district.

The number of electric vehicles operational in the district is very low as per the current data, said Bose Jacob, deputy chief engineer KSEB. However, the KSEB is planning to introduce a number of vehicle charging stations as the state government aims to increase the number of electric vehicles to 1 million by 2022, he said.

The plan is to set up charging stations at every 4km to help the electric vehicle users. The KSEB is planning to start the charging stations at KSEB’s own land or other government land in the initial phase. Discussions have started with private parties also for commencing charging stations with private partnership.

Of a total of 26 stations sanctioned in Kozhikode 14 will be operated by KSEB empanelled agencies. Six stations will be run directly by the KSEB and six other stations will be operated by private parties.

The vehicle stations are being planned to aim to promote the use of electric vehicles in the state. The stations will provide safe, reliable, accessible, and affordable charging infrastructure.

The station will have exclusive transformer, substation equipment and safety appliances. The station will have 14x7 metre area to accommodate the vehicles.

Apart from Kozhikode, other cities in the district will also get vehicle charging stations. The central government has given nod for 131 charging stations across Kerala. Kochi will get the maximum number of stations- 150. While Kannur will get 27 charging stations Thrissur will get 28 stations.

We do not expect many to turn up to the charging stations in the beginning as the number of electric vehicles is minimal, said Bose Jacob. More number of people will come up to purchase electric vehicles only if there are sufficient number of charging stations , he said adding that the initiative is aimed at promoting eco-friendly e-vehicles .

The state government has also issued direction to give fresh permit only to green auto rickshaws in Kochi, Thiruvananthapuram and Kozhikode, said the official. The charging stations would be helpful to the e-auto owners, he added.
