Title: Madurai: Actor Vadivelu harassing me for money: Producer
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Vadivelu

MADURAI: Tamil movie producer G Sathish Kumar, who produced the 2015 film ‘Eli’ starring comedian Vadivelu in the lead, accused the actor of harassing him by sending his men to demand money on Wednesday.

The Madurai-based producer, who is also into real estate business, claimed that Vadivelu sent his men on December 31 to threaten him for money. His manager Govindaraj had lodged a complaint with the K Pudur police. Police booked a man three people, including a woman, on charges of voluntarily causing injuries, threatening with dire consequences, scolding using bad words and criminal trespass. Vadivelu, however, has not been booked by the police.

Manikandan, who is believed that have visited the producer’s residence in Moondrumavadi, on behalf of Vadivelu, is among the persons booked. He allegedly went to Satish Kumar’s house on the pretext of giving a wedding invitation when Sathish Kumar was in Chennai. Manikandan and along with a few people allegedly threatened Govindaraj inquiring his employer’s whereabouts. They also beat him up when he questioned reason behind their visit, Sathish said.

Sathish also said that there had been disputes between him and the actor ever since the movie ‘Eli’ incurred heavy loses. “We had disputes over money for which we took the matter to court and it was to be settled amicably. However, now, these men have come and made death threats,” he said. CCTV footage from outside Sathish Kumar’s residence has also been submitted to the police which provided description of the accused.

Title: Anti-narco ops will continue: Top cop
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Jaipur: ‘Operation clean sweep’, launched in October 2019 by Rajasthan police to curb sale of narcotics, will continue in the city in 2020.

While presenting the 2019 report card of crimes in Jaipur, police commissioner Anand Srivastava on Wednesday said that they have achieved success in registering 153 cases against peddlers dealing in narcotics and illegal liquor. They have also arrested 176 bootleggers and drug peddlers in the city in past three months.

“We will continue to act against narcotics and illegal liquor this year too. We will continue it until we completely prevent such activities in the city,” said Srivastava. In the past three months, 249kg of marijuana, 2 quintal poppy husk, one kg opium, one kg charas, 292gm smack, 5.2gm cocaine, 42.5gm MDMS and 7.5gm brown sugar, were seized by the police in raids conducted at different places in the city.

Title: Woman, 44, held for cheating Tangedco job aspirant of Rs 5 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Police arrested a 44-year-old woman on charges of cheating an MBA graduate of Rs 5.15 lakh promising a job in Tangedco, here on Wednesday. Police identified the accused as R Indhumathi, a resident of Keerambur at Thuraiyur in Trichy.

Investigations revealed that Indhumathi was the mastermind behind the crime. The arrest was made after a complaint lodged by victim B Manimekalai, a native of Thavittupatti village in Thuraiyur in Trichy district. Police are looking for another woman who is also involved in the case, police said.

Manimekalai has been preparing for competitive examinations. She had worked as a teacher at a private school in Thuraiyur between 2012 and 2016. During the time she had befriended with Manjula, who was also working at the school. She introduced Indhumathi to Manimekalai. She promised Manimekalai that she will help her get a job in Tangedco at Tennur in Trichy, stating that she knew many politicians and former ministers.

Manimekalai handed over Rs 5.15 lakh to Indhumathi in the presence of her son R Nishar, 22, and her brother Mani, police said. The victim had first transferred Rs 4.45 lakh to Indhumathi’s bank account on various dates since February 7, 2017. A sum of Rs 70,000 was handed over to Indhumathi, Nizhar and Mani at their house. Manjula was also present at that time, Manimekalai stated in her complaint.

The accused have also cheated several lakhs of rupees from many job aspirants promising jobs in various government departments, the complaint stated.

Based on the complaint, district crime branch police arrested Indhumathi and are looking for Manjula who is on the run, police said. Indhumathi has been remanded in judicial custody by a court.

Title: Inter-faith group ‘supports’ CAA
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

NEW DELHI: An inter-faith delegation comprising spiritual leaders and social reformers met minister of state for home G Kishan Reddy on Wednesday to purportedly express solidarity with the government's decision to bring the Citizenship Amendment Act in aid of persecuted minorities from Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh.

A home ministry release issued after the interaction said the delegation members - Jain Acharya Dr Lokeshji, meditation guru Swami Deepankar, Mufti Shamoon Qasmi, Sardar Sant Singh, Veer Chakra awardee Col (Retd) T P Tyagi, Vineet Kumar and Gautam - "expressed solidarity with the government and faith in its policies".

The delegation, which called on Reddy amid ongoing protests in different parts of the country against CAA, unanimously affirmed that the CAA concerns only foreign immigrants and no Indian, from whichever religion, caste, color or creed, has anything to fear, said the release. Highlighting the principles of dharma and ahimsa, the delegation affirmed its belief that the legislation was born out of humanitarian concerns for those who had fled to India from Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh fearing religious persecution.

The delegation, according to the home ministry, said India being a land of mutual acceptance and harmony, protests against a decision that aims to alleviate the suffering of such uprooted families, were unacceptable. The legislation is based on a perfect rationale and objective premise, the members were quoted as saying.

The delegation members are said to have declared their intention to urge people to guard themselves against "misinformation meant to destabilise our foundations of mutual respect and acceptance".

The spiritual men also expressed their desire to meet Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah "with this message of peace and solidarity," stated the home ministry.

Title: More funds for Bhamashah than free med scheme
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Jaipur: The previous BJP government gave much impetus to Bhamashah health insurance scheme over the free medicine scheme of the earlier Congress government.

It increased the budgetary allocation from Rs 213 crore under the Bhamashah scheme in 2015-16 to a whooping Rs 1,491 crores in the election year 2018-19.

During the same period, the allocation for free diagnostics, free medicine has jumped by Rs 29 crore and Rs 142 crore, respectively.

Rajan Chaudhary, a healthcare expert, said Bhamashah was an attempt to privatise healthcare and to pass the onus on private players. “Raje government made all attempts to pass on the healthcare system into the hands of private players through insurance companies. I demand that present government should respect the mandate and hold fair inquiry on how the budget under this head was used on how many patients were benefitted,” said Chaudhary.

The present government, however, has slashed the budget from Rs 1,491 crore to Rs 631 crore but has also reduced the fee medicine scheme budget from Rs 557.09 crore to Rs 556.43 crore.

Gehlot government has merged the central government’s Ayushman Bharat scheme and the Bhamashah scheme to introduce a new scheme called Bhamshajh Ayushman Bharat Mahatma Gandhi Rajasthan Health Insurance scheme. The activist further says that state has to introduce steps like social auditing and community monitoring so that misuse should be stopped and resources would be utilised properly.

Title: Madurai: Lawyer arrested in Tirunelveli temple idol theft case
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The idol wing CID on Tuesday arrested a lawyer in the connection with the theft of a panchaloha idol and jewellery from Sri Bhadrakali Amman temple at Keelpattamudaiyarpuram in Tirunelveli district in 2017. Madhavan, 36, is the fourth person to be arrested in connection with the case. On January 30, 2017, the temple’s door was found broken open. The idol of Bhadrakali Amman, three gold mangalyam necklaces and two silver thali kodi necklaces were missing. Balamurugan was the first to get arrested. He returned the stolen panchaloha idol. Later, Arunkumar and Suresh were arrested, after which the case was transferred to the idol wing CID. Investigations revealed the role of Madhavan in the case.

Title: Banking, insurance hit, but national strike has no impact on normal life
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

As part of nationwide bandh called by trade unions, BSNL employees affiliated to various unions staged a novel... Read More

TRICHY: The nationwide strike called by various trade unions did not affect normal life as government and private buses, autos, taxies and trucks operated as usual. However, banks, insurance, post and BSNL offices remained closed though 90% of shops and commercial establishments remained open.

Police arrested 3,372 protestors from across the central region as they tried to stage protests including rail and road roko as part of the strike on Wednesday.

Police arrested 328 protesters while they tried to block Trichy-Karaikal passenger train, Cholan Express and Ernakulam Express at various stations in the delta districts. A total of 3,044 protestors were arrested by police as they tried to stage road roko in 50 places in the region.

Trade unions including CITU, AITUC, HMS, AIUTUC, TUCC, AICCTU and UTUC and State Government Employees’ Federation, worker and employees of central and state public sector firms including BSNL, banks, insurance and transport corporations participated in various protests in the region against the Centre’s privatization of public sector undertakings and implementation of ‘anti-labour laws’.

BSNL employees staged a novel protest in front of the head post office in Trichy as they carried a man who posed like a dead body. Police intercepted the procession and arrested them. Members of the Joint Forum of Unions and Associations of Airport Authority of India staged a demonstration in front of the Trichy airport showing solidarity to the striking unions, though the forum was not affiliated to any of the central trade unions, convenor of the forum D Yuvarajesh said.

A large number of employees from Ponmalai Railway workshop affiliated to Southern Railway Mazdoor Union (SRMU) staged a demonstration near the Divisional Railway Manager’s office in Trichy. They raised slogans against the Union governments’ move to privatize Railways and other public sector units across the country. Postal employees also abstained from work on Wednesday. Meanwhile, a section of farmers headed by secretary of Thanjavur District Cauvery Farmers Protection Association Swamimalai S Vimalnathan staged a protest by standing in the middle of an agriculture land in Kumbakonam. They raised slogans against the anti-farmer policies of the Union government and demanded to increase procurement price of their produce.

Title: Case against Allan & Thwaha: Rights activists urge Yechury to step in
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kozhikode: Rights activists, who are part of ‘Allan-Thwaha Human Rights Protection Committee’, have urged CPM general secretary Sitaram Yechury to intervene to persuade the Kerala government to take back the case against Allan Shuhaib and Thwaha Fasal from the National Investigation Agency (NIA).

In a letter to Yechury, committee member and Anweshi chairperson K Ajitha said there was a provision in the Unlawful Activities Prevention Act (UAPA) to request the Centre to return the case to state police.

“There is a definite provision in the NIA Act that allows the state government to conduct investigation even in the case of offences scheduled under the NIA Act. Specifically, Section 7 (b) allows to ‘transfer the case to the state government for investigation and trial of the offences’,” the letter said.

Ajitha said initially the CPM was sympathetic towards the youths who have been accused of links with the Maoists and had condemned the invocation of the UAPA in the case. The party had promised to have a re-look into the case and some party leaders had even visited their houses.

Moreover, the chief minister had assured the youths’ families of that the committee set up to review UAPA cases in the state will have a close look at the case, kindling the hopes of dropping of the charges, Ajitha said.

The CPM state committee and the LDF convener were also against the invocation of the UAPA against the youths, Ajitha said. In the meantime, the NIA took over the case and the chief minister made a U-turn in his approach. He said in the assembly and at a press conference that the youths were indeed Maoists, she said.

Ajitha said the country has been passing through difficult times, which warrant a joint agitation. But the state government’s attitude has been dampener, she said, adding that popular support to the CPM and the government has eroded and that several activists and cultural leaders have raised concern over the Left government’s stand.

Title: Vasundhara Raje govt spent only 50% of capital fund on med upkeep
Content:
Vasundhara Raje

JAIPUR: Almost 50% of the capital fund under the health budget meant for upgrading medical equipment, facilities and constriction in the government hospitals remained unutilised during the regime of former chief minister Vasundhara Raje .The preliminary reports into the death of infants in J K Lon Hospital blamed poor infrastructure which piled up over the years. Figures from the state budget pages say that nearly 50% of the capital fund was utilized from 2014-15 till 2017-18.For instance, in 2014-15 financial year, the total capital fund allocated was Rs 1,073 crore, while the amount utilised was just Rs 484 crore. The sorry state of affairs doesn’t stop here. In 2017-18, the total capital fund allocated was highest till date of Rs 1,330.62 crore, while the amount spent was Rs 657.54 which constitute for about 40.84% amount utilised in the year.“The apathy by the previous government in the spending the capital fund has created a wide gap in upgrading of the medical equipment and strengthening facilities right from Primary Health Centres to Dispensaries and from satellite hospitals to civil hospitals,” said Nisar Ahmed of Budget Analysis Rajasthan Centre (BARC).The draft of documents of 2018-19 also presents the bleak picture about the spending of the capital fund. Reports have suggested that death in JK Lone Hospital in Kota is also due to shortage of heaters, warmers, oxygen kits, shortage of medical equipment in ICU and wards, broken windowpanes, lack of hygiene and improper water outlets.Former health minister Kalicharan Saraf (December 2016 till the term ended) has refused to own up the responsibility of amount under the important component being unused.“I am a politician and can track figures. If the capital fund is not spent fully during my tenure, it should be asked to the then health officials Naveen Jain and Veenu Gupta,” said Saraf.TOI repeatedly called health minister Raghu Sharma for his reaction but got no response. Going by the admission of the Sharma, several equipment have become non-functional due to lack of maintenance.“Capital fund is required for the regular maintenance of the machines some of which are in tune of crores of rupees,” said Mukesh Goswami of Mazdoor Kisan Shakti Sangathan , who is also advocating for right to health.

Title: Newly launched Cheetah patrol squads turn toothless
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Just a week into its launch, the city police have trimmed the number of Cheetah Patrol teams from ten to just two.

The patrols were introduced to improve traffic law enforcement on city roads and were flagged off by chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan on New Year’s Day. Besides reducing the number of patrols, new city commissioner Balram Kumar Upadhyay has also brought their activities directly under his control.

Under the original plan, the patrols were to function under the two assistant commissioners (North and South) of the city traffic division.

Speaking to TOI, commissioner Upadhyay said the changes will not affect traffic law enforcement.

‘’The city traffic division already has four law enforcement squads and their duties overlap with those of the Cheetah Patrols,’’ said Upadhyay.

Upadhyay said the city police would strive to achieve 100% compliance with helmet and seatbelt rules. The Cheetah Patrols would conduct surprise inspections, the city commissioner said.

‘’There are people who wear helmets when they see officers conducting inspections and would remove them as soon as they reach the next junction. Cheetah Patrols will target such motorists. They may conduct checks at one place and then shift to another place the very next minute,” the commissioner said.

However, this surprise nature will not conflict with the existing directions of the state police chief regarding on-road inspections that forbid officers from pouncing on motorists, leading to accidents.

The Cheetah Patrols were envisioned by state police chief Loknath Behera after he held a meeting with residents two months ago to hear their woes and concerns related to vehicular traffic in the city.

Former commissioner MR Ajithkumar was tasked with preparing a detailed report and he proposed 10 teams. He also mobilised ten sub inspectors to lead the patrols.

It is learned that Behere ratified the decision to cut down the number of patrols with an aim to expand the project to other police districts. The officers who were selected for the squad may be redeployed to other police districts soon in this connection.

Meanwhile, there are also rumours that the focus on ‘law enforcement’ was only a ruse to use police personnel to increase penalising motorists and thereby increase collection of petty charges.

There are several officers in the department worried that this would only result in adversely affecting the cordial relationship between police and public.

Title: Farmers urge authorities to open DPCs as paddy harvest nears
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Trichy: As samba paddy harvest is round the corner in Lalgudi block in Trichy district, farmers in the area have appealed to the district administration to open direct procurement centres (DPCs) as soon as possible.

Unlike other blocks in the district, farmers in Lalgudi largely take up samba paddy cultivation every year due to their access to borewell water. This year hundreds of farmers have taken up samba paddy cultivation for the season as rain, Cauvery water and water from other irrigation channels were favourable, agriculture officials said.

Now the crop is ready for harvest. There is a possibility that the harvest would begin from January 10, farmers said.

Lalgudi is the only area where a considerable number of farmers takes up samba irrespective of water released from Mettur dam for delta cultivation. Farmers from Lalgudi largely rely on borewells, said state spokesperson of Bharatiya Kisan Sangam N Veerasekaran.

“Once harvest is started, farmers have no option but to sell their produce in the open market for low price, as no DPC is functioning in Lalgudi block. Usually Tamil Nadu Civil Supplies Corporation (TNCSC) open around 15 DPCs in Lalgudi block to help farmers from being cheated,” he said.

Meanwhile, officials from district administration said that once they get instructions form the collector, the TNCSC authorities would open the required number of DPCs in Lalgudi.

Title: Counting of votes held in two panchayat unions
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

TRICHY: Counting of votes polled in the elections to the Oorudaiyapatti panchayat president and Reddimangudi panchayat ward member posts were held here on Wednesday. The counting was postponed by the State Election Commission on January 2, as one of the candidate’s name was missing from the final voters list released on December 22.

Four candidates, D Rathinakumar, T Rengasami, P Viswanathan and M Ramasamy, had filed their nominations to contest the post of a president at Oorudaiyapatti panchayat in T Pettai union in Trichy district.

Election was held on December 30. However, counting was not conducted on January 2, for the panchayat after Viswanathan, one of the contestants, had taken the issue that his name was not included in the voters’ list, to the electoral officers. Subsequently, the counting was postponed to January 8.

On Wednesday, the counting was completed by noon and D Rathinakumar has emerged winner with 471 votes out of 1,109 valid votes polled. While Viswanathan managed to secure only 19 votes and T Rengasamy 350 votes, officials said.

In Rettimangudi panchayat in Pullambadi union, the counting was postponed due to some confusion during the January 2 counting of votes in Ward 4.

On Wednesday’s counting, S Rubanya has been elected ward member after securing 148 votes. The other contestant S Dhara got 69 votes.

Title: CSI synod council to meet in city to discuss gender equality
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Trichy: The 36th session of the synod council meeting of the Church of South India (CSI) will be held at the Bishop Heber College in Trichy from Saturday.

With a membership of 45 lakh people across five southern states of India, CSI is the biggest Protestant Church in India. Organized into 24 dioceses, each under the spiritual supervision of a bishop, the church is governed by a synod, which elects a moderator (presiding bishop) every three years. The officers of the new triennium will be elected by the official delegates of the synod of which around 375 delegates will take part in the election process from the 24 dioceses of the CSI.

The four-day event will be led by moderator of the CSI Thomas K Oommen and deputy moderator, Vadapalli Prasada Rao. Saying that discussions and paper presentations on varied topics will be part of the event, Thomas K Oommen said that gender equality will be an important topic of discussion.

The Church operates 1,419 aided primary schools, 48 unaided primary schools, 228 aided middle schools, nine unaided middle schools, 257 aided higher secondary schools and 84 unaided higher secondary schools.

Besides, it also runs 31 aided colleges including Bishop Heber, Trichy, 63 unaided colleges, 10 aided technical institutions, 37 unaided technical institutions, two paramedical institutions (aided), 22 unaided paramedical institutions, one aided professional institution, 13 unaided professional institutions, and 30 other educational institutions.

Title: Plan to raze Tagore’s Puri house hits opposition wall
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Opposition from locals has forced the Puri district administration to do a rethink on its plan to raze the century-old house of Nobel laureate Rabindranath Tagore at Chakratirtha Road, in Puri. “It is an unsafe building. But we are sensitive to its legacy and heritage. We will see what best can be done in this regard,” Puri district collector Balwant Singh assured on Wednesday.

The change of heart follows protest from locals, prominent individuals and members of the state chapter of Indian National Trust for Art and Cultural Heritage (INTACH).

“Tagore was in love with this place. He had penned several poems here during his stay. Tagore had renovated Patherpuri House. This should be restored instead of demolishing it,” heritage expert and historian Anil Dhir said.

The building has a bust of the poet. “There are several documents and articles penned by Tagore that are still there in the house. Though some of these documents have been lost due to lack of maintenance, some of the writings still remain,” Dhir added. A portion of the house is being used as a hostel of the local Samanta Chandra Sekhara Junior College. The building is dilapidated and its foundation got further weakened by Cyclone Fani that hit Puri on May 3 last year. The wind also blew away the roof of the building. This led the state works department to declare the building unsafe.

A senior teacher at Samanta Chandra Sekhara Junior College said they have requested the works department to restore the building and turn it into a museum to preserve the documents and artifacts.

Priyadarshan Patnaik, a convener of Shree Jagannath Sena, said the state government should preserve the heritage building instead of demolishing it. “The government can convert Patherpuri House into a museum. Tagore had composed several literary works, including a portion of Gitanjali, during his stay here. We should respect his legacy by restoring the building,” Patnaik said.

Amiya Bhusan Tripathy, state convener of INTACH, said his organization has requested chief minister Naveen Patnaik to restore and conserve Tagore’s house. “If the government wants, INTACH can give a new lease of life to Paherpuri House,” Tripathy said. He said Kanika Library and Assembly Hall at the iconic Ravenshaw University, the Cuttack Circuit House and the old Board of Revenue Building too were at declared unsafe, but have now been restored with INTACH’s help.

Title: 4th tiger found dead in 4 days in Sattari forest
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

It is believed by some that the recent killing of domesticated animals in the area could have led to the tiger... Read More

PANAJI: The death toll of tigers rose to four in the state within four days, after a tiger cub was found buried, while, a few meters away, the carcass of the mother tigress was discovered in a decomposed condition by forest officials on Wednesday. Earlier, on January 7, combing operations by forest officials had found a dead cub.

The combing operations were launched after the carcass of a four-year-old male tiger was first spotted on January 5, in the forest of Golauli in Sattari taluka.

Though forest officials said the tigers were most probably killed after feeding on a poisoned buffalo, postmortem carried out on three of the tiger carcasses have shown no evidence of death due to poisoning.

“There is possibility that the tigers died due to poisoning, but so far we have not found evidences. Our investigation is in process. After forensic reports are available, reason for the death of the tigers would be known. On Thursday, postmortem of the fourth tiger (the cub found on Wednesday) will be carried out,” deputy conservator of forests Vikas Desai said.

Police too were involved in the investigations, with the dog squad being brought at the spot where the tiger carcasses were found inside the Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary. But as a week had passed since the deaths, the dogs could not provide any leads.

After Dr Harsh Bathini conducted postmortem of the female cub and the mother tigress on Wednesday, it was reported that all the claws and teeths were intact. In case of one of the earlier tiger carcasses, claws were missing.

The reports of four tiger deaths are unprecendented in Goa and has left wildlife conservationists and residents of nearby areas in shock.

It is believed by some that the recent killing of domesticated animals in the area could have lead to the tigers being poisoned. A case has been registered against unidentified persons under the Wildlife Protection Act and four suspects have been rounded up.

“Goa government does not have any concrete plans in place for protection of the tigers in the Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary. On December 23, a tigress with three cubs were captured by a camera trap. Earlier, on December 22, a cow from the nearby settlement had been killed and, on December 30, a buffalo had been killed. In this scenario, officials should have planned a strategy to avoid anguish of the locals,” said Amrutsingh, who heads Animal Rescue Squad.

Resident of Bhuipal village in Sattari, Suryakant Gaonkar, told TOI, “The death of four tigers is indeed shocking. For the first time, we have seen how treacherously the tigers have been killed and attempts have been made to destroy the evidences. This is painful. The forest department has to investigate the matter thoroughly and has to plan mitigation measures on warfooting to protect the remaining tigers in the Mhadei sanctuary. The man-tiger conflict should be dealt with properly to avoid the repetition of such tragic misdeed.”

Last year, the Wildlife Institute of India census had reported the presence of three tigers in the Goa corridor. Forest officials later said that the tiger number was up to five in the Goa corridor, based on the tigers captured on the camera trap, after the census period.

Title: Govt moves SC seeking transfer of pleas challenging CAA in HCs to apex court
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

As petitions challenging validity of the Citizenship Amendment Act have been filed in various high courts, the Centre on Wednesday pleaded the Supreme Court to transfer all petitions to itself for adjudication. Appearing before a bench headed by Chief Justice SA Bobde , solicitor general Tushar Mehta said the high courts may come to contradictory conclusions on validity of the Act and it would be better if the issue is adjudicated by the apex court. Although the bench observed that there is nothing wrong in HCs examining the issue and the apex court will look into it in case of contradiction, it, however, agreed to hear the Centre's plea on Mehta's insistence. It posted the case for January 10.

Title: Cane from jail to be part of Pongal gift hamper
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Trichy central prison inmates busy harvesting sugarcane on Wednesday which was cultivated by them inside the p... Read More

TRICHY: This Pongal too, sugarcane cultivated by the inmates of Trichy central prison on its campus will be available for the people to taste. Cultivated on 1.25 acres, the fully grown sugarcane is ready for harvest and the first lot was cut from the fields here on Wednesday.

Deputy inspector general, prisons, Trichy range G Shanmugasundaram and the officials have planned the cut in a way that the sugarcane reaches the people in time for Pongal. The prison authorities have already received an order for the canes from the state government to be included in the Pongal gift hamper.

“We estimate that 35,000 to 40,000 pieces of 2-foot-long sugarcane will have to be supplied to the cooperative department for Pongal gift hamper. The pieces will be ready to use as the prisoners will clean them completely,” said office superintendent of central prison A Thirumurugan.

The cultivation of the sugarcane commenced in April 2019 though the area of cultivation was reduced to 1.25 acres from 2 acres in previous years. The prison authorities said they applied organic fertilizers to the cultivation besides a negligible amount of pesticide on the advice of agriculture department officials. It was the hard work of 20 prisoners, handpicked by the authorities based on their good conduct, that resulted in the good harvest, said Thirumurugan. DIG Shanmugasundaram said the rest of the sugarcane will be distributed among prison staff and prisoners.

Authorities estimate the sale of sugarcane to fetch an income of Rs 2.5 lakh this year. Officials said 20% of the income will be split so as to give 80% of it to the prisoners and 20% to the victim relief fund. The cultivation of sugarcane, brinjal, lady’s finger, small onion and several other garden plants is also in full swing on the 100 acres of vacant land on the prison campus. A total of 60 prisoners are involved in agricultural activities.

Besides good conduct, the willingness of prisoners and their previous experience in agriculture are also taken into consideration before involving them in the work. DIG Shanmugasundaram said that small onion will be ready for harvest in 20 days.

Title: Hosp asked to pay Rs 50L for negligence
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

State Consumer Commission has asked Bhandari Hospital, Jaipur owner Dr Bhandari and two other doctors to pay a compensation of Rs 50 lakh for medical negligence to the family to a girl who lost her life after operation on suspected appendix. The amount had to be paid on the date of filing the petition on December 23, 2014 with 9% interest.

Title: ‘Compostables not substitute for plastic bags’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: ‘Compostable’ plastic bags may be used only as an alternative for garbage bags, the environment department said. With the department issuing a clarification on use of compostable substitutes, the city corporation is likely to take steps to regulate the inflow of carry bags labelled as ‘compostable’.

On Sunday, TOI had reported on how the lack of clarity over use of compostable carry bags led to hoarding of these bags by merchants in the city.

According to the environment department, compostable plastic can only be used as a substitute for garbage bags made of plastic, including for hospital use.

The department has also enlisted various non-plastic substitutes for banned plastic carry bags, non-woven bags, plastic packets, plastic drinking water pouches and plastic sheets.

Cloth and paper bags have been recommended as a non-plastic substitute for banned covers, bags and packets made of plastic and compostable plastic is not included under the list of alternatives.

New guidelines have been mandated for compostable materials. It shall bear details of the company that manufactures, the agency that markets, the material specification, date of manufacturing, batch number and approval details of the Central Pollution Control Board.

CPCB approval with licence number and validity may be given in the form of QR code. Further, the environment department has mandated that the compostable carry bag shall dissolve in dicholoromethane (methylene dichloride) and this shall be indicated in the packaging bag/cover/sheets as a preliminary test for identification.

Earlier, the government had issued an order exempting plastic products made of compostable plastic from the ban. The order had noted that it should bear the compostable’ label ‘and conform to IS/ISO 17088: 2008 titled as specification for ‘compostable plastic’ as defined in the Plastic Waste (Management and Handling) Rules, 2016.

Meanwhile the city corporation has sold over 25,000 cloth bags since the plastic ban came into effect. A government department alone placed an order for 12,000 bags.

The return counter set up by the civic body for merchants to hand over banned plastic carry bags also received over 3 tons of banned items.

Segregated plastic bags ideal for shredding will be sold to Clean Kerala Co Ltd at a rate of Rs 18 per kg.

Title: Restaurant owner hacked to death by unidentified gang
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PUDUKOTTAI: A 35-year-old man was hacked to death by an unidentified gang in Kothamangalam in Pudukottai late on Tuesday.

M Suresh from Kothamangalam near Alangudi owned a restaurant at Vaadimanagar bazaar in Kothamangalam.

On Tuesday night, when he was on his way back to his house situated two kilometres away from his restaurant on a two-wheeler, a gang intercepted and launched an indiscriminate attack on him with machetes. On hearing his screams, neighbours rushed to he spot but the gang fled the scene. Suresh died on the spot.

The Keeramangalam police visited the spot and inquired with the locals people about the gang.

However, they could not get any clue about the motive behind the murder and the identity of the accused.

Police have launched an investigation to find out if Suresh had any previous enmity with anyone.

Police sifted CCTV footage in the area.

Meanwhile, his body was brought to the government hospital for postmortem.

Suresh is survived by his wife and one-year-old daughter.

Title: Trade unions’ strike gets mixed response in state
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Members of trade unions stage a dharna in the city on Wednesday

JAIPUR: The nationwide strike call given by 10 central trade unions drew mixed response in Rajasthan on Wednesday with banking and roadways services remaining partially affected. However, most of the markets in the state, schools and colleges remained opened. Disruption to public transport services was minimal.

Mahesh Mishra, general secretary of Rajasthan Pradesh bank employees union, said, “Direct and indirect banking business to the tune of Rs 10,000 crore got affected today due to the strike. Of the total nearly 25,000 bank employees in the state, almost 20,000 joined the strike.”

Rajasthan roadways employees affiliated with CITU also participated in the ' Bharat bandh '.

“Of the total employees, there are nearly 3,000 employees affiliated with CITU in roadways who are participating in the Bharat bandh,” Kishan Singh Rathore , general secretary of Rajasthan roadways workers' union (CITU), claimed.

Rajasthan deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot said that the Centre should take cognisance of the nationwide strike called by labour unions, saying every section of the country was dissatisfied due to a communication gap.

“You (Centre) will not communicate, you will not explain, you will not try to understand people, then what is the meaning of democracy ?” Pilot asked. “Winning an election does not mean that you have become supreme. We should keep our hearts, minds and ears open, and listen to people.”

Pilot said the government should leave its “ego” behind and hold a dialogue.

The central trade unions organised the protest against labour reforms, FDI, disinvestment, corporatisation and privatisation policies of the government. The demands included minimum wage and social security for the working class.

Similarly, thousands of workers of textile and cement industries, krishi mandis also participated in the strike in different parts of the state.

“Workers of textile units in Reengus (Sikar), Bhawanimandi ( Jhalawar ) and of other units located in Malviya nagar industrial area, Vishwakarma industrial area of Jaipur participated in the strike. The strike impact was also there in krisi mandis of Hanumangarh , Ganganagar,” CITU state president Ravindra Shukla said.

Title: Times Vaikunda Ekadasi Isai Thiruvizha a hit
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Tadepalli Rukmini Srikrishna and her troupe performing at Times Vaikunta Ekadasi Isai Thiruvizha at Amma Manda... Read More

TRICHY: The first-ever “Times Vaikunta Ekadasi Isai Thiruvizha” in Trichy evoked good response among the city folks on Wednesday.

An initiative of The Times of India in association with Dhanalakshmi Srinivasan Group, the event was held at KVM hotels in Srirangam to commemorate Vaikunda Ekathesi festival Srirangam.

Tadepalli Rukmini Sri Krishna and her troupe had the audience in thrall with their Carnatic music apart from a few devotional songs. A decent crowd of Carnatic music lovers enjoyed the devotional musical evening with popular Carnatic numbers, Thirupaavai and Bharathiyar songs.

The event was an extension of the 15th special issue of Bhoologa Vaikundam festival for the readers of The Times of India and was created to praise the glory of the deity at Srirangam during the Ekadasi festivities.

Title: Panel to Raj govt: Go for Dassault Falcon jet
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Jaipur: The high-powered committee meeting held on Wednesday under the chairmanship of chief secretary D B Gupta has recommended to the government to go for a Dassault Falcon jet for the use of VVIPs in the state. The pane is expected to cost about Rs 214 crore.

Sources said all the leading manufacturers had responded to an expression of interest invited by the state aviation department. But what went in favour of Dassault Falcon was its ability to withstand the acute hot weather conditions and operate in shorter air strips.

An official privy to the meeting said, “Bombardier and Dassault were the two contenders. What went is favour of Dassault was its suitability to operate in extreme weather conditions.”

The Rajasthan government owns two aircraft and an Augusta helicopter. One aircraft is 28 years old while the other is around 17 years old. The Augusta helicopter was grounded after it suffered a technical glitch in November 2011. The government has been hiring jet planes for VVIP movement ever since the Augusta helicopter was grounded, which according to officials cost around Rs 4 lakh per hour. The acquisition of another state pane has been a long overdue. The previous Raje government had also planned to buy a plane , but it did not take off. It was during Raje's tenure that the controversial Augusta helicopter was acquired.

Title: Dehradun: Teachers, students of Nirbhaya’s institute hail SC decision
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

DEHRADUN: The friends and teachers of Nirbhaya, the Delhi gang rape victim, hailed the Supreme Court’s decision of sticking to its capital punishment verdict in the case. “The punishment to these men is a lesson to all those who even think of doing such heinous crimes. We stand by Nirbhaya 's parents, as always, in their quest of justice,” said Harish Arora, head of the city-based institute from where the 23-year-old victim completed her paramedical course.

The institute, where Nirbhaya studied for four years, now gives scholarship in her name to girls who hail from poor socio-economic background. According to the institute officials, around 25 girls have been given scholarships since 2012. “We give scholarship of Rs 4-Rs 5 lakh to girl students from poor economic background. Every year, around 5 to 8 girls get to avail this grant. They just have to pay Rs 10,000-Rs 15,000 for the entire course,” said Arora, while adding that her friends and teachers are also content with the court’s verdict. Speaking to TOI, other teachers who taught her said she was a brilliant student and highlighted that she scored really well in her last examinations, whose results were declared after her demise. "Supreme Court upholding its verdict is a strong message to those who commit such heinous crimes. Our faith in the judiciary has been reinstated. I feel that now, those who even think of raping women will fear the consequences of committing such a crime,” said Jitendra Singha, one of the teachers of the institute.

Earlier on Tuesday, SC had issued death warrant for four convicts in the 2012 Nirbhaya gang-rape case. Their execution will be held on January 22 at 7 am in Tihar jail. The court said that the convicts can use their legal remedies within 14 days. The order was pronounced by Additional Sessions Judge Satish Kumar Arora who issued death warrants against them. The four convicts are — Mukesh, Vinay Sharma, Akshay Singh, and Pawan Gupta.

Title: Uttrakhand holds first e-Cabinet, doubles grants for Mansarovar Yatra for residents
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat with ministers Madan Kaushik, Harak Singh Rawat and Satpal Maharaj at the... Read More

DEHRADUN: In a move to reduce the use of papers in official works, Uttarakhand witnessed its first e-cabinet meet on Wednesday. One of the decisions of the cabinet was to double the grant given to people of Uttarakhand going on Kailash Mansarovar Yatra. The meet also paved way for the recruitment of guest lecturers by colleges, which were short of teachers, for a period of 11 months.

Sharing the information, urban development minister Madan Kaushik said, “Earlier, a grant of Rs 25,000 was given to people of Uttarakhand going on Kailash Mansarovar Yatra. The cabinet has given nod to a proposal to double the grant amount to Rs 50,000.”

There are many degree colleges, which have seats of teachers lying vacant. “To ensure that the education of students is not impacted, we have allowed the colleges to recruit guest lecturers for a period of 11 months. Each lecturer would be given Rs 500 per class and each day the guest lecturer is expected to take two classes.”

The cabinet also approved the support price for sugarcane, which had been announced earlier. The government had fixed the price at Rs 317 (normal variety) and Rs 327 (high quality variety) per quintal.

Till now only women and members of SC community availed the benefits of Ganga Gai Mahila Yojana. Making an amendment, the cabinet decided to extend the benefits to all members of co-operative societies. “Priority in this regard would always be given to women members,” Kaushik said.

Earlier, the state government had given approval for the construction of disaster-affected houses in Kedarpuri through CSR funds. “The cabinet has made a slight amendment and added that now the state government, through its resources, can also build houses damaged in Kedarpuri,” Kaushik said.

Speaking about the e-cabinet, chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat said, “The motive is to promote paperless transactions, time-bound completion of projects and prepare a data base. With technology, it would be easier to check the decisions taken in the past. Personnel department will also come up with a portal for e-cabinet.

Title: Doctors save 670g newborn in Udaipur
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

UDAIPUR: Doctors of the Special Newborn Care Unit (SNCU) at the government RNT Medical College here saved the life of an extremely underweight newborn who weighed just 670 grams at birth.

After receiving critical care and treatment, the baby has gained weight and now is around 1375 grams. She was discharged on Tuesday. This was also the first case where any newborn was admitted in the government hospital in the last 75 days.

Devali Bai (18) of Nichali Odan in Rajsamand district gave birth to a baby girl at 26 weeks gestation on October 27. The delivery took place at her home and later the baby was taken to Nathdwara Government Hospital from where she was referred to Maharana Bhupal Hospital attached to RNT Medical College. The baby was admitted to SNCU on the same day.

Dr R L Suman, medical superintendent, told TOI that the newborn’s mother weighed just 40kg and was primipara (woman giving birth first time) had taken 3 antenatal visits and 2 doses of TT. He said the newborn, due to premature delivery, was very ill because of extreme low birth weight.

Senior professor and head of paediatrics department Dr Suresh Goyal told TOI, “The baby was kept on oxygen, intravenous fluids, parenteral nutrition , baseline antibiotics and monitoring. The baby was transfused blood four times. The health of the baby deteriorated number of times during the first 30 days because of feeding problems, but later started gaining weight.

Title: Nainital: Inmate calling system in jails by March end
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

NAINITAL: The state government on Wednesday informed the Uttarakhand high court (HC) that it will install a ‘prison inmate calling system’ in all jails in the state within three months.

This comes after the bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Alok Kumar Verma took cognizance of a letter by a former Army man who is in jail and had complained of the unavailability of any means for the inmates to talk to their families.

“Court was informed that the government had studied the systems in jails of places such as Punjab and Haryana and is in the process to acquire equipment to install the calling systems in jails across the state. We have also said that the facility will become functional within three months and is being done in collaboration by the BSNL,” said a lawyer appearing for the government.
