Title: Keralites prefer brandy to rum
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The sales figures of Kerala State Beverages Corporation (BEVCO) with respect to the market share of IMFL sales in the state shows a change in the drinking pattern in the last one decade. According to the figures, brandy is steadily grabbing the market instead of rum that once used to be the hit favourite of Keralites, indicating the change of trend in consumers’ drinking preferences in the last one decade.

At the same time, the market share for vodka, whiskey and gin and wine are a meagre figure. The rum brands, which accounted for about 52% of the market share till 2010, has steadily dropped over the past nine years and now stands at 43%. Brandy has picked up gains and now boasts of 51% share in the state’s liquor market.

BEVCO attributes one of the reasons behind this trend to the rise in the price of the extra neutral alcohol (ENA), the major ingredient for manufacturing the Indian-made foreign liquor (IMFL), of late. Though both IMFL varients use ENA, rum brands are usually cheaper than brandy brands, prompting the manufacturers to push for brandy brands.

“BEVCO had revised the rates of IMFL by only a meagre figure in the last many years, but the price of ENA has been spiralling upwards. Due to this reason, suppliers also prefer to supply brandy more than rum, which is generally cheaper,” former managing director of BEVCO and former excise commissioner Anil Xavier said. BEVCO sources say that rum brands are having a huge demand in the market, but are not available in adequate supply.

At the same time, vodka, whiskey and gin together accounts for only 6% of sales. While whiskey sales account for 4%, others together constitute only 2% sales.

The whiskey brands have also had a decline in the market share over the years. “There was a time when the market share of whiskey was as high as 16%, which is now only 4% which shows the change in drinking preferences,” sources said. But this trend is against likely to change. With the state’s liquor market now open for foreign made foreign liquor (FMFL), those preferring whiskey brands are now opting for more FMFL brands. “Whiskey is an expensive drink of the lot, and majority of those who are spending on Whiskey are now opting for FMFL as better products are available in FMFL. So a change in the sales pattern will be visible in the coming few years,” sources added. There are 306 retail outlets under BEVCO in the state.

Title: I rate Russell as the best, says Geet
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Ahmedabad: Billiards maestro Geet Sethi rates Mike Russell as the best among the players he has played with. The rivalry between Sethi and Russell was a riveting feature of billiards in the 1990s.

I rate Russell as the best as far as having the calibre on the table is concerned, said Geet, one of the greatest sporting talents India has ever produced, on the sidelines of the 6Red Snooker tournament in Ahmedabad on Wednesday.

“Russell and myself used to have umpteen breaks of 700-800 during our peak days. In the present era, I consider Pankaj Advani, who has been dominating the sport for long, an absolute champion material. He is a class apart and has won a high number of titles. He has the metal toughness to be the No. 1 in the country.”

On his comeback to the green baize, Geet said he realised last year that he needed to keep playing. "I felt that my body had lost some of the agility and I wanted to get some exercise and bring some rhythm back into the body. That's how it started and I got hooked to the game again."

“Recently, I had a break of over 500 during a practice session in Dubai and am very pleased that I am getting back into shape,” said the maestro who considers his break of 1276 during the World Billiards Championship as the high point of his illustrious career.

Geet is happy that the cue game has picked up in Gujarat in the last few years. “It is very pleasing to see that in the last seven-eight years, there has been a rise in snooker centres all over the state like in Rajkot, Vadodara and Surat,” said Sethi.

Geet feels Ahmedabad’s Dhvaj Haria is the future of Gujarat in the sport.

“Dhvaj has been the runner-up at the national billiards championship in the last two years. He works hard and is talented. Recently Dhvaj has beaten Pankaj in two back-to back tournaments and this augurs well for him,’’ said Geet.

Title: Kota’s JK Lon Hospital readies plan to double bed capacity
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The death of 100 children in JK Lon Hospital in December last year had exposed shortage of equipment, staff an... Read More

JAIPUR: The Government Medical College in Kota is planning to double its bed capacity from existing 157 to 313. This comes after TOI’s report ‘Kota’s JK Lon Hospital needs 300 more beds for ailing children’ published on January 6.

The death of 100 children in JK Lon Hospital in December last year had exposed shortage of equipment, staff and bed capacity in the institute. In 2019, 16,892 patients were admitted to the hospital.

Informing about the shortage of beds, Government Medical College principal and controller Vijay Sardana said the move to increase the beds have started. “We are preparing a proposal of adding another 156 beds, which include 90 general ward beds, 36 in neonatal ICU and 30 in paediatric ICU,” Sardana said.

TOI had highlighted that up to three children are cramped on a single bed at the hospital. Since the facility cannot deny treatment to patients coming in critical condition, they accommodate more than one child on one bed, which puts a child at higher risk of getting infected from other patients getting treatment on the same bed.

JK Lon Hospital officials said if 156 more beds were added, the capacity would get doubled. The health department will rope in the public works department to finalise the budget needed to increase the capacity.

According to a 2017 report of the hospital’s paediatric department, a copy of which is with TOI, the facility needs 300 more beds to cater to ailing kid population in Kota, Baran, Bundi and Jhalawar . The hospital’s move to increase the number of beds has been decided keeping in mind the availability of space with them at 40,000 square-metre sprawling land on which the two-storey building was constructed. However, more than half of the land does not have any construction.

In 2017, the government knew that there is a need for expansion of facilities for paediatric population and it planned a separate Hadauti Institute of Child Health in Kota at a cost of Rs 30 crore, but all that remained on paper. A meeting under the then health minister Kali Charan Saraf was also held and on the basis of that, Hadauti Institute of Child Health was planned.

Title: Budget allocation for education sector inadequate, says activist
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Pune: India’s annual public spending on education — at just 0.45% of the gross domestic product (GDP) — is inadequate to meet the goal of quality education for the country’s burgeoning and world’s largest young population, said education rights activist Sharad Javadekar of the Akhil Bharatiya Samajwadi Adhyapak Sabha.

He recently presented the education perspective of the budgetary allocations for the sector, at the Jan Arth Sankalpa budget series seminar. He said India’s allocation severely dwarfed in comparison to the global average and even when compared to other economically challenged countries.

Citing the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) data, he said even the relatively economically-backward countries such as Kenya, Namibia, Botswana spent over 7% of their GDP on education.

He said the government needed to increase the allocation to 6% of the GDP to undo the neglect of the sector over decades and raise funds for the same by undoing multiple corporate sops.

India’s proposed spend of Rs94,854 crore in the budgetary allocations of the current financial year, was an increase of 13% over the previous year’s revised estimates.

Javadekar said that despite the talk of push to education, schools and universities in India continued to have a vacancy of 11 lakh teachers.

“Only when the state funds education, will the state of public education and infrastructure of the institutions improve ... For equality in every sphere of life, publicly-funded institutions are necessary,” he said.

In his presentation, he said that despite social guarantees such as Right to Education, almost thalf the students dropped out between Std I to X.

“The root cause of unequal access to quality education is not teachers, it is the system. For over a decade, teachers have continued to be on contract in many public institutes,” he said.

Title: Satellite system to contact space crew soon: Isro
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Isro chairman K Sivan (PTI photo)

NEW DELHI: Indian Space Research Organisation ( Isro ) is going to set up its own satellite communication system for constant monitoring and contacting Indian astronauts in space much before the Gaganyaan or manned mission is launched by 2022.

Isro chairman K Sivan told TOI that "a constellation of two geo satellites constituting the Indian Data Relay Satellite System (IDRSS) will establish the space communication system that will help the Gaganyaan space crew talk to the ground station. The first geo satellite will be launched this year before the first unmanned testflight of Gaganyaan, which is likely to be launched in December or first half of 2021. The second satellite will be launched before the second unmanned testflight next year. Both testflights will carry a humanoid to space."

The satellites, which will be placed at the geostationary orbit at 36,000 km, will envelop the entire globe and help constant relay of communication from astronauts in space to the earth station without any time lapse.

Without data relay satellites, Isro will have to create a large number of ground stations or hire a foreign communication service otherwise the space crew will not be in contact at all time with ground staff.

All space powers like the US, Russia and European Union, which had launched their own manned missions earlier, have their own space communication systems. The US has American Tracking and Data Relay Satellite System, Russia has Luch or Satellite Data Relay Network and Europe has European Data Relay System. China, too, has its Tianlian data tracking system.

Earlier, Isro chairman K Sivan had told TOI though four IAF pilots have been chosen for advanced space training in Russia starting this month, "there could eventually be only one or three astronauts that will go to space".

Meanwhile, the Defence Food Research Laboratory in Mysore has prepared special desi food items and developed special containers to help astronauts drink liquids, including water and juices, in space where there is no gravity. Food heaters will also be provided to the space crew.

Title: Crimes rise in Jaipur but cops play it down
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: The 2019 crime figures released on Wednesday threatens to undermine the sense of safety among people.City police, however, claimed that significant increase in the number of crimes was nothing but the policy of free registration of cases, which they adopted in 2019. Police said they accepted every complaint and registered it.While data shows slight decline in murder cases in 2019, it reported significant rise in registration of cases of abduction, dacoity, attempt to murder and rapes.The report presented by Jaipur police commissioner Anand Srivastava stated 46% rise in number of cases registered under IPC in 2019 in comparision to 2018. The report shows that registration of cases of crimes against women also shot up by 66% in 2019 comparing with 2018 figures.According to the report, 93 people were murdered in the city in 2019, three less than 2018 figures. Police claimed they solved almost all the murder cases.As far as crimes against women, it was found that city police registered 3,474 cases in 2019 in comparision to 2,099 a year earlier. Moreover, cases under SC-ST atrocities, the registration of cases were almost doubled. In 2018, 511 cases were registered while in 2018, there were 255 cases.However, Srivastava claimed that the figures reflected that they had registered all the complaints without denying anyone.“We have a policy of free registration. Anyone coming with a complaint to us, we register them. The complaint is wrong or right, it will be decided during investigation. So, it is the figure of registrations of cases, which has increased by 46% in the city,” said Srivastava, while justifying the increase in cases registered under different sections of IPC.A total of 33,180 cases had been registered in 2019 against 22,754 in 2018. “Despite that, registration of cases have increased, we have just 14% pendency,” said Srivastava.While talking about 66% rise in cases of crimes against women, he said they had registered every complaint of domestic violence, family dispute and other such cases, which is why, there is an increase in registration of cases.

Title: 8.3 lakh get challans for violation of traffic rules
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: With an average of daily 2,275 challans, the city traffic police issued challans to 8.3 lakh people for violating traffic rules in 2019, says the report issued by Jaipur police commissionerate on Wednesday.

According to the report, the city police have collected Rs 10.8 crore from the traffic rules violators as fine. The police have deposited the collected fine to the state treasury.

Besides, the report says that 6,797 driving licences have been suspended in 2019. The police also took strict action against drunken driving as they launched a campaign by deploying police teams on important roads in the night to check drunken driving. The police issued 24,207 challans for drunken driving in past year.

Moreover, the police are also planning to launch a Golden Hour App with Rs 42 lakh fund. The App will be useful for creating a green corridor for ambulances. During peak hours of traffic movement, it becomes difficult for an ambulance to move faster. The police claimed that with the new App, they will be able to create green corridor for ambulances.

Title: 15-year-olds can add names in birth certs till Dec 31, 2021
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Jaipur: Rajasthan chief registrar has extended the date for adding names in birth certificates of citizens above 15 years for two years.

Accepting the plea of Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) to extend the date, the registrar issued an order on Wednesday stating that residents can now add add names in birth certificates till December 31, 2021. The corporation had recently announced that citizens above 15 years would be allowed to register their names in their birth records till December 31, 2019. Sources said after the National Register of Citizens (NRC) announcement, people have become more aware and rushing to JMC to get their names added in birth certificates.

“To avoid hassles in future, people have started coming to JMC for getting their names added in their birth certificates. With this, other identity documents including passports and voter identity cards can be easily procured. The extension will provide relief to all the residents.” According to officials, chief registrar of births and deaths had issued directions permitting municipal bodies to issue birth certificates after adding names in the blank column. After the deadline, rules did not permit to add names in the certificate once a citizen reaches 15 years.

A senior official said, “People above 15 years, who do not have their names in the birth certificates, are advised to complete the process. Now, with the extension, residents should add names as per convenience.”TNN

Title: SC issues notices to Centre, Goa as mining companies seek lease renewal
Content:
Supreme Court on Wednesday issued notices to the Centre and state governments on separate petitions filed by t... Read More

PANAJI: The Supreme Court on Wednesday issued notices to the Centre and state governments on separate petitions filed by two mining companies seeking a direction to renew their mining lease up to 2037. The court has sought replies from the government within four weeks.In February 2018, the Supreme Court had quashed the second renewal of 88 mining leases and stopped mining activities from March 2018.The petition has been filed against the Union government and the state government. The petitioners asked the SC to direct the state government to direct execute a lease extension deed to its mining lease deed with a new end date of 2037, in terms of Section 8A(3) of the Mines and Minerals (Development and Regulation) Act, 1957.Two mining companies approached the state government to extend their mining leases till 2037 as the life of a mining lease is 50 years. The state government in principle agreed to the request of mining companies but rejected the request of mining companies in lines of the apex court decision.The Union government abolished mining concessions and converted them into leases in 1987, with effect from 1961.“The Abolition Act, which came into force on May 23, 1987, granted deemed mining leases to inter alia the petitioner, while abolishing the mining concessions granted to the petitioner under the erstwhile regime with effect from November 22, 1987, vide Section 5(1) of the Abolition Act. Section 5(2) of the Abolition Act further provided that upon the expiry of a mining lease, the holder of such lease may apply for the renewal thereof in terms of the provisions of the MMDR Act,” states the petition.The petitioner stated that prior to the interruption and shutdown of mining in the state, Goa’s mining industry contributed well over 15% of the state GDP output. However, due to intermittent mining operations between 2014 and 2018, this contribution reduced to about 1%, and post April 2018, this figure reduced to nil, which has had severe consequences on the Goan economy.The petitioners said that the unemployment rate in Goa in 2019 was 34.5%, ie, the highest in the country. Moreover, only about 10% of the affected persons (approximately 1.5 lakh individuals) had managed to find alternative sources of livelihood. Increased and prolonged unemployment has also had a negative psychological and social impact on the population.“The shutdown of mining activities has resulted in a sharp drop of income levels ranging from 30-50%, and has affected over 3,00,000 households in Goa. The average monthly income, savings and expenditure have also witnessed a major drop after the stoppage of mining activities,” the petitioner said.

Title: Collect OBC data in Census ’21, Maha resolution urges Centre
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

MUMBAI: The state legislative assembly on Wednesday unanimously passed a resolution asking the Centre to add an Other Backward Classes (OBC) column in the census to be launched in 2021.

The Union home ministry had issued a statement in 2018 that OBC data would be collected in Census 2021 , but there is still no clarity on whether it will be done. The Census pre-test apparently did not collect the information. Published caste numbers were last collected under the British in 1931.

The resolution was moved suo motu by Speaker Nana Patole and unanimously passed by the lower House. "I feel there is a need for a caste column for 'OBC' in the form for the census that will start in 2021. This will help us find out the population of OBCs in the state correctly," said Patole, while speaking during a special one-day session of the assembly.

However, deputy CM Ajit Pawar said the issue could be discussed in the Business Advisory Committee (BAC) first and then taken up in the budget session beginning next month. Parliamentary affairs minister Anil Parab also said only the business finalised by the BAC for the day should be taken up by the House.

At this point, Patole said taking up the issue (caste-based Census) next month would be too late. Leader of Opposition Devendra Fadnavis said the Opposition would support such a resolution. "Different figures regarding the OBC population in the state are given, making it very difficult to plan policies for that section of the society. Budgeting and planning can be done when we have the correct numbers," said Fadnavis.

Food and civil supplies minister Chhagan Bhujbal of NCP said the demand for a caste-based census had been long pending. "We are still planning welfare schemes for OBCs in the state based on some British-era figures. There is definitely a need to have a fresh census to know the exact number of the community," said Bhujbal. After this, the House passed the resolution by voice vote.

Title: Forced to endorse CAA, Jyoti Nivas girls protest
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Bengaluru: Tension prevailed outside Jyoti Nivas College in Koramangala on Wednesday after a few men put up a banner endorsing the Citizenship (Amendment) Act on the institution’s compound and allegedly tried to force a few girl students to sign on it.

According to sources, students leaving the campus around 4.30pm were accosted by CAA supporters who began forcing them to sign on a flex banner put up on the college wall. When some students objected, the activists insisted they sign it.

Parinitha (name changed) told TOI: “When I declined to sign the banner, a few men began shouting at me in abusive language. As they continued to shout at us, many students gathered and questioned the men about their conduct. One of our professors heading out for a tea break noticed the commotion and came to the spot. He made several attempts to defuse the situation, but they did not heed his pleas,” she said.

The professor, who didn’t want to be identified, said, “The men held up a poster which had pictures of Union home minister Amit Shah, Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Bengaluru South MP Tejasvi Surya. The men also handed out pamphlets to students and told them to sign the petition,” said the professor.

Jyoti Nivas College student union president Rebecca Raj told TOI: “The pro-CAA men were pressurising my collegemates to sign the petition. Due to the chaos, the girls were able to leave the college only at 5.30pm.”

Koramangala police said when they rushed to the spot when they heard about the incident and brought the situation under control. A police officer said there was no case registered in this matter.

Title: Minister makes heads turn standing in hospital queue
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

BALANGIR: As usual, there was a long queue outside the ticket counter of the outpatient department at Santha Bhima Bhoi Medical College and Hospital in Balangir . People had travelled long distances to see the doctors. Suddenly there was a murmur. Standing in the queue was tourism minister Jyoti Prakash Panigrahi, who had come to review the hospital facilities as part of ‘Mo Sarkar’ and instead of walking straight inside, decided to stand in the line. Odisha Tourism Corporation chairman Shrimayee Mishra was also present.

Panigrahi said he waited for his turn like other patients. “I had some orthopaedic problem and the doctor advised him to get an X-ray done,” Panigrahi said.

Dr Gopabandhu Patra, who saw Panigrahi said the minister has tennis elbow and he advised him to do an X-ray and then consult a specialist.

“Initially I could not recognize him. But when the dean, superintendent and the media entered the outpatient ward, I realized that the tourism minister had come,” Patra said.

Panigrahi visited different wards of the hospital and talked to the patients and their relatives to inquire about the quality of healthcare facilities in the hospital.

Bablu Patel, who was standing along with the minister in the queue said Panigrahi was wearing a helmet to hide his identity. He waited for his turn in front of the counter as well as the X-ray room.

Title: Govt has not failed on Mhadei issue: Rodrigues
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Saligao: Water resources minister Filipe Neri Rodrigues said the government has not failed in fighting the legal battle over Mhadei water dispute issue.

“We have a strong case before the Supreme Court . There is a need for all parties and all people to fight the battle unitedly. Mhadei is our lifeline and it is our mother. We must not hesitate to fight for its protection,” said Rodrigues on Wednesday.

He was speaking after inaugurating the works for the improvement of a pond in Bastora. Rodrigues said the department has taken concrete steps towards water preservation and conservation under the water conservation scheme of the central government.

“In future, wars are going to be fought on water. I am glad to see all the panch members united towards ensuring water conservation in this area,” he said. Also present were Aldona MLA Glen Ticlo, Bastora sarpanch Savio Martins, deputy sarpanch Manisha Naik, Mapusa councillor Franky Carvalho, and other panch members.

Title: Colonial-era bungalow to be turned into Gandhi museum
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Mahatma Gandhi stayed in the bungalow for three days in 1934 during his historic Harijan padayatra in Odisha.

Kendrapada: A colonial bungalow at Garapur, on the outskirts of Kendrapada, where Mahatma Gandhi stayed for three days in 1934 during his historic padayatra will be turned into a museum .

“We decided to convert the bungalow into a museum to remind people of the significance of the 1934 padayatra and highlight the Mahatma’s role in the freedom struggle,” said Sashibhusan Behera, former minister and Kendrapada MLA.

On Tuesday, works minister Prafulla Kumar Mallik discussed about the project with the district administration. The building is now under the works department. A counter selling khadi, a photo gallery, a library and conference hall will be part of the proposed museum. “Mahatma Gandhi used tables, chairs and other furniture during his visit to Kendrapada district. The authorities will preserve those in the museum,” said the minister .

The father of the nation stayed in the bungalow from May 27 to May 29, 1934, during his historic padayatra.

“The padayatra is an important event in the country’s freedom struggle. Gandhi allowed dalits to enter temples in some villages during his long walk in Odisha in 1934. He also addressed a public meeting at Garapur on May 28, 1934,” said Nanda Kishor Parida, the former principal of Kendrapada College.

The Mahatma toured different places of Kendrapada during his five-day stay in the district.

He was accompanied by Meera Ben, Gopabandhu Choudhury, Rajkrushna Bose, Rama Devi, a German youth K. Kuto, Uma Bajaj, Binod Kanungo, Surendranath Pattnayak, Manmohan Choudhury and Jadumani Mangaraj, said Dr Basudev Das, a researcher of Kendrapada.

On May 30, 1934, he visited Dhumat village and stayed in a house, which was later converted into a Gandhi ashram. He had also planted a banyan tree near the ashram , added Das. The tree can still be see now, said the researcher.

Title: I-T settlement panel can resolve foreign black money matters: Gujarat HC
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Gujarat high court

AHMEDABAD: The Income Tax department has lost a case in the Gujarat high court against its own Income Tax Settlement Commission, over entertaining a case of black money in foreign countries held by NRIs, after their firm was named in the Panama papers expose.

In a recent judgment, a bench of Justice H N Devani and Justice S K Vishen rejected a petition filed by the principal commissioner of Income Tax taking exception to an order passed by the settlement commission on full disclosure of foreign income and assets. The I-T department insisted that the owners of the firm were liable to action under the Black Money (Undisclosed Foreign Income and Assets) and Imposition of Tax Act, and the settlement commission had no power to settle the issue about such black money under the Income Tax Act.

In this case, the Panama papers expose in April 2016 named one Overseas Pearl Ltd, registered in the British Virgin Islands. In October 2016, I-T sleuths raided the premises of Banco Products Ltd, which is the parent company of the firm located in the Virgin Islands, in Vadodara. While the I-T department’s process was under way, the owners of the firm, three brothers – Vimal Patel, Samir Patel and Mehul Patel – approached the settlement commission and disclosed more than Rs 100 crore lying in various countries. They later disclosed more money and in all offered to pay tax on more than Rs 129 crore of undisclosed money. In January 2019, the settlement commission computed tax and interest and ordered the Patel brothers to make payments to the I-T department in four instalments in one year.

The I-T department challenged the settlement commission’s order on the ground that it does not have jurisdiction to settle the issue with regard to undisclosed foreign money and assets, as the Black Money Act bars it from settling the matter. The department contended that the special Black Money Act empowers the department to initiate proceedings against the Patel brothers separately.

In April 2019, the high court stayed the settlement commission’s order for settlement. However, after hearing the case, it upheld the commission’s decision and rejected the I-T department’s case saying that the issue was settled by the commission under the Income Tax Act, which is valid.

The HC pulled up the I-T department for its double stand on the commission’s proceedings, that the revenue department did not act when the commission gave it an opportunity to decide whether the commission should settle the matter, or the I-T department would act under the Black Money Act. In fact, the I-T department invited the commission’s order and later took “a somersault” to say that the commission did not have jurisdiction.

The HC further said that the settlement commission has jurisdiction to settle the issue of foreign undisclosed money under the I-T Act and the Black Money Act does not have any restriction.

Title: What have you done to curb sand mining? HC asks Goa
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The high court of Bombay at Goa on Wednesday asked the state government to indicate the steps being taken to implement its judgment to stop illegal sand mining in Goa.

The Goa River Sand Protection Network (GRSPN) filed a contempt petition in the high court and placed on record several photographs “which suggest that sand mining is continuing and there is at least prima facie some deficit in the manner of action on the part of the authorities”.

The GRSPN said that despite a detailed judgment with directions on December 18 dealing with illegal extraction of sand from Goa’s rivers, the activity has continued unabated and has even increased in some places.

“Five detailed complaints were filed thus far, post the judgement. However, the directions are not being enforced,” states the contempt petition. “Not a single boat has been confiscated, nor truck. Not a single FIR has been filed, though in each area, dozens of persons are involved. Persons owning land on which the illegally extracted sand is stacked are not charged for being in receipt of stolen goods. The scenario is bizarre.” It also states that trucks carrying sand do so openly without fear of authorities.

The network filed complaints on December 24, 26, 27, 29 and 31 and found that violators were alerted in advance before officials from the department of mines and geology visited the site. Following this, complaints were filed with the inspector general of police (IGP) and director of transport.

Trucks usually commence transporting illegal sand from 4am, and long lines of such trucks are a regular sight in some places. Since all this extraction is illegal, it results in a huge loss in revenue to the state.

Title: Fitness boost: More open gyms to come up in Port City soon
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Residents in the city will soon have more reasons to work out in the open as the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) plans to expand its ‘open air gyms’ initiative in 2020. The initiative is aimed at promoting a healthy lifestyle, free of cost. Sixty-three open air gyms have already been thrown open to the public in parks and other places in the city.

Equipment at the open air gyms range from chest press, double shoulder twirl, double parallel bar, to skywalker and abs board. A visit by TOI to the VMRDA Health Arena early on Wednesday morning saw several people waiting for their turn to use the equipment at the open air gym. GVMC officials said while the gyms are spread across all zones of the city, the densely-populated Zone II has 28 such gyms.

GVMC commissioner G Srijana said the civic body wants to take the initiative forward given the positive public response. “The GVMC has so far developed 63 open gyms, with 374 equipment, in all eight zones of the city. We also want to convert all open places under the GVMC into green spaces. We have already identified 200 places and will soon call for tenders,” said Srijana.

R Narasimham, a private employee in the city, working out on the bench press at Shivaji Park on Wednesday, said the gyms were highly beneficial to the public. “I have been jogging for the last five years. With the open air gym at Shivaji Park, I can now include some variety into my fitness regimen. The best thing about these equipment is that the user’s body weight works as a counterweight,” he said.

N Sandeep, who was trying out the equipment, lauded the initiative. “As these gyms do not have any supervision, the onus lies on the public to properly utilise the equipment to increase their durability,” he said.

As per GVMC tender guidelines, the bidder has to ensure maintenance of the equipment for four years and offer a warranty of one year.

Title: JMC yet to shift two temples, mosque from Khadda Basti
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Jaipur: Within a week, six plots at the Khadda Basti in Adarsh Nagar will be auctioned by the Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) where once more than 600 families used to reside. All the houses on the land have been cleared by the JMC but two temples and a mosque still stands on the encroached property.

People, who were living in the basti, said that they are demanding separate land for temples and mosque. “We want government to provide separate lands to worship. It would be better for the government to shift these religious structures at Jaisinghpura Khor where we have been given flats. It is a sensitive matter which is why government is taking time to decide,” said Ramesh Kumar, one of the residents who was displaced in October 2017 along with others after the decision of the Rajasthan High Court.

Officials at JMC said that they are still in a dilemma.

An official said, we will take time to deal with the issue. “Rajasthan High Court in 2017 said that the final decision to shift these religious structures will be of the local bodies. All three are illegal structures on the encroached land but people have threatened to protest if one is shifted and not the other,” said the official. There are 50 plots in Jaisinghpura Khor area where more than 1,200 people are residing. Residents claim that though they have been given land, it has become a headache for them.

“Living 15 km from the city where water is scarce and electricity cuts are frequent, it has become difficult for us to survive. The level of fluoride in the drinking water is very high. We have complained many times to the authorities but nothing has been resolved yet,” said Ramesh Kumar, one of the residents who was displaced in October 2017 after the decision of the Rajasthan High Court.

Most of the residents were daily wagers who now have to travel 30 km daily for livelihood. “We have to travel to the city for work and many people have to stop their children’s education as the schools are far away. The area is secluded and nearest population is 4 km away. The government hasn’t helped us even if they claim they will,” said Bhola Ram, a resident of the Khadda Basti.

Title: CCP, DAC, traffic cell to meet today to decide Lokotsav NOC
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Panaji: A day before the scheduled start of the folk festival Lokotsav , the directorate of art and culture (DAC) continues to grapple with receiving the necessary permits to hold the ten-day fest in Panaji. The Corporation of the City of Panaji ( CCP ) will meet DAC and Goa police traffic cell officials on Thursday to decide on parking arrangements.

Mayor Uday Madkaikar said that the decision on whether or not an NOC would be granted to the festival will only be taken after the meeting.

“The DAC has submitted a traffic plan to us for parking at SAG grounds. We are calling a meeting with the traffic cell, fire services, officers of DAC and the CCP commissioner on Wednesday to take the final decision on the matter,” Madkaikar told TOI. The festival is scheduled to start on January 10.

Campal residents had held a meeting with the CCP on Monday to complain about the traffic congestion caused in the area owing to the festival, which prompted the CCP to direct the DAC to submit necessary permits by Tuesday or face cancellation of the festival.

The DAC on Tuesday approached the Sports Authority of Goa (SAG) to allot them space at Campal grounds to accommodate vehicles for parking, and were granted the same. On Wednesday, the DAC submitted the parking plans to CCP.

DAC director Gurudas Pilernekar said, “We have got an NOC from SAG and have submitted it to CCP. The fire services have conducted an inspection and the NOC is likely to come on Thursday”.

Dharmesh Angle, DySP (traffic), North Goa, said that some clarifications have been sought from the DAC regarding the parking plan.

“Whatever parking space was available last year (at the SAG football ground), the DAC has taken over to accommodate additional stalls so that place will not be available for vehicle parking this year. They will have to declare their parking area following which we can decide and then process the file,” Angle said.

Title: Colder nights loom for Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Brace up for chilling nights for the next 48 hours. The India Meteorological department has predicted that the night temperature in Ahmedabad city is expected to fall by around three degrees and was expected to be around 12C.

According to the IMD Officials, change in wind direction and the morning’s induced cyclonic circulation over southwest Rajasthan and neighbourhood caused the weather change.

In Gujarat , the minimum temperature is likely to drop by 2-3°C,” said an IMD official. He added that the minimum temperature in Ahmedabad city was likely to be around 12 degrees.

On Wednesday, the city had recorded a minimum temperature of 14.8 degrees which was two degrees above normal.

The weathermen predict that from Friday there will be gradual rise in minimum temperature over the region and Ahmedabad. The maximum temperature in the city was 26 degrees which was 1.7 degree below the normal.

The weatherman has forecast dry weather for the next five days in the state. Naliya was the coldest place in the state with a minimum temperature of 10 degrees, followed by Bhuj with 11.4 degrees and Rajkot with 11.8 degrees.

Officials of the India Meteorological Department (IMD) said that this trend seems to be here to stay. After a prolonged monsoon, the state seems to be headed for a not-so-cold winter. The Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation, meanwhile, has taken up a drive to ensure that homeless people are shifted to nearby night shelters.

Surat was the hottest city in the state with a minimum temperature of 18.1 degrees while Valsad had a minimum temperature of 17.1 degrees.

Title: Son-in-law behind double murder: Shweta’s father
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

JAIPUR: Father of Shweta Tiwari , who was found murdered in her own house on Tuesday, alleged that his daughter and her son were murdered by her husband.

While police have not arrested anyone yet, Shweta’s family is certain that her husband was behind the double murders.

Choking on his tears, her father Suresh Mishra told TOI, “Since my daughter got married in 2011, the couple had been having problems. She often told her mother on how my son-in-law was harassing her. Even after she was killed, he did not call us but instead called one of our relatives.”

After Shweta’s body was found on Tuesday, her son’s body was found on Wednesday afternoon in an open space. It appeared that the accused had not even tried to hide the body but just dumped it in the open.

“My grandson was born nearly seven years after my daughter’s marriage and even after that the couple kept having marital disputes. On January 5, she called and told us that my son-in-law had beaten her up. He also called us and said that we should take her back home to Kanpur otherwise he would kill her,” said Suresh.

The family also gave a written complaint on Wednesday against Shweta’s husband in which they have mentioned the incidents which happened since the couple tied the knot in 2011.

Shweta’s brother, Shubham Mishra also said that her husband was also asking for money from them and said, “In the past also, he had been physically violent with her and few years back, she had returned home to us and stayed for seven-eight months. She had also written to us saying that he was troubling her. My father had some money in the fixed deposit and my brother-in-law was asking for that as well. I cannot think of anyone who would want to kill her and I am certain that he killed both of them. We want police to arrest him and he should be given the maximum punishment.”

Cops are checking the veracity of the allegation but till now have not arrested either the husband or anyone else in the matter. The crime has shocked not just the residents but also police and an official added this kind of brutal murder is very rare especially of the baby and we all are shocked that someone can commit such a crime in broad daylight.

Title: Hyderabad: University students boycott class, no impact on schools
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Osmania University students participate in a demonstration against violence on JNU campus.

HYDERABAD: A section of students of University of Hyderabad (UoH), Osmania University (OU), Maulana Azad National Urdu University (Manuu) and the Tata Institute of Social Sciences (TISS), Hyderabad boycotted classes and held a protest at their campuses in support of the All India General Strike on Wednesday.

Led by UoH students’ union, a rally was held from the Life Sciences building to the main gate. “Our agenda is clear – oppose CAA/NRC, seek employment for all and make universities a safe hub for students where they can voice their opinions,” said UOH student union president, Abhishek Nandan. A section of students from Manuu also participated in the protest by boycotting classes.

At OU, members of the Dalit Minority Students Association burnt effigies of the Bharatiya Janta Party at the Arts College. OU students demanded the release of Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad. The students also organised a protest rally demanding revocation of CAA and NRC at Arts College on Wednesday morning.

TISS students extended their solidarity with Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) students as they opposed the CAA and NRC. “The country is under turmoil due to the introduction of sectarian and communally motivated CAA and NRC. These laws are undoubtedly capable of polarising the society and destroy the secular garb of the state,” read a statement issued by TISS students.

While classes were affected in universities, there was no impact in schools and other colleges. Practical exams of class 10 and class 12 students in Central Board of Secondary Education schools went on smoothly in all schools. The Joint Entrance Examinations (Mains) also saw no undue interruptions.

Title: As fires ravage Australia, Telugus lend a helping hand
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Krishna Ganugapati (in blue shirt) along with other volunteers has been organising drives to provide essential... Read More

HYDERABAD: As bushfires continue to rage in Australia , Indians are doing their bit to help people whose homes have been destroyed and protect animals who have become the chief victims of the calamity.

With Victoria facing the brunt of the bushfires this month, local Indian-Australian community members have been organising donation camps, food drives and gathering emergency supplies.

One of the most challenging jobs has been that of Karthik Thanigaimani, a volunteer with the Country Fire Authority (CFA), Point Cook Fire Brigade. He has been at the frontline, battling the fires starting from New South Wales. Speaking to TOI, Thanigaimani said he has been part of several ‘strike teams’ trying to prevent the fires from spreading deployed at ground zero for about five days at a time. “At the line of containment, we take up several measures including backburning, a controlled burn mechanism,” he said. The infrastructure architect working for Infosys says he will probably be deployed again soon.

Madhav Vadepalli, who hails from Secunderabad and is an entrepreneur in Melbourne ’s Werribee south, has been gathering relief material for wild animals that have been displaced or injured because of the raging fires. “Many animals such as kangaroos, koalas and possums are being looked after Werribee Open Range Zoo after their habitat was destroyed. Zoo authorities made a plea for cotton or flannelette material to make pouches or wraps for the animals,” Vadepalli said.

According to Vadepalli, the most tragic event of this crisis is that among the animals are rescued, many are still very young. “Joeys (infant kangaroos) need pouches to replicate the feeling of their mothers carrying them,” he said. Vadepalli and other volunteers have been going around collecting material that can be used to help the recovery process.

“We have been collecting tonnes of supplies to help those affected. In fact, now we have been asked to stop since there is not enough storage space. People are being urged to make monetary donations,” said Krishna Ganugapati from Melbourne’s Tarneit, who owns a petrol station in Maffra, close to the fires in East Gippsland region. Several local temples have carried out their own fund-raising activities and restaurants being run by Indians were providing food for those displaced.

Instrumental in the organisational effort has been Karthik Arasu. Though back home on a vacation, his heart has been with those hit by the fires. "I asked some of my friends to get together and plan the thecamp. Water, non-perishable food, toiletry and other emergency requirements have been a priority.” He added that several local temples have carried out their own fundraising activities and restaurants being run by Indians were providing food for displaced for free.

Title: Bengaluru: Wrongly placed sign gives resident false hopes of gas link
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

A GAIL gas yellow safety marker outside an HSR Layout house.

BENGALURU: A resident of Sector 3 in HSR Layout noticed a yellow safety marker carrying GAIL Gas Limited (GGL) markings right outside his home indicating that a PNG line ran under the road. He approached the utility hoping for a new connection.

His application was, however, rejected after preliminary digging in the area made it clear that there was no pipeline running under it. The contractor employed had erroneously installed it there , GAIL claimed.

“The marker, as claimed by a few people, is not fake. It is a genuine GGL safety marker. It has however, been put up in a road which does not have a pipeline running through it — an error on the part of the contractor who was entrusted with the job,” said a GAIL official.

“Three months ago, we issued instructions to all our officers to replace broken or damaged safety markers in the city with new ones. Pipeline works were supposed to be taken up at 15th B Main as per our previous plan. However, BBMP changed the rules last year, which prevents us from carrying out any work on newly asphalted roads for three years. The contractor was not aware of this,” explained the official.

“We have permission to build our network over 100km in HSR Layout. That particular road stretch, however, still does not have a pipeline running under it,” the GAIL official added.

Although GAIL passed the blame on to the contractor, a previous document published by it says: ‘The contractor shall supply, fabricate and install the pipeline markers along the pipeline route. The locations of markers as indicated in the approved drawings shall be treated for guidance purposes only and the exact location shall be based on built drainage and as directed by the company.”.

GGL said all such wrongly installed markers in the city will be removed soon.

Title: Lokotsav to feature live demos of Goa’s traditional crafts
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

About 20 artisans from around Goa will showcase their skills.

PANAJI: Aiming to celebrate those practising traditional crafts , the upcoming edition of Lokotsav will feature one of the biggest stalls dedicated to handloom weaving, woodcraft and pottery.

The section will also feature a live demonstration of these rare crafts, thus giving artisans a platform to spread awareness about their skill while also serving as a potent retail opportunity. About 20 artisans from Pernem, Sakhali and Dharbandora will be given the opportunity to showcase their skills through this platform over the course of the ten-day festival.

Handloom weavers will weave towels and bedsheets made from organic cotton sourced from the National Handloom Development Corporation Ltd while potters will showcase the art of pottery. It will also have bamboo artisans showcasing bamboo craft and handicraftsmen doing woodcraft.

“Since many rural Goans have stopped practicing these crafts, this initiative is an effort towards their revival,” said director of department of handicrafts, textile and coir Arvind Bodge. “The objective behind displaying the skills of these artisans live is to demonstrate to those attending the hand-holding support by the department. It will also create awareness and help develop an interest among other artisans participating in the festival to take up these vocations.”

The items created by the showcasing artisans will also be kept for sale. “The initiative will also open a direct market for artisans wherein we will be connecting consumers directly with manufacturers, thus eliminating the middle man,” Bodge said.

Lokotsav is scheduled to be held at Kala Academy’s Darya Sagar and the Campal ground, Panaji, from January 10 onwards. Artisans from various parts of the country, besides Goa, will be selling their art and craftwork at the 10-day festival.

Title: Jaipur: Ward 20 of Walled City has highest population
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Ward 20 under Hawa Mahal constituency with 16,199 people is the most populated ward in Walled City, which falls under Jaipur Heritage Municipal Corporation (JHMC) jurisdiction.

After the state government finalised the delimitation exercise and redefined the limits of municipal wards in Jaipur for the second time, the least populated ward is 55 under Jhotwara constituency with 8,491people. This wards falls under Greater Jaipur Municipal Corporation .

After new boundaries were drawn up, city has 250 wards, which includes 100 wards of Walled City (Jaipur Heritage) and 150 wards of outer area termed as Greater Jaipur Municipal Corporation (GJMC).

The exercise being s carried out according to the 2011 Census, when the population of Jaipur was 30.46 lakh. In GJMC, ward 76 of Sanganer constituency has highest population with 13,765 people. In Walled City area, ward 75 in Kishanpole constituency is the least populated with 8,800 people. The delimitation exercise in the city was carried out for the fourth time in history. The JMC had 70 wards when it was formed in 1994. After that in 2009, delimitation was carried out for the first time and wards were increased to 77. In 2014, the number of wards were increased from 77 to 91.

Title: Bharat bandh: Cab and banking services take a hit in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Workers of Andhra Bank participate in a demonstration in Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: Cab and banking services were partially affected by the nationwide strike called by various trade unions protesting the Union government’s alleged anti-worker policies on Wednesday.

People who commute using app-based cab services faced inconvenience as they were not able to book cabs during early hours of the day.

“Reaching office was a hassle as I was not able to book any cab today. It is particularly difficult to get transport during peak hours in the morning. I was forced to take a bus after repeatedly trying to book a cab for almost half an hour,” said B Jhansi, a resident of Ramnagar. Another commuter, Phani Kumar said: “The cab drivers were not accepting any bookings today. I was fortunate enough to find an auto from my place to the metro station.”

However, with most vehicles including metro rail, buses and autos plying on city roads, there was little impact of the cab strike on transport services.

Meanwhile, operations in all public sector banks in the city also seemed to have been affected during the day.

“Except SBI, most banks have extended their cooperation to the strike and stopped all counter operations such as cash deposits and withdrawals. This affected only those who deal in cash transactions,” said a public sector bank employee on condition of anonymity.

Trade union leaders informed at a protest meeting that the employees of state-owned Singareni Collieries Company and several other workers belonging to various trade unions participated in the strike.

Power sector employees, workers and engineers also went on a strike on a call given by National Coordination Committee of Electricity Employees and Engineers (NCCOEEE), a united platform of unions and federations of electricity employees and engineers.

They have been fighting against the Union government’s move to pass the Electricity (Amendment) Bill as well as other privatisation policies, which they say are against the power utilities, consumers and employees.

Title: Updation of voters’ list set to begin
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The exercise to update voters’ list before local body elections, scheduled for end of 2020, will begin on January 20, state election commissioner V Bhaskaran said here on Wednesday.

The elections will be held in 941 grama panchayats, 152 block and 14 district panchayats and 86 municipalities. Mattannur and six municipal corporations will be excluded from it. Voters’ list of wards that went for elections after 2015 would be used in the draft list that would be published on January 20. In other wards where elections were last held in 2015, the voters’ list of 2015 would be used.

Those who have completed 18 years of age as on January 1, 2020 are eligible to be included in the voters’ list. Opportunities will be available for corrections and additions of details in the current list. Draft voters’ list is available for the public at all local self government institutions. It is also available on www.lsgelection.kerala.gov.in. Copies will be available for free to all recognized political parties and parties with representation in state legislative assembly. tnn

Title: Student satyagrahis strike an emotional chord in onlookers
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Bengaluru: From sewing the map of India using pieces of clothes to sharing sambar-rice with complete strangers, a 24-hour protest by students against recent hooliganism at Jawaharlal Nehru University ( JNU ), New Delhi, climaxed on a buoyant note on Wednesday at Maurya Circle.

The relay protest — from 6pm on Tuesday to 6pm on Wednesday — was organised and led by students and supported by 'Hum Bharat Ke Log', a federation of more than 50 NGOs, individuals and activists, registered a presence of 1,500 to 2,000 students at any given point of time, organisers said.

The protest was live screened at JNU and Shaheen Bagh in New Delhi through Instagram, which the protesters described as an ‘emotional moment’.

Saqib Idrees, 21, said that following the JNU attack , around 50 students had decided to come together at Maurya Circle and sit down for a long Satyagraha , but the protest snowballed into a massive demonstration defying all expectations.

The overnight satyagraha also saw an exchange of food, help and support from the most unexpected quarters.

“One person saw us standing, sitting and lying down on the road and got a red carpet without any hesitation. Someone set up an extra tent for us free-of-cost. Later in the night, Savera Tea served free tea to 2,000 people. All of this was heart-warming,” Idrees said.

Idrees was also on a hunger strike from 4pm on Tuesday till 4pm on Wednesday and replicated the candle-protest of ‘Shaheen Bagh’ where protesters were seen enduring the pain of melting candle wax on their palms. “I was joined by a stranger. It is symbolic of our movement, which connects us all without any introductions,” he said.

Prachi Shah, a student, said she was at the protest site after 10pm and saw people exchanging packs of biscuits and fruit juice. “Most of them were meeting each other for the first time. Then, a local resident got us sambar and rice,” she said.

“We have had night-outs studying, chatting and partying. Now is the time we spend time doing something worthwhile,” she said, adding that they also educated people around about the Citizenship (Amendment) Act.

The support helped the students stay up the entire night and discuss ideas and compose poetry while making placards.

Zia Nomani, a member of ‘Hum Bharat Ke Log’, said, “The energy was amazing at the protest. We were discussing the life and times of Bhagat Singh and realised his time was different because he was fighting foreigners. Whereas, we are fighting our own people. So, it is important that we show restraint and maintain peace at all costs,” Nomani said.

Deepali Bhardwaj, a student said, “Teachers and professionals too are participating in the protests.” She added that the attack on JNU students has also changed the ideological leanings of some parents she knew, who earlier were against the protests.

Guha joins protest

Historian Ramachandra Guha visited the protest site. “For too long, the western influence has tried to create an artificial divide between the Gandhian and Ambedkar sides. We must realise that they were two individuals who had their disagreements but were united on several things. Like absolute commitment to ending untouchability, commitment to equality and in Gandhi’s case, absolute commitment to Hindu-Muslim unity,” Guha said.

He also asked the students to respect the importance of non-violence, both in action and deeds. “They will call you all kind of things, but don’t speak as they do. Stick to specifics and talk about the discriminatory legislation that the CAA represents, don’t speak of fascism,” he said.

Guha also applauded the diversity of the crowd and asked the students to keep the peaceful tempo of the struggle. “It will be a long arduous struggle, please keep it peaceful,” he said.

What youths want

* Quash FIR registered against JNU Students’ Union president Aishe Ghosh

* File FIR against masked attackers as against unnamed people

* Amit Shah resign as home minister

IIM-B students, faculty condemn attack on JNU

Students and faculty of the Indian Institute of Management, Bangalore on Wednesday issued a statement condemning the attack on students and faculty members of JNU. The statement is signed by 268 students and faculty in their independent capacity. It said the attack was an anathema to the principles of any open and tolerant society. “The systematic way in which universities have been targeted to silence ideological dissent is not acceptable under any terms,” the statement read.

Title: Afghanistan establishes consulate in Hyderabad, wants expertise to set up IT hub
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

(From L to R) Minister Mahmood Ali with Afghan Embassy’s Tahir Qaadiri and Afghanistan deputy foreign minister... Read More

HYDERABAD: The Consulate General of Islamic Republic of Afghanistan in Hyderabad was inaugurated on Wednesday. This will be the country’s second consulate in the country with the first one being in Mumbai. Afghanistan has its embassy in New Delhi.

Stating that the establishment of the consulate will usher in new opportunities, Afghanistan deputy foreign minister Naheed Esar said: “While there exists air connectivity between Kabul, Delhi and Mumbai, we would like to add Hyderabad among the newer destinations in this corridor.” She added that economic ties between the countries would focus in sectors such as transit, energy and trade. Esar invited businesses from the city to establish bases in Afghanistan.

The minister said the establishment of the consulate came at a crucial juncture for Afghanistan, when it is transitioning from being an aid-recipient country to a self-reliant one. Highlighting another dimension of Hyderabad’s relationship with Kabul, state home minister Mohammed Mahmood Ali said that there were many Afghan students pursuing their studies here. Besides education he also stressed on the need to build trade ties including in traditional items.

Charge d’affaires of the Afghan embassy in New Delhi, Tahir Qaadiri said that since Hyderabad was known to be an IT hub , it would be interesting to see a ‘silicon valley’ established in Afghanistan as well. “The inauguration of the consulate here will open south India to our nation,” he said and added that a Hyderabad-Jalalabad sister city partnership could be on the horizon. Mohammed Ibrahimkhil of the consulate in Hyderabad said that he looked forward to the deepening of historical ties between the two countries.

Title: Several stranded at Hyderabad airport as app-based cabs grind to halt
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

App-based cabs such as Ola and Uber cater to the maximum percentage of airport traffic.

HYDERABAD: Many passengers waiting to hire app-based cabs at Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (RGIA) on Wednesday morning faced inconvenience after many drivers switched off their devices, protesting the state and central government’s anti-worker policies. App-based cabs such as Ola and Uber cater to the maximum percentage of airport traffic.

“After waiting for my niece, who was initially stuck for a long time at the baggage collection point, we had to again wait for a cab for a long time. Finally, we hired a radio cab,” said M Yashaswini, a resident of Begumpet. However, services began running as usual after 11am. A video of police officials trying to convince the striking cab drivers to resume their duties also surfaced on WhatsApp groups.

“Nearly 3,000 app-based cab drivers participated in the national trade union strike at Hyderabad airport . The drivers switched off their mobile devices in support of the protest,” said Shaik Salauddin, chairman of the Telangana State Taxi and Drivers’ Joint Action Committee.

However, an RGIA spokesperson said, “We have no reports of inconvenience caused to passengers. Even if there was a problem with app-based cabs, we have radio cabs, Pushpak buses and other transport services at the airport to cater to passengers.”

Contrary to the claim of cab drivers’ association that 3,000 cabs at the airport participated in the strike, the airport spokesperson said that there are only around 500 app-based cabs at RGIA that are constantly shuttling between the city and airport.

Title: Hyderabad: Staff defy Centre’s warning, abstain from work
Content:
Insurance corporation employees hold protest in Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: Thousands of workers participated in dharnas and protest meetings across the city, including Dharna Chowk near Indira Park, as part of ‘Bharat Bandh’ call given by 10 central trade unions (CTUs) on Wednesday.The workers struck work, including at RBI regional office at Saifabad, LIC offices and Vidyuth Karmika Bhavan, Mint Compound among other places, despite the Union government warning trade unions of consequences if they went ahead with the one-day strike .Speaking at the protest meeting at Dharna Chowk, trade union leaders informed that lakhs of workers from Telangana participated in the strike, pressing for demands such as pay hike, social security, revision of minimum wage, five-day week among others.“While we have been asking for minimum wage of Rs 21,000 per month, the Union labour minister decides that we should be getting Rs 174 per day, which amounts to Rs 4,600 per month. With the cost of living in cities like Hyderabad increasing every day, how will we survive with a salary of Rs 4,600?” question All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC) general secretary VS Bose.“The minimum salary of a central government employee is Rs 21,000. They should be ashamed of themselves for looking down upon workers who toil day and night for the welfare of our country. Both, the prime minister and chief minister of Telangana should mend their ways at least now and take measures for rightful implementation of labour laws or resign from their positions,” Bose added.Revising the minimum wage is among the 13-point charter of demands, including measures from the government to contain unemployment. Former CPI general secretary Suravaram Sudhakar Reddy said, “At least three lakh workers from various trade unions participated in the strike. The strike was successful, but we will not stop with this if our demands are not met. We will be forced to intensify our protests in future.”
