Title: Mumbai University directs firing of 2 MCA teachers for ‘negligence’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Mumbai University

MUMBAI: To send out a strong message to “negligent” paper-setters, Mumbai University , in a rare move, has directed that services of two teachers be terminated and recognition of one be cancelled for three years, for repeating an old question paper for the Master of Computer Application ( MCA ) exam held in December. Till now, the university usually barred teachers from exam work for one to three years for similar “negligence”.

The teachers were in the paper-setting committee of the Statistics and Probability paper for MCA Semester-I students. The exam was held on December 11. The question paper, though, was exactly the same for the exam held on May 23, 2018. The questions throughout the paper were identical with an exception of the last. In the December 2019 paper, the first question is repeated as the sixth. In the May 2018 paper, questions one and six were different. Board of Studies for MCA confirmed the papers were identical.

After the confirmation, the university’s unfair means inquiry committee, after going through due process, decided to cancel the recognition of the paper-setting committee chairman for three years. This would mean that the teacher will not be able to teach for three years. The university has also directed the termination of two other paper-setters in the committee. The names of the teachers are withheld by the university as the examination process is confidential.

An official from the university’s examination section said they hope to send out a strong message to paper-setters. ‘The decision was taken after a thorough inquiry. This move may act as a deterrent for teachers who do not take the examination process seriously. We hope to avoid similar goof-ups in future,” said the official. The university administration has been taking stringent action against defaulting colleges for a year. It even withheld the sanction of a few colleges, which did not complete their quota of paper assessment, which delayed results in the past.

Title: Light-&-sound show fiasco may figure in ministry meet
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Jaipur: With the ‘turf war’ refusing to die down, the fate of RTDC ’s Rs 45 crore light & sound show projects hangs in balance. The fiasco is certainly going to be part of the discussion when the state tourism department officials meet their counterparts at the Centre on January 16, said an official.

Despite having selected the implementing agencies through a tender, RTDC is yet to issue work orders for the light & sound show projects.

“This shows all is not well in the tourism department. The minister has written to principal secretary of tourism, who is the chairman of RTDC, to cancel the tenders but there is no compliance of the letter. On the other hand, the RTDC is not issuing work orders to the selected bidders. The ice has to be broken if the government is serious about the project,” said the official.

All along, RTDC has maintained that its tendering process was fair and transparent but it has desisted from issuing work orders so far. “The issue has become a little sticky and only after the chief minister’s office (CMO) interferes, the logjam would end,” said another official.

TOI tried to speak to RTDC (Rajasthan Tourism Development Corporation) managing director but he said he is on tour and said can only reply after coming to office.

The turf war has also affected the functioning of the department. The department is yet to finalise the draft for tourism policy, while many other departments like the industries, renewable energy and agriculture have brought in policies.

“The department has to act fast now. They cannot delay things any more. If the department shows dynamism, it can get some Central projects for which applications are pending. As such, Rajasthan is not priority for the BJP-led Central government. That may be the reasons why the proposals for new circuits are still pending. On top of that if the tourism department in the state projects such a poor picture of it, there is hardly any chance to get any Central projects,” said the official.

Now, time has come to bury the turf war, forget the ego clashes and work for the promotion of tourism in the state, he said.

The funds have been received under the Prasad Heritage Circuit scheme, Swadesh Darshan and spiritual tourism scheme to put up light and sound show projects at 10 monuments.

Title: ABVP wants GU student council elections to be non-political
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

PANAJI: The Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad ( ABVP ) in Goa on Wednesday said that in view of the recent happenings at Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) in New Delhi, it should be ensured that Goa University student elections are kept free from political affiliations.

“It should be seen that Goa University elections are not fought with party affiliations, and that the elections should be open elections,” Prabha Naik said.

The last Goa University student council elections in August saw ABVP at loggerheads with BJP’s student wing, due to which the elections had to be postponed by the university.

ABVP had then said that it was because they were in a winning position that the Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha ( BJYM ) employed political pressure and tactics to postpone the election.

BJYM eventually won the polls amidst ABVP claims of political interference.

Title: Nitin Gadkari to inaugurate Khau Galli in Nagpur
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Nitin Gadkari

NAGPUR: City MP and Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari will inaugurate Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s Khau Galli — eating street — in front of Raman Science Centre, Gandhisagar, on Thursday at 6pm.

State energy minister Nitin Raut, home minister Anil Deshmukh, dairy development minister Sunil Kedar, Rajya Sabha MP Dr Vikas Mahatme, leader of opposition and former CM Devendra Fadnavis, MLCs Nago Ganar, Prakash Gajbhiye, Anil Sole, Jogendra Kawade, Girish Vyas, MLAs Krishna Khopde, Vikas Kumbhare, Mohan Mate and Vikas Thakre will also remain present.

Though there were 32 stalls at Khau Galli, only six eating joints will be operational from Thursday, said sports consultative committee chairman Pramod Chikhale.

Title: Experts: Growth projections for Amaravati unrealistic
Content:
Illustration used for representational purpose

AMARAVATI: Making it tough to defend the capital city project in Amaravati , expert panels say that none of the top global commerce and trade centres in the world is reporting massive Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) as projected for Amaravati.Singapore, which has become a hot destination for many multinational firms, is reporting 2% CAGR while Dubai is logging 7%. Surprisingly, the planners of Amaravati had projected 16% CAGR in next 20 years.Interestingly, designers of Amaravati (comprising 29 villages) projected that the city would grow to a size of 1.5 crore population in a decade although it has a population of around 1.8 lakh, at present.According to Boston Consulting Group (BCG) report Singapore’s population increased by only 37 lakh in 53 years. Singapore had 19 lakh population in 1965 and it touched 56 lakh by 2019. While population growth rate is 0.69%, its CAGR stood at 2%. This is despite Singapore being considered as a global economic power house.“In this background, assuming to achieve almost 16% CAGA in a nascent city (this is not even a city) is like a wild dream,” said a senior official who monitored the studies of the expert panels for the capital city.He said that many greenfield cities planned in the last 50 years have failed to achieve the goals as the respective governments had failed to pump funds due to poor returns. The financial district project launched in China in 2008 could see a population of 30,000 even after a decade in spite of China’s vigorous attempts to make it a liveable city.The UAE spent close to Rs 30,139 crore to build a new green field city in Masdar to provide basic infrastructure for a population of 10,000. Similarly, it spent nearly Rs 20,000 crore to build another green field city, Neom.“This is why building a green field city has been found very unsuccessful as it requires massive quantum of funds to create infrastructure. The wealthy nations too could not afford the costs of building green field cities,” said a renowned architect associated with the experts panel.Many such new cities have failed to reach the targets due to poor economic activities. Only two new cities-Navi Mumbai (India) and Shenzen (China) were found successful thanks to the overcrowded neighbouring cities (Mumbai) and Hong Kong.The previous TDP government had planned roads and electricity works in Amaravati at a cost of nearly Rs.52,000 crore. Although the government awarded tenders for about Rs 44,000 crore, only works to the tune of nearly Rs 15,000 crore witnessed reasonable progress.While the six-lane highway between Vijayawada-Chennai never witnessed traffic jams, the CRDA initiated eight and 10 lane roads in the nascent city Amaravati.“It clearly shows as to whose sake these works have been planned? Who will get benefited except the contractors?” Dr LSN Prasad, asked a retired economics professor.

Title: Vizag as executive capital may tilt the scales in favour of Bhogapuram airport
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The proposal to set up the executive capital of the state at Vizag has opened up the possibility of the Union government clearing the decks for construction of a greenfield airport at Bhogapuram.

On January 3, responding to a query by Congress MP T Subbarami Reddy on commencement of works at Bhogapuram airport , minister of civil aviation, Hardeep Singh Puri, said, “We are in a position to facilitate this as and when it is ready.”

Officials of the Andhra Pradesh Airports Development Corporation Limited (APADCL) have viewed the minister’s statement as an indication of the viability of the project. “In all probability now, the Airports Authority of India (AAI) will stick to their earlier assurance of closing Visakhapatnam airport for 30 years once Bhogapuram airport becomes operational. The project would otherwise not be viable,” said Virender Singh, managing director and CEO of APADCL to TOI.

Construction of the airport has been mired in controversy since December 2015 when the AAI had given a written assurance to the previous TDP-led government that Visakhapatnam airport would be closed for 30 years once the airport at Bhogapuram became operational. However, after the TDP pulled out of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) in March 2018, the APADCL anticipated hurdles in the project and in December 2018, former minister of state for civil aviation, Jayant Sinha, ruled out the closure of Visakhapatnam airport, stating that the AAI had already spent crores to develop infrastructure at the airport.

A report carried in TOI on May 17, 2019 stated that the APADCL had proposed compensating AAI for the money spent on developing infrastructure at Visakhapatnam airport. Although the AAI had not responded to the proposal, the APADCL had pegged compensation amount at Rs 40 crore. AAI officials had said there was no reason to shut the airport given the rising number of passengers in the paste few years. The APADCL had already spent Rs 800 crore out of the Rs 24,020 crore meant for the project at the time.

“With the recent statement made by the civil aviation minister, we are hopeful that the decks for Bhogapuram airport will be cleared soon. The airport will be useful if Vizag becomes the executive capital of the state,” said a senior APADCL official to TOI.

Title: Cops look into role of contract killers in twin murder case, question hubby
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: The murder of mother-son duo is shrouded in mystery as police have not found any possible suspects but are questioning her husband Rohit Tiwari who has filed an FIR over his wife’s murder and abduction of the toddler.

Tiwari, in his complaint, stated that he had received a message on his phone asking for Rs 30 lakh ransom and Shweta’s number was used to send the message. The mobile is yet to be recovered.

Sources said unidentified accused took out Shweta’s phone’s sim card and put it in another phone to send ransom message. The first message originated from Sanganer area; though officials have not confirmed it.

“The knife looks to be unused and moreover there are high chances that more than one accused was involved in the killings. Even if the husband was involved, he might have hired contractual killers. There are many aspects of the investigation which we are looking at and at this point nothing can be said with certainty,” added police.

“We are questioning Rohit to get more details and as of now not taking cognizance of the ransom demand. The priority is to solve the double murder,” said Rahul Jain, DCP, Jaipur East.

Interestingly, on Tuesday, the canine of the dog squad had stopped close to the spot where the child’s body was discovered and had started barking but cops couldn’t find the body. Cops also questioned people who had visited the family’s residence around the time of murder but claim they are not suspects at present. Many questions remain unanswered in the murder case which has sent shock waves across the city. Besides, cops are still unsure if the knife found at spot was actually the one which used to slit Shweta Tiwari ’s throat on Tuesday. Additionally it was found that Tiwari was at work at the time of the incident.

“The knife looks to be unused and moreover there are high chances that more than one accused was involved in the killings. Even if the husband was involved, he might have hired contractual killers. There are many aspects of the investigation which we are looking at and at this point nothing can be said with certainty”, added a police official on condition of anonymity.

The biggest issue faced by the police in the probe is lack of CCTV camera in the complex’s premises and the official further said, “No one is saying anything and the biggest problem is that there are hardly any CCTV cameras in the complex because of which we are unable to get additional leads.”

Title: Bank strike: Transactions worth Rs 12,000 crore held up
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The strike was part of a nationwide strike call by All India Bank Employees’ Association

AHMEDABAD: As some 40,000 bank employees from across Gujarat went on a daylong strike on Wednesday, financial transactions to the tune of Rs 12,000 crore came to a grinding halt. Banking services including cash withdrawal and deposits were hit across most public sector bank branches where employees did not turn up for work, except for the State Bank of India group. The strike was part of a nationwide strike call by All India Bank Employees’ Association. Bankers are protesting several issues plaguing the bank employees.

Sharing more details, Janak Rawal, general secretary, Maha Gujarat Bank Employees Association (MGBEA) said, “All bank employees congregated outside the Sabarmati Ashram in Ahmedabad and participated in a peaceful protest march till the collector office in Ahmedabad.”

Bank employees from smaller centres including Palanpur, Bhavnagar, Rajkot and Vadodara, among others participated in the strike and held demonstrations at respective centres, said Rawal.

Bank employees are protesting non-revision of their wages. “We have demanded that wilful default be declared as a criminal offence. At the same time, government should initiate efforts to make recruitments in the banking sector,” Rawal further added.Sources said that ATM services were also hit in some places because cash vaults of most banks were shut due to bank closure and thus, money could not be loaded across places.

That apart, other banking services including cheque clearing and instrument issuance were also impacted due to the bank strike . Trade and industry body representatives said that repeated and frequent strikes by bankers are hurting businesses. “Since the bankers had announced a strike in advance, traders could plan their transactions and cheque deposits in advance. However, with daily transactions, cheque clearances, deposits and issuance of letters of credit and issuance getting halted, the business operations are bound to get impacted,” said Jayendra Tanna, president, Gujarat Trader Federation (GTF).

Apart from bank employees, insurance company employees also went on strike.

Title: FIR against contractor in city building fire
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Jaipur: A day after three labourers died in a building fire at Anita Colony area near Gandhi Nagar railway station on Tuesday evening, an FIR was registered against a contractor on Wednesday. “One of the injured labourer has registered an FIR against contractor Abbas,” Bajaj Nagar SHO Manvendra Singh said. He said they were investigating the matter. “Two persons are undergoing treatment at SMS Hospital,” said Singh. The incident took place around 8.15pm on Tuesday when the six labourers were working in the building where wooden interior work was in progress. tnn

Title: Chennai: Property tax rollback not effected online, say residents
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: More than 45 days since municipal administration minister S P Velumani announced rollback of the property tax hike in urban local bodies, several Chennai residents say the civic body’s online services are still asking for the hiked rates.

A Chennai Corporation official, however, said they had rolled back the rates online too and if there was any ambiguity, residents could petition the revenue department or their respective zonal offices and get it rectified immediately.

The government had announced on November 19 that it had set up a committee to examine representations against the tax hike and that till its report came, in the old rates would prevail.

Some residents’ associations had even written to the Chennai Corporation Commissioner seeking clarity on the status of property tax.

“The inaction on the part of corporation officials causes confusion and many residents are unable or unwilling to make the payment,” said V S Jayaraman of T Nagar Residents welfare association. Jayaraman acknowledged that the property tax rates had been rolled back to 2017-18 rates in some streets.

Jayaraman pointed out that in certain cases, there had been two increases because of change in usage. A resident of Motilal street in T Nagar was surprised to learn that the civic body had hiked property tax for 2017-18 itself due to the status of his property turning ‘tenanted’.

In September 2019, the property owner wrote to the revenue officials seeking clarity and documentary evidence as he had neither let out nor leased the property to anyone. The issue is pending before the Regional Deputy Commissioner, Jayaraman said.

The tax revision came about from July 2018 without any consultation with residents. Residents were also shocked by the quantum of tax hike -- as against the promise of keeping maximum raise at 50 %, residents of some localities complained that the tax went up by 600%. Residents associations in Nanganallur ( Alandur zone), for example, have decided to not pay until the old rates are put up.

Title: Second campus of KISS comes up in Baripada
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: Chief minister Naveen Patnaik inaugurated the Adani-KISS Tribal Residential School, the second campus of Kalinga Institute of Social Sciences ( KISS ), at Bankishole in Baripada, Mayurbhanj district , on Wednesday.

The residential school will provide free education to 15,000 tribal students from from Classes I to XII in the district. Inaugurating the school, Naveen said education is empowerment and real transformation is possible through education. “The work of KISS and its founder Samanta for the empowerment of tribals through education is praiseworthy,” he added.

The students of Class XII after passing out from Adani-KISS can pursue higher education in KISS deemed to be university, Bhubaneswar. It has also been decided by KISS that candidates belonging to Mayurbhanj district will get employment in the Adani-KISS School. Spread over 50 acres, the school is fully equipped with modern facilities and developed with complete financial support from the Adani Foundation, official sources said.

Chairperson of Adani Foundation Priti Adani said, “Education is the most powerful tool for social transformation. Adani Foundation is happy to strengthen the education scenario in the far-off tribal areas of Odisha by partnering with the prestigious KISS”.

On this occasion, a 50-bed hospital was inaugurated by Priti on the Adani-KISS campus. The 24X7 hospital will be managed by the Kalinga Institute of Medical Sciences (KIMS), Bhubaneswar.

Title: Rural police base may shift to Narsipatnam
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Visakha Rural Police headquarters may be shifted to a rural area from the city if the executive capital proposal becomes a reality.

The police are, however, chalking out their own plans. “If more districts are formed based on parliamentary constituencies, then Visakhapatnam will become three districts--Visakhapatnam, Anakapalli and Araku. If not, the base of rural police would be shifted from the city to a rural area, most probably Narsipatnam ,” sources said.

Visakha rural area, except Vizag city and its outskirts, has 43 police stations, including 14 in Visakha Agency and 11 Maoist-affected mandals.

The police have been on a continuous combing operation with armed reserve and special forces for the last 25 years. “Shifting is not easy. We need a vast area for armed reserve forces and quarters, besides other issues,” a senior police officer said.

Around 3,000 personnel including 1,000 Armed Reserve cops are part of the district police. Of 43 mandals in the district, 37 mandals with 902 gram panchayats come under Visakha rural police district, which has one woman PS, one crime PS, two traffic PS and two marine police stations apart from 43 law and order police stations in four sub-divisions. Of which two subdivisions Chintapalli and Paderu are facing the Naxals problem.

The proposal to shif Visakha Rural administrative wing and armed forces was mooted in 2012 when the police top brass discussed ways to crack down on Maoists.

Rural SP Babujee Attada said he has no communication about the proposal.

Title: Goa: ‘Resume mining, and till then, pay all retrenched workers Rs 20,000 a month’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The rally and public meeting also stated that the central and state governments are ‘against working people’.

PANAJI: Following a mass rally and public meeting that opposed the “anti-people” and “anti-labour” policies of the state and central govenments, the Goa Convention of Workers sent a list of demands to PM Narendra Modi, CM Pramod Sawant and governor Satya Pal Malik. They demanded the resumption of mining through the formation of the Goa Mineral Development Corporation and a retention (monthly) allowance of Rs 20,000 paid to all mining workers till the resumption.

“It will take a long time for the government to resume mining in Goa through auctioning. If they form a corporation, there will not be any legal hurdles. Till mining resumes, all retrenched workers should be compensated with Rs 20,000 per month,” said convenor of the Goa Convention of Workers, Suhaas Naik.

“The policies of the central and state government are against working people,” Naik said. “Instead of real issues like unemployment of workers, farmers’ and students’ issues, irrelevant issues are being debated nationally. There is large scale unemployment in the country. The government must focus on generating employment. There are no industries coming to Goa because there is no infrastructure. The government must look into all this so that many employment-generating industries come to Goa and provide jobs to people.”

The Goa convention of workers is a joint platform of all major trade unions and mass organisations, comprising the All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC), Centre of Indian Trade Unions (CITU), All India Bank Employees Association (AIBEA), etc.

A large number of lifeguards made their presence felt at the meeting demanding that the government resolve their issues.

Title: Cop arrested taking bribe of Rs 20,000 in Kota
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

KOTA: Anti-Corruption Bureau ( ACB ) sleuths in Kota arrested an assistant sub inspector (ASI), posted in Ramganjmandi police station of Kota district after he accepted a bribe of Rs 20,000 from an accused in a case for not arresting him and later sorting out the matter.

Assistant sub inspector Manhorelal Jat, posted in Ramganjmandi police station of the district was arrested on Wednesday after he had accepted the bribe from one Hariprasad Soni, an accused in a case under Sections 354 K(2), 506 and 509 of IPC, said ASP, ACB, Kota Chandrasheel Thakur.

The accused ASI demanded the bribe amount for not arresting the accused in the case and sorting out the matter, he added. Soni had approached ACB, Kota on Tuesday and lodged a complaint in this connection expressing his intention not to pay the bribe.

Title: Students can help keep Nagpur clean: Mayor
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Mayor Sandip Joshi on Wednesday appealed to the principals of city schools to help Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) educate students to involve their parents in keeping the city clean so that its standing improves in the upcoming Swachh Bharat ranking.

Addressing a conference of school principals at the Suresh Bhat Auditorium on Tuesday, the mayor briefed them about the NMC’s initiative to launch ‘Mummy, Papa You Too’ campaign, emphasizing on the role of citizens in keeping the city clean. The campaign will begin on January 13 and end on January 19, he said.

Deputy mayor Manisha Kothe, municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar and NMC’s education officer Priti Mishrikotkar were present.

Title: Hajipur rape accused now claims he was in Hyderabad on day of crime
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The well in which body of victims were found

Title: Lukewarm response to bandh call as life largely unaffected
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Panaji: Normal life remained unaffected in Goa on Wednesday on the day of a nationwide strike called by 10 central trade unions to protest against the government’s “anti-people” policies. Various labour unions held a massive public meeting under the banner Goa Convention of Workers, but the event failed to pull in private sector employees.

“Nobody was aware of the strike, at least in Verna. Everything was normal. Nobody was on the road so there was no impact here,” president of Goa State Industries Association Damodar Kochkar said.

While attendance at some nationalised banks was low, private sector banks said that there was no impact on their operations.

In Goa, the All India Trade Union Congress, Indian National Trade Union Congress, Goa Bank Employees Association, Centre of Indian Trade Unions, Goa Trade Union Confederation, Goa Bus Owners Association, BSNL Employees Union and several others participated in the strike. The strike in Goa began with a protest meeting and march from the circle near the Kadamba bus terminus at the city entrance and culminated in a massive rally at Azad Maidan in Panaji.

Some private bus operators stayed off the roads in solidarity with the strike call given by the unions, but public transport remained functional and commuters did not face any significant inconvenience in the state.

No violence was reported in the state nor did any of the unions enforce the strike.

Title: Village devpt officerheld for bribery in Bundi
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kota: Bundi ACB on Wednesday arrested a village development officer posted in Dhowda gram panchayat in Bundi district for accepted a bribe of Rs 44,000 from the husband of sarpanch. The accused had demanded the amount for sanctioning two bills of development and construction work carried out in gram panchyat and for not interfering in the process.

Title: Minor raped by relative in Bundi district
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

KOTA: A five-year-old girl was raped by her relative in Karwar village under Karwar police station of Bundi district around 3pm on Wednesday.

The accused fled after the minor started screaming. She was profusely bleeding when she was rescued by her family members. Police have lodged a rape case against the accused under sections of the IPC and Pocso Act. The girl was raped by her relative in a room in an agriculture field. She was playing near a well outside the room and her parents and other family members were working in the field, Karwar SHO Hariram Jajunda said.

The accused, who is reportedly around 18–20 years old, lured the minor to the room and raped her, the SHO said.

Title: ABVP-NSUI clash: Caught on camera, attackers ‘unknown’ in FIR
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Now, the case will be probed by city crime branch

AHMEDABAD: Even while videos of the clash on Tuesday afternoon between activists of the Akhil Bhartiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP), the student wing of the RSS, and the National Students Union of India (NSUI), the student wing of the Congress, captured many persons, without masks indulging in violence in public, city police have failed to identify anybody yet, and filed an FIR against 25 ‘unknown’ persons from both groups.

While the cops kept saying that a fair probe would be conducted, minister of state for home Pradipsinh Jadeja on Wednesday said the investigation had been handed over to city crime branch.

“Congress leaders have been trying to create law and order problems in Gujarat for long. In Gandhinagar, their workers attacked police (during the LRD protest), a Congress councillor was involved in the violence in Shah-e-Alam and pelted stones at police. Then, their workers armed with weapons had attacked the ABVP office. Now, the case will be probed by city crime branch,” said Jadeja.

City police sources said NSUI leaders injured in the attack and the Congress expressed no faith in Paldi police. “Their argument was that the cops had allegedly witnessed the violence as mute spectators outside the ABVP office in Paldi Gaam on Tuesday morning,” said a senior city police official.

There was high drama at Paldi police station on Tuesday night, as the cops took 17 hours to register the FIR. While DCP Zone 7 K N Damor claimed that two separate FIRs would be registered, police inspector B S Rabari of Paldi police, who had witnessed the violence, became the complainant. He filed a case of rioting and causing injuries with weapons against “25 unknown members each from the ABVP and NSUI”. The FIR was finally filed at 4.30am on Wednesday and did not include any names.

An official of Paldi police said, “NSUI leader and Hardik Patel’s aide Nikhil Savani, who was attacked, insisted on the names of Gujarat BJP secretary Pradipsinh Jadeja and Bhartiya Janata Yuva Morcha (BJYM) Gujarat president Rutvij Patel be included in the FIR. As Savani could not be convinced to drop these two names, the Paldi PI himself became the complainant and filed a case against unknown persons,” said a police official privy to the developments.

Senior officials said the investigation was transferred to crime branch because Paldi police was engaged in bandobast at various government-sponsored events in the city. “Crime branch will conduct a speedy probe in the case,” said the official.

Before the case was transferred to crime branch, Damor, on why no arrests were made despite exhaustive video footage available, said: “Investigation is on and we will watch the video and ascertain the identity of the accused. All accused will be booked.”

Title: Buses and trucks remain off roads, ministers ride pillion to reach Secretariat
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

BHUBANESWAR: The central trade unions’ call for a nationwide bandh against the Centre’s ‘anti-people’ policies on Wednesday evoked a mixed response in the state.

While buses and trucks remained off the road on Wednesday morning, the government said the bandh was peaceful.

Commercial establishments, banks, petrol pumps and schools remained shut for the day in Cuttack , Bhubaneswar, Rourkela, Berhampur, Sambalpur and Puri, among other places.

Commuters had a difficult time as the East Coast Railway (ECoR) cancelled three passenger trains (Cuttack-Bhadrak, Bhubaneswar-Berhampur and Paradip-Cuttack), and several other trains were delayed by hours because of ‘rail roko’ agitations in Bhubaneswar, Balasore and Jharsuguda stations.

In Bhubaneswar, big markets like those in Unit I and Unit II wore a deserted look. Shopping malls, too, were closed in the morning and opened only after sundown. Protesters took out marches and motorcycle rallies in the city to enforce the bandh.

Several ministers and officers were seen arriving at their offices on motorcycles. Steel and mines minister Prafulla Mallik and information and public relations minister Raghunandan Das were seen riding pillion on bikes to the secretariat or the Lok Seva Bhawan.

Those who travelled to Bhubaneswar by train and on buses on Wednesday could not proceed further from the railway stations and the Baramunda interstate bus terminal as autos and private city buses did not run. “I was stuck for more than two hours at Baramunda,” said Ritesh Sahu, a pharmacist who reached the state capital from Keonjhar by bus.

The JEE Main examinees reached the examination centres either by riding on bikes, or shelling out exorbitant fares to auto-rickshaws. Some even walked to the exam centres.

Anup Sahoo, Cuttack-Bhubaneswar additional commissioner, said police took more than 500 workers of Congress and the Left parties into preventive custody in Bhubaneswar. Bhubaneswar DCP (traffic) Sagarika Nath said those taking out motorcycle rallies without wearing helmets would face action.

The bandh disrupted coal transportation and production across mines in Talcher. Coal transportation to other states using railway wagons was also disrupted as agitators held rail rokos at Angul and Talcher railway stations.

Mining activities, including the loading and unloading of minerals, in the Joda mining sector also came to a grinding halt. Deputy director of mines (Joda) L D Nayak said, “The daylong bandh caused losses of about Rs 10 to 12 crore.”

Minister of state for home Divya Shankar Mishra, “The bandh was peaceful with no incident of violence reported from anywhere.”

The Odisha Pradesh Congress Committee (OPCC) president, Niranjan Patnaik, termed the bandh a ‘huge success’.

The BJD, however, distanced itself from the bandh. “We are not in favour of disruption of life,” said minister Raghunandan Das. The BJP called the bandh a ‘complete failure’.

Title: Illegal construction halted at heritage site
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Following the recent reports of neglect of the geo-heritage site of Erra Matti Dibbalu (Red Sand Hills) and initiatives taken by heritage lovers to clean up the site partially on Sunday, revenue department officials have prevented plans of illegal construction of cashew farmers, who were about to set up concrete structures at the site near Bheemili.

Heritage activists had noted boulders and stone blocks behind the site around a fortnight ago but were unsure of their purpose. On Tuesday, heritage activist Jayshree Hatangadi observed a lorry loading the blocks while passing by the site.

“On enquiry, a cashew farmer Ramulu told me that they had planned setting up a small house at the site for storage of cashew and other agriculture-related works. However, revenue officials have asked them to remove the stone blocks and warned them against constructions at the site. They are now clearing away the construction materials,” she said.

When contacted, tahsildar-MRO of Bheemili, KV Eshwara Rao, told TOI, “As soon as it came to our notice that a farmer is trying to construct a cement house on the government land at Erra Matti Dibbalu, we told them to clear the building materials immediately. The Coastal Regulation Zone (CRZ) norms do not permit construction of any permanent structure at the site. Erra Matti Dibbalu is a protected site as declared by the Geological Survey of India. If we find evidence of construction at this site, a criminal case will be booked.”

Title: Nagpur: In New Year, CBSE to focus on competency-based education
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

NAGPUR: The much-awaited ‘new year’ letter by CBSE chairperson, which lays down guidelines for the year , is focusing on competency-based education (CBE). Anita Karwal wrote to all affiliated schools and said CBE focuses on student’s demonstration of desired learning outcomes as central to the learning process. The other key guidelines laid down by the board is about keeping students fit through physical activities via the ‘Fit India Movement’ campaign.

Karwal mentions that all schools are expected to have well-defined learning outcomes for every grade, which are observable and measurable. She added that schools must help to “empower learners to focus on mastery of valuable skills and knowledge through these learning outcomes, deemed to be essential for success in life”.

Training of principals/teachers will also be pivotal to the board achieving their targets. For this, CBSE from time to time will be providing details about the training schedule and topics.

The board will be moving ahead to strengthen its initiative of ‘Hubs of Learning’ (Hol) to ensure enhancement of quality of education and promote self-improvement. Hol is a cluster of 4-6 neighbourhood schools for their collaborative growth and inspired self-improvement. The main aim of this collaborative partnership between schools is to create an ecosystem wherein the schools, in a hub, learn from each other and partner each other for best practices in various aspects.

Karwal is also trying to put in place a concrete system of self-evaluation to standardize the schooling ecosystem. The process of School Quality Assessment and Assurance (SQAA) involves two essential phases. Phase one is self-assessment, using different instruments of SQAA through an online method, whereas in phase two, the same is validated by the external peer assessor team by visiting the assessee school. The CBSE chief said this assessment should ideally be done once every three years, starting from the current calendar year. Soon, all schools will be provided with an online link for SQAA.

The Fit India Movement, launched by PM Narendra Modi, will now be integrated in schools from November. Every school will be mandated to six working days during the third and fourth week of November to celebrate the Fit India School Week. This would instill in students the understanding for regular physical activity thus enhancing their self-esteem and confidence. Board has tasked the schools for ensuring that all students, parents, staff and management actively participate in the campaign.

Title: No impact of bandh in city
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The nation-wide bandh call given by central trade unions, including Centre of Indian Trade Unions ( CITU ) and Indian National Trade Union Congress ( INTUC ), against the anti-labour policies of the BJP-led government at the Centre evoked only a partial response in Visakhapatnam district on Wednesday.

Members of various trade unions participated in the protests, ‘rasta rokos’, public meetings and human chain formations and sloganeered against the BJP-led government. Large numbers of police personnel were deployed at major junctions in Vizag city.

Arguments between protestors and the police broke out on National Highway (NH)-16 after a human chain formation brought traffic to a standstill and police were called in.

State-run RTC buses were operational later in the morning and a majority of commercial establishments stayed open. Most educational institutions declared a holiday.

Title: ‘Cops pressed me to drop Rutvij Patel’s name’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Ahmedabad: Gujarat NSUI general secretary Nikhil Savani, who is a close aide of Congress leader Hardik Patel, and hospitalised for a head injury, had refused to sign a copy of the complaint he gave Paldi police, alleging that they were pressuring him to not name BYJM Gujarat president, Rutvij Patel.

“Police have been pressurizing me to drop the name of Rutvij Patel. Massive police deployment has been made outside VS Hospital, where I have been admitted. If police do not file FIR against the culprits, I will sit on dharna in front of the commissioner’s office,” Savani tweeted on Wednesday. Congress and NSUI leaders alleged that the VS Hospital administration was pressurizing Savani to get discharged from the hospital.

“Savani had named Rutvij Patel and BJP leader Pradipsinh Vaghela, but the police are trying to convince us not to name them in the FIR,” said NSUI general secretary Bhavik Solanki. Gujarat Congress president Amit Chavda and party leaders met CP Ashish Bhatia on Tuesday over police’s reluctance to include the names in the FIR.

Title: E-membership drive by Congress proves sluggish
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: A digital membership drive by Congress which was rolled out in Goa to enrol 2 lakh members by January 15 has struggled to take off, with the party struggling to enrol more than 5,000 till date.

As part of a nationwide membership drive, Congress launched an app-based membership exercise in November, but the drive has been hit by technical issues as well as factionalism within the party.

“Right now, it is a pilot project, and whatever difficulties we are facing, we are sorting out. This is the first time Congress has gone in for digital registration,” said state party president Girish Chodankar.

When asked to elaborate, Chodankar said that practical difficulties in reaching out to supporters, along with poor internet connectivity, has slowed down the membership drive.

“There are practical difficulties where in one family of five people, only one person will have a smartphone and currently we can enrol just one person on one mobile phone,” said Chodankar.

AICC secretary J D Seelam launched the membership drive in Goa with a workshop being conducted to acquaint party functionaries with the app.

To prevent misuse and to ensure genuine members were enrolled, the app requires new members to provide their voter ID number and confirm their enrolment using a one-time password that is sent to the phone number.

“We are going aggressively from next week on,” said Congress spokesperson Urfan Mulla, who has been put in charge of St Cruz constituency. “If you ask me about only minority members, we have registered around 800 individuals in St Cruz.”

Since the membership drive began, Congress has succeeded in registering around 700 enrolment officers, while primary members were registered in Navelim, Cumbarjua and St Andre.

Title: Naveen Patnaik announces Rs 5 crore grant for Jagannath temple revamp
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Chief minister Naveen Patnaik on Wednesday announced Rs 5 crore development package of the Jagannath temple in Baripada . The preservation and conservation of the 16th century temple was a long-standing demand of locals and servitors.

“Today is a golden day for the district of Mayurbhanj. Today, the foundation has been laid for developmental projects worth Rs 200 crore while projects worth Rs 50 crore have been inaugurated. It includes drinking water and bridge and road construction and so on. These projects will continue the development of the state. We will continue our efforts to give Mayurbhanj a special place in the development map of Odisha,” said Naveen while addressing a gathering. The CM also announced that the government will develop various tourist spots in the district, like Devkund and Khiching. “It is indeed a matter of great pleasure that the chief minister considered the demand of the people of Baripada and sanctioned funds for preservation and conservation of the Jagannath temple here,” revenue minister Sudam Marndi said.

Title: Nagpur: Orange City Craft Mela from January 10
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

NAGPUR: The much-awaited Orange City Craft Mela organized by South-Central Zone Cultural Centre will commence in the city from January 10-19.

The event is a one-stop destination, offering a cultural potpourri to citizens. This year, the ten-day festival will have a bigger and better look in terms of participants and artistes.

Giving details of the festival to the media on Wednesday, Deepak Khirwadkar, Director of SCZCC, said, “This year’s craft mela will have a variety of stalls, food items and folk culture. People will enjoy it to the core.”

More than 150 handicraft artists will showcase their items at stalls. Tribal and folk artistes, around 300 in number, will perform at the event.

Around 25 stalls will be devoted to street food, Rajasthani food, desserts and many other cuisines. Folk artistes from different states such as mukkhate from Maharashtra, Ranappa from Orissa, pahadi dance from Jammu and Kashmir, Rikampada from Arunachal Pradesh, Veernatyam from Andhra Pradesh, Bhortala from Assam, Malvi dance from Madhya Pradesh and Lana singing and natkartab from Rajasthan will be at their dancing best.

“From January 15-19, every evening at 6.30pm, there will be a tribal dance performance. ‘Bahuroopi’ artistes from Rajasthan will be the highlight of the event,” said Khirwadkar.

Tribal dance performances will be presented by artistes such as Pungcholam from Manipur, Sabalpuri from Orissa, Purvantike from Karnataka, Gaur Madia from Chhattisgarh, Dhal Thumri from Assam, Sangrai Mong from Tripura, Bonal from Telangana, Siddhi Dhamal from Gujrat and Nagada from Haryana.

“Handicraft items such as pottery, furniture, handloom, dress material, jute craft and bel metal will be displayed. Waterproof tents will protect stalls from rains,” added Khirwadkar.

This year, the emphasis is on cleanliness. Bins, for wet and dry garbage, will be placed at various places on the premises.

Five women guests, IAS Madhvi Khode, social workers Kanchan Gadkari and Jyoti Bawankule, former mayor Nanda Jichkar and Muktadevi Mohite (fine arts department, Nagpur University) will grace the occasion.

The entry fee is Rs25 and the timings, 2pm-9.30pm.

Title: JNU violence: 6 students detained for ‘unlawful assembly’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Nashik: The Sarkarwada police on Wednesday detained six students’ activists at the premises of a city-based college for ‘unlawful assembly’ after they tried to persuade the college students to express solidarity with the students of Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) and protest against the brutalities by masked goons in the Delhi college.

The detained students belonged to Charta Bharti Vidyarthi Sanghatana and Samyak Vidyarthi Andolan outfits who had appealed to city colleges to observe a bandh to protest against the brutalities against JNU students.

Members of these students’ organisations went to various colleges on Wednesday forenoon raising slogans against the Union government and Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP). They condemned the incident at JNU and demanded immediate action against those responsible for the violence.

These students’ activists were armed with posters and banners decrying the incident at JNU and were critical of ABVP.

“The students of the country are fearful that similar incidents can take place in any educational institute. We demand that the powers-that-be act tough against those involved in the JNU incident to send right signals to the students’ fraternity of the country,” demanded the agitating students.

During their visit to one of the colleges in the Gangapur Road area, a police team from Sarkarwada asked the students to disperse immediately.

“It was an unlawful assembly of the students as Section 144 of Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) is in place in the city. We had to detain six of these senior functionaries of the two students outfits as they did not heed to our request to disperse,” police officials said, adding that all the detained students were taken to Sarkarwada police station.

Title: Now, explore tourism centres in ‘Anavandi’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The Kerala State Road Transport Corporation (KSRTC) has launched a campaign titled ‘The Great Anavandi Expedition’ to promote its services to tourist destinations in the capital. The initiative was announced in the social media page of KSRTC .

The Facebook post of KSRTC reads “Kerala is a Paradise of Travellers – God’s Own Country…The details of the services will be provided here”. The details of tourism destinations, bus stops and timing of bus services will be regularly updated on the social media page.

“KSRTC fares are much cheaper compared to alternatives. We have been receiving lot of queries about services to major tourism places in the state on our WhatsApp number 8129562972. So, we planned to provide details through the social media page, which is popular among regular travellers,” said a member of the social media cell, KSRTC.

On Wednesday, KSRTC shared the details of bus services to Kovalam Lighthouse beach, Hawah beach and Samudra beach. The stop for buses going to Kovalam is at the north bus stand in East Fort.

“The bus services to Kovalam start from 5.45am and bus services are available between Kovalam and East Fort at an interval of 15 minutes till 9.30pm. The KSRTC AC low floor bus services to Kovalam are also available for tourists.

In the coming days, bus services to other destinations such as Ponmudi and Neyyar Dam will be shared on the page.

People may also contact KSRTC control room (0471 2463799) and city unit (0471 2461013).

Title: Nagpur: Nurture talented students: Doctor
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Dr Chandrashekhar Meshram in conversation with Sagar Kadiwala, on Wednesday

NAGPUR: In this day and age, it is important to identify talent in the youth, encourage them and provide them opportunities to nurture their skills, said neurologist Dr Chandrashekhar Meshram, in an interview organized by Vidarbha Hindi Sahitya Sammelan at Mor Bhavan, Sitabuldi, on Wednesday.

He was interviewed by littérateur Sagar Khadiwala as part of ‘Samvad’ series which serves as a medium to interact with prominent personalities from various fields.

Meshram said, “Smartphones and TVs inhibit creative aptitude of people. They are silent killers. Advent of this technology is impacting all aspects of our life and there are barely any face-to-face conversations these days.”

Revisiting his childhood, he said, “My father was in health care sphere and he asked me to follow suit. I did my pre-medical studies from Institute of Science and MBBS from Government Medical College.”

“I was advised that lakhs of people have done MBBS, so if I wish to enhance my credibility, I need to attain the highest education in my stream. As I was interested in mathematics, I went for neurology as it requires logical thinking,” he said.

Speaking about the medical field in the periphery of Nagpur, Meshram said, “The dynamics between doctors and their patients and interpersonal relationship between doctors is better in Nagpur than in any other city as there is considerable interaction among everyone. I lived in Mumbai for a while but could not adapt to the fast-paced lifestyle where social life was negligible.”

When Khadiwala enquired about the cure for increasing cases of memory loss in senior citizens, Meshram said, “Research is still on in neurology. Memory loss usually occurs due to old age or deficiency of vitamin B12, generally in vegetarians, which causes dementia. As life expectancy increases, susceptibility to such diseases rises.”

Giving tips for maintaining a healthy lifestyle, he laid emphasis on the importance of regular physical and mental exercise. He said, “Physical activities improve blood circulation in brain. By mental exercise, I mean that one should never retire and sit idle. We must participate in social activities to keep ourselves engaged.”

Being chairman of Orange City Cultural Foundation, Meshram said Orange City International Film Festival is a means to provide a platform to local talent and encourage new artistes.

Title: Gujarat: ‘36,000km fibre network by March’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Of 7,692 villages, optical fibre connectivity has already been provided to 3,651 gram panchayats in the second... Read More

AHMEDABAD: To provide high-speed internet connectivity to thousands of villagers, the Gujarat government aims to lay 36,000 kilometres of optical fibre across the state by March 2020, in the second phase of the Centre’s ambitious BharatNet initiative. The first phase saw 16,000km of optical fibre laid to provide broadband connectivity to 6,400 gram panchayats.

“An optical fibre network of 36,000km will be laid in Gujarat in the second phase, or ‘BharatNet 2’. Some 20,000km of fibre has been laid. We aim to finish the remaining 16,000km by March 2020,” said Dharmendra Sharma, director, technical and infrastructure (ITS), Gujarat Fibre Grid Network Ltd (GFGNL).

Gujarat government floated the special purpose vehicle (SPV) GFGNL to work with the Centre’s Bharat Broadband Network Ltd (BBNL), which is setting up the optical fibre network under the BharatNet project.

GFGNL has been established under Gujarat’s science and technology department and is creating a backbone network which will help mobile operators, internet service providers and government agencies to deliver multiple services to the doorsteps of villagers.

Of 7,692 villages, optical fibre connectivity has already been provided to 3,651 gram panchayats in the second phase as of December 2019. “The project is at an advanced stage. All 14,000 gram panchayats will be broadband-enabled after the second phase,” Sharma added.

These gram panchayats are to be connected with a 100 Mbps bandwidth which is scalable up to 1 Gbps. “Gujarat is far ahead of other states in implementing this initiative, which will connect villages to the state capital Gandhinagar . People in rural areas will be able to get several e-services from the government,” said the science and technical education secretary, Hareet Shukla.

“School, colleges and hospitals under these panchayats will also benefit. Our plan is to provide services like e-education, e-health, e-agriculture services, e-government and internet to all villagers by 2020,” Sharma added.

ITI Ltd and GTPL Hathaway Ltd and Polycab India Ltd are implementing the project through the EPC (engineering, procurement and construction) model. The Centre has sanctioned Rs 1,943 crore for the second phase of BharatNet, while the outlay was Rs 500 to Rs 600 crore for the first phase.

Title: Mapusa urban bank stares at liquidation
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Mapusa Urban Co-Operative Bank (MUCB), which has till February 18 to find a way out of its financial woes, appears to have run out of options and time with the only source of hope resting on the state government’s intervention.

The economic slowdown and pressure on the banking system has caused even stable cooperative banks to shy away from a merger with MUCB.

“There is hardly any time for a merger now. The fall of Punjab and Maharashtra Cooperative Bank had a very bad impact on cooperative banks and we were really hit badly. Well established banks are worried that if they take over a bank that is under Reserve Bank of India’s sanctions then in the immediate term it will affect their balance sheet,” former chairman of the bank, Ramakant Khalap said.

The RBI, through a directive issued on November 18, extended the financial sanctions imposed on July 24, 2015, till February 18. RBI’s directions had come after MUCB sought additional time to complete a merger process with Thane Janata Sahakari Bank (TJSB). However, a few days after the directive was issued the merger talks were called off after TJSB’s shareholders expressed concerns over the proposed merger.

MUCB needs around Rs 50 crore as share capital infusion in order to come out of RBI’s financial sanctions, but with the government also struggling financially, options remain limited, officials said.

While admitting that the bank appeared to be heading for liquidation, Khalap said he was still holding on to hope. He also said that even if the bank was shut down, the 2 lakh-odd depositors would be able to get all their money back.

“The bank’s total deposits are Rs 350 crore of which Rs 230 crore is in government securities. Besides this, all the accounts are covered by insurance. We have calculated that we will be able to get Rs 170 crore in insurance, which we can pay to our depositors,” Khalap said.

MUCB also has real estate assets with a book value of Rs 90 crore, but the market value of the properties could be higher, Khalap said.

Title: Bandh-spooked Kolkata takes a chill pill
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Howrah at 6.33am

KOLKATA: Wednesday’s strike impacted Kolkata partially with stray incidents reported from various pockets. The banking sector was crippled but most offices — including Nabanna and those in Sector V — managed to operate normally. Ninety people were arrested but specific cases were yet to be drawn up. Among those detained, 23 are women.

The first incident was reported from Jadavpur where the bandh enforcers first blocked the Jadavpur railway station after a culmination of a rally led by local CPM MLA Sujan Chakraborty. Two trains got delayed. The bandh supporters then tried to block Jadavpur 8B bus stand. The protesters allegedly set a tyre on fire around 10.30am and reportedly attacked a bus and a police vehicle. Chakraborty denied any arson attempt. RAF was deployed in the area and Chakraborty was detained with 30 others.

Two more skirmishes were reported from Behala and Rashbehari. At Rashbehari, a group of Left and Congress supporters tried to block the crossing. The protesters ransacked a private bus before a police team led by DC (South) Meeraj Khalid intervened and RAF managed to bring the situation under control in 15 minutes.

At Behala, a CPM rally at Sakuntala Park came face to face with Trinamool supporters after they deflated the tyres of multiple government buses. One of it was sent back from Behala Bakultala . A huge contingent of cops escorted the bus till Behala Chowrasta. Trinamool supporters opposed the CPM for trying to “forcefully” implement the bandh and an exchange of words followed before cops intervened.

The flow of traffic was disrupted around 10am on the Central Avenue near Bowbazar where the bandh supporters tried to block the road and allegedly set a tyre on fire. A similar gathering was witnessed at College Street and the pro-bandh rallyists were pushed towards MG Road. A minor scuffle between cops and Left-Congress supporters was reported from Beliaghata as well.

The bandh enforcers and Bidhannagar police got involved in a skirmish at the Karunamoyee bus stand in Salt Lake after the former tried stopping government buses from leaving the terminus. Attempts by bandh supporters — led by CPM leader Koninica Bhattacharya — to try and block ticket counters at Dum Dum railway and Metro stations were quickly foiled by the security posted there.

Back at Jadavpur — and across Rajabazar, Burrabazar and Park Circus — the cops did not intervene immediately as bandh enforcers asked shop owners to down their shutters. But all obliged. “There were several students from SFI who were leading the protests at Jadavpur University gate 4. They did play cricket and chess on the main SC Mullick Road, but we did not let the normal flow of travel get hampered,” said a police source.

The police said they had made heavy arrangements at important crossings like Shyambazar, Ultadanga , Esplanade and Behala. Police have not yet received any specific complaint of arson from the city though “final reports were still being collected”.

Title: Organ donation policies in Maharashtra ideal: Bengaluru doctors
Content:
Representative image

Maharashtra has emerged a leading state in organ donation surpassing Tamil Nadu and Telangana in last two years

NAGPUR: Maharashtra has emerged a leading state in organ donation surpassing Tamil Nadu and Telangana in last two years. Policies of the state on organ donation are ideal and the network of zonal transplant coordination centres is very effective, said doctors from Bengaluru-based Narayana Health City.Narayana Health City is a leading network of hospitals having strong presence in south India, which earlier used to be leading in organ donation.“Maharashtra has good coordination between government and non-government sectors which has ensured high number of organ retrievals and transplants from brain-stem dead (BSD) donors. The state also funds many surgeries and transplants under various health schemes to help poor people in need of organ transplant,” said Dr Julius Punnen, senior heart and lung transplant consultant.Nagpur witnessed its first lung retrieval in September 2019. Punnen said rising number of organ retrieval is encouraging, but transportation and transplant services also need to be developed. “Currently, lung transplant in India is at a stage where kidney transplant was 20 years ago. Lungs are complicated organs and transplant needs many technical advancements,” said Punnen.Dr Basha Khan, senior pulmonology and critical care consultant, said less than 100 successful lung transplants have been performed in India till date. “A few doctors in India are trained in lung transplant. We have performed two lung transplants in our hospital so far,” he added.Bone marrow transplant is important for Vidarbha as the region has predominant number of patients who need this.Dr Sunil Bhatt, paediatric hemato-oncologists and an expert in bone marrow transplants, said, “Apart from various cancers, bone marrow transplant is final remedy in thalassaemia and sickle cell. The number of patients living with these diseases is more in Vidarbha, but donors matching them are hardly available. For this, more healthy people from Vidarbha should come forward and register as blood stem cell donors.”Dr Rajiv Ranjan Sinha, an expert in liver transplant, said awareness should be created about living-donor liver transplant in Maharashtra. “In living-donor liver transplant, a portion of the liver of a healthy person is removed and placed into someone whose liver is no longer working properly. It’s safe and can save many lives.”“Liver retrieval and transplant from brain-dead patient has become common in Maharashtra. The next step is to create awareness about live donor liver transplant,” he said.The Bengaluru doctors also conducted an interactive scientific session in association with the Nagpur branch of Indian Medical Association (IMA).

Title: Shimla snow makes toll plaza face the heat
Content:
A snow-covered view after the fresh snowfall in Shimla (ANI Photo)

PANCHKULA: Snowfall in Shimla has choked the Chandimandir toll plaza . Since the hill station wore a white mantle, the number of vehicles going towards the capital of Himachal Pradesh has increased on weekdays too, increasing the workload of the staff already struggling to manage the traffic following the implementation of FASTag.On Monday, 38,050 vehicles crossed the plaza. Similarly, on Tuesday, the number was 36,639. On Wednesday till 7 pm, the figure was 30,095 — 14,030 cash users and 16,065 FASTag users. The average count on weekdays is 30,000 vehicles.Staff said there has been a slight improvement in the number of FASTag users but poor pasting of stickers is making it difficult to scan them, leading to delays and chaos. “Vehicle owners are pasting the stickers on the front side of the windscreen. They must paste it inside and in the centre, so that it is easier to scan.”The toll authorities with eight manual FASTag scanning machines are working hard to manage the chaos. The Chandimandir toll plaza has ordered three more machines to manage the traffic. However, there is no relief to commuters using cash lanes. Only one cash lane is permissible.A FASTag operator said, “Some people enter the lane with empty FASTag wallet and start recharging their account online, leading to a long queue”.On the other hand, a security guard managing the traffic complained people have been fighting with them to let them enter the FASTag lane without having the sticker on their vehicle. “It is not possible for us to allow them to enter FASTag lane without the sticker. We have received directions and are just doing our job,” they said.A total of 14 lanes exist on both sides of the toll plaza, seven on each side. According to the new rule, if anyone accidentally enters a FASTag lane or is out of cash in his FASTag wallet, the person has to pay double the normal charge to cross the toll plaza.

Title: Ahmedabad: Will burn copies of CAA, says Jignesh Mevani
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

JigneshMevani

AHMEDABAD: Dalit activist and Vadgam MLA Jignesh Mevani on Wednesday said that he and other activists will burn copies of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) on January 10, when the state government intends to pass a resolution in the assembly in support of CAA .

Announcing his programme protesting the new citizenship law, Mevani said Gujarat chief minister Vijay Rupani should first provide evidence of his citizenship. “He has come from Burma (Myanmar). First, he should give evidence for himself. Until he shows the evidence for himself, we will not furnish our papers,” Mevani said at a meeting of activists who have decided to protest the new citizenship law.

Mevani said this is their non-cooperation movement against the “black law”. “Many members of de-notified tribes (DNT) don’t have documents. What will they do? This is an effort by the government to divert attention from real issues like unemployment,” Mevani said.

Another activist, Ashok Chaudhary, said, “The gradual curtailment of rights is an insult to the people. How can you ask a tribal person living in this country to prove that they are the citizens of this country? The country’s prestige as being a non-discriminatory state is crumbling.”

DNT activist Daxin Chhara said that DNTs lived in detention centres across the country for five years when the country became independent. The government later did not have any rehabilitation policy for these tribes. “It isn’t possible for DNTs to furnish documents if asked for the National Population Register (NPR) or National Register of Citizens (NRC). We will not give our papers even if we have them,” he said.

Title: Migratory birds in Jodhpur face Chinese manjha threat
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

JODHPUR: Deadly Chinese manjha has been taking toll on migratory birds in their winter abode in Khinchan in Phalodi . Two Demoiselle Cranes have been killed in the past two weeks and one has been under treatment at the rescue centre.

Following the deaths, the district administration has ordered police to take action against those selling Chinese manjha in the town. The deadly string has emerged as a new threat to the migratory birds in Khinchan injuring them during their flight.

ADM (Phalodi) Hakam Khan on Wednesday visited the habitat of the bird fondly known as “Kurjan” in the Marwar region and apprised himself with the issues related to the bird. A bird lover and expert on the bird Sevaram Mali said that the officer was informed about the emerging threat of the Chinese manjha to the bird. “We told Khan that two birds have been killed and a few are injured because of Chinese manjha in the past two weeks. Understanding this threat, he has given directions to the police to take action against the sellers of the deadly manjha,” said Mali adding that such incidents are reported every year and many die due to this manjha.

Recently about 40 birds had died of food poisoning after consumption of pesticide laced grains and many had got injured which had to be referred to the rescue centre where a team of veterinarians had provided them the medication to save them.

“We had given a representation to the administration last week requesting to undertake necessary works for the safety and conservation of the bird as Khinchan was synonymous with the bird now globally and large number of tourists and bird lovers converge here to watch the bird,” said Mali.

Khan said soon a meeting will be held by the administration with the tourism department, forest department, animal husbandry department and the municipality to address the issues of birds’ conservation and development of the facilities at the rescue centre.
