Title: 2 held for drugging and looting women
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Vizianagaram police on Wednesday arrested two persons for drugging two women and looting their gold ornaments after befriending them.

The accused have been identified as K Lakshmu Naidu of Srikakulam and T Prasad from Payakaraopeta in Visakhapatnam district. Over 300 grams of gold jewellery were recovered from the duo.

Explaining the modus operandi of the duo, Vizianagaram superintendent of police (SP) B Raja Kumari said Naidu and Prasad would befriend passengers, especially women, on buses and trains, and collect their phone numbers. They would then offer female passengers biscuits or chocolates laced with sedatives and loot their gold ornaments.

In some instances, they would call the women and invite them to lunch or dinner, and offer them a sedative-laced soft drink before looting their gold jewellery.

Based on complaints registered by the women, a special team was formed and the duo detained for questioning. Naidu and Prasad confessed that they had looted over 500 gm of gold jewellery.

Police said Lakshmu Naidu is a habitual offender and had also duped several youth to the tune of Rs 70 lakh by assuring them employment in the Indian Army. He has over 13 cases registered against him under various police stations in northern Andhra Pradesh.

Title: BSF steps up vigil due to fog
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Jaisalmer: Due to heavy fog at Indo-Pak border adjoining Rajasthan, BSF has been directed to maintain extra vigilance and more troops have been deployed at the border. Electronic surveillance devices & indigenous methods are being used to monitor security at the border. TNN

Title: New Opa water plant ops on Jan 17
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Ponda: The public works department (PWD) is gearing up to commission the newly-constructed 27MLD (million litres per day) water treatment plant at Opa on January 17.

Work on the plant had began in 2013 and was expected to be ready by 2015. The plant at Khandepar in Ponda taluka was set up to provide potable water exclusively to Kadamba Plateau in Bainguinim-Old Goa, which at present solely relies on tanker water, and to enhance the water distribution to Panaji city.

Pipelines have been laid from Opa to Panaji, and a 5,000 cubic meter (CuM) master balancing reservoir (MBR) has been constructed at the Curti hillock where the treatment will take place.

The water from the MBR will then be released through gravity.

PWD officials said the entire system, including MBR and the pipeline network, has been disinfected by backwashing and dosing it with chlorine.

Title: Woman held with paramour after husband found murdered
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Nashik: A 25-year-old woman has been arrested along with her ‘ paramour ’ for the murder of her husband in Takli village of Malegaon taluka in Nashik district on December 28 last year. The duo confessed to the crime, said police.

The woman was arrested from Takli while her paramour from Nashik city on Wednesday, said police.

Inspector K K Patil of the local crime branch, Nashik rural, said the body of a man was found in the bushes along a farm in Takli village on December 29.

The officer said that soon after the victim was identified as Sandeep Khairnar, police started inquiring from the inhabitants of Takli village if he had any dispute with anyone. Police shifted their focus to the victim’s family after the villagers said the man did not have any dispute or enmity with anybody.

“The crime branch then started investigating another angle and found that the victim’s wife hailed from Chikhalohol village and had an affair with the arrested suspect, Vilas Jagtap,” said Patil.

According to the officer, the woman was called to the Malegoan police station and quizzed. She admitted to having an affair with Vilas since her college days. They parted ways after their marriages, but got in touch after the death of Vilas’s wife nine months ago.

“Vilas then started frequenting the woman’s house when her husband used to be on duty at a fuel station. around 8.30 pm on December 28, Khairnar came home and found Vilas with his wife. Soon, a fight broke out and Khairnar and the woman strangulated him with a nylon rope. The same night, Vilas carried the body on his bike and dumped it in the bushes near the farm,” said Patil.

A few hours later, the woman called her father and other relatives and pretended that her husband had not reached home from work.

Police said the woman has two children aged below three years and that they have been handed over to their grandparents.

Title: Kota minor raped, held hostage in MP
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

Title: I travelled without fear, wish more people did
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

When I set off from home in Tobin Road for my shop at Chandni on Wednesday, there was no concern over the bandh call. The situation, after all, has changed in the past decade. In the past, travelling to the city centre and opening the shop was not an option. It was a risk to life and property. But bandhs have lost the venom in recent years and do not cast a shadow on life anymore.

Around 9.30am, I hailed an auto and reached Sinthi More in seven minutes. There, I was surpised at the length of the queue. Usually there are eight to nine persons. But on Wednesday, there were around 40. One state bus did come but it was so crowded that boarding it was impossible.

After a 45-minute wait, I got into an auto and reached Shyambazar in 15 minutes. With few buses around, I decided to take the Metro and was at Chandni in 20 minutes. There, I joined some shop-owners who had arrived and waited for the others. This has been the practice in recent years. We wait till everyone has arrived and then open the shops together. If the concesus is on keeping the shutters down, we do so. But that hasn't happened for a while.

Wednesday though seemed different with a group of youths with Congress flags gathering on the street and getting into a scuffle with cops. Soon, there were other youths trickling out of lanes and joining the motley group. This did not bode well. It was defintiely not like the pitched battle one used to witness on bandh days earlier but it wasn't normal either. After an hour of monitoring the situation, we decided not open shops.

The return journey was uneventful but for the long wait for the auto at Shyambazar. All along the way, I kept wondering why we were allowing bandhs to make a comeback. Though other shopkeepers and I had not witnessed picketing, forced road blockades or scenes of violence, the absence of people on the road going about their everyday lives made the difference.

I don't know why people stayed away. For someone who wished to travel, it may have taken a little more time but it was not that difficult. Those who have their own transport, the thin traffic meant travel was a breeze on Wednesday.

Ghosh, 28, has a family engineering machinery business

Title: West Bengal: Fewer private buses, cabs on road, government fleet saves day
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Passengers rush to get on to a bus in Ultadanga on Wednesday morning

KOLKATA: There were more state buses on the road than usual on Wednesday but many private transporters chose to play safe, leading to fewer buses and cabs on city roads. Yet those who wished to travel within the city, either to work or to someplace else, did manage to do so with that extra commute time.

State buses hit the road in numbers with drivers in helmets geared for trouble. Though it wasn't like the Opposition-called bandhs during the Left Front regime when near-empty buses plied on the streets, the number of commuters were fewer than a regular weekday.

A state transport department official said it operated 1,150 buses in the city on Wednesday against the usual 900. But with some neighbourhoods like localities on either side of Sarat Bose Road dependant only on private buses that were nearly half the usual numbers, residents had a tough time.

So did those who travel by cabs. App cabs, less in number, were so much in demand that they proved tough to book. A family that arrived at Sealdah station was still waiting for the app cab they had managed to book 40 minutes earlier while another family found it frustrating as no cabs were available on the app for nearly half an hour. However, there were plenty of yellow metered cabs in sight. But none were willing to go on meter and demanded nearly twice the rate.

At the airport, the taxi count was half the number that usually report at the pre-paid counter at Kolkata airport, leading to longer waiting time. Passngers had to wait an additional 20-45 minutes for taxis. Those who availed buses though had no such issue with more number of Volvo buses servicing the routes.

“The situation was alright most of the day barring a period between 11.30am and 1pm when the number of cabs had reduced to single digits,” an airport official said. That shuttles operated in good numbers came as a boon for IT employees travelling to and from Sector V.

Title: 7 impersonators arrested by Agra cops during UPTET
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Agra: In a joint operation by various Agra police teams, seven impersonators, including cheating mafia kingpin, were arrested during Uttar Pradesh Teacher Eligibility Test (UPTET) on Wednesday.

The arrests were made at different locations after police teams caught an impersonator, identified as Ravi Ranjan of Rajendra Nagar Patna, who was appearing for a candidate at an examination centre Khalsa Santosh Singh Inter College of Rakabganj police jurisdiction. An FIR was registered.

“During interrogation, Ravi revealed about the man, identified as Bhavesh of Sadabad, Hathras, who recruited him for the impersonation job. Further investigations revealed that Bhavesh worked for cheating mafia gang which was operated by Ramhari of Dholpur and Komal Singh of Agra. Several teams were dispatched to arrest the gang’s kingpin and other impersonators appearing for candidates in the UPTET,” read Agra police press statement.

The other accused apprehended were Neeraj Sharma, Ramavatar Singh, Satyabhan and Raviranjan Sharma.

Title: Helmet rule violators galore despite regular campaigns
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

(blurb: A total of 31,697 two-wheeler riders were fined for flouting the helmet rule last year while action was taken against 21,392 in the year 2018.)

Nashik: The year 2019 saw 10,000 more bikers without helmet and being fined for flouting the rule as compared to the year before that, despite sustained awareness campaigns by police as well as other stakeholders on the importance of the headgear towards personal safety.

However, the continuous action by police against bikers without helmet is evident from the fact that more than 90% of two-wheeler riders are seen using the headgear in the city.

According to data available with the traffic branch of the city police, 21,392 bikers were fined for not wearing helmet in 2018. However, the number of such violations in 2019 increased to 31,697.

A senior police officer (traffic) said it is easier to spot and fine two-wheeler riders without helmets now because most people have started following the rule. “This is in stark contrast to the scenario in 2018 and the years before that as only one in 10 bikers wore the helmet.”

Police said that their aim is to bring down the rate of fatal accidents on the city’s roads. The maximum number of deaths in road accidents is due to head injuries suffered by bikers in the absence of helmet.

“Taking into account the fatalities due to the violation of the helmet rule, a massive drive was launched throughout the year against two-wheeler riders,” said the officers.

Police officers said the drive against helmet rule violators will continue with the same zeal until 100% bikders follow the rule for their own safety.

Title: Two held for stealing defence gadgets worth Rs 12.5 crore
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

ALWAR: The Behror police seized a truck that its owner had reported stolen as part of a plan to sell off a consignment worth Rs 12.5 crore meant for security agencies, including Army and Indian Air Force . The truck owner Dharmendra Singh (44) and driver Pintu Kewat (28) were later arrested in Alwar district and most of the consignment was recovered.

According to the police, the truck carried electronic equipment and the two men had planned to sell it as scrap.

The police refused to disclose the exact nature of the consignment or the establishments in Kota and Jaipur where it was to be delivered though sources said that the consignment contained hardware, software and technical equipment. A case related to truck carrying grocery items being stolen from an eatery on Behror highway was registered at Behror police station on January 4.

Title: Rajasthan: Gangster Papla’s close aide held
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR/ALWAR: Rajasthan ’s Special Operations Group (SOG) arrested gangster Vikram Singh alias Papla ’s close aide from Haryana’s Mahendragarh. The accused had planned and executed Papla’s escape from Behror police station on September 6, 2019.

The arrested person has been identified as 27-year-old Dharamveer who was a wanted criminal in Haryana with a reward of Rs 50,000 on him.

Anil Paliwal, ADG, SOG and ATS said, “The accused had also helped Papla escape from Mahendragarh district court premises in September 2017. He was the main accused in Papla’s escape from Behror police station four months back. He was the one who had called all the gang members and asked them to fire at the cops with the intention to flee with Papla.” The accused is being questioned at present. Till now police has arrested 24 accused in Papla break lock out of which 13 are those who had rewards on their arrest.

Papla, who is wanted in Haryana for five murders, was taken into custody by Behror police after he was found to be in possession of approximately Rs 31 lakh. When he was being held at the police station, at least 15 of his gang members barged into the station and fired indiscriminately with AK-47s and fled with him. Although teams have been working to track Papla, they are yet to trace the elusive gangster.

Title: 100-year-old ‘makar’ donated to museum
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Usually, a ‘makar’ is styled to have rectangular squares wherein painted glass is mounted on each square on ei... Read More

PANAJI: A century-old ‘ makar ’ (a wooden swing with a frame), which was earlier used during Makarotsav to display the idol of goddess Mahalasa was recently donated to the Goa State Museum. A family heirloom of Shiroda-based Sudesh Desai, themakar is on display at the Adil Shah Palace in Panaji until January 10.

Usually made from teakwood, a ‘makar’ is styled to have rectangular squares wherein painted glass is mounted on each square on either side of the idol. In recent times, people decorate the squares with coloured paper instead.

“A makar is displayed only in the chowk or the middle of the temple and the idol is placed inside the largest square of the makar,” said Subhash Jan, a Ponda-based professor at Ameya HIgher Secondary School in Curti.

“The deity is decorated with gold ornaments and the makar is decorated with flowers during Makarotsav. The festival is only seen in the temples that have moved out of Antruz (Ponda) due to Portuguese atrocities,” he added.

“The music played during makarotsav has percussion instruments like dhol, tasso and surt besides the tasale (metal instrument) and shehnai (wind instrument). The music played at the festival is very different from other festivals in Goa,” Jan said.

Visual images of the festival –– which showcases various incarnations of goddess Durga and the idol dressed in nine different outfits over the nine days of Navratri –– have been displayed at a temporary exhibition at the Adil Shah Palace as part of the museum week celebrations, this year.

“So far, there is no study done on the Makarotsav festival. The photographs are therefore an effort towards documentation of the festival.” said director of the Goa State Museum, Radha Bhave.

Title: Pak migrant sisters fleeing from Jodhpur kin seek cover
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Jaisalmer: Two sisters, who are migrants from Pakistan — and are on the run from their relatives who allegedly tried to sell them — met Pokhran SDO and have sought security. The duo migrated from Pakistan with their family in 2015 and have been residing at Lodta village under Dechu police station in Jodhpur district. The SDO has requested Balotara dy SP to provide them with security. Lakshmi (24), belonging from Hindu Bhil community, is a migrant from Pakistan and has been trying to flee her relatives in Jodhpur, who allegedly tried to sell her and her sister. She, her sister and two children have thus sought security from her relatives who have also threatened to kill them. Her family is scared and hiding at different places. She also gave a memorandum in the name of home minister to SDO. TNN

Title: High-altitude half marathon to become annual event
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Inspired by the huge success of the high-altitude half marathon , organized at Ponmudi last Sunday, ITEN Runners’ Club plans to make it an annual event. As many as 230 runners participated in the second edition of the Golden Peak Half Marathon.

The 21km uphill run, which began from Government Higher Secondary School, Anappara, and concluded at Ponmudi Upper Sanatorium, covered 22 hairpin bends. It ended 3,400 feet above sea level. The race was flagged off by the school PTA president Sivankutty Asari. There were a few participants from the UK, USA, Australia and Poland also.

“Our club has been conducting training in the uphill route in Ponmudi for past many years. Permission was sought from forest department, police and other officials concerned as the area is ecologically fragile. The Golden Peak Half Marathon is challenging because of the terrain. Only those with previous experience of participating in half marathons were allowed to register. This marathon tests the endurance of even seasoned runners,” said Shino Mol Palathanath, organizing committee member.

“A larger crowd could upset the balance of such a pristine and sensitive environment. As the club advocates and practices responsible running, registration was closed after 230 people had registered for the run,” she said.

The club aims to promote marathon as a sport rather than a fitness activity through these events.

The organizers of the marathon collected the waste generated after the event and brought it back to the city for proper disposal.

The competition was held in open, senior, veteran and super veteran categories. Aji P won in the open category (men) and Merina Mathew won in the open category (women). Christopher Roberts from Australia won in the senior category (men) and Rema A K in senior category (women). Pradeep Kumar won in veteran category (men) and Jessy P Jacob won in veteran category (women). Paul PI won in the super veteran category.

Title: Secunderabad: Ensuing SCB election sees a flurry of first-time hopefuls
Content:
The office building of Secunderabad Cantonment Board

SECUNDERABAD: With Secunderabad Cantonment Board ( SCB ) elections round the corner, the number of aspirants hoping to win a seat has grown substantially.With former civilian ward members and their kith and kin already vying for a top spot in the poll race, many new faces have also shown keen interest to fight the election. Several aspirants have started interacting with voters to understand their concerns. Meanwhile, leaders of various political parties have begun to lobby to bag a ticket.“We do not have any political experience to contest the polls . What is needed is a clear understanding of local civic issues and the will to resolve them,” said a youngster who is hoping to enter the poll arena.The Cantonment board election is considered by political parties as prestigious and hence, all parties are busy selecting the most eligible candidate to put forward.For instance, TN Srinivas, who currently serves as chairman of agriculture market committee (AMC), Bowenpally, is a close aide of Secunderabad Cantonment TRS MLA G Sayanna. Srinivas is keen to enter the fray as tenure of an SCB ward member is five years whereas the post of the chairman of AMC lasts only one year. Outlining his plans, he said: “I have decided to contest the SCB elections. I need Sayanna’s blessings.”Similarly, Anand Babu, who is a close aide of Malkajgiri TRS MLA Mynampally Hanumantha Rao, and TDP leader Muppidi Madhukar, who is currently a TDP Cantonment coordinator, are likely to contest from ward 1.While Shravan Kumar of BJP and DB Devender are likely to contest from ward 3, P Narasimha Yadav and Telukunta Satish are keen to contest from ward 4, said sources.

Title: 25-yr-old hangs self
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Hyderabad: A 25-year-old housewife died after allegedly facing harassment at the hands of her husband and in-laws in Pahadi Shareef limits on Wednesday. The family of the victim filed a dowry death case.

The deceased, Rabbani Begum, a resident of Balapur married Mohammed Waseem five years ago. They have two children.

Soon after their marriage, Rabbani’s in-laws started harassing her physically and mentally and did not allow her speak to her parents. According to police, the victim hanged herself on Tuesday night. TNN

Title: Workshop highlights need of milk fortification
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Nashik: Milk manufacturers from across Nashik and neighbouring districts were on Wednesday sensitized about the need for milk fortification during a day-long workshop organised by NGOs Global Alliance Improved Nutrition (GAIN) and Vastsalya.

Milk fortification is a process of adding Vitamin A and D to the milk. The workshop was organised with the support of Food and Drugs Administration, Nashik.

Approximately 50 milk producers from across Nashik, Dhule, Jalgaon, Nandurbar and Ahmednagar district participated in the workshop. The technical experts at the programme acquainted the milk producers with the process of fortification.

Chandrashekhar Salunke, joint director of FDA, said, “The aim of the workshop was to make milk manufacturers aware of the importance of milk fortification. Given the high burden of Vitamin A and D deficiencies among young children and adults, we have to take the lead to spread awareness about milk fortification. The government, too, has included milk fortification in its national programme. Thus, we are encouraging milk producers to take lead in this regard in the interest of the society.”

Salunke said that the milk fortification process at the dairy level would cost just 2 paise per litre.

Kusum from Vatsalya underlined the need and importance of milk fortification. She said that 62% of the population in India has low serum blood levels of vitamin A and about 50% to 94% of people in various states across the country suffered from Vitamin D deficiency.

She also said that micronutrient malnutrition was prevalent in all the age groups, but the consequences were more severe when it affected children below 24 months of age as they are largely irreversible.

Food fortification is extremely helpful in addressing micronutrient deficiencies, Kusum added.

There is a pre-mix available for milk fortification. The fortification has no impact on the shelf life of any kind of milk. Further, the fortification process neither changes the colour nor flavour of the milk, she said.

Title: Hi-tech traffic control system gets green signal
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A number of important junctions in the city will soon be equipped with a state-of-the-art vehicle actuated control (VAC) traffic signalling system . The Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC), after talks with city police, has zeroed in on 50 junctions that will get the new signalling facility.

The system is expected to assist traffic police by measuring traffic density and changing signals accordingly. At present, signals at city junctions work on fixed time (FT) modes in which a signal turns green after a fixed interval and remains green for a predetermined period even in the absence of traffic at the signal.

“VAC is designed in a way such that the CCTV cameras would measure the density of traffic at all points and decide which side is to be given the green signal and which side needs a red signal. It will keep on calculating the traffic density and adjust the timing,” said a senior GVMC official looking after the project.

Police said besides regular traffic, the system will benefit movement of emergency vehicles such as ambulances and fire tenders, especially in cases in which an ambulance is held up behind vehicles at a red light, even when there is no traffic on the side that has a green signal.

“However, we will still post traffic cops at these important signals so that they switch to a manual signalling system in case of emergency,” said a senior traffic official.

The system will also be installed at Satyam junction, Thatichetlapalem junction, NAD junction and Hanumanthawaka junction.
