Title: Delhi Metro corridors with tracks on road, three-coach trains
Content:
A Delhi Metro train (file photo)

NEW DELHI: Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) has submitted detailed project reports for the two proposed Metrolite corridors — Rithala to Narela (21.7km) and Kirti Nagar to Dwarka ECC (Exhibition-cum-Convention Centre) in Sector 25 (19km) — to Delhi government for approval. After getting a nod from the government and the Centre, DMRC expects to complete the two projects within three years. The Rithala-Narela corridor is expected to come up first.Unlike metro corridors, Metrolite will be a light rail project that will mostly run on road surface. However, unlike similar projects in other cities around the world that share road space with other modes of transport, the Rithala-Narela and Kirti Nagar-Dwarka ECC Metrolite corridors will have dedicated corridors that are fenced on both sides. DMRC has gone for dedicated, fenced corridors as sharing road space with other vehicles would have reduced the train’s average speed considerably.While it was earlier expected that apart from the Rithala-Narela section, two other proposed Phase-IV corridors of Delhi Metro — Lajpat Nagar-Saket G Block (7.9km) and Inderlok-Indraprastha (12.5km) — would also get Metrolite corridors, these have not been found feasible and will have metro services. DMRC found out that on both the Lajpat Nagar-Saket G Block and Inderlok-Indraprastha corridors, Metrolite wouldn’t be able to handle the expected passenger traffic.According to Delhi government officials, the Rithala-Narela Metrolite project will cost Rs 2,914 crore, out of which Delhi Development Authority is expected to provide Rs 200 crore as the corridor will provide some much-needed connectivity to its Narela sub-city. Apart from Narela and different sectors of Rohini, the corridor will also pass through areas like Bawana, Puth Khurd, Sanoth, Bhorgarh and Anaj Mandi. Sources said that unlike metro systems, which are more capital intensive, Metrolite has simpler infrastructure, which brings down the cost. As the corridor will run mostly on roads, the cost that could be incurred for elevated or underground corridors will not be included.The Kirti Nagar-Dwarka ECC Metrolite corridor is not part of DMRC’s Phase-IV project, but a standalone corridor will originate from the Kirti Nagar interchange station, connecting the corridor to the Blue (Dwarka-Noida City Centre) and Green (Inder Lok-Brig Hoshiar Singh) lines. On the other end, the corridor will be connected to the high-speed Airport Express Line , which is being extended from Dwarka Sector 21 to Dwarka ECC in Sector 25. The project cost of the second corridor is Rs 2,673 crore and apart from Kirti Nagar and different sectors of Dwarka, it will pass through areas like Saraswati Garden, Mayapuri, Hari Nagar, Shiv Puri, Dabri, Sitapuri Extension, Mahavir Enclave and Dhool Siras Village.A Metrolite train, which will have three-coach sets and will comfortably accommodate 300 passengers at a time, will be sufficient to handle the passenger traffic on this route. As per DMRC’s DPR, two sets could be joined to make a six-coach train in case of increased demand. The system will draw power from overhead traction.Even though the corridors are yet to receive Delhi government or the Centre’s approval, DMRC has initiated the process of procuring 22 Metrolite coaches for the Kirti Nagar-Dwarka ECC corridor to save time. DMRC will rope in a firm that will design, manufacture, supply, test and commission the Metrolite trains, apart from providing comprehensive maintenance up to 15 years for the standard gauge trains and a train depot.

Title: SC stays HC panchayat order, phase-4 of rural polls may be hit
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

JAIPUR: The Supreme Court on Wednesday stayed Rajasthan High Court ’s order that cancelled the notifications reorganising certain gram panchayats and panchayat samitis after November 15-16. An apex court bench headed by chief Justice S Arvind Bobde has posted the next hearing in the case on February 24.

Following the high court order dated December 13 that nullified panchayat bodies created after November 15-16, the state election commission had announced panchayats polls in four phases beginning January 17. The state government, in the meantime, had filed a special leave petition (SLP) in the Supreme Court challenging HC order.

The apex court’s stay order is likely to impact the panchayat elections’ fourth phase, which includes 1,954 gram panchayats and 126 panchayat samitis spread over 26 districts. The panchayat bodies that were created through notifications issued on December 1 and 12 are included in the fourth phase polling as part of rural bodies that existed prior to these notifications.

Legal experts believe that the SC ’s stay order has brought the panchayat bodies created through the notifications of December 1 and 12 back into existence. It was, however, not clear if the state election commission would reschedule the polling for these rural bodies.

The election commission declined to react on the development and said it was awaiting copy of the Supreme Court order.

“The state government did not make the state election commission a party in the SLP. So, we are not privy to the information in the petition and the apex court order. We are waiting for the order copy,” said an official.

Commission officials, though, said that the apex court has not stayed the panchayat elections. “So, the process that has already been set in motion will remain unaffected,” an official said.

The panchayati raj department too was tightlipped about the development.

The high court, while cancelling the notifications, had said, “Since delimitation cannot be an ever-continuing exercise... thus, all the notifications subsequent to the notification dated 15/16.11.2019, pertaining to the issue in question, stand quashed and set aside, except for the notifications which are purely rectifying the typographical errors.”

The high court thus nullified the notification issued by the state government on December 1 and December 12, creating 1,954 gram panchayats and 126 panchayat samitis in 26 districts.

Title: Kolkata: JEE aspirants walk extra mile on exam day
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Parents of JEE aspirants outside the Sector V exam centre

KOLKATA: Primary schoolteacher Surojit Chowdhury had thought his daughter Sreeja may miss her JEE (Main) examinations on Wednesday. She didn’t only because Chowdhury’s friend Subir Kumar Raha, a former IAF personnel, offered to take Sreeja and his own son, also a JEE (Main) examinee, to the examination centre. They took a private car from Madhyagram early and paid nearly Rs 1,000 to reach the Sector V centre much before their 12:30pm examination deadline.

Chowdhury, who teaches in a primary school in Kolkata Leather Complex in Bantala, said: “Had it been a normal day, I would have taken a casual leave. Because it was a bandh day, I could not avail any leave. The thought that my daughter may have to sit out for her examination is harrowing. I was lucky that my friend stepped in and volunteered to take my daughter. I reached here after school.” Both Chowdhury and Raha said that they would like to plead to political parties not to call for bandh on exam days.

Baguiati residents Anita and her husband Bikash left home early this morning to reach the examination centre at 7:30am. Their son was to appear for his JEE (Mains) at 9:30 am. “We did not want to take any risk. We hired a private car and left home early. Last night, we were very anxious. It is not fair to trouble children on examination day ,” Anita said.

Presidency University students were scheduled to sit for their semester examinations on Wednesday. The Student’s Union, however, urged the authorities to postpone it to Thursday. Kaushiki Dattachoudhury, a third-year English student, said, “The exam was postponed as most of the university is in solidarity with the campus attack and oppose fee hike and CAA-NRC. They also considered how most students would face problems finding transport. Even as I speak, a picketing is going on outside the gates.”

In Jadavpur University , most of departments did not have any classes as majority of the students decided to boycott classes. Chandreyee Halder, a PG first-year student of the film studies department, said, “I support the bandh. In school, we always had to attend classes even if we supported the strike. I am fortunate I am exercise my rights in my university.”

Title: Secunderabad man kills self over failed relationship
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: A 21-year-old private employee from Secunderabad committed suicide two days after his friend killed himself. The victim, Ravi Chaitanya, was a resident of East Marredpally.

The victim’s friend is suspected to have killed himself on account of a failed relationship . Police registered a case on Wednesday.

Ravi Chaitanya was allegedly depressed after his friend and office colleague committed suicide only a couple of days ago in Tukaramgate. Ravi on Tuesday hanged himself while his parents were not at home to the ceiling fan.

Police suspect that Ravi himself was going through issues in his relationship.

“It was found that Ravi was in a relationship. But in the recent past, the woman had been avoiding him and he was depressed about this. A few days ago, one of the victim’s friends (who was also his colleague) committed suicide allegedly due to a failed love affair ,” said Marredpally inspector, M Mattaiah.

“He did not leave any suicide note. We suspect that a failed love affair led to him taking this step,” added the officer. Ravi’s body was shifted to Gandhi Hospital for autopsy and a case of suspicious death was registered.

Title: Rajasthan: Court orders fresh FIR in 2006 Dara Singh encounter case
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

BJP minister Rajendra Rathore is among the 23 accused named in the FIR

JAIPUR: A lower court here on Wednesday directed Bani Park police to register a fresh FIR in the 2006 Dara Singh fake encounter case following a petition by his son Amit Beniwal charging the accused of criminal conspiracy and forgery.

Metropolitan magistrate court-17 ordered police to file an FIR against the 23 accused under Section 156(3) of the CrPC. Initially, there were 14 accused in the case.

The 23 include former BJP minister Rajendra Rathore, Jat Mahasabha president Rajaram Meel, senior police officers and two brothers of Dara, one of whom is already dead.

Beniwal said his mother Sushila Devi, the original petitioner in the case, was misled and pressurised by the accused in connivance with some influential community leaders resulting the accused in the case going scot-free.

He also accused his uncles — Late Shisharam and Sumer Singh — of acting at the behest of former minister Rathore and obtaining signatures of his mother on blank papers and later misusing it.

Beniwal claimed Rathore paid money to his uncles, but they just helped Dara’s family to construct his incomplete house.

Since the case involved high-profile politicians and police officers, the case was contested with the help of community leaders, he said.

But they also connived with the accused and misled his mother resulting her to turn hostile. Apart from his mother, Dara’s brothers had also turned hostile during the trial resulting all the 14 accused the case, including senior IPS officers, acquitted by the trial court in March 2018.

Bootlegger Dara was allegedly killed in an encounter by the SOG in 2006. Later, the Supreme Court had asked the CBI to investigate the encounter on a petition filed by Dara’s wife Sushila alleging that it was staged.

Title: It’s BJP vs BJP at Mormugao municipality
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

VASCO: Ruling and opposition councillors of the Mormugao Municipal Council, both backed by BJP legislators, are engaged in a feud over the assigning of labourers to clean wards. While the opposition panel alleged that vice-chairperson Reema Sonurlekar is ignoring their wards, Sonurlekar refuted the allegation saying the trend was set by the opposition itself when it was in power.

“Sonurlekar is acting in a dictatorial manner. She books labourers for a period of 20-25 days but does not assign them to the wards of opposition councillors,” said councillor Muraru Bandekar.

Sonurlekar, however, denied the charge saying that labourers are assigned to all wards irrespective of whether they are that of the ruling or opposition. “Yes we do give priority to wards of ruling councillors, but we have given labourers to all councillors irrespective of whether they belong to the ruling or opposition,” she said.

“Councillors don’t get labourers when asked to clean their wards, but a security guard was given labourers to clean his building in Goa Rehabilitation Board Colony at Sada,” ex-vice chairperson Shashikant Parab alleged.

The vice chairperson went on to allege that the precedent of harassing opposition councillors set by the present opposition during its tenure. .

Bandekar further alleged that Sonurlekar was ill treating the labourers resulting in them going on a strike a couple of days ago. “Even their salaries are not paid on time. We will be complaining about all the to the urban development minister,” he said.

The opposition panel is backed by urban development minister Milind Naik while the ruling is backed by Vasco MLA Carlos Alemida.

The opposition have filed an RTI into the functioning of the council, especially their expenses.

Title: Vivekananda Reddy murder: Andhra Pradesh high court allows SIT to continue probe
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Andhra Pradesh high court (File Photo)

VIJAYAWADA: The government on Wednesday told the high court that the investigation into the murder case of YS Vivekananda Reddy was at an advanced stage and that there was no need for a CBI probe.

Advocate general S Sriram told the high court that the Special Investigation Team ( SIT ) probe was impartial and the team was questioning the persons belonged to all political parties as part of the investigation.

While two petitions moved by chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy and Y S Sowbhagya were in pending with the high court, former minister Adinarayana Reddy and TDP MLC BTech Ravi recently moved the high court seeking CBI probe.

Appearing on behalf of Adinarayana Reddy, senior counsel Vedula Venkata Ramana said that the family members of YS Vivekananda Reddy and the chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy, the then leader of opposition, had made protested against the SIT investigation.

“They had prayed in writ petitions that for instilling public confidence an impartial inquiry is required with an independent agency like CBI or any other agency which is not under the direct control of either the state government or the Director General of Police (DGP). The allegation stands good even today as the present SIT works under the state government and the actions of SIT as said in the petition of Jaganmohan Reddy are arbitrary and ultra vires the provisions of Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC),” the counsel Ramana said.

The counsel for Sowbhagya, Vivekananda Reddy’s wife, pressed for a CBI probe as there was no development in the SIT investigation. The SIT said it has examined 62 witnesses but do not have a clue about the criminals. He said the second chief of SIT stepping down from the investigation created doubts and so as to inspire confidence, the case may be transferred to an independent agency like CBI, said the counsel for Sowbhagya.

The counsel for BTech Ravi said exempting one Parameswar Reddy from lie detector, polygraph and Narco Analysis tests created doubts about the SIT investigation.

The advocate general argued that the contention of Adinarayana Reddy and BTech Ravi was that they are likely to be implicated in the case. Whereas the contention in the petition moved by the then opposition leader was that the SIT was not questioning the suspects for which he sought CBI probe.

The SIT is questioning every suspect including representatives of all political parties including YSRC, Jana Sena and the family members. The inconvenience of a person who joined the investigation and the political affiliations of that person cannot be a ground for CBI probe, said the AG.

The high court also directed the AG to file counter affidavits on interim applications moved by Sowbhagya by January 19.

The high court directed the Special Investigation Team (SIT) to continue its investigation but not to file the final report before January 20, the next day of hearing of the petitions

Title: Union leader’s letter to hotel flies in face of strike exemption
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kottayam: Even as the state government and the leaders of various trade unions have assured that the tourism sector won’t be affected by the general strike, a CITU leader sent a letter to a resort in the popular tourist destination in the country Kumarakom, saying that the contract workers of the resort will not report for work on the strike day.

The letter to the general manager of Taj resort and spa was sent by K K Harikuttan, district secretary of Kerala Artisans Union (CITU). In the letter he has informed that workers who are on a Fixed Term Contract belonging to the CITU union will not be present for work on the strike day. The workers include staff belonging to stewarding, laundry, gardening, cutting tender coconut etc. The leader has also sought the cooperation of the resort regarding this. The operation of the resort was badly affected on the day due to the absence of these workers. However, the resort management was not ready to officially comment about it. This move by the trade union comes at a time when the trade unions had exempted the state’s tourism sector from the strike. The Kerala Travel Mart Society had hailed “exemplary” the decision by political parties and trade unions to exempt the state’s tourism sector from Wednesday's strike. The chief minister and the tourism minister had also assured that the sector won’t be affected by the strike. Meanwhile, Harikuttan, the person who had written the letter when contacted said that, the matter in the letter was written by the panchayath committee of the trade union. “It may be related to workers taking part in the strike. The matter in the letter was written by the panchayath committee,” said Harikuttan whose name and official seal appears in the letter. Arunkumar, K, secretary, Chamber of Vembanad Hotels and Resorts, said that apart from the issues faced by one of the resorts in Kumarakom, there was no reports of unpleasant incidents in the region. He also welcomed the move to exempt the tourism sector form the strike. “Destination to destination travel was not at all affected. The tourists were happy. The drivers reported no issues,” he said.

Title: Burglars decamps with goods worth Rs42k
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Nashik: House break-ins continue to take place undeterred with police recording at least one case in some or the other part of the city on a daily basis.

On Tuesday, a case of house break-in was registered by Ambad police where in the burglars managed to decamp with valuables worth Rs 42,000 from a house at Shivaji Chowk in Cidco area.

According to police, the incident took place January 3 and January 4 when the owner of the house had gone out for some work.

“The complainant had locked the house at 11.30 am on Friday and returned home the next day at 7.30 am. When he reached home, he saw the lock on the main door was broken and the house was completely ransacked. Articles including two gas cylinders, two large utensils used for filling water, mixer grinder, cooker, 32-inch LED television, gold ring worth Rs 15,000 and eight sarees worth Rs 8,000 were stolen by the suspect,” a police officer said.

“We have registered an offence of house breaking against the unidentified burglar and looking for clues. We will soon nab him,” he added.

Title: Will Delhi University be next, ask students out on road in protest
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The students said they were protesting peacefully and there was no violence

NEW DELHI: Students came out in strength in Delhi University ’s North Campus on Wednesday, boycotting their classes to protest that the last few months had proved they were no longer safe on campuses .

“The regularity with which students are being attacked bothers me and my family. Who would want to send their children to study in Delhi when this is state of affairs here?” said Dighreandar Singh of the Delhi College of Economics. “Is this what the government should be doing? Shouldn’t it be protecting the institutions and the students? But first they increased the fees, then sent police to beat the students and finally, failed to prevent goons entering the campus.”

There were many who shared Singh’s view. Swati Sharma, who studies in Hindu College, said, “I fear that if JNU, Jamia and Aligarh Muslim University can be attacked, even Delhi University can be targeted? We should not wait for something to happen to DU students for us to react. Unless we raise our voices today, we cannot bring about change. We stand with the students of JNU, Jamia and AMU. They are not alone.”

A student from of Lady Shri Ram College, who requested not to be named, said that being a citizen of India or a student both “leave me feeling unsafe”. Somul Singh of Daulat Ram College emphasised, “We are protesting peacefully, there is no violence here. This is what the democracy teaches us — to voice our opinions. I don’t know what the central government gets out of repressing us.”

Bhavna of Indraprastha University rued the whole controversy over the citizenship laws had been turned into a Hindu vs Muslims issue when “normal educated people like us” have no problems with India’s diversity. “Why the disparity? Why the attacks? We are students. Is this what we take from our growing years?” she asked.

Colleges like Miranda, LSR, St Stephen’s and Delhi School of Economics held independent protests within their premises. Meanwhile, the students’ union of Hindu College requested the students to join the protest at the Arts Faculty while demanding that Mushaira 2020, the annual literary festival, be postponed till further notice.

Title: Rain lashes city, more showers likely
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kanpur: Medium to light showers accompanied with thunderstorms lashed different areas of the city on Wednesday bringing back the chill.

The day temperature came down from 22.6 degrees Celsius to 15.8 degrees. However, due to cloud cover during late night hours, the minimum temperature rose by 1.5 degrees and was recorded at 13.2 degrees Celsius.

The rainfall reduced the difference between the day and the night temperatures.

The Met department of CSA University said that rains started on late Tuesday night and continued throughout the day. The rain gauge recorded for the day was 7.6 mm. The city may witness more showers, predicted Met and added that rains occurred due to snowfall in hills.

Title: Photos: Varun Dhawan, Shraddha Kapoor & Nora Fatehi promote 'Street Dancer 3D' in style!
Content: We will have to see how things pan out once we start shooting for films, say Gujarati filmmakers after I&B Ministry releases SOPs for film shoots

Title: NLSIU draft for gig economy to be ready by February
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

View of National Law School of India University (NLSIU) entrance in Bengaluru.

BENGALURU: The National Law School of India University (NLSIU) will submit draft guidelines for the gig economy, the labour market which primarily offers short-term contracts or freelance work as opposed to permanent, long-term jobs, to the government in February.

The BS Yediyurappa-led government may either table a bill in the assembly or frame guidelines under existing laws to protect rights of employees. The draft could be submitted in time for it to be tabled during the budget session of the state legislature next month.

One of the government’s terms of reference to NLSIU is to “protect interests of employees, who work more than eight hours a day”. Employees have also been demanding a minimum wage and basic incentives. “Once the NLSIU prepares the draft, the bill will be debated at an open forum,” said an official of the labour department.

Since 2010, the gig economy in the state has steadily grown, with an increasing number of people subscribing to various application-based platforms for services such as booking cabs, renting houses or getting food delivered to their doorsteps. With more than two lakh people employed as delivery men, cab drivers and executives with Ola, Uber, Swiggy, Zomato etc., the gig economy is a major contributor to the job market in the state.

However, with a spurt in profitability of businesses, concerns have been raised over the possibility of managements “exploiting” employees. Earlier last year, realising the potential of application-based businesses and its employment potential, the government mulled bringing in a law to ensure the welfare of employees. The idea was debated and discussed at an open meeting involving all stakeholders including employees and employers. The NLSIU was roped in and concrete results are likely now.

However, concerns remain whether the law, even if drafted and passed in the legislature, will ever be implemented. With the government extending exemption for IT and ITES firms in the state from labour laws, application-based firms could shield itself from any legislation as IT is at the core of these companies.

“It is true some may try to seek protection under the exemption, but the government is quite firm on bringing them under the ambit of labour laws,” a senior government official said.

Title: BJP govt has worst environ record: AAP
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

PANAJI: Fearing that the local government may not do justice, AAP has requested the National Tiger Conservation Authority of India to take cognisance of the four tiger deaths.

The party accused the government of having the worst track record when it comes to protecting the environment. Patricia Fernandes of AAP’s women’s cell said the government has never shown any concern when it comes to the rampant hill cuttings.

Title: Woman loses Rs 48,000 to online fraudster
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Nashik: A woman was duped of Rs 48,689 by an online fraudster on Sunday after she clicked on a link sent to her mobile phone for updating her Know Your Customer (KYC) details.

An offence in this regard has been registered with the cybercrime police station who said that a 76-year-old man, a resident of Shikhrewadi, Nashik Road, approached them with a complaint stating that his wife was cheated by a conman in an online fraud.

The complainant told police that the fraudster claimed to be an executive of a private pay wallet agency. The suspect sent the link to the woman’s mobile phone and asked her to update her details after clicking on the said link.

He said that his wife got a message on her mobile phone asking her to contact a certain phone number for updating her KYC details in the private pay wallet agency. When she dialled the number, the conman on the other side pretended to be the executive of the company and asked her to open the link he had sent on her mobile phone.

The complainant told police that when his wife clicked on the said link, Rs 48,689 cash was withdrawn from her bank account.

The cybercrime police said that they are investigating the case in details, adding that they have come across similar cases in the past.

Police said that these conmen pretend to be bank representatives and send random messages to people who often fall prey to their tactics.

Title: Speed breakers worsening congestion, claim commuters
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Commuters in the city have a different kind of complaint these days. Speed breakers placed by traffic police at major junctions in the city a few months ago have drawn the flak of commuters who claim that traffic congestion has increased.

Speed breakers have been placed at junctions such as VIP Road, Beach Road, Siripuram, MVP Colony, Port Stadium, Birla and Satyam junction. Commuters, however, claim that traffic on these stretches has worsened.

Bonica Das, a city-based lecturer said, “Thespeed breakers are increasing traffic at main junctions. There are people who do not slow down at such points and as everyone is in a hurry, they drive recklessly. This is dangerous not only for them but also commuters around them.”

S Srinivas, an entrepreneur, said, “The barricades are punishing the majority of safe drivers because those who drive dangerously swerve through them. With hundreds of traffic cameras in place, it should be quite easy to see that barricades are creating traffic jams instead of allowing for the smooth flow of traffic.”

M Deepak, another entrepreneur, said, “There are major junctions that need engineering solutions. These barricades instead of solving traffic problems create more issues at peak hours.”

G Sambasiva Rao, former president of AP Chambers of Commerce, said, “In an effort to control traffic, line discipline is required for effective management of traffic. We have put forward a representation for expansion of service roads for free flow of traffic. We will be holding a round table meeting with stakeholders from GVMC, VMRDA, AP Chambers of Commerce and the police department to discuss alternate solutions.”

Meanwhile, a senior traffic police official said, “We have received a number of complaints from people regarding the inconvenience caused by speed breakers. This issue will be discussed at the next review meeting,” adding that, “A few months ago, speed breakers and barricades were removed from Maddilapalem automotive junction after a protest was held.”

Title: SCR: Platform ticket rates to be doubled
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Secunderabad: The South Central Railways ( SCR ) will temporarily enhance the platform ticket rates at Secunderabad and Kacheguda railway stations during Sankranti.

According to a press release issued by the SCR on Wednesday, the rate of platform ticket will be enhanced from present Rs 10 to Rs 20 from January 9, 2020 to January 19, 2020.

The decision to enhance the platform ticket rates during the festive season was taken in order to regulate the entry of public onto the platforms and to avoid inconvenience to the bonafide passengers during Sankranti, stated the press release. TNN

Title: Day after city woman’s murder, 2-year-old son also found dead
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Jaipur: Police on Wednesday found the body of a 21-month-old boy from a vacant plot near his residential complex in Pratap Nagar, a day after his mother, Shweta Tiwari (35), was found murdered in their apartment. Shweta’s husband, Rohit, is being questioned.

Forensic experts collected samples from the plot after Rohit identified his son Shreyam. Initial investigations suggest the child died of a fatal blow to his head. Shweta, too, was found dead with grave head injuries besides a slit throat. Police suspect she was killed sometime between 2-5pm on Tuesday.

Cops on Tuesday had collected blood samples from two rooms of the 3BHK flat, and recovered the weapons of crime — a pestle and knife — from the apartment. The fingerprints found on them are being examined by forensic experts.

Rohit, a native of Delhi and an Indian Oil Corporation employee, had moved to the city two years ago with Shweta, a native of Kanpur. He was at work when their maid found her body in the living room and informed neighbours, who alerted cops. Shreyam had been missing since then.

On Wednesday afternoon, a police search party ultimately found the child’s body in a vacant plot just over the boundary wall of the residential complex where the family lived.

Sources said the body was dumped there on Tuesday itself.

Shweta’s family reached Jaipur on Wednesday and was preparing to leave with her body for Kanpur when they learnt that Shreyam’s body, too, had been found. They left with the bodies once the postmortems were done. Shweta’s brother, Shubham Mishra, said, “We were preparing to take my sister’s body home when we learnt about my nephew. We were praying that he would be found alive but now are heading home with two bodies.”

“Based on the evidence, we will link the series of events that transpired and arrest the culprit as soon as possible,” said DCP (Jaipur East) Rahul Jain.

Title: Maharashtra: Verification of crop loan soon; 7,000 yet to link Aadhaar
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The state administration will soon start the loan verification of around 1.40 lakh farmers after they complete the process of linking their Aadhaar to their bank accounts as mandated by the state government for the loan waiver scheme.

About 8,012 farmers are yet to be link Aadhaar to their bank accounts. “There are about 8,012 farmers whose bank accounts are yet to be linked to Aadhaar. We are confident that in next five days this figure will be zero,” city collector Suraj Mandhare said.

According to Mandhare, farmers with loan of up to Rs 2 lakh are eligible for waiver as per the government scheme and, hence, the farmers have to link their bank accounts with their Aadhaar so that the government can know the exact outstanding loan amount of every farmer.

“There is no provision to understand which farmer has taken loan from how many banks. Also, there is a problem in clubbing the outstanding amount if a particular farmer has taken loan from several banks. Therefore, linking the bank accounts – multiple numbers – to Adhaar will help the authorities to understand the exact outstanding loan amount of every farmer,” he said.

Mandhare also said that since only those with loans of up to Rs 2 lakh were eligible for the waiver, there could be chances that a person might have taken loans from two different banks and the quantum could be up to Rs 1.75 lakh each. There could be a possibility that the farmer could get the benefit in both the banks.

“When a farmer links his Aadhaar to his bank account, the administration will be able to know the loan amount of every farmer and ascertain if the farmers fulfilled the condition and, accordingly, extend the loan waiver to him,” Mandhare added.

After all the farmers complete the Aadhaar linking process, the next step would be to find out the outstanding loan amount of each farmer.

“The process of calculating the total outstanding will be carried out by the accounts department. In a couple of days, we will segregate the number of farmers eligible for the loan waiver scheme from those who are not. After validation, the information will be sent to state government for further action,” the collector said.

Title: Sonakshi, Varun Dhawan lend voice to protests against JNU attack
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Mumbai: Members of the Hindi film industry increasingly rallied behind the students of Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU), taking a cue from actress Deepika Padukone who made a bold presence at the university despite having a new release ‘Chhapaak’ coming up this Friday.

Sonakshi Sinha, Varun Dhawan , Sonam Kapoor , Twinkle Khanna , Suniel Shetty and Nikkhil Advani were among the prominent personalities who backed the cause.

Deepika Padukone had made a bold statement when she visited JNU on Tuesday evening and supported JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh who was injured during Sunday’s violence. This prompted right-wingers to call for the boycott of her film. The move, however, caused them embarrassment on the very first day as several copycat users showing the same film ticket to prove they had variously cancelled their tickets to the film. It even evoked a mocking note from actress Raveena Tandon.

On Wednesday, Sonakshi Sinha voiced anger against the masked assailants of JNU saying, “No matter which political party you support, do you support violence? Don't visuals of bleeding students and teachers shake you up? We can’t sit on the fence any longer. Kudos to Deepika Padukone for showing up, and all those who spoke for speaking up. This is not the time to stay quiet.”

Actor Varun Dhawan, who is touring Madhya Pradesh, called it a “sad and dangerous situation”. He said, “(I) Cannot stay neutral on such issues. It’s dangerous and sad if masked people enter an educational institution and all this happens.”

Director Vikramaditya Motwane tweeted, “Deepika’s stand is going to make a lot of young people question their parents, their peers and their government. Hopefully they'll go out and educate themselves. And not parrot everything authority tells them. She's a true hero.”

Nimrat Kaur made a succinct comment, “Leading from the front, the tallest Deepika Padukone.”

Nikkhil Advani whose pinned tweet is a snapshot of India's Constitution pointed out that Deepika was taking a bigger risk by expressing her solidarity as she is also producer of the film. “As producer today Deepika Padukone would've been standing in the preview theatres in Mumbai waiting to hear praise being showered on her maiden production. She instead chose to stand in solidarity with JNU students knowing fully well the ramifications of her actions. Respect.”

Filmmaker Anurag Kashyap too spoke on the speaking of the significance of Deepika’s visit to JNU. “It sends out a very strong message of not just being in solidarity but of feeling their pain without fear. A lot of people in the film industry don’t do it because it might go against their business but Deepika has managed to negate that fear and give courage to many others who were probably waiting for someone else to take the lead,” he said. Dismissing those who claimed her JNU visit was a publicity stunt, Kashyap said: “It’s an even bigger statement when she does it on the eve of her film’s release. Anybody in the business will tell you it is hara-kiri, especially when you are also the producer of the film. She has a lot more at stake.”

Actress Chitrangda Singh posted a blend of religious symbols including along with a note saying, “This is the country my father fought for. This is the country he raised me to believe in. Students are the backbone of this country. We can't go far by breaking them.”

Earlier, Twinkle Khanna reacted to a news report on the JNU attack saying, “India, where cows seem to receive more protection than students, is also a country that now refuses to be cowed down. You can't oppress people with violence. There will be more protests, more strikes, more people on the street.”

Actor Suniel Shetty condemned the attack in an interview to a film portal. He said, “Absolute disaster. I could be Hindu, Muslim, Sikh, Christian. I can be anybody from BJP, Congress, Shiv Sena, NCP or any other party. But I have no right to go into a temple of education and beat up the kids. You come wearing masks and call yourself men? If you are men why not roam openly? Whichever party has done it, it is not done. At the same time, some students might not be students, they might be protesters, putting up placards like 'Free Kashmir'. Kashmir was, is and will remain ours. I think these things should be very clear.”

Title: Delhi may get new police chief by this month-end
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Amulya Patnaik may not be given an extension as Delhi assembly elections get over just a week after his retire... Read More

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police might get a new chief by the end of this month as the Union ministry of home affairs is learnt to have sought the Election Commission’s nod to replace the incumbent commissioner , Amulya Patnaik .

A ministry official said that Patnaik might not be given an extension as Delhi assembly elections get over just a week after his retirement, which is January 31. “A call has not been taken yet, but if an extension was on the cards it would have been announced by now,” he added.

Also, Patnaik has completed three years in the post and the Election Commission may not want to bend the rules regarding the reshuffle of officers.

With this development, speculations are rife about the new police chief. Sources pointed out that given the recent gaffes involving Delhi Police, the government is likely to keep in mind two aspects while considering an officer’s candidature — expertise in maintaining law and order and experience in running a metro city.

While a few officers in the UT cadre are in the race, officials said there are chances that the government might opt for an “outsider” for the post and “spring a surprise” as they did in the appointment of the CBI director last year. Interestingly, Delhi has always had a top cop from the UT cadre. In the last two decades, UP-cadre officer Ajay Raj Sharma was the last one to be placed in the chair in 1999.

Sources said there are three frontrunners from outside the UT cadre— 1985-batch officer Subodh Jaiswal (Mahrashtra cadre), SM Sahay (J&K cadre) and AK Sharma (Gujarat cadre) of the 1987 batch.

Jaiswal and Sahay are being considered on the basis of their experience in dealing with terrorism and intelligence. Jaiswal was earlier Mumbai Police commissioner and is currently serving as DGP of Maharashtra. Sharma was serving in CBI and is currently in CRPF.

Among the frontrunners are 1987-batch officer Mohammed Taj Hasan, SBK Singh (1988), Balaji Shrivastav (1988) and Sandeep Goyal from the 1989 batch. 1984-batch IPS officer Rakesh Asthana and 1985-batch officers Ajay Kashyap, Prabhat Singh and SN Shrivastava are also in the race. The names of three or more officers is likely to be sent to UPSC and the government for appointment by next week.

Title: Uttrakhand: Snow, rain block roads in hills
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

UTTARKASHI/PITHORAGARH: Incessant rain and snowfall from Monday evening onwards led to disruption of road connectivity and power supply in several districts of the state causing major inconvenience to residents of places situated in high-altitude areas.

On Wednesday, the Yamuna valley remained disconnected from Uttarkashi district headquarters as a thick blanket of snow covered Radi Top area of Yamunotri highway. Heavy snowfall near Rana Chatti area of Yamunotri highway disconnected nearly a dozen villages of Geeth Patti from Barkot tehsil. Besides, several roads like Harsil-Mukhba, Kunwa-Kaflon, Uttarkashi-Lambgaun, Hanumanchatti-Kharsali, Kunsala-Kupda, Ghansali-Tilwada, Naitwad-Sankari, to name a few, remained blocked due to snowfall.

Gangotri highway (ahead of Gangnani) had also got blocked on Tuesday morning, disconnecting Harsil and eight other villages of Upla Taknor region from Uttarkashi district headquarter, due to heavy snowfall.

Incessant snowfall and rain also hit electricity supply in 30 villages of the district. Besides, around 150 roads in Chamoli district were reported to have got affected due to landslides triggered by heavy rainfall.

Meanwhile, normal life across Pithoragarh district in Kumaon was affected as several areas received light-to-moderate rain spells and snowfall.

The temperature levels were reported to have dipped below the zero mark in Munsyari and Dharchula towns due to snowfall. Kalamuni and Balati also got covered in a six-inch-deep blanket due to the snow spell.

Snowfall led to connectivity woes in the district as well as the Thal-Munsyari road leading to Munsyari remained cut off for the fifth day on Wednesday. “Many people including tourists wishing to experience snowfall have been forced to use Jauljibi Munsiyari route, which is 25 kilometre longer,” said Devendra Singh, a local.

The Kailash Mansarovar route and Darma, Chaudas and Byas valleys have also got covered in snow. “Locals of Munsiyari are facing a lot of inconvenience due to snow-covered roads. It has become difficult for us to take sick persons to hospital,” said Lok Bahabur Singh, another local.

Title: What’s in the name of this rose? Monica Bellucci, that’s what
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

A gardener tends to rose bushes at AHSI

KOLKATA: A rose by any other name would not be Monica Bellucci .

Dedicated to the popular Italian actress, who starred in Hollywood films like, ‘The Matrix Reloaded’, ‘The Passion of the Christ’ and Bond film ‘Spectre’, the carmine-pink rose will be among the 60-odd varieties that will be showcased at the Agri-Horticultural Society of India (AHSI) during its bi-centenary celebrations from January 9 to 12. AHSI will also host the World Regional Rose Convention (WRRC), a prestigious event that celebrates the flower found universally that symbolizes love, passion, joy, humility, appreciation, admiration and enchantment.

“Rose is the only flower that connects the entire world. When someone gives a rose anywhere in the world, it symbolizes friendship and love. There is no other flower that connects the world the way the rose does. There are 40,000 rose varieties across the globe, of which around 3,000 are found in India. AHSI has 75 varieties. Around 60 varieties with different colour combinations will be showcased at the show,” said AHSI president Sunil Kanoria.

Apart from the Monica Bellucci Rose, created by Meiland Richardier, the rare varieties of roses on display will include Over the Moon, a hybrid tea rose cultivar, bred by Pierre Orard in France, and Joy of Life, bred by Hans Jürgen Evers of Germany. The Bengal rose, blood red in colour, is distinct from other Indian varieties.

Celebrated Thai floral artist Phubast Chesdmethee, popularly called Poo, will create an installation for the show and curate a floral fashion show. Around 300 delegates from all over the world, including members of the World Rose Society, headquartered in Brussels, will discuss the technology development, research and markets and share their perspective on roses. The show will also present perennial flowers, medicinal plants, a wide range of foliage plants, cacti, succulents and bonsai grown in pots.

While the past 200 years had been eventful, Kanoria said AHSI was keen to focus on reviving the R&D centre and partner universities and corporate groups to improve its utilization. AHSI, founded by William Carey, played a key role in introduction of tea bushes to Assam and a wide variety of vegetables and fruits in pre-Independence India, like cauliflower , cabbage, tomato and beet.

In the run-up to the bi-centenary year, the AHSI garden has been revamped and nearly 50,000 plants have been added in last six-seven months.

Title: Justice Murti of AP high court retires
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Vijayawada: The full court of Andhra Pradesh high court along with members of bar association bade farewell to Justice M Seetharama Murti on Wednesday, which was the last working day of the HC before Sankranti vacation.

Justice Murti hails from a family of lawyers from Kakinada in East Godavari district. He was a lawyer for 12 years before becoming a district judge in 1996.

Justice Murti was appointed as additional judge of the high court in 2013. In 2016, he was appointed as a judge of high court of judicature at Hyderabad for Telangana and AP. After the bifurcation, he was allotted to AP high court, on January 1, 2019.

Justice Seetharama Murti also worked as senior faculty and additional director of the Andhra Pradesh Judicial Academy.

Title: Two killed, 29 hurt as buses collide
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The buses which collided head on, in Chittoor district on Wednesday

Tirupati: Two persons were killed, and 29 were injured, in a ghastly road mishap involving two buses at Kasipentla village in Chandragiri mandal of Chittoor district early on Wednesday morning.

The incident happened near the Heritage Foods plant on the Puthalapattu Naidupet highway, 28 km from Tirupati, when APSRTC’s Amaravati bus from Vijayawada to Kuppam rammed into a private travels bus which was on its way from Sabarimala to Nalgonda in Telangana.

Chandragiri police and rescue teams rushed to the spot and extricated the bodies from the bus. Gas cutters and welding equipment was used to separate the vehicles.

The deceased were identified as Ramesh, the Amaravati bus driver (belonging to Penamalur), and the coach attendant Prasad, who was from Vuyyuru—both in Krishna district.

Some of the mildly injured were transported to the SVRR government general hospital in Tirupati with the help of trucks passing by as there weren’t enough ambulances.

Title: Nashik: District administratio to set up village-level weather stations
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The district currently has 92 weather stations at circle offices.

NASHIK: The district administration is considering setting up of weather stations at village level to get exact climatic data for bringing in transparency in providing aid to the farmers in times of inclement weather and other issues.

The district currently has 92 weather stations located at the Circle office – which is a group of several villages. The weather readings – especially the rainfall, are taken by the Circle officer who then reports the same to the tahsildar office, where the data is collected and recorded for further use.

“At this point in time there is a huge disparity of rains and one may find that there is heavy rain on one side of the road and the other side is dry. As far as Circle office jurisdiction is concerned, in the rural areas, the area covered is more than 16 sq km or even more. There are chances that a village in the Circle does not receive rain at all while the neighbouring villages are flooded with water,” a senior officer from the district disaster management pointed out.

At times of deciding heavy rain, average rain, etc and when there is a situation of loss of crop due to heavy rain or even because of drought or water scarcity, the rain gauge reading plays a vital role. “Given the above situation, it is impossible to get better weather records. Opening up of more weather stations can help the administration get the micro-level information,” the officer said.

In order to reach out to the last-man enabling justice, the district administration has asked the official bodies and departmental officers to put a request for the installation of weather stations. “The gram panchayat, the panchayat samiti, the talathi office or even others can present their demands for setting up of the weather stations, which will be monitored by the officers from the corresponding bodies/govt agencies,” the officer said.

The officer further pointed out that the funds for buying and installation of the weather stations would be taken up from the district innovation funds. “There is a provision in for spending of district funds for such works under the head of district innovation funds. The funds from the district planning committee will be used for setting up,” the officer said.

Considering the number of requests the administration will choose whether to go for manual weather station or the automated weather station. “In the district, the administration has put up manual weather stations and it could think of installing the automated weather stations to cut down the human intervention and timely updating of the weather notes,” the officer said.

Title: Discom staff hold mass hunger strike
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Guntur: Scores of employees from Southern Power Distribution Company Limited (SPDCL) participated in mass hunger strike against the Centre’s plans to make amendments to the energy Act , 2003, here on Wednesday. Senior officials also extended their support to the agitation by visiting the hunger strike camp. Employees from different wings in SPDCL attended the strike held at the Vidyuth Bhavan in the city.

Addressing the gathering, Andhra Pradesh Electricity Employees Association (APEEA-1104) state general secretary M Veeranjaneyulu said that they would not hesitate to intensify the agitation if the Centre did not relent on the issue. “The proposed amendments to the energy Act, 2003 are going to hit the consumers as well as employees. People should also hit the streets opposing the amendments,” said Veeranjaneyulu. He said that it would be very difficult for the state governments to implement the subsidies being offered. He also alleged that the new amendments would help the private corporate sector.

State union deputy secretary AVSS Prasad said that entire energy sector would collapse if the new bill was cleared by the parliament. He said that agriculture sector would be biggest victim with the amendments as several state governments were giving free power to farmers.

Prasad said that no private firm had successfully managed either an energy plant or the distribution system in the country due to the strong presence of PSUs. He alleged that private firms were conspiring to weaken PSUs and loot public money.

Employees held a massive human chain on Guntur-Bapatla road demanding the immediate withdrawal of amendments.

Title: Midnight pangs in Panaji after ‘ros omelette’ carts seized
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Panaji: The Corporation of the City of Panaji ( CCP ) has seized 14 food carts operating near Don Bosco school in Panaji after they were found dumping waste in the drains.

“We will have a meeting and decide what action can be taken against them. We will either impose a penalty or cancel their license,” CCP mayor Uday Madkaikar said.

The CCP raided the place after they received multiple complaints from residents in the vicinity as well as from Don Bosco school of stench emanating from the area.

“A team was sent and they found the drains filled up with chicken bones and food waste with a rotten smell,” Madkaikar said, adding that the vendors were recently warned and their operations stopped for four days after complaints were received.

“We have been collecting their waste regularly. They are unfortunately repeating this behaviour. People’s health is at stake. (Panaji MLA) Atanasio Monserrate permitted them to operate on humanitarian grounds, but they cannot carry out their business by inconveniencing others. The place was very dirty and full of mosquitoes.” the Panaji mayor said that the CCP’s town vending committee will meet to identify alternate places where the food carts can be shifted.

He also attributed flooding in the area to the food cart operators, who clog up the drains with garbage. “We told them we would provide them with garbage collection and water, but it is their responsibility to keep the place clean,” Madkaikar told reporters.

Of the 92 food carts in the city, 17 operate near Don Bosco school, all of which were seized, however, three selling only cold drinks have been permitted to continue operations.

Title: Delhi: No suggestion to shut JNU down, MHRD asks VC to open dialogue
Content:
M Jagadesh Kumar (PTI photo)

NEW DELHI: Denying that the Jawaharlal Nehru University administration had made any suggestion to “shut it down”, officials of the Union human resource development ministry said that the unrest over hiked hostel fees had been prolonged by a leftist student group’s refusal to accept a compromise formula suggested by the ministry as well as vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar ’s reluctance to open a dialogue or show leniency to student protesters. At a meeting on Wednesday, the ministry asked Kumar to restore normalcy on the campus at the earliest and advised him to be more communicative with students and take the faculty into confidence while making decisions.Asked if JNU , in its report to the HRD ministry on Monday, had suggested shutting down the university temporarily, Kumar asserted, “We made no such suggestions.” He was accompanied by Professor Satish Chandra Garkoti, Rector-II, at the meeting, the first time after the stalemate since October 28 last year over the sharp increase in hostel fees that the VC was meeting MHRD officials.Amit Khare, secretary, HRD ministry, disclosed that JNU officials gave a factual report of what happened on the campus on Sunday. “The VC also informed us that the administration was making all efforts to restore normalcy and had appealed to all the stakeholders to maintain peace and not get provoked by misinformation,” said Khare.According to an HRD ministry official, “The VC needs to be more communicative. He briefed the ministry on the events of January 5 and said that he has done everything as per the statutes. However, the ministry feels he should be more open and available. There has been a complete communication breakdown. He may have difficulties speaking to the students at this juncture, but he should at least meet the faculty and take them into confidence.”According to a ministry insider, the faceoff could have ended nearly a month ago had the VC and one leftist student group not remained adamant and non-negotiable in their stances. “During the meetings with the students, a section of the representatives agreed to the suggested measures of the HRD ministry, which included the University Grants Commission bearing the newly levied utility and services charges in hostel fees, notifying JNUSU and taking a lenient view against the protesting students,” another HRD ministry official said. “However, the university administration showed reluctance to implement the suggested measures. So the students intensified their agitation for a complete rollback of the hike and then blocked the registration process.”The VC, who has been severely criticised by students and faculty members for not taking immediate measures when a mob attack began on the campus last Sunday, told the ministry officials that efforts were being made to facilitate semester registration for “willing” students. However, an official said the ministry was of the view that the university should not pressure students to register within a fixed period. “If there is no last date for registering, the tension is automatically reduced,” the official reasoned.On confusion over payment of hostel fees during the registration process, the ministry has asked Kumar to clarify that only Rs 300 would be charged. “They are students and we are here to provide them education, not deprive them of it. The ministry will ensure funds if there is record of discussion on this,” the official added.

Title: Why give ‘special treatment’ to KTR at Tirumala temple, asks BJP
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

KT Rama Rao

TIRUPATI: Questioning the preferential treatment accorded to Telangana minister KT Rama Rao at the Lord Venkateswara temple in Tirumala on Vaikunta Ekadasi day (January 6), BJP state secretary and former TTD trust board member G Bhanu Prakash Reddy on Wednesday said the temple management flouted norms by allowing KTR’s family members to enter the temple through the biometric entry point.

In a letter to AP chief secretary Nilam Sawhney, he alleged that TTD management tried to appease KTR by allowing him and his family members to enter the temple through the biometric entry point, which is a clear case of violation of temple norms.

Urging the CS to order an enquiry and to direct the TTD administration to release the CCTV footage from the biometric entry point, the Mahadwaram and the Padikavali points at the Tirumala temple, which will establish beyond doubt that the temple management flouted all norms.

Title: RVNL gives nod to KMDA to build Chingrighata-New Town flyover
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: The Rail Vikas Nigam Limited (RVNL) on Tuesday gave the go-ahead to the flyover that the Kolkata Metropolitan Development Authority recently proposed to build from the Chingrighata crossing on E M Bypass to New Town , parallel to the Metro alignment on Salt Lake Bypass .“RVNL has granted no-objection and conditional certificate to KMDA to construct a flyover that will move parallel to the Metro line on Salt Lake Bypass. It will start from Chingrighata and end at New Town and will cross over Nicco Park and Sector V . A detailed alignment drawing of the proposed flyover will be prepared and an environment impact assessment test will be conducted,” said a KMDA official.In 2013, a flyover was conceptualised to connect Bypass with New Town—crossing over a portion of the East Kolkata Wetlands—with an aim to decongest the busy Chingrighata crossing and Salt Lake Bypass. The government revived the project but environmentalists raised objections, saying the construction would lead to irreversible damage to the wetlands. The Calcutta High Court issued an injunction on the project, saying the clearance would have to come from the Centre. Following the injunction, a Centre-appointed committee visited the site earlier last year and suggested that the authorities should alter the alignment. Accordingly, KMDA engineers a couple of months ago revised their plan and came up with the Salt Lake Bypass alignment.KMDA officials can start constructions only after completing several steps, such as getting the plan approved, preparing a detailed project report, obtaining environment clearance and receiving administrative as well as financial sanctions from the state cabinet. The authorities said that before the work on the ground began, they would have to think about what to do with the existing 400m-long one-way flyover at the Chingrighata crossing. A structural health study has revealed that flyover has turned weak but long-term repairs were not an option. Officials said they would keep strengthening the structure and allow light vehicles only till the new flyover was ready and this could be dismantled.

Title: Eastern Railway brings hi-tech solution for safety
Content:
A Duronto Express train (File photo)

KOLKATA: Three automated devices developed by the Asansol Division of Eastern Railway (ER) will ensure safety for trains running between eastern and northern India, including important ones like the Rajdhanis and Durontos. In addition to safety, the devices will also ensure improved punctuality of these train services.The technicians who are involved in developing the devices have focussed on three basic areas where things can go wrong, leading to disasters.“The first of these devices is a level-crossing gateman alert system. Gatemen are supposed to keep vigil throughout the day and night to ensure that tracks are free from infringement by road vehicles when trains pass. However, gatemen sometimes fall asleep, particularly at night in remote locations. That is why, the device generates an alarm at the intervals of every 30 minutes to alert them. If a gateman fails to acknowledge, the device automatically alerts the sectional supervisor or permanent way official-in-charge. The officials can also use this device to communicate with the gateman, when needed,” said Nikhil Kumar Chakraborty, CPRO, ER. The device costs about Rs 45,000.Sometimes there are delays in closing level-crossing gates by the gatemen due to miscommunication. At times, station masters or assistant station masters forget to alert the gatemen at interlocked level-crossing gates of approaching trains.Till now, station masters communicate with them through magneto telephones where the conversation is not recorded. The ASM-LC communication system developed recently uses GPRS technology while the alerts are sent by the press of a button. The gatemen receive both visual and audio alerts and have to respond in time. Both the times of informing and response are recorded and stored in a cloud for verification later, if required. Each unit costs about Rs 78,000.“Till now, it was the station master’s word against the gateman’s. In the end, passengers suffered. Under the new system, the alarm at the gateman’s end will only stop after he acknowledges the instruction. If there is a delay in response, he can be hauled up,” said Chakraborty. Oversized vehicles passing through a level-crossing gate can also cause severe problems.At times, their tops get entangled in overhead equipment, resulting in major snags that last for long. Trains forced to make unscheduled stops for such reasons are prone to accidents. Though there are height barriers at either end of level-crossings, oversized vehicles sometimes knock them down, causing more trouble for trains. The new system detects oversized vehicles from a distance and emits a warning, both audio and visual till it stops. It costs Rs 98,000 to build the device.“The devices are now being tried out at specific locations and will be distributed to all stations and gates after more are manufactured,” said the CPRO.

Title: VMC pulls out all stops to rectify SS-19 errors
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The right things to boast about: People take pictures at the selfie points set up by the VMC in the city on Tu... Read More

Vijayawada: The Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) has requested citizens to participate in Swachh initiatives to help the city achieve the best rank in Swachh Survekshan 2020. The civic body launched the campaign ‘I Support Vijayawada’ to educate people about the importance of feedback in achieving top rank in Swachh Survekshan.

Vijayawada, which emerged as India’s cleanest big city in 2018 had a bitter experience the following year. Vijayawada, which secured the fifth rank in 2018 slipped to 12th position in 2019. VMC authorities identified poor feedback and lack of involvement of the public in Swachh initiatives as the main reasons for the poor performance.

Civic officials have turned their focus to rectifying the mistakes made in 2019. This year VMC has established selfie points at multiple locations to motivate students to post their Swachh activities on social media and tag the civic body.

“We are doing our best to achieve the top rank this year. The first two-quarters of survey is over and we have entered the third quarter. Feedback of citizens is important at this stage and we request them to answer calls from Swachh Survekshan survey and give positive feedback. Smartphone users are requested to give feedback in Swachh Survekshan - 2020 website,” said VMC commissioner Prasanna Venkatesh.

He added that health and sanitation wings will hold awareness camps at parks, residential colonies, apartments, colleges, schools.

Meanwhile, with Swachh Survekshan inspection teams expected to visit the city soon, the civic body has its intensified special drive to control open urination Swachh Grahis (volunteers) have been deployed at problem areas to control open urination.

Title: Disaster Act set to be imposed in Trimbakeshwar
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Nashik: District collector Suraj Mandhare has decided to implement the district Disaster Management Act in Trimbakeshwar to ensure disaster-free conduct of Nivruttinath Maharaj Yatra scheduled on January 20.

The pilgrim town has a population of only 13,000 people and every year during the yatra between January 19 to 21, close to 2 lakh people visit the place. In order to ensure the safe conduct of the fair, the administration has clamped the district Disaster Management Act for the area with two incident commanders – the local police inspector PS Karpe and the chief officer of Trimbak Municipal Council Pravin Nikam.

“In order to ensure there is a safe passage of the event when huge numbers of pilgrims are going to come to Trimbak, we have clamped the disaster management act and given all the authorities of ensuring the safety and security of the pilgrims and even eviction of the encroachments without any liberty and other thoughts to the local officials,” said collector Suraj Mandhare.

Across three days around 5 lakh, people will be there at a given moment and there will be a floating population of another lakh in the small town as a result of which food, health, and sanitation measures are required to be raised for the people coming here. The people coming here would put a strain on narrow streets, the infrastructure of the town, provision of cooking foods and many things that could affect the pilgrims as well as the locals.

Karpe and Pravin would be responsible for making arrangements for the smooth passage of the people. “They will take measures to avoid a stampede, ensure all civic supplies run normal, health and medical services are available to each and everybody, in any case, availability of fire-fighting and rescue services, removal of any kind of impediments in and around the temples that could create problems for the people,” the officer said.

All the people who fail to adhere to orders of these authorities and create problems for the administration will be booked under section 51 of the Disaster Management Act for obstructing the officer in discharging his duties under the Act.

Title: Experts confirm prehistoric rock art in Telangana, find ancients tools, fossils
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Examination using Raman spectroscopy confirmed that the rock art was from prehistoric age

HYDERABAD: Raman Spectroscopy examination confirmed that the anthromorphic rock art found at Ontigundu in in Bhadradri Kottagudem district was prehistoric rock art.

Historians and Rock Art Society of India members also found prehistoric stone tools at the site.

Sriramoju Haragopal of Historian of Telangana Jagruthi told TOI, “ We have examined the rock art found in Ontigundu with Raman Spectrometer. The technique helps to identify thousand-year-old materials used in rock paintings, without interfering with the rock art texture.”

“ Rock art structures in the shape of a snake, monitor lizard, flower, Sun and as well as Anthromorphic pictures were found here. We traced the rock art to middle-stone age and old stone age .We found red and white rock art paintings too. We also found stone-age tools in the same area,” said Haragopal.

The team of historians include Kondaveeting Gopi, Jaganmohan Rao from Bhadrachalam, Katta Srinivas from Khammam, Bandi Muralidhar Reddy, an expert on rocket arts and Katta Gnaneswar, an expert on Raman Spectroscopy of Hyderabad and Kondreti Bhaskar of Kanigir.

The team had spent more than two days at the spot situated near a jungle to obtain the relevant information.

Historians also found plant fossil at the site. “The plant fossils belong to Angiosperms, and it may be date back to six crore years. There is huge potential for further studies. The government should set up fencing at the site to protect it,” said Haragopal.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: 258 special trains to clear Sankranti rush
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representational Image

VIJAYAWADA: In a bid to regulate passenger rush, around 258 special trains – either transiting or originating from Vijayawada have been arranged so far, ahead of this year’s Sankranti festival. All trains have been operating from January 1 till January 20 to cater to the arriving-departing passengers.

Vijayawada railway division officials have already issued a travel advisory asking people to avoid crowding platforms during the festive season by saying their goodbyes from, and welcoming their relatives at, the concourse or waiting areas. Special train services are being run to cater to all class of rail passengers. There are Jansadharan (only second seating accommodation), AC Special, Suvidha (Special Fare) and Special Trains being run in all directions from Vijayawada.

Despite providing more than seven special trains between Vijayawada and Hyderabad, the waiting list numbers are still spiking as high as 350 in the past two days. Officials admit that they did not anticipate the rush to increase this much compared to the previous years. Railway officials said that most of the passenger rush was coming from Hyderabad to Vijayawada.

The second wave was towards Vizag and Godavari districts, while the third wave are mostly pilgrims heading towards Tirupati. Officials also said that they would be increasing the platform ticket prices to Rs 20 from Rs 10 during the festive days to regulate the crowd. A notification in this regard will be out in the coming days.

Senior officials said that they have deployed special duty staff to manage the platform timings to ensure that there is no inordinate delay compared to the previous years. They also said that this is the first time they are taking this initiative after studying the issues that arose during previous Sankranti seasons.

Passengers can also utilise the ‘UTS on Mobile’ App to book unreserved tickets on their smartphones.
