Title: RTI reply reveals JNU cut down on hiring of guards
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

NEW DELHI: The reply to an RTI query filed by a former JNUSU president has revealed that the university inked a pact with a security agency to hire 250 security guards last year, which, sources said, was lower than the earlier requirement of 400 or above.

The RTI reply, which was received 10 days before the violence broke out on Sunday on JNU campus, gave out details of the new contract for the security agency. While the initial tender had mentioned the requirement for 400 personnel — ex-servicemen, with a contract period of two years — the agreement later signed with Army Welfare Placement Organisation and Cyclops Security and Allied Service Private was for 250 guards.

Former JNUSU president N Sai Balaji, who had filed the RTI, said: “If JNU needed only 250 security personnel as per the new contract, then why was the administration paying money for 200 extra guards to an agency earlier?”

He alleged that the administration had cut down the security on campus, which had ultimately rendered it unsafe. “The university was paying Rs 35,000 per guard to the security company earlier and the number of personnel was higher. Now, around Rs 50,000 per person is being paid to the company while the number of guards has come down. This is akin to compromising the security of the campus,” Balaji claimed.

When contacted, JNU registrar Pramod Kumar said the requirement was lowered following an audit conducted for “efficiency of security on campus”.

Title: Mixed response to Bharat Bandh in city
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Nashik: The left organisations on Wednesday took out a rally in the city in support of the Bharat Bandh called by trade unions across the country.

Barring some industrial units, production process in majority of the units was unaffected. Similarly, the operations in the banking sector remained unaffected.

In addition, the members of different trade unions staged a roadblock in the Peth area of rural Nashik for some time.

“Around 90% establishments participated in the one-day strike to protest against the anti-worker and farmers’ policies of the Union government and to press for various demands. We received good response from different sectors, including industries, banks, post offices, zilla parishad, Nashik Municipal Corporation and other establishments,” said Raju Desle, state secretary of the All India Trade Union Congress.

An action committee of different trade unions was formed to make the strike successful. A long march was organised from the Golf Club ground to district collectorate as part of the protest.

A delegation of different trade unions met district collector Suraj Mandhare and presented a memorandum of their demands, seeking minimum wages of Rs 21,000 per month to workers in all establishments, minimum Rs 10,000 per month pension to farmers and workers, abolishment of contract system in permanent works, reducing taxes by centre and state governments on fuel to reduce the prices and immediate recruitment on 24 lakh vacant posts in the central and state governments.

NMC headquarters wear deserted look

The headquarters as well as all the six divisional offices of the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) wore a deserted look on Wednesday as 5,000 employees joined the Bharat Bandh to press for their demands. They staged demonstrations at the main gate of the Rajiv Gandhi Bhavan — headquarters of the NMC.

Title: Deputy commissioner lodges plaint against fake order
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Sindhu B Rupesh, deputy commissioner of Dakshina Kannada. (File photo)

Title: Manish Sisodia criticises education model in BJP-ruled states
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Sisodia said the AAP government had transformed the education system of the city

NEW DELHI: Senior Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) functionary Manish Sisodia on Wednesday launched a fresh attack against BJP on the issue of the closure of government schools in BJP-ruled states .

At a press conference, Sisodia said that the AAP government has transformed the education system of the city. While it added 20,000 classrooms in schools, 1.3 lakh students left private schools to join government schools, said the deputy chief minister.

“Enrolment in BJP-run municipal schools, which are in bad shape, has witnessed a sharp decline,” he added.

“This election will be fought on the basis of real work. Education has been our priority in the five years that we have governed Delhi,” Sisodia said.

He added that the schools were in pathetic condition when his party assumed power in 2015. "Under the AAP government, 20,000 classrooms have been constructed of which 8,000 have already been handed over. The government has invested significantly in infrastructure and facilities like green boards, modular desks and world-class sports facilities. We have built a total of 25 new school buildings and 30 are under construction. Six Schools of Excellence and five Rajkiya Pratibha Vikas Vidyalayas are transforming the lives of the students,” Sisodia said, adding that Delhi now has several government schools with better infrastructure than private schools.

Slamming the governance model of BJP-ruled states, Sisodia claimed that the Haryana government had shut down 208 government schools between 2015 and 2018. In the same period, the Rajasthan government closed down 4,000 schools, he said. “In UP, more than 40% of primary schools do not have electricity supply. In Delhi, 109 primary schools have been shut down by the municipal corporations in the last nine years, with the number going down from 1,764 in 2011-12 to 1,655 in 2019-20,” he added.

Sisodia stated that enrolment in municipal schools has declined by 1.3 lakh in the last four years (2015-16 to 2018-19) whereas the enrolment in Delhi government schools has increased by 6,000 in the corresponding period. The enrolment in elementary schools in BJP and Congress-ruled states has only decreased in the last four years – a decrease of 14 lakh in UP, 4.2 lakh in Haryana and one lakh in Punjab. The figures were derived from the Central government data on elementary education, Sisodia claimed.

Sisodia said that the AAP government has upgraded sporting infrastructure in schools. "Delhi now has four synthetic athletics tracks; four more are nearing completion; and three synthetic hockey turfs and two synthetic football grounds are ready. Six state-of-the-art swimming pools are ready and nine more are nearing completion. We have also constructed two synthetic basketball courts. Two sports hostels with training facilities are nearing completion and an archery field and a synthetic volleyball court are getting ready,” he said.

BJP spokesperson Harish Khurana, however, rubbished Sisodia’s claims about municipal schools and said that he was no person to judge the education standards in other BJP-ruled states.

“A total of 763 Delhi government schools do not have principals, only 30% schools teach science and the AAP government has outsourced mathematics teaching,” Khurana said. He claimed that the AAP government spent only 30% of the education budget.

Title: Sanjivani will buy cane, chief minister Pramod Sawant assures farmers
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

PONDA: Resolving farmers ’ dilemma over whether to cultivate sugarcane or not, chief minister Pramod Sawant on Tuesday assured them that the Sanjivani Co-operative Sugar Factory at Dharbandora will procure sugarcane from them and told them to continue cultivating the crop.

The government’s decision to keep the factory shut during this year’s crushing season had put the farmers in a predicament. Sawant said it was immaterial whether the cane would be crushed at the factory’s new plant or whether it would be sent to some other factory and assured them Sanjivani would procure their produce next year.

Presently, as the factory is not in production, it procures cane from Goa’s farmers and sends it to Laila Sugar Factory at Khanapur in Karnataka.

The chief minister also assured the farmers that the harvesting rate for their cane will be raised from Rs 200 to Rs 600 per tonne from this year.

He, however, said he could not hike canes rate from the existing Rs 3,000 to Rs 4,000 per tonne. The factory has been paying Rs 1,200 and in addition the agriculture department pays a support price of Rs 1,800.

Title: Central team to probe tiger deaths
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

It is believed by some that the recent killing of domesticated animals in the area could have led to the tiger... Read More

PANAJI: The Centre on Wednesday constituted a two-member committee to inquire into the tiger deaths and asked for its report within seven days.

The panel consists of Rajendra Garawad of National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA), Bengaluru and regional deputy director, western region, Mumbai.

Deputy inspector general of forest (NTCA) Nishant Verma said the team would inquire into the cause of death, action taken by the forest authorities and compliance of the standard operating procedure issued by the government with regards to tiger death and disposal of the carcass.

The committee also has to suggest legal course of action as per the provision of the Wildlife (Protection) Act.

Earlier, health minister Vishwajit Rane sought central inquiry into the tiger deaths and “requested” Union forest minister Prakash Javadekar to send a team to conduct a “detailed investigation” into it.

Meanwhile, science and technology minister Michael Lobo said the perpetrators should be jailed for 20 years for the crime. “It’s the darkest day in the history of Goa in terms of biodiversity conservation, especially the national animal,” he said.

He said to resolve the man-animal conflict, there should be rehabilitation of the inhabitants in such areas.

Title: Former T-Hub CEO launches $60m VC fund for tech startups
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Hyderabad: Former T-Hub CEO Jay Krishna has joined hands with entrepreneurs Srikanth Chintalapati and Kevin Jacobs to launch a US$60 million cross-border, early-stage venture capital fund , Mantra Capital, that will focus on deep tech for human good.

The fund, which has already raised US$ 24 million out of US$ 60 million, will focus on investing in seed and pre-Series A round startups with advanced solutions for human good.

Startups in sectors like food and agritech, circular economy and healthtech with products and solutions that use advanced science and leading-edge technologies like AI, ML, blockchain, photonics and robotics will attract its funds, Mantra Capital said.

While Jay Krishna will be heading the deal flow in India, handling product management and business development for portfolio startups and bringing in global partnerships, Srikanth Chintalapati will be responsible for supporting Indian portfolio startups in product development as well as scaling their operations and distribution in India. Kevin Jacobs will be handling the US deal flow, assessing the target startups, as well as managing exits or merger and acquisitions (M&A) of the portfolio companies.

“The fund will focus on scaling innovative solutions that have rapid acceleration potential and can solve problems locally with a massive global impact. We have started scouting for startups in India and international markets like US for initial investments and are already in advanced dialogue with a couple of startups,” said Jay Krishna, general partner-India, Mantra Capital.

“Our target is to close our first fund by the end of 2020,” said Srikanth Chintalapati, partner, Mantra Capital.

Mantra Capital will provide offshore venture services and managed services to global startups. As part of venture services it will scout and curate US and Indian startups for corporate innovation scaling programs that will be launched in the second quarter of 2020. It will also partner with global corporates and global accelerators to help startups Go-To-Market (GTM.)

Title: Normalcy in bandh, govt offices remained closed
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kolhapur: The city government administration came to a standstill with normal life being partially affected during the Bharat bandh called by the leftist trade unions on Wednesday.

The bandh saw markets were closed for few hours with primary schools and colleges functioning to its usual working hours but high schools were closed. The Swabhimani shetkari Sanghatana (SSS) staged rasta rook at various places thus disturbing the routine activities in the rural Kolhapur .

Most of the government employees and officials stayed away from the work, as they condemned the central government’s anti-labor policies. The officials were shouting slogans outside the office and staging a sit out near town hall in the afternoon. Few officials were seen in the government offices as they had no idea about the strike.

Shivaji University functioned normally. S D Lad, president of district education platform said, “Over 40,000 employees from around 4,000 schools in Kolhapur district, including teaching and non-teaching staff and aided and un-aided schools participated in the nationwide agitation for our long-pending demands. The schools were kept shut and no academic activities were performed to show the support of the bandh.”

When contacted Asha Ubale, District education officer (primary), Kolhapur, said that there were reports of the schools remained shut especially from the secondary education sector. “We are yet to receive any confirmation about whether teachers from the primary schools participated in the bandh,” she added.

Khanderao Jagdale, member of the teachers’ body from the unaided schools of Kolhapur district said that staff members from all the unaided schools (primary and secondary) participated in the bandh.

Kolhapur municipal corporation functioned normally as employees union extended support to the strike but did not participate. As a result, the bus service of Kolhapur municipal transport remained unaffected. Shops and other commercial establishments were closed for a few hours in the morning while other industrial units in surrounding areas remained closed during bandh period.

Traffic on national highway 4 remained unaffected during bandh period even as workers of Swabhimani Shetkari Sanghatana (SSS) staged rasta-roko at various places. SSS workers, led by Raju Shetti blocked Kolhapur-Sangli road at Ankli. Bandh evoked good response, where SSS influences Kolhapur district. Traffic at Ankli was disrupted for an hour. The incidents of Rasta Roko was reported from Bidshed, Haldi, Sangrul phata in Karveer taluka, at Bambawade in Shahuwadi taluka and from other places.

Bus service of Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) ran without any impact on employees staying away from the strike. Officials of MSRTC said that the number of commuters was also not affected. Rickshaw service in the city was also normal.

According to police officials, no untoward incident has been reported in the the district so far and police have not registered cases against protesters in the district till now.

In western Maharashtra, bandh evoked no response as only government offices remained non-functional. Normalcy in life was seen in Satara, Sangli and Solapur.

Title: ‘Check for poaching syndicate’
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Panaji: Member of Goa State Environmental Protection Council Nandkumar Kamat has demanded that an emergency meeting be convened of the State Wildlife Advisory Board headed by the chief minister to discuss the tiger deaths. “It’s a serious issue as an international poaching syndicate may be involved because tiger claws cost Rs 5 lakh and above in illegal trade,” he said in a letter to the chief minister on Wednesday.

Title: Gold chain worth Rs 50,000 snatched
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kolhapur: A 60-year-old woman was robbed of her gold chain by two unidentified men riding a motorcycle on the road at Katkar Mal in the Rajarampuri area on Tuesday afternoon.

A case in this regard has been registered with the Rajarampuri police station. Police said that the suspects approached the woman on the pretext of asking an address, snatched her chain and fled from the spot.

The victim, Sulochana Mahadev Jadhav of Daulat Nagar, told police that she was walking when the duo approached her and asked the location of a nearby place. When she was busy telling them the directions, the pillion rider snatched her chain and the the duo sped away.

“We have registered a case against unidentified persons in this regard. We are investigating the case in details,” said a police officer.

Title: AE experts suggest measures to reduce chances of flooding
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kolhapur: The experts from Architects and Engineers (AE) Association suggested several measures to reduce the flood intensity of Panchganga river .

A meeting was held between the delegation of AE and the officials of various agencies led by the district collector Daulat Desai on Wednesday. They discussed several issues mainly about the floods and regional planning.

Senior architect Rajendra Sawant said, “We have to ensure that the intensity of the floods is reduced. The buildings constructed in the prohibitive zone have to be flood-proof. The blue flood line may be extended if the flooding continues to be affected by man-made reasons.”

The suggestions made in the meeting include removal of all the obstructions in the river flow, flood protection work should be undertaken, the city’s development plan should be made keeping the flooding situation in mind, sediments should be removed from the river and agricultural activities along the river banks should be stopped.

Some of the architects and engineers objected to the flood lines published recently by the water resources department. They said that the flood lines will hamper the development activities and some claimed that the developers are ready to make changes to avoid the loss of the properties and lives in case of the floods.

The other issue discussed was related to the regional plan. The experts said that there are several flaws in the plan which has been approved by the state government last year.

“We highlighted the issue of the small hamlets which are 50 years to 200 years old. These hamlets should be brought into the Gaothan (village limit) areas for regulated development. To make the changes in the development rules, we decided to send a proposal to the state government for clear guidelines. In the next meeting we are going to discuss the issues of unified development rules and Kolhapur Urban Area Development Authority (KUADA),” said Ajay Korane, president of AE.

Title: Dead tiger cub found at Mhadei sanctuary
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Keri: Two days after the carcass of a tiger was found inside the Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary, on Tuesday a dead cub was found in the vicinity.

The carcass was not much decomposed, sources said. It was found in the bushes of Golauli in Dongurli-Thane village of Sattari taluka, inside the sanctuary.

Camera traps had recently shown a tigress moving around in the sanctuary along with three cubs.

Forest department officials rushed to the site on getting the information.

The chief minister has ordered an inquiry into the death of the four-year-old tiger, which was found on Sunday. “Preliminary investigation has revealed poisoning as the cause of death,” the CM’s office said on Monday.

Title: NITK helps farmers to preserve unique taro
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Technology to rescue: The Kunubis from Joida taluk in Uttara Kannada will now able to store their unique varie... Read More

Title: Mumbai: 2019 sees lowest road fatalities in 9 years
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: The lowest number of road fatalities on Mumbai’s streets in nine years were recorded in 2019 . As many as 403 people were killed in 378 fatal crashes. The fatalities last year were down 15% compared with 2018 and were 28% lower than in 2011. Traffic police attributed the reduction to crash data analysis, design-oriented interventions and stricter enforcement. But motorists said increased congestion due to ongoing infrastructure projects had reduced vehicle speeds and that too was a factor in decreasing crashes.The number of accidental injuries—2,882 people hurt in 2,325 crashes—was the lowest since 2011. “We study crash data from previous years, analyse reasons and take corrective action. It could be something as simple as installing street lights in a dark lane or increasing the parapet wall of a bridge,” said Madhukar Pandey, joint commissioner, traffic.Pedestrians lose lives the most in road crashes in the city, as seen in previous years. Design interventions to making streets safer for pedestrians to cross has made a difference though. The intersections that were revamped include Nagpada junction, Bandra HP junction and, recently, the CD Barfiwala junction at Andheri. “As far as enforcement is concerned, our focus has been on curbing drunk driving, speeding, riding triple seat, talking on phone while driving and jumping signals,” said Pandey.From 2013 to 2015, fatalities climbed before dipping.Transport experts said fatalities can be minimised further if drivers are disciplined. “Motorcyclists are the biggest culprits when it comes to haphazard riding. Besides riding in the wrong direction and incorrectly overtaking from the left, they often squeeze into the gap between a BEST bus and a pavement hitting the passenger getting off a bus. More punitive measures, a strict driving licence-issuing system and more education are required,” said activist Ashok Datar. He added tackling the parking crisis should be a priority. “Vehicles parked on the footpath force people to walk on the carriageway, putting lives at risk.” Another expert said the state must implement heavy penalties given in amended Motor Vehicles Act. A system to recover every e-challan issued is needed too.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Daily needs prime focus in far-end area of capital
Content:
A Delhi Metro train (File photo)

NEW DELHI: As thousands protest against the new citizenship laws in different parts of Delhi, over towards the Haryana border in Najafgarh, these issues are deep down the pecking order. Reaching this far-flung area has become easier with the Delhi Metro making an ingress to Najafgarh and the Grey Line set to stretch it further to Dhansa. The transit pain alleviated, the people of this assembly constituency are focused on daily needs like infrastructure, water and electricity rather than national policies and legislations.The Najafgarh constituency has a core of Jats with an occupational mix of farming and trading . Employment is a concern in the area. “There has been considerable improvement in the last five years power and water supply, but jobs are still hard to come by,” said Ishwar Singh, a retired Delhi Transport Corporation employee. “The next generation, which is more educated, has to travel several hours from Najafgarh to find jobs.”The expectations the voters have of their political representatives are, therefore, high. In 2015, sitting Aam Aadmi Party MLA Kailash Gahlot (55,598) won the seat from Indian National Lok Dal’s Bharat Singh (54,043) by just over 1,500 votes. BJP’s Ajeet Singh Kharkhari finished third with 39,462 votes, while the Congress candidate had to settle for the fourth spot.Before Delhi Metro access, the Najafgarh road from Dwarka was constantly jammed and unable to cope with the traffic. With the Nangli and Najafgarh metro stations coming up on the same road, some of the burden of commuters has been lifted, but road users are still a grumpy lot.The metro connectivity was a promise made by Gahlot, who is Delhi’s transport minister. People say extension of the urban train network to Dhansa will help decongest the road and expect Gahlot, if elected, to complete the task. “The sitting MLA has done a lot of work. Water, schools and electricity have been improved and now with Delhi Metro reaching Dhansa, people will have a better time,” opined Sanjay Kumar, a resident of Mitraon.Mukesh Vats, a resident of Prem Nagar, was happy with the reduced electricity bills and the improved water supply, but he said space for recreation in each locality would be nice.“Hospitals and government schools were the priorities and we are satisfied with that. But maybe in the next five years, the government can focus on creating more parks,” said Vats.Shakuntala, a fruit seller who lives in Roshanpura, similarly said cheap water and electricity impacted the lives of everyone. “My electricity bill has reduced and I am delighted a new water pipeline has been laid. These are what are more important to most people. They do not brood too much over national issues,” she smiled.

Title: Retired excise officer, wife bludgeoned to death in Muzaffarpur
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

MUZAFFARPUR: A 65-year-old retired senior excise official and his wife were found bludgeoned to death in their house at Gyan Lok Colony in Muzaffarpur town on Wednesday afternoon.

Ajay Kumar Sharma and his wife Renu were killed the previous night and their bodies were spotted the next day by a neighbour, who informed his elder brother. Sharma had retired as assistant inspector general from the state prohibition and excise department five years ago.

Police suspect robbery as a possible motive behind the murders as several household items, including a TV set and a tow-wheeler, were found missing. However, senior police officers who reached the spot, including SP (city) P K Mandal, refused to rule out foul play.

“I personally inspected the spot. It appears the couple was killed during robbery but we cannot arrive at any firm conclusion on the motive behind the crime,” SP (City) P K Mandal said, adding the stolen two-wheeler has been recovered.

The SP (city) along with DSP R N Paswan and SHO of Brahmapura police station had reached the spot around 1.30 pm after being informed by the Ajay’s elder brother Saroj Kumar Sharma, who is a lawyer at the local civil court.

“I got a phone call from a neighbour informing about the incident after which I rushed to my brother’s house. I found the dead body of my brother on bed and his wife Renu lying in a pool of blood below the bed. Their heads were bludgeoned with some heavy object , possibly iron rod or stick,” Saroj said, adding some household items were lying scattered in the house.

“Some valuables like television sets, a two wheeler (scooty) and several other items were missing from the house,” he told media persons.

Saroj, however, refused to speculate on the reason behind the crime. He informed that his brother’s wife Renu is the sister of Muzaffarpur deputy development commissioner Ujjwal Kumar Singh.

Title: Policy for private shacks next year: Pramod Sawant
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: The state government will come out with a shack policy for private shack owners next year, chief minister Pramod Sawant said on Wednesday.

Several issues were raised by private shack operators at a meeting chaired by Sawant at Altinho, Panaji. They said that every season they face problems as the tourism department and civic bodies create hurdles due to which they had to approach the high court last year.

In the petition, the private shack owners association had sought a time-bound schedule for acceptance and disposal of applications to set up shacks in private properties. In November 2019, the high court of Bombay at Goa had directed panchayats and municipalities to dispose of pending application of private shack operators expeditiously considering that the shacks would be seasonal.

Responding to the issues raised by the Private Property Shack Owners Association, Sawant said that till a policy is put in place, the process to register private shack owners with the department of tourism will begin which will help give better facilities to the shack owners and also help the government generate revenue.

Title: Just 394 hospital beds added by AAP govt: BJP thinktank
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: A report by a BJP thinktank on Wednesday claimed that the Aam Aadmi Party government in Delhi had added only 394 beds in the state-run hospitals instead of 30 ,000 beds it had promised before the 2015 assembly elections Prepared by Public Policy Research Centre (PPRC), ‘Delhi: A City on Ventilator’ was released on Wednesday by BJP vice-president and PPRC director Vinay Sahasrabuddhe in the presence of party MPs Ramesh Bidhuri and Meenakshi Lekhi.The report, based on RTI queries and field visits to hospitals and other Delhi government health infrastructure, also listed “shortcomings” in the mohalla clinic network, a pet project of the AAP government.Deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia did not comment on the report, but AAP in the past had rejected PPRC’s claims, saying it was a partisan body.“Healthcare in Delhi has been one of the main planks of AAP government’s publicity. In this background, it is pertinent that the government is held accountable for the steps that it claims to have undertaken for bettering healthcare services in its hospitals,” said Sumit Bhasin, another PPRC director.“Far from tripling hospital beds to 30,000, the Kejriwal government could add a mere 394 beds in five years. It could add only seven beds every month for the first 56 months of its rule,” Bidhuri said.Sahasrabuddhe alleged that mohalla clinics didn’t match the standards of primary healthcare centres and were more like health sub-centres.Lekhi pointed out that in its five-year tenure, the AAP government had been pulled up multiple times by Delhi high court over its inability to meet the growing healthcare demands in the city.

Title: Just 394 hospital beds added by AAP govt: BJP thinktank
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: A report by a BJP thinktank on Wednesday claimed that the Aam Aadmi Party government in Delhi had added only 394 beds in the state-run hospitals instead of 30,000 beds it had promised before the 2015 assembly elections .

Prepared by Public Policy Research Centre (PPRC), ‘Delhi: A City on Ventilator’ was released on Wednesday by BJP vice-president and PPRC director Vinay Sahasrabuddhe in the presence of party MPs Ramesh Bidhuri and Meenakshi Lekhi.

The report, based on RTI queries and field visits to hospitals and other Delhi government health infrastructure, also listed “shortcomings” in the mohalla clinic network, a pet project of the AAP government.

Deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia did not comment on the report, but AAP in the past had rejected PPRC’s claims, saying it was a partisan body.

“Healthcare in Delhi has been one of the main planks of AAP government’s publicity. In this background, it is pertinent that the government is held accountable for the steps that it claims to have undertaken for bettering healthcare services in its hospitals,” said Sumit Bhasin, another PPRC director.

“Far from tripling hospital beds to 30,000, the Kejriwal government could add a mere 394 beds in five years. It could add only seven beds every month for the first 56 months of its rule,” Bidhuri said.

Sahasrabuddhe alleged that mohalla clinics didn’t match the standards of primary healthcare centres and were more like health sub-centres.

Lekhi pointed out that in its five-year tenure, the AAP government had been pulled up multiple times by Delhi high court over its inability to meet the growing healthcare demands in the city.

Title: NMC plot rent jumps from Rs 25 thousand to Rs 57.95 lakh a year
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

NAGPUR: In a desperate move to boost its revenue, the cash-strapped Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has increased rent of its leasehold shops, plots and ottas (platforms) between 4 and 231 times after linking the rent to the ready recknoer value of the property.

As the astronomical hike has made it nearly impossible to run businesses, several leaseholders have appealed to mayor and other office-bearers to reconsider the decision. A delegation of Chamber of Associations of Maharashtra Industry and Trade (CAMIT), led by president Dipen Agrawal, also met Maharashtra cabinet minister Nitin Raut and apprised him about the issue.

As per a chart presented by CAMIT, rent of one of the leased plots at Kadbi Square was Rs24,990 per annum. It increased to Rs57.95 lakh after the hike, making it a whopping 23,190% jump. Similarly, rent of a plot in Lakadganj increased from Rs6,970 to Rs11.57 lakh per annum, an increase of 16,613%. Rent of an otta for vegetable sellers in Cotton Market jumped from Rs660 to Rs12,744, an increase of 1,931%. Similar hikes have been effected in remaining markets also.

Acting on the complaints, mayor Sandip Joshi held a meeting with the leaseholders on January 4 and constituted a committee under BJP corporator Sanjay Bangale to review the rental policy. The committee will hear the grievances of the leaseholders and also discuss the matter with NMC officials before deciding on the new policy. The committee also comprises representatives of leaseholders — Moiz Burhani, Wallabh Parekh, Sanjay Nabira, NMC’s assistant commissioner (market) Vijay Humne, legal officer Venkatesh Kaple, market superintendent Shrikant Vaidya and deputy engineer of town planning department Shrikant Deshpande.

Agrawal told TOI that the NMC has made a major mistake by linking ready reckoner value with rent of the shops, plots and ottas. “NMC’s responsibility is to provide services to the people and not extract exorbitant revenue. These leaseholders facilitate various types of markets to the citizens like kirana, vegetables, fruits, flowers, wood products etc. Many of the leases are for 5-60 years. NMC leases these properties for 11 months, which is renewed from time-to-time,” said Agrawal, adding the civic body demands rent on monthly basis.

“NMC had revised the rent policy in 1992. Since then, it has been increasing rent by 10% every three years. The civic body revised the rent by linking it to ready reckoner value from April 1, 2018. After leaseholders under CAMIT and other associations raised the issue, the NMC reduced the rent by 50% in November 2018. Despite the reduction, the hike remains too stiff,” he pointed out.

Bangale said the committee will meet soon and come up with a new policy. “Nature of leasehold shops, plots and ottas are totally different, but all have been brought under the revised rent system without classifying them. This has resulted in hefty increase in the rents of all,” he said.

“Hike should be effected in regular intervals and not in one stroke. Need is to consider income of leaseholders, location of shops, plots, ottas and other factors. Due to the steep hike, many of the leaseholders stopped paying rent or paid as per old system, resulting in revenue loss for the civic body,” Bangale admitted, adding the committee will also explore the possibilities of long term revision instead of the present 11-month period.

Title: TruJet to add new routes, Belgavi, Tirupati, Mysuru to be connected
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kolhapur: Hyderabad-based private airline TruJet will add three new routes to its existing Kolhapur-Mumbai flight operations from January 18.

According to airport director Kamalkumar Kataria, TruJet will extend its services to Belgavi, Mysuru , and Tirupati .

“At present. the Mumbai-Kolhapur flight lands directly at the Kolhapur airport and returnsto Mumbai. From January 18, there will be a flight to Tirupati which will first travel to Belgavi, then to Mysuru. It will start its return journey from Mysuru to Belgavi and from Belgavi to Kolhapur. This same flight will then travel to Mumbai,” he said.

According to Kataria, the TruJet flight will arrive at the Kolhapur airport at 1.35 pm and depart to Mumbai at 1.55 pm. Another flight will travel from Mumbai to Kolhapur. It will reach Kolhapur airport at 5 pm and depart to Belgavi at 5.15 pm.

The travel time from Kolhapur to Belgavi and vice-versa will be 30 minutes. At present, the Kolhapur airport has connectivity to Mumbai, Hyderabad, Tirupati, and Bengaluru cities, Kataria said.

He added that with these new additions, the daily flight operations at the Kolhapur airport will reach to 12.

“This is a small airport with limited resources. Yet, we have managed to provide satisfactory services to over one lakh passengers over the last one year with over 2,000 flight operations,” he said.

He said that, at present, the airport is undergoing various developmental projects worth Rs 274 crore, including the 14 km compound wall, Rs 80 crore runway expansion and Rs 65 crore terminal building and air traffic control tower.

Currently, Kolhapur airport is used by Air Alliance, IndiGo, and TruJet on Hyderabad, Bengaluru, Tirupati, and Mumbai routes. “The Mumbai service is on halt for three days owing to different issues, however, it will resume soon,” Kataria said.

Title: Hyderabad: Technical snag delays Metro services
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

The services were disrupted between Ameerpet and Raidurg due to a technical snag

HYDERABAD: Heavy rush was seen at Ameerpet Metro station on Wednesday around 9am after services were disrupted on the stretch between Ameerpet and Raidurg due to a technical snag. Nine trains were halted.

While posting a video of the rush at Ameerpet station, a commuter, Sarap Rakesh Gupta @rakesh_sarap tweeted, “What’s wrong today at Ameerpet Metro Station?” Many other commuters, too, posted pictures of heavy rush.

Services were restored after about half-an-hour. HMRL managing director NVS Reddy said, “Trains are running normal. There was delay for a few minutes.”

Earlier, in November, a technical snag had halted Metro services on the Nagole-Hitec City route, causing severe inconvenience to passengers.

Near Ameerpet station, passengers had to be evacuated from the train through the emergency exit and they had to walk on the tracks to reach the station.

Title: KMC demolishes wall obstructing visitors from parking vehicles at hosp basement
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kolhapur: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) on Wednesday demolished a wall obstructing visitors from parking their vehicles at the basement of a hospital located in Rajarampuri.

The municipal corporation has undertaken the task of clearing the basement parking of large establishments in the city.

Several complaints have been made to the civic body stating that the visitors are not allowed to park their vehicles at the basements and that they are forced to park on roads.

The complaints also mentioned about the inconvenience faced by visitors if their vehicles are confiscated by the traffic police department due to parking on roadside.

A senior civic official, on the condition of anonymity, said, “The standing committee has given us directions to remove all the encroachments in the basement parking of large establishments. So far, we have issued notices to over 25 establishments including hotels, lodgings and hospitals. We have started the action after we found that the owners or operators of these establishments do not clear the encroachments on their own. On Wednesday, we demolished a wall constructed to obstruct the vehicles of the visitors to park their vehicles in the basement of the hospital. Similar action will be undertaken soon at other establishments.”

The civic body has focused on congested areas such as Rajarampuri, Shahupuri and Lakshmipuri. The residents of these areas have been asking the civic administration to take steps to make these areas congestion-free.

Recently, the municipal corporation conducted an anti-encroachment drive to remove hawkers from one of the busy lanes of Rajarampuri. MLA Chandrakant Jadhav has directed the KMC and the traffic department to make the lanes in Rajarampuri congestion-free on priority and then focus on the rest of the areas.

Title: Hyderabad: Cyberabad police face flak over ‘intel on jihadis in MNCs’ tweet
Price row: Iconic mutton dishes go off the plate
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Kolhapur: The iconic mutton dishes have gone off the menu of most hotels and restaurants in Kolhapur , the erstwhile princely state and a key southern city of Maharashtra, in a climax of the two-month row over the meat prices.

Since Monday, mutton shops have stopped selling the meat claiming that they cannot afford the Rs 480 per kg price fixed by a 25-member panel appointed by the district administration. They claim that the rate was forced upon them.

The fiery red curry (tambda rassa) and is mild counterpart white curry (pandhra rassa), along with the meat pickles and roasts, are the most famous delicacies from Kolhapur known across the country. Tourists visiting Kolhapur not just tread to the famous Mahalaxmi temple and then bag the iconic footwear, but do not miss out on a hearty meal of these culinary preparations.

Sanjay Kadam, a hotelier from Rajarampuri, said, “We have stopped serving mutton dishes. We have to convince the customers to relish other dishes. We are concerned about this mutton row since we are losing the customers.”

He added that around 80 to 100 dishes of mutton are served at his hotel daily, making up a large portion of his business. Hoteliers like him are hoping for a quick resolution to the price row.

Vijay Kamble, a mutton seller, said they share a close bond with the hoteliers. “We have provided quality mutton to the hoteliers whenever they demanded. The hoteliers are asking us to start the shops as they are not getting good quality mutton from outside. We will continue our strike. None from the administration approached us to start the shops,” he said.

Consumers are moving to hotels outside the city, where hoteliers have some access to local mutton from the rural hinterland.

Meanwhile, the forum demanding mutton at cheaper rates started one sale centre. They converted a tea shop from Rajarampuri into a mutton shop. Baba Indulkar, the convenor of the forum, said they got the goats certified from the KMC’s veterinary officer and provided mutton at Rs 480 per kg to the consumers. Indulkar claimed that over 60 kilogram of mutton was sold from the centre in just one day.

Title: Nagpur: Nationwide strike hits government hospitals in city
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Asha workers at RBI square

NAGPUR: Work at Government Medical College , Mayo Hospital , Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC)-run hospitals and health care centres, Regional Mental Hospital, and Daga Hospital remained badly affected after nurses and support staff comprising Class 4 employees joined nationwide strike call by Left unions on Wednesday.

Over 1,200 nurses from GMC and around 280 from Mayo did not report to work. Large number of Asha workers too struck work which is likely to impact the upcoming pulse polio drive on January 19. NMC staff under Urban National Health Mission also took a day off to join the demonstration at Samvidhan Square.

An official from GMC said resident doctors and nursing students were roped in as alternative arrangement for the day. Mayo dean Dr Ajay Keolia agreed it wasn’t business as usual but efforts were made to keep things under control. “The flow of patient was less due to rains but operations were performed as surgery department didn’t go on strike. All deliveries were conducted while post mortems too were done,” he said.

Keolia said the director of medical education and research had already issued instructions and meetings were held for making alternative arrangements. “First year classes too were held while a body donation was done at anatomy department,” he said.

At GMC, an official said though the medical services are covered under ESMA, many went on strike. “We will see if a day’s pay would be cut or any action taken against them. Medications and timely doses were affected and OPD too was hit because of lack of manpower,” the official added.

The situation was same at Regional Mental Hospital, NMC hospitals and Daga where patients and their relatives faced difficulties.

Title: Ex-Bhagalpur DM named in Srijan case
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The CBI filed a supplementary chargesheet in the Srijan scam case against 10 people, including former Bhagalpur DM Virendra Yadav , before a special court in Patna on Wednesday.

The scam, which was handed over to the CBI for probe in 2017, is related to the transfer of around Rs 2,000 crore from several government bank accounts in Bhagalpur and others districts to accounts of an NGO Srijan Mahila Vikash Sahyog Samiti.

Sources said Yadav is the first IAS officer whose name surfaced officially so far after the case was handed over to the federal agency by the Nitish Kumar government. Initially, the scam was being probed by the economic offences unit of the state police.

CBI spokesperson RK Gaur said it’s a supplementary chargesheet in which Yadav has been named as an accused. Yadav, a 2004 batch Bihar cadre IAS officer, is currently posted as special secretary in the backward class and extremely backward class welfare department.

CBI sources said Yadav was posted as Bhagalpur DM for little over a year. “He was posted there as DM in the middle of 2014. It was during this period that the maximum amount of money was siphoned off from the bank account to the district land acquisition office,” CBI sources said, adding, more than Rs 300 crore was siphoned off into Srijan’s account from the land acquisition office’s bank account.

Title: Agra-Mathura city transport service increases fare, irks passengers
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Agra: After the Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (UPSRTC), the Agra-Mathura city bus transport service has also increased the fare by at least 10 paise per kilometer on different routes. On Wednesday, the increase in fare resulted in an argument between bus conductors and passengers. Customers said that no prior information was given regarding the fare hike.

Under the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal Mission (JNNURM) scheme, the Agra- Mathura city transport service operates a total of 230 buses. Out of these 170 buses are operated in Agra and 60 buses in Mathura.

According to the revised rate, the fare from Agra Cantt to Bhagwan Talkies, the busiest route of the city, has been increased to Rs 25 from its previous rate of Rs 22.

The fare from Agra to Fatehabad has been increased from Rs 35 to 39. The fare from Agra to Pinahat has been increased from Rs 58 to 64.

Managing director of the Agra-Mathura city bus transport service RBL Sharma said, “Following the UPSRTC, minor increase has been made in the fare of city bus service. This will help in improving operations.”

Pratap Pura resident Sunil Verma said, “Fare bus has been increased without any prior information. Fare from Sai Ka Takia to Bhagwan Talkies was Rs 12 which has now been increased to Rs 15. I am factory worker and a daily commuter. The increase in fare does affect me. Increase in the bus fare is highly unreasonable. The UPSRTC administration should have ensured better facilities for the passengers before taking this decision.”

Khandari resident Naresh Yadav said, “Condition of the city buses is very poor. With broken glasses, the seats are in a wear and tear state in most of the buses. Following poor maintenance, buses make a lot of noise causing inconvenience to the passengers. Authorities should have made efforts to ensure safe and comfortable travel for passengers before increasing the fare.”

Title: Revenue minister Thorat appointed guardian minister of Kolhapur
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kolhapur: State revenue minister Balasaheb Thorat has been appointed guardian minister of Kolhapur district.

The Congress MLA from Sangamner is also the president of Maharashtra Congress Committee and has been credited with forming the alliance with Shiv Sena to form the government in the state.

Thorat is considered as the loyalist of the central leadership of Congress.

Congress MLC and minister of state Satej Patil was the frontrunner for the post of the district guardian minister. However, Patil has been appointed as the district guardian minister of Bhandara district. Rural development minister and senior leader of Nationalist Congress Party Hasan Mushrif has been appointed the guardian minister of Ahmednagar district, Thorat’s home district.

According to the sources, the NCP had claimed to have its person as the guardian minister of Ahmednagar due to the victory of a large number of its MLA. A consensus seems to have reached between Congress and NCP and therefore Thorat has been given the post.

Thorat as the guardian minister will preside over the meetings of district planning and development council (DPDC). The first meeting of which is likely to take place soon.

The Congress local leaders are happy with Thorat’s appointment though a bit disappointed for Satej Patil.

Patil is probably the only MoS who has been appointed the guardian minister. The local Congress leader said that Thorat is the most compatible choice since for the first time in the recent years Congress has performed well in the district in assembly elections. Having the state president of the party as the guardian minister will help grow the party base in the district and in the region.

Water resources minister Jayant Patil has been appointed the guardian minister of his home district Sangli and Balasaheb Patil as the guardian minister of Satara district.

Title: SUTA members to protest against VC
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kolhapur: The faculty members of colleges associated with the Shivaji University Teachers’ Association will protest against the vice-chancellor of Shivaji University, Kolhapur , (SUK) Devanand Shinde in front of chancellor’s office (Rajbhavan) in Mumbai on January 2, read a press statement from SUTA .

The SUTA members carried out a one-day protest against the VC over alleged irregularities at the SUK campus on Tuesday. The protesters said that they are demanding Shinde’s resignation over various lapses committed by him during his four-year tenure.

“We have had meetings to discuss the lapses with the V-C last year in the month of May. However, there was no action initiated by him. Hence, we have decided to continue protests against him. We had protested during the senate meeting earlier last month as well and had warned of more agitations,” a press statement from SUTA read.

It was alleged that there were irregularities on Shinde’s part in granting invalid affiliation to a Satara-based college. The said college was given fresh affiliation by the V-C. The affiliation of the said college was cancelled way back in June 2000, yet, the college was granted affiliation last year which violates the guidelines of the Maharashtra Universities Act.

Shinde has, in the past, denied all allegations against him claiming that they are baseless and fictional.

Title: No efforts to protect tiger in Goa: Congress
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The Congress on Wednesday criticised the government for four tiger deaths saying there were no efforts made to protect the national animal in the state.

President of state Congress, Girish Chodankar alleged that like the drug trade, poachers were flourishing under government patronage. Questioning the government’s silence, he demanded that the CM come clear on status of protection of tigers .

Title: Nagpur: Treated worse than animals: Axis Bank contract workers
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Question of livelihood

NAGPUR: New generation or private sector banks have largely remained insulated by the countrywide strike calls. On Wednesday, however, lower level work like data entry and house keeping was hit in Axis Bank .

As Bhartiya Kamgar Sena, the Shiv Sena-affiliated union for the first time responded to a strike call by Left and Congress unions, contract workers from Axis Bank also came out to protest. The small group holding saffron banners could be seen apart among scores of red flags of the communist unions. The workers not only complained of poor wages and lack of job security, but also insulting behaviour by their superiors.

“It’s for the first time that we have staged protests in a joint forum like this. The only union under Bharatiya Kamgar Sena that has joined the rally is its Axis Bank unit though the union also has a presence in some of the other private sector banks,” said Sanjay Lonare from Bharatiya Kamgar Sena’s Axis Bank unit.

“The lower level work in all the Axis Bank branches of the state has been hit today or taken over by regular workers. The 7,500 contract workforce in Axis Bank’s branches in Maharashtra are on strike. The contract workers here are affiliated to the Kamgar Sena,” he said.

“The condition of contractor workers is worse than animals. Salaries range between Rs13,000 to Rs17,000 a month. Though it’s difficult to make ends meet, contract workers are even denied basic rights like leave. A single day’s leave not only leads to a pay cut, but also a threat of losing the job. Women workers’ services are terminated after they return from maternity leave,” he said.

Provident fund is deducted from salaries but other terms and conditions are framed in such a way that employees are not eligible for gratuity at all. Contract workers are engaged on a three-yearly basis. Even as the same employees are continued, their services are terminated after every three years and a fresh contract has to be signed. This leads to a break in service due to which the minimum period of five years for getting gratuity is not maintained, he said.

“In June, an e-mail intimating plans to lay off 750 contract workers had left everyone worried. We hardly have any scope to get other employment. One of the workers in Nagpur also attempted suicide following the news but was saved. Finally, due to the unions’ pressure the move was withdrawn,” said a worker.

Vishal Shende said he is 33 years old and earns Rs17,000 a month. He may be better compared to many of his colleagues yet the sum is too less to meet expenses. “We have to work much beyond the regular eight hour shift yet there is no over time. With age, chances of getting another job is also reducing. I see no scope of a hike in wages,” he said.

“We do all the menial work like cleaning plates and arranging food during the staffers’ birthday celebrations but nobody bothers to even wish us on our birthdays, forget offering food,” said Lonare.

Title: 31st Road Safety Week to be held from Jan 11-17
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kolhapur: The Regional Transport Office (RTO), Kolhapur , and the police department will observe the 31st Road Safety Week from January 11 to January 17.

Several programmes, including rallies, camps and awareness drives, workshops, social media campaigns and road safety programmes in schools and colleges, will be organised to spread awareness among people and students about road safety.

RTO officials said that this year they will mark the event in a peculiar way. They will felicitate the rule violators, signal jumpers and other defaulters found during the Road Safety Week by giving them a rose and requesting them not to commit such wrongdoings in the future.

“The number of road accidents continue to vary year-by-year as per the statistics. Also, the number of vehicles on the roads continue to increase every day in contray to the width and the length of the roads. In such instances, we can only educate people about following traffic rules and safe driving, especially the youngsters. Through this initiative, including seminars and workshops on the occasions of Road Safety Week, we will try and reach out to people, especially youngsters and inform them about the need of following traffic rules,” said a senior RTO official.

The official said that they have also identified accident-prone black spots in the district, adding that special efforts will be taken to reduce them.

“We will also launch several drives to keep a check on bikers and other motorists to ensure that they follow traffic rules,” he added.

Title: AMC issues notices in garbage collection scam
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Agra: The Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) has started taking action in the door-to-door garbage collection scam. Municipal Commsioner Arun Prakash has issued notices to the executive engineer (environment) Rajiv Rathi, four zonal sanitation officers (ZSO) and five companies which were tasked for door-to-door garbage collection.

Notices have been issued seeking clarification within three days on the approval of fake bills of door-to-door service produced by the companies without verification.

A report on the probe ordered by mayor Naveen Jain, presented in the municipal board meeting on Monday, revealed that private companies entrusted with the task of door-to-door garbage collection in the city were paid Rs 22.65 crore without verification of work done. Investigation revealed that only 10.5% garbage collection was done in 83 wards of the city.

The ZSOs who have been issued notices for lack of proper monitoring of the door-to-door garbage collection work includes Dayaram Sisodiya, Shriram Chaurasia, Surendra Singh and Mahendra Singh.

Municipal commissioner Arun Prakash said, “Notices have been issued to the environmental engineer, four ZSOs and five private companies for malpractices in the door-to-door garbage collection plan. Following response to the notices, suitable action will be taken in the entire matter. In case required, we will be taking legal action against the companies for recovery of money taken by them on the basis of fake bills.”

Title: Tamil Nadu: If plans go well, a tram may take you around Mahabalipuram
Content:
The tram would pass through the UNESCO-accredited sites of Shore Temple, the Five Rathas, Arjuna’s Penance and... Read More

CHENNAI: In a bid to amp up amenities and attract more tourists to Mahabalipuram , the state government is planning to introduce a comprehensive parking space and a tram service within the tourist town.Emulating tramways in Bordeaux in France and Basel in Switzerland, which help tourists get a feel of the place on the cities’ streets, the government has proposed the plan.A centralised parking space for all tourist vehicles has been proposed. A revenue official confirmed to TOI that the department has identified a place near Karu Kathamman Temple in the beach-facing town and a proposal sent to the concerned department.Earlier, there was a proposal to create a similar space at the entrance of the town on East Coast Road. Since the move hit a roadblock due to legal issues after a lawyer moved court, revenue officials chose for an alternative site.The proposal for the parking was discussed during a meeting at the secretariat. A senior officer who attended the meeting said setting up a tram service close to the parking space was also discussed.Elaborating further, the revenue official said, “The tram will run through the town roads and narrow lanes revealing the intricate construction of the Pallava kings and artefacts of the town. This way, tourists can see the whole town without having to walk around exhaustively.”Tourists will have to get a pass to use the tram service and can hop on and off the service to see the sites at their own pace, he added. The tram would pass through the UNESCO-accredited sites of Shore Temple, the Five Rathas, Arjuna’s Penance and Krishna ’s Butterball among other places.Historians, however, are wary of the proposal, seeing it might cause potential damage to the heritage monuments . Ramachandran Nagaswamy, an Indian historian, archaeologist and epigraphist said, “First the state government should form a committee comprising officials from the concerned departments and activists, and show the route in which the tram will pass through the town.”Mahabalipuram has seen a noticeable increase in footfall since it was renovated for the second informal summit of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Chinese president Xi Jinping held on October 11 and 12 last year. Though hawkers were removed ahead of the summit, more vendors have mushroomed. Nagasamy said the appreciation of heritage sites was on the decline as such, adding, “this should not worsen the situation.”

Title: Telangana: Family robbed, missing servants on radar
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

HYDERABAD: Unknown offenders gave sedatives to three members of a family residing in a villa at Kokapet and decamped with their valuables while the victims were unconscious.

Though the incident took place on Saturday, it came to light on Wednesday. Police suspect the involvement of their servants..

Narsingi police said businessman Srinivas Reddy, his wife and their younger daughter was found unconscious by the couple’s elder daughter on Saturday. She rushed her parents and sister to hospital. “The condition of the three victims is stable and they are recovering,’’ sub-inspector Laxman said. The three family members were given sedatives.

The family members have raised suspicion on the missing Nepali couple, who joined as servants in December.

Title: Bangalore Gate all set for makeover
Content:
Octori Post at Bangalore Gate

History of Octroi Post

BENGALURU: The 19th century heritage structure located in Chamarajpet, known as Bangalore Gate or octroi post , will soon regain its old glory, thanks to the city police commissioner.The Indian National Trust for Art and Cultural Heritage (Intach) had taken up restoration work of the dilapidated colonial structure following a Twitter appeal by top cop Bhaskar Rao.He said restoring the post has been his dream. “I have lived my life in the southern part of the city and I know the importance of the octroi post,” Rao said. After renovation, it will also house a library for police personnel, he added.The revamp is funded by heritage lovers and the primary donor is Basant Poddar, chairperson of Mineral Enterprises Ltd (MEL). “The basic cost of renovation is estimated at Rs 50 lakh. However, it may go up if we build a fountain and walking lane inside,” Poddar said.“Octroi post, which is around 80 sqm, is among the most important heritage structures in the city. We have studied its history before holding discussions with engineers on the nature of restoration work,” he said. Work will be completed by the end of January or February, he added.SK Aruni, historian and regional director of Indian Council of Historical Research, opined that the octroi post could have been a tax collection point between 1900 and 1910 — taxing people entering the city from Mysuru Road. Originally the Bengaluru-Mysuru Road started from KIMS Hospital circle in KR Market. However, as the city expanded rapidly, Mysuru Road was shifted to its present location around 1950, Aruni added.In 1830s, the road opposite KIMS Hospital was marked as the beginning of the road to Mysuru. It passed Gandhi Baazar and Girinagar before joining Mysuru Road on the border of Girinagar. However, the city was beginning to expand and residents started opting for presentday Mysuru Road. On the other hand, Chamarajpet also started to grow. Accordingly, the octroi post was constructed at Sirsi Circle as it was the borderline for then Bangalore,” he added.

Title: Don’t mislead people on ownership rights in illegal colonies, says BJP
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Vijender Gupta

NEW DELHI: Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) on Wednesday alleged that the ruling Aam Aadmi Party was trying to “mislead” people on the issue of providing ownership rights to the residents of unauthorised colonies by questioning the authenticity of the registration documents.

Addressing a press conference, leader of Opposition in Delhi assembly Vijender Gupta said that it was “ridiculous” that AAP national convener and Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal was raising question on the registration process of the house deeds, which was being executed by a sub-registrar under his own government.

“Kejriwal and other AAP leaders should not commit the sin of misleading the people of unauthorised colonies. The campaign of the BJP government (at the Centre) to confer ownership rights is progressing fast. Kejriwal cannot stop the registration process of land and houses in unauthorised colonies at any cost,” Gupta said.

The AAP leaders, including Kejriwal and his deputy Manish Sisodia, have questioned the exercise in unauthorised colonies and alleged that “fake” registration certificates were being given to the people.

Calling the registration process a “big fraud”, Sisodia said a property cannot be registered unless the land use for the plot was changed to residential. “The registry document clearly says that any existing law – such as the DDA Act or the Delhi Masterplan - can be enforced in these colonies. Armed with a court or an NGT order, an official can start demolition of these colonies and this paper cannot save them,” he added.

Gupta said about one lakh people had registered themselves on the Delhi Development Authority (DDA) website for ownership rights of their properties, adding, “This is because they have full faith in the BJP government.”

BJP MP from North-West Delhi Hans Raj Hans alleged that the chief minister did not want the benefits of the Centre’s schemes to reach poor people.
