Title: Robbers fail to open locker after entering bank
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Kolhapur: Unidentified men broke open the locks of a nationalised bank branch located in Dhamod village of Radhanagari Taluka on Tuesday night but failed to break the bank locker as they returned empty-handed.

According to the superintendent of police Abhinav Deshmukh, the cash and valuables worth Rs 2.84 crore are safe in the bank’s vault. The accused also tried to break open shutters another cooperative bank located on the same road on Tuesday night said police.

On Wednesday morning, when the bank officials went to open the branch, they found the locks of the entrance door broken. After entering the bank they found the locks of the strong room broken. However, the locks of the locker were safe as the robbers failed to open the locker. They immediately alerted the police department who rushed with the dog squad and fingerprint experts.

“We are gathering information regarding the incident and are investigating the case in details. The robbers had cut the cable connected to siren before entering the bank. We have gathered the CCTV footage from the neighbouring areas and are examining it,” said a police officer.

Title: Delhi: JNU says over 3,000 register for new semester
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Jawaharlal Nehru University

NEW DELHI: The Jawaharlal Nehru University vice-chancellor on Tuesday claimed that 3,552 out of the total 8,600 students had registered for the new semester despite the boycott call given by JNU Students Union ( JNUSU ).

JNUSU, however, dismissed the claim stating that only around 170 students had registered as two schools — languages and social sciences, which have the most students — were in complete lockdown.

Saket Moon, JNUSU vice-president, told TOI, “If you speak to most students, they will say they haven’t registered. School of Languages has close to 3,200 students and School of Social Sciences around 2,800. These are the largest schools. Someone in the office informed us that only 170 people had registered.”

To complete the registration process, students have to clear the hostel dues and pay the registration fees. Following this, they need to go to their respective departments and submit the folio signed by the guide and the head.

Registration was disrupted on January 3 when a group of students allegedly entered the server room of the university and damaged the wires. Had the registration been completed by January 5, the new semester would have started. Now, there is no clarity on what will happen to the academic calendar. Many complained that because of extension of the registration process and continuation of the stalemate, the winter semester could be disrupted.

Teachers said the solution would have been rolling back the fee hike and extending the monsoon semester by two weeks. In two weeks, the assessment and examination would have been completed. “The academic calendar has to be shifted a little further. The monsoon semester could have been extended by two weeks. The winter semester could have continued by cutting short the summer vacation. This would have ensured that the new academic year began on time. If the administration delays in resolving the issues, the university’s academic calendar will go haywire,” said JNUTA president DK Lobiyal.

Despite repeated attempts by TOI through phone calls and messages, the JNU administration didn’t respond to the queries. On Wednesday, JNUSU called for another day of strike making it the 72nd day of agitation that started as part of the protest against the hostel fee hike . Because of the strike, classes were kept on hold in many departments and centres and students did not sit for the exams.

Title: Light rain in Agra region causes dip in mercury
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Agra: Agra region witnessed light rain on Wednesday morning causing difficulties for school-going children. Candidates for teacher eligibility test (TET) also faced inconvenience. Drizzling occurred in the evening too.

According to India Meteorological Department (IMD), 0.7 mm rainfall was recorded in Agra on Wednesday. The mercury level is likely to drop over the next week. Dense fog can be seen between December 9 and 12.

There was also overcast condition on Wednesday. Cold wave flowed at a speed of 20 km per hour making people in open shiver. The maximum temperature was recorded at 18 degrees Celsius which was four degrees Celsius less than normal. The minimum temperature remained 13 degrees Celsius.

Besides Agra, rainfall took place in parts of Firozabad, Mathura, Etah, Aligarh and Mainpuri. In Aligarh, 1.2 mm rainfall was recorded. Here maximum temperature remained 15 degrees Celsius and minimum temperature was recorded at 12 degrees Celsius.

Besides rainfall, poor condition of roads and lack of proper lighting arrangement caused a lot of difficulties for people in different parts of the city.

Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) - to relieve people staying outdoors from cold wave - operated gas heaters at over a dozen places in the evening. Besides, people set up bonfires.

District agriculture officer, Rampravesh Verma, said, “Light rain took place in Agra. It is beneficial for wheat and mustard crops. The potato crop is at risk of getting affected. Farmers are being told about the precautionary measures.”

Meanwhile, Wednesday’s air quality index in Agra was recorded in the poor category at 209. According to central pollution control board (CPCB), particulate matter 2.5 remained the prominent pollutant. The air quality in poor category can cause breathing discomfort to most people on prolonged exposure.

Title: Anti-CAA clashes: AMU students file petition in HC for investigation into police role
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Agra: A group consisting students and teachers of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) has moved Allahabad high court with a writ petition, seeking probe into the role of district administration, paramilitary force and varsity administration in the December 15 violence. The legal team of AMU Coordination Committee filed the writ on Tuesday.

The violence had left at least 70 people injured.

The Allahabad high court has already asked the NHRC to probe the role of police into the violence.

Asad Hayat, who is representing AMU Coordination Committee in the court, alleged that the varsity administration is working “under political pressure” and must also be held responsible for the police brutality.

“Since the university administration was not sincerely engaging with the stakeholders, it was imperative to go to court. He further added that this is being done not just to exercise the democratic rights of the students but also to protect democratic values,” he said. Hayat also tried to highlight the separate versions on the permission granted to police to enter the campus.

“The letter the police are presenting as a proof of permission to enter the campus is dated December 13 and is for security arrangements outside the administrative block, written by the Registrar. On that day, Dr Kafeel Khan along with political analyst Yogendra Yadav, were scheduled to arrive in the campus.”

“If the police had a permission of December 15, then why are they not showing it in the court?” he asked.

When contacted, Registrar of the university, Abdul Hamid, said that the district administration was asked to take steps to maintain public order in the university campus on December 15.

Aligarh DIG Akash Kulhary also claimed that they had a written permission, which has been submitted in the court. He told TOI that December 13 letter was the different one.

Title: Freed fishermen meet CM, get Rs 5L each to restart lives
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Twenty fishermen from Vizianagaram and Srikakulam districts, who were lodged in a Karachi jail for 14 months after straying into Pakistan waters in November 2018, reached Vijayawada late on Tuesday night and met chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy on Wednesday.

“We had little hope of coming back. We are grateful to the chief minister for his efforts in securing our release,” said one of them. While 20 of the 22 fishermen have been released, the remaining two are likely to be released in the next one-two weeks, officials said.

Jagan, who announced a grant of Rs 5 lakh to each of the fishermen to restart their lives, also directed officials to expedite the construction of fishing harbours in Vizianagaram and Srikakulam. He expressed anguish after learning that more than 15,000 fishermen were travelling to Gujarat due to the absence of fishing jetties.

“It is sad to know that nearly 15,000 people are going to Gujarat to work as labour, despite AP having a vast coastline. Soon, a jetty for the fishermen will be provided in Srikakulam and Vizianagaram districts,” he said. He also said the state would do its best to bring back fishermen from the state who are lodged in Bangladesh jails at the earliest.

As many as 22 fishermen from Vizianagaram, Srikakulam and East Godavari districts went fishing in November 2018 and strayed into Pakistan waters. They were detained by the Pakistan coast guard, and later sent to a jail in Karachi jail.

The state government’s constant efforts with the Centre paved way for their release. Marketing and fisheries minister Mopidevi Venkata Ramana went to Wagah border to receive the fishermen after they were released by Pakistani authorities and brought them back.

Surada Kishore, 18, from Etcherla mandal in Srikakulam district, said they lost their way off Gujarat coast while fishing in the deep seas.

“We were arrested by the Pakistan coast guard and were sent to a jail in Karachi. The only communication with our families back home was through letters.

“ In jail, we were made to work very hard, especially those from India are made to work even harder. I am very happy to be back home,” he said, while adding that he would pursue his studies with the financial support extended by the chief minister.

Title: Nagpur: World Bank favours more private sector engagement to tackle Tuberculosis
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image


NAGPUR: The World Bank and Government of India have a loan agreement of $400 million to expand the coverage and quality of interventions for control of tuberculosis (TB). It also supports the government’s national strategic plan to end TB in India by 2025. “The private sector engagement will be one of the priorities of the World Bank,” said Ronald Upenyu Mutasa, the bank’s task team leader for the TB elimination programme of South East Asia. “World Bank supports scaling of engagement of the private sector in health services, especially for the goal of TB elimination in India. There is flexibility in the funding pattern. Private hospitals and NGOs working for the elimination of TB need to come up with concrete plans through the proper channel,” Mutasa said. According to him, Maharashtra is one of the nine priority states in the TB mission and has a big opportunity in the next five years. He also had a word of praise for central and state governments for effective implementation of the TB eradication programme. “The Indian government made many changes in the fund allotment rules in 2019 which makes it easier for the private sector to come forward and contribute for the cause. The government is readily giving the multi-drug resistant TB (MDR) ward if private hospital demands,” he said. With the help of the World Bank, the government provides financial incentives to private sector care providers for reporting cases of TB and ensuring that their patients complete the treatment regimen. It also provides direct benefit transfers to patients for acquiring the critical nutrition needed during treatment. World Bank funds also help GOI to strengthen monitoring and implementation of Nikshay — a web-based TB case monitoring system. Former deputy director general for TB control in the ministry of health and family welfare, Dr Sunil Khaparde, who now works as national adviser to the GOI on the issue, said the World Bank programme also supports the ministry of health and family welfare to develop and implement a human resource plan to meet institutional capacity needs at the Centre and state level. Chest physician, Dr Ravindra Sarnaik, said that pulmonologists and NGOs in the city are keen to make city TB free for which they will prepare implementable plans now. “Dr Ronald Mutasa has given a very positive message to people from the private sector willing to work for elimination of TB. We will adhere to the established protocol,” he said.

Title: Coimbatore: Can Pollachi be made district? People give mixed response
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

On Tuesday,deputy speaker Jayaraman, during his speech in the assembly, reiterated the demand to make Pollachi... Read More

COIMBATORE: A day after deputy speaker Jayaraman reiterated the demand to make Pollachi a separate district, stakeholders are divided in their opinions on the issue. While industrialists and traders believe that the move would help improve the economy of the largely agricultural region, farmers are of the opinion that Pollachi does not have enough industries or revenues to sustain itself as a district.

On Tuesday, the deputy speaker, during his speech in the assembly, demanded that Pollachi be made a separate district. He said Pollachi was a revenue block from 1857 when Tirupur was just a firka. “Pollachi along with Madathukulam, Valparai and Udumalpet should be carved into a separate district,” he said.

Industrialists and traders echoed Jayaraman’s demand arguing that this administrative move was crucial to realise the growth potential of the region. “Pollachi, which is dominated by agricultural economy and lands, needs a lot more agriculture-based industries to see fast growth. It will also help in development of tourism. The move will help increase per capita income,” said vice-president of the Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industries and educationist S Venkkatesh. “Now people must keep travelling to Coimbatore to get every permission and make policy decision regarding our region.”

Secretary of the Pollachi Small Scale Traders Association A Harikrishnan agreed that constantly having to travel to Coimbatore to get permissions for new industries, explain situations and demand policy changes or even sort out tax issues is becoming difficult for them. “Even to get a licence for a trivial matter like operating a cracker shop, we need to travel all the way there,” he said.

“We also believe that if Pollachi were to be a separate district, it will bring more attention to the region which will increase land value,” he added.

However, farmers believe that it is better for the region to stay with Coimbatore. “Unlike Tirupur that has a large garment industry, Pollachi has no major industry except coir, which is comparatively very small. We don’t have a large enough industrial economy or revenue system to sustain as a separate district,” said coconut farmer K Jothimani.

Title: CAA Protest News: As CAA stir rages, Tricolour supplies hit
Content: Retailers sold an estimated 3.5 lakh national flags for the rally, among the biggest non-violent gatherings... Read More HYDERABAD: With both supporters and opponents of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) carrying the Tricolour during their rallies, suppliers of the National Flag have for the first time run out of stock ahead of Republic Day.The anti-CAA rally on January 4, which saw thousands taking to the streets in Hyderabad, shrunk the stock further. Retailers sold an estimated 3.5 lakh national flags for the rally, among the biggest non-violent gatherings for a cause in Hyderabad in six decades. In fact, flag sellers have sought fresh stocks from manufacturers, who are working overtime to meet the huge demand.Suppliers say Hyderabad is likely to see a further spurt in the demand in next two days as Asaduddin Owaisi’s AIMIM has proposed a mega rally from Mir Alam Idgah to Shastripuram in the city outskirts on January 10. Owaisi, who announced that he would hoist the National Flag at Charminar on the Republic Day, has ordered a 10 feet by 30 feet Tricolour.“Generally, demand for the National Flag goes up before Republic Day and Independence Day. But the last fortnight has seen huge demand across the country. Retailers in Delhi are calling us to enquire if we can arrange fresh supplies,” said flag bulk manufacturer Mahendar Reddy of Vidy Arts Flags at Nagole in the city.Shaik Osman of SK Group, a bulk manufacturer at Mailardevpally, told TOI that the flag market in Osmangunj had virtually run out of stock. Retailers have now placed orders to meet the demand for Republic Day. “We have hired extra workers to stitch flags. On January 3 and 4, retailers had jacked up prices. A 20x30 inch flag, normally sold for Rs 15, was sold for Rs 30 while 30x45 inch flag was sold for Rs 50 as against Rs 30 on other days,” he said. Osman is making the huge flag for Owaisi.M Chanda, who runs ARC Flag shop, said an estimated 10 lakh flags have been sold in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh since the CAA protests began three weeks ago. “We have never seen such demand for the Tricolour during the period considered as off-season. There is a demand from small towns too. We have ordered for more flags to meet the requirement,” he said.Tehreek Muslim Shabban leader Mushtaq Malik, who organised the January 4 rally, said they had bought small flags for even Rs 100 while they are sold for Rs 20 during normal days. “The city has never witnessed such a large number of people carrying the tricolour during a protest for a cause,” he added.

Title: Sushmita Sen channels her inner child as she sways on a swing; watch the video here
Content: Although Sushmita Sen has been away from the silver screen, the actress was in touch with her fans through her social media. Sush loves to treat everyone with pictures and videos from her day to day activities. Most of the posts include her workout videos, pictures with daughters and boyfriend Rohman Shawl.Now, the actress took to her Instagram to share a new video which will take you back to your childhood when you used to enjoy a swing! In the video, the actress can be seen enjoying a swing ride. She captioned the picture, "To witness a sunrise from a #swing is to re-member the magical power of hope from one’s childhood😊❤️🤗💃🏻🌈 #workday #childplays 😁❤️ I love you guys soooooo much! #sharing #sunrise #woooosh #thisfeeling #nature #oneness #hope 💋"Check out the video here:Meanwhile, on the work front, the former beauty queen recently announced about her second innings and return to the screen after a long hiatus of almost 10 years. She was last seen in a Bengali film titled ' Nirbaak '.Sushmita has been in the news for her relationship with her boyfriend Rohman Shawl. Their respective social media feeds prove that the couple is in love truly madly deeply!

Title: 'No duty cuts to soften fuel spike'
Content:
Petroleum minister Dharmendra Pradhan (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The government has ruled out an immediate cut in taxes on petrol and diesel to soften the impact of the geo-political tensions, which have triggered a spike in global crude oil prices .Brent prices crossed the $71-a-barrel mark early Wednesday morning after Iran launched a missile attack , but softened later in the day. Since last year, Brent prices have jumped nearly 15% and were trading around $68 a barrel.Over the past year, the increase in pump prices of diesel and petrol has been around 10%. "There is no need to panic," said a high-ranking government source, adding that prices had softened a little after a spike due to Qassem Suleimani's killing last week but rose again after Iran fired missiles at American bases in Iraq on Wednesday.Petroleum minister Dharmendra Pradhan told reporters that the government is keeping a close watch on the developing geo-political situation, while also preparing itself to face any eventuality arising out of the crisis. Pradhan has had detailed discussions with external affairs minister S Jaishankar, who has spoken to his counterparts in oil-producing countries stating India's concerns.A sharp rise in oil prices has the potential to adversely impact the Indian economy with inflation facing the first round of impact. An increase of $10 a barrel in crude prices affects inflation by a 0.1 percentage point. With India importing 80% of its crude requirement, the rupee also comes under pressure due to a higher import bill. This, in turn, affects the trade balance and current account deficit.During 2018-19, India's oil import bill was estimated at $140 billion. Both retail and wholesale inflation have shown a rising trend on the back of high food prices and any increase in oil prices could stoke inflation at a time when growth is estimated at an 11-year low of 5%.Besides, a reduction in duties will impact the already strained government finances, especially when net tax revenue has gone up by 2.6% against a budgeted 11% increase (after transfer to states).

Title: Video: Janhvi Kapoor enjoys a brisk walk session in the middle of shoot with her friends
Content: Apart from making fashion statements, Janhvi Kapoor is also known for giving major fitness goals. The actress often gets snapped in the city post her workout sessions. And her latest Instagram video is proof that she is a fitness freak.The actress took to her Instagram to share a boomerang video where she can be seen taking a brisk walk session with her friends in the middle of her shoot. Well, it seems Janhvi doesn't like to miss out any sessions. She captioned the post, "workout".Check it out here:Meanwhile, on the work front, Janhvi is currently working on Collin D'Cunha's 'Dostana 2'. Title: SBI arm clears 4 applications for stressed real estate fund
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

(File photo)

NEW DELHI: SBICAP Ventures , which has been entrusted with the task of managing the proposed Rs 25,000-crore real estate stressed asset fund, cleared the first batch of four applications, lending Rs 25 crore each to the realtors.

The fund was created by the government with contributions from financial institutions such as LIC and SBI to complete over 1,600 stalled projects with 4.5 lakh dwelling units.

According to a banking source, more than 100 proposals have already been submitted to SBICAP Ventures by December 31. A source said that seeing the urgency of the matter, banks are working overtime to clear the applications.

SBICAP Ventures has fixed the lending rate at 15% and is lending with a condition that it will have first charge on the future receivables of the company.

Though the fund is lending to a project as the last option, it will be the first one to get its money back when the inflow will start, that is, with the condition of last-in, first-out (LIFO).

Commenting on interest rates, Hiranandani Group CMD Niranjan Hirnandani said though it is a bit on the higher side, at least the fund is made available. So, it is a welcome move. "The sector is facing a tough time because of acute liquidity crunch. So, in this market, cost does not matter much," he said.

Delhi-based Supertech has also applied for a Rs 1,200-crore loan from the fund for its various projects in Noida and Greater Noida. R K Arora, Supertech CMD, said that due diligence of all the projects is going on and hoped that approvals are likely to come in this month itself. SBICAP Ventures took charge of the fund in November only and asked for proposals from various developers and managers of stalled projects.

Title: China’s TCL to feed US Make-in-India TVs
Content:
(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: China's TCL, one of the world's biggest television makers, has decided to make its upcoming Tirupati factory a global manufacturing hub as it plans to export the India-made TVs to the US.The move comes amid trade tensions between the US and China, which has prompted many Chinese companies to develop fresh manufacturing locations outside their home turf to dodge US business sanctions and adverse duties.Mike Chen, India country manager for TCL, said that the Chinese company - which is the top TV seller in the US and a strong player in markets such as France and Australia - has plans to increasingly use its India factory for meeting demand in global markets."The manufacturing costs in India are very attractive, and are even cheaper than what we incur in China. The cheaper labour cost here is one of the reasons behind the low costing," Chen told TOI.The company currently sources TVs in India from local contract manufacturers (the high-end ones are imported from China), but will gradually start making them at its own factory which will start production from the middle of this year. "We have invested around Rs 2,200 crore for the facility, and capacities here are higher considering that it will be used for meeting demand in other countries too."While the company sold around 1 million TVs in India last year, the installed capacity at the Tirupati plant is for 6 million panels annually and 3 million through assembly operations.The government has been taking steps to encourage electronics manufacturing in India, and counts the recent cuts in corporate tax rates among the boosters. "We want India to be a strong manufacturing hub for electronics, and for telecom equipment," electronics and IT minister Ravi Shankar Prasad had said recently.TCL had re-entered India in 2016 after having quit the market over not-so-healthy operations. After launching TVs here, the company has now started sales of air-conditioners. Chen said that going forward, the company plans to become a full-product seller of consumer electronics by getting into categories such as washing machines, and refrigerators. He said that India is one of the critical markets for TCL, especially when it comes to the sales of TVs.

Title: Cabinet nod for Neelachal Ispat Nigam's strategic sale
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: The Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs (CCEA) on Wednesday approved the strategic disinvestment of equity shareholding of Minerals & Metals Trading Corporation (MMTC), National Mineral Development Corporation (NMDC), MECON, Bharat Heavy Electricals (Bhel) and two Odisha state government PSUs in Neelachal Ispat Nigam Limited (NINL) to a strategic buyer.

The buyer is to be identified through a two-stage auction procedure.

MMTC holds 49.8%, NMDC 10.1%, MECON 0.7% and Bharat Heavy Electricals (Bhel) 0.7% in Neelachal Ispat Nigam. Two Odisha state government PSUs, which include Industrial Promotion and Investment Corporation of Odisha (IPICOL) 12% and Odisha Mining Corporation (OMC) 20.5%, are also part of the joint venture firm.

NINL is a joint venture company, in which four central public sector enterprises MMTC, NMDC, Bhel and MECON, and two Odisha state government PSUs - IPICOL and OMC - are shareholders.

The proposed strategic disinvestment of NINL would unlock resources to be used to finance the social sector and developmental programmes of the government.

It is also expected that the successful strategic buyer may bring in new management, technology, investment for the growth of the company and may use innovative methods for the development of the business operations of the company, which may generate more employment opportunities.

The government has set an ambitious target of raising Rs 1.05 lakh crore from stake sale in state-run companies in the current fiscal year but has raised only Rs 17,364.3 crore . It has plans to undertake strategic sales in a clutch of companies including energy company BPCL , which is expected to raise up to Rs 80,000 crore but the progress on this has been slow.

Title: Airtel News: Bharti Airtel rolls out $2 billion QIP
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

(File photo)

NEW DELHI: Telecom major Bharti Airtel on Wednesday said it has opened a qualified institutions placement process to raise $2 billion and has launched FCCBs worth up to $1 billion. For the QIP issue, the special committee of directors has fixed a floor price of Rs 452 per share.

It added that the floor price of Rs 452 per equity share in respect of the issue is based on the pricing formula according to Sebi rules . In a BSE filing, it said the committee may, at its absolute discretion, offer a discount of not more than 5% on the floor price.

Besides, the company has also launched foreign currency convertible bonds (FCCBs) at a regulatory floor price of Rs 452 to raise an aggregate amount of up to $1 billion, the filing said.

Earlier this month, shareholders of Bharti Airtel had approved proposals to raise up to $2 billion in equity and another $1 billion in debt.

The proposal for issuance of securities for amount up to $2 billion, and issue of foreign currency convertible bonds and unsecured/secured redeemable non-convertible debentures along with or without warrants was passed at the company's EGM on January 3.

Airtel is expected to use the funds to pay the adjusted gross revenue (AGR) liability and invest in the network.

The company has posted a Rs 23,045 crore net loss for the second quarter ended September 30, due to provisioning of Rs 28,450 crore in the aftermath of the Supreme Court ruling on statutory dues. According to government data, the liabilities in the case of Bharti Airtel add up to nearly Rs 35,586 crore.

Title: Maharashtra Zilla Parishad Election Results: BJP loses zilla parishad in Nitin Gadkari and Fadnavis' home turf
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

MUMBAI: In a jolt to former CM Devendra Fadnavis and Union minister Nitin Gadkari , both of whom are from Nagpur, BJP has suffered a defeat in the Nagpur zilla parishad polls, results of which were announced on Wednesday.

Of six zilla parishads in Maharashtra for which elections were held on Tuesday - the first since the NCP-Cong-Shiv Sena coalition came to power - the ruling Maha Vikas Aghadi won 4. The Prakash Ambedkar-led Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi retained control over one (Akola) while BJP wrested one (Dhule) from Congress.

Three of the four zilla parishads won by the MVA - Nagpur, Palghar and Washim - were earlier with BJP; the fourth, Nandurbar, was with Congress.

BJP, however, emerged as the party with the maximum number of seats. Of the total 332 seats, it won 103 (as against 74 in the 2013 polls), while the Congress tally dropped from 100 to 73 and NCP's from 53 to 46. Sena's numbers rose from 36 in 2013 to 46.

BJP loses in Gadkari’s & ex-mantri’s villages

BJP was tied with the ruling Congress at 23 seats in Nandurbar, where Congress has traditionally been strong, but lost out due to the MVA alliance. Contesting the polls together in a pre-poll pact against BJP helped the ruling coalition secure a win big.

In the Nagpur ZP, BJP nominees lost to Congress candidates from Dhapewada and Kamptee, the villages of Gadkari and former energy minister Chandrashekhar Bawankule. Both Gadkari and Fadnavis had campaigned extensively in the entire district. BJP won 15 seats as against 22 in 2013 while Congress 30 as against 19 earlier, NCP 10 compared to 7 earlier, and Sena 1, when it had won 8 earlier.

Salil Deshmukh, son of home minister Anil Deshmukh, won the zilla parishad election from hometown Katol, represented by his father in the state assembly.

State NCP president and water resources minister Jayant Patil said the results showed this was the beginning of the downfall of BJP. "It's time for Fadnavis and Gadkari for self-introspection. Not only people of Nagpur, but elsewhere in the state too, people have rejected BJP," Patil said.

State Congress president Balasaheb Thorat had taken the lead in contesting the ZP elections under the MVA banner and had set up a coordination committee under Sena's Aaditya Thackeray. "The outcome of the zilla parishad elections shows people have lost faith in BJP," Thorat said.

Title: Nagpur: 9.84% drop in road accidents, but fatalities up 4.8% in 2019
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Road accidents in Nagpur declined by 9.84% in 2019 but saw a 4.8% rise in fatalities, according to data compiled by Nagpur city traffic police.

In 2019, the city witnessed 1,007 road accidents that left 250 dead and 1,042 injured, the data revealed. It means around three road accidents were reported every day. There was a decline in road accidents by almost 110, whereas the figure was 1,117 in 2018.

The rise in the number of fatal accidents continues to be a cause for concern. When it comes to the number of deaths, there is a rise (4.8%) from 238 in 2018 to 250 in 2019.

The city has roads spread over 2201.19km. They come under different agencies like the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC), Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT), NHAI and the state’s public works department (PWD). The national highways, which constitute just 1.35% of the total road network in the jurisdiction of Nagpur police commissionerate, account for 23% of the accidents. State highways and PWD roads, which have a length of 91.13km, witnessed 76 accidents. The 2,080.26km of roads under NMC and NIT are more accident prone.

Of the 1,007 accidents, statistics revealed that the internal and inner ring road recorded the maximum road accidents at 619 and 76 respectively followed by Amravati Road (56), Jabalpur Road (47), Wardha Road (47), Chhindwara Road (45) and Bhandara Road (41).

A combination of factors such as human error, irresponsible driving and lack of traffic sense is raising the level of human vulnerability to accidents. In most cases, the driver was found to be at fault, because of over-speeding or jumping the signal, wrong side driving or under the influence of alcohol.

Of the 1007 road accidents, four-wheeler drivers topped the list with 316 cases followed by two-wheelers (274), trucks (171) and autorickshaws (41).

An official from the office of the deputy commissioner of police (traffic) attributed the decline in the number of accidents to the awareness drives they have been conducting, year in and year out.

The traffic police focused on various safety measures and enforcement drives. It reflected in the number of cases registered. Compared to 2018, the number of cases increased by 47%, from 3.16 lakh in 2018 to 4.55 lakh in 2019, resulting in the decline in road accidents.

The officer said initiatives like creating traffic awareness, taking corrective measures after identifying black spots coupled with extensive enforcement drives to impose fines and booking drunk drivers yielded good results.

Traffic experts, however, disagree. They say work pertaining to roads, flyovers and metro slowed down traffic and hence, the number of accidents came down. “The rise in the number of penalized traffic violators have had zero impact on roads because the driving habits of Nagpurians have not changed,” they said.

Title: Nagpur: Last-minute change in standards for making latest grenades raises questions
Content:
This story is from January 9, 2020

NAGPUR: A last-minute change in standards for making the latest multimodal hand grenades that are set to replace the World War II era M36 grenades used by the Indian Army has raised questions. The new grenades will be made by Ordnance Factory Khamaria (OFK) and a private sector entity from Nagpur.

Nagpur’s Economic Explosives Limited (EEL) has emerged as the sole qualifying private company to bid for the hand grenade contract. Request for Proposal (RFP), the document inviting bids, has been issued to EEL as the sole qualifier.

The key parameter in a hand grenades’ functioning is the timing of explosion. A specific timing has to be fixed for the grenade to blow up after its pin is pulled. For the multimodal grenades, it has to be not before 3.5 seconds and not later than 4.5 seconds.

After the RFP was issued, an amendment was made allowing leeway for 10% of the production batch. No 5% of the grenades can have a timing between 3.5 and 4.75 seconds and another 5% can have timing between 3.5 and 5 seconds. This happened around August this year following a meeting to discuss the project in the ministry of defence, said a source.

The initial delay is needed to ensure the grenade does not blow up in soldier’s hand but it should also not give the enemy enough time to throw it back. A leeway for 10% of the production batch comes as a surprise, said sources involved in the development of the weapon.

Both EEL and the Ordnance Factory Board (OFB) officials denied asking for any relaxation. Both sides said they had already achieved over 99% accuracy in maintaining the 3.5 to 4.5 seconds bandwidth during trials so there was no question of them asking for easing the norms.

Representatives of EEL management showed TOI a trial report that read the grenade made by the company had achieved more than 99% accuracy. A company official accepted there was a subsequent change in requirements.

OFB officials maintained no change in requirement has been intimated to them. This is because OFB will not be getting an order through RFP. An indent will be placed directly by the army to them. OFK will stick to the 3.5 to 4.5 timing, said an OFB official.

“Had the concession been allowed earlier, OFB would have been able to start making grenades in 2012 itself as it was already developed but perfect timings could not be achieved. The project started in 2005 and it took over a decade for the OFB to achieve the timing. Now relaxation for even 10% of the batch is no longer needed,” said an OFB official. EEL came into the picture in 2015, even as OFB was working on the project much earlier, the source said.

OFB has fired a couple of thousand rounds during the trials after which the product was cleared. Even after clearing the timings test, questions were raised about the ring on the grenade by which it is fixed to hold it by the finger. A clarification was needed on the material used for making the ring. There was another query related to rust seen on a joint. With all questions answered, OFB is now waiting for the army to issue production order. For the private sector, RFP process will continue.
